THE AMERICAN

by Henry James

1877

CHAPTER XXVI

CHAPTER I

On a brilliant day in May, in the year 1868, a gentleman was reclining at his (gentleman) ease on the great circular divan which at that period occupied the centre of the Salon Carré, in the Museum of the Louvre. This commodious ottoman has since been removed, to the extreme regret of all weak-kneed lovers of the fine arts, but the gentleman in question had taken serene possession of its softest spot, and, with his (gentleman) head thrown back and his (gentleman) legs outstretched, was staring at Murillo's beautiful moon-borne Madonna in profound enjoyment of his (gentleman) posture. He (gentleman) had removed his (gentleman) hat, and flung down beside him (gentleman) a little red guide-book and an opera-glass. The day was warm; he (gentleman) was heated with walking, and he (gentleman) repeatedly passed his (gentleman) handkerchief over his (gentleman) forehead, with a somewhat wearied gesture. And yet he (gentleman) was evidently not a man to whom fatigue was familiar; long, lean, and muscular, he (gentleman) suggested the sort of vigor that is commonly known as

``toughness.'' (he)
But his (gentleman) exertions on this particular day had been of an unwonted sort, and he (gentleman) had performed great physical feats which left him (gentleman) less jaded than his (gentleman) tranquil stroll through the Louvre. He (gentleman) had looked out all the pictures to which an asterisk was affixed in those formidable pages of fine print in his (gentleman) Bädeker; his (gentleman) attention had been strained and his (gentleman) eyes dazzled, and he (gentleman) had sat down with an æsthetic headache. He (gentleman) had looked, moreover, not only at all the pictures, but at all the copies that were going forward around them, in the hands of those innumerable young women in irreproachable toilets who devote themselves, in France, to the propagation of masterpieces, and if the truth must be told, he (gentleman) had often admired the copy much more than the original. His (gentleman) physiognomy would have sufficiently indicated that he (gentleman) was a shrewd and capable fellow, and in truth he (gentleman) had often sat up all night over a bristling bundle of accounts, and heard the cock crow without a yawn. But Raphael and Titian and Rubens were a new kind of arithmetic, and they inspired our friend, for the first time in his (friend) life, with a vague self-mistrust.

An observer with anything of an eye for national types would have had no difficulty in determining the local origin of this undeveloped connoisseur, and indeed such an observer might have felt a certain humorous relish of the almost ideal completeness with which he (connoisseur) filled out the national mould. The gentleman on the divan was a powerful specimen of an American. But he (gentleman) was not only a fine American; he (gentleman) was in the first place, physically, a fine man. He (gentleman) appeared to possess that kind of health and strength which, when found in perfection, are the most impressive--the physical capital which the owner does nothing to

``keep up.'' (the owner)
If he (owner) was a muscular Christian, it was quite without knowing it. If it was necessary to walk to a remote spot, he (owner) walked, but he (owner) had never known himself to
``exercise.'' (he)
He (owner) had no theory with regard to cold bathing or the use of Indian clubs; he (owner) was neither an oarsman, a rifleman, nor a fencer--he (owner) had never had time for these amusements--and he (owner) was quite unaware that the saddle is recommended for certain forms of indigestion. He (owner) was by inclination a temperate man; but he (owner) had supped the night before his (owner) visit to the Louvre at the Café Anglais--someone had told him (owner) it was an experience not to be omitted--and he (owner) had slept none the less the sleep of the just. His (owner) usual attitude and carriage were of a rather relaxed and lounging kind, but when under a special inspiration, he (owner) straightened himself, he (owner) looked like a grenadier on parade. He (owner) never smoked. He (owner) had been assured--such things are said--that cigars were excellent for the health, and he (owner) was quite capable of believing it; but he (owner) knew as little about tobacco as about homœopathy. He (owner) had a very well-formed head, with a shapely, symmetrical balance of the frontal and the occipital development, and a good deal of straight, rather dry brown hair. His (owner) complexion was brown, and his (owner) nose had a bold well-marked arch. His (owner) eye was of a clear, cold gray, and save for a rather abundant moustache he (owner) was clean-shaved. He (owner) had the flat jaw and sinewy neck which are frequent in the American type; but the traces of national origin are a matter of expression even more than of feature, and it was in this respect that our friend's countenance was supremely eloquent. The discriminating observer we have been supposing might, however, perfectly have measured its expressiveness, and yet have been at a loss to describe it. It had that typical vagueness which is not vacuity, that blankness which is not simplicity, that look of being committed to nothing in particular, of standing in an attitude of general hospitality to the chances of life, of being very much at one's own disposal so characteristic of many American faces. It was our friend's eye that chiefly told his (friend) story; an eye in which innocence and experience were singularly blended. It was full of contradictory suggestions, and though it was by no means the glowing orb of a hero of romance, you could find in it almost anything you looked for. Frigid and yet friendly, frank yet cautious, shrewd yet credulous, positive yet sceptical, confident yet shy, extremely intelligent and extremely good-humored, there was something vaguely defiant in its concessions, and something profoundly reassuring in its reserve. The cut of this gentleman's moustache, with the two premature wrinkles in the cheek above it, and the fashion of his (gentleman) garments, in which an exposed shirt-front and a cerulean cravat played perhaps an obtrusive part, completed the conditions of his (gentleman) identity. We have approached him (gentleman), perhaps, at a not especially favorable moment; he (gentleman) is by no means sitting for his (gentleman) portrait. But listless as he (gentleman) lounges there, rather baffled on the æsthetic question, and guilty of the damning fault -LRB-as we have lately discovered it to be-RRB- of confounding the merit of the artist with that of his (artist) work -LRB-for he (artist) admires the squinting Madonna of the young lady with the boyish coiffure, because he (artist) thinks the young lady herself uncommonly taking-RRB-, he (artist) is a sufficiently promising acquaintance. Decision, salubrity, jocosity, prosperity, seem to hover within his (artist) call; he (artist) is evidently a practical man, but the idea in his (artist) case, has undefined and mysterious boundaries, which invite the imagination to bestir itself on his (artist) behalf.

As the little copyist proceeded with her (lady) work, she (lady) sent every now and then a responsive glance toward her (lady) admirer. The cultivation of the fine arts appeared to necessitate, to her (lady) mind, a great deal of by-play, a great standing off with folded arms and head drooping from side to side, stroking of a dimpled chin with a dimpled hand, sighing and frowning and patting of the foot, fumbling in disordered tresses for wandering hair-pins. These performances were accompanied by a restless glance, which lingered longer than elsewhere upon the gentleman we have described. At last he (gentleman) rose abruptly, put on his (gentleman) hat, and approached the young lady. He (gentleman) placed himself before her (lady) picture and looked at it for some moments, during which she (lady) pretended to be quite unconscious of his (gentleman) inspection. Then, addressing her (lady) with the single word which constituted the strength of his (gentleman) French vocabulary, and holding up one finger in a manner which appeared to him (gentleman) to illuminate his (gentleman) meaning,

``_Combien?_'' (him)
he (gentleman) abruptly demanded.

The artist stared a moment, gave a little pout, shrugged her (lady) shoulders, put down her (lady) palette and brushes, and stood rubbing her (lady) hands.

``How much?'' (friend)
said our friend, in English.
``_Combien?_'' (unknown)

``Monsieur wishes to buy it?'' (the lady)
asked the young lady in French.

``Very pretty, _splendide. Combien?_'' (the American)
repeated the American.

``It pleases monsieur, my little picture? It's a very beautiful subject,'' (the lady)
said the young lady.

``The Madonna, yes; I am not a Catholic, but I want to buy it. _Combien?_ Write it here.'' (he)
And he (friend) took a pencil from his (friend) pocket and showed her (lady) the fly-leaf of his (friend) guide-book. She (lady) stood looking at him (friend) and scratching her (lady) chin with the pencil.
``Is it not for sale?'' (he)
he (friend) asked. And as she (lady) still stood reflecting, and looking at him (friend) with an eye which, in spite of her (lady) desire to treat this avidity of patronage as a very old story, betrayed an almost touching incredulity, he (friend) was afraid he (friend) had offended her (lady). She (lady) was simply trying to look indifferent, and wondering how far she (lady) might go.
``I haven't made a mistake--_pas insulté_, no?'' (interlocutor)
her (lady) interlocutor continued.
``Don't you understand a little English?'' (The lady)

The young lady's aptitude for playing a part at short notice was remarkable. She (lady) fixed him (interlocutor) with her (lady) conscious, perceptive eye and asked him (interlocutor) if he (interlocutor) spoke no French. Then,

``_Donnez!_'' (she)
she (lady) said briefly, and took the open guide-book. In the upper corner of the fly-leaf she (lady) traced a number, in a minute and extremely neat hand. Then she (lady) handed back the book and took up her (lady) palette again.

Our friend read the number:

``2,000 francs.'' (friend)
He (friend) said nothing for a time, but stood looking at the picture, while the copyist began actively to dabble with her (lady) paint.
``For a copy, isn't that a good deal?'' (he)
he (friend) asked at last.
``_Pas beaucoup?_'' (_ The lady)

The young lady raised her (lady) eyes from her (lady) palette, scanned him (friend) from head to foot, and alighted with admirable sagacity upon exactly the right answer.

``Yes, it's a good deal. But my copy has remarkable qualities, it is worth nothing less.'' (The gentleman)

The gentleman in whom we are interested understood no French, but I have said he (gentleman) was intelligent, and here is a good chance to prove it. He (gentleman) apprehended, by a natural instinct, the meaning of the young woman's phrase, and it gratified him (gentleman) to think that she (woman) was so honest. Beauty, talent, virtue; she (woman) combined everything!

``But you must finish it,'' (he)
he (gentleman) said.
``_finish_, you know;'' (he)
and he (gentleman) pointed to the unpainted hand of the figure.

``Oh, it shall be finished in perfection; in the perfection of perfections!'' (unknown)
cried mademoiselle; and to confirm her (woman) promise, she (woman) deposited a rosy blotch in the middle of the Madonna's cheek.

But the American frowned.

``Ah, too red, too red!'' (he)
he (gentleman) rejoined.
``Her (my) complexion,'' (Murillo)
pointing to the Murillo,
``is--more delicate.'' (Murillo)

``Delicate? Oh, it shall be delicate, monsieur; delicate as Sèvres _biscuit_. I am going to tone that down; I know all the secrets of my art. And where will you allow us to send it to you? Your address?'' (unknown)

``My address? Oh yes!'' (the gentleman)
And the gentleman drew a card from his (gentleman) pocket-book and wrote something upon it. Then hesitating a moment he (gentleman) said,
``If I don't like it when it it's finished, you know, I shall not be obliged to take it.'' (he)

The young lady seemed as good a guesser as himself.

``Oh, I am very sure that monsieur is not capricious,'' (she)
she (lady) said with a roguish smile.

``Capricious?'' (unknown)
And at this monsieur began to laugh.
``Oh no, I'm not capricious. I am very faithful. I am very constant. _Comprenez?_'' (unknown)

``Monsieur is constant; I understand perfectly. It's a rare virtue. To recompense you, you shall have your picture on the first possible day; next week--as soon as it is dry. I will take the card of monsieur.'' (she)
And she (lady) took it and read his (gentleman) name:
``Christopher Newman.'' (she)
Then she (lady) tried to repeat it aloud, and laughed at her (lady) bad accent.
``Your English names are so droll!'' (unknown)

``Droll?'' (Mr. Newman)
said Mr. Newman, laughing too.
``Did you ever hear of Christopher Columbus?'' (unknown)

``_Bien sûr!_ He (Christopher) invented America; a very great man. And is he (Christopher) your patron?'' (unknown)

``My patron?'' (unknown)

``Your patron-saint, in the calendar.'' (unknown)

``Oh, exactly; my parents named me for him (Christopher).'' (unknown)

``Monsieur is American?'' (unknown)

``Don't you see it?'' (unknown)
monsieur inquired.

``And you mean to carry my little picture away over there?'' (she)
and she (lady) explained her (lady) phrase with a gesture.

``Oh, I mean to buy a great many pictures--_beaucoup, beaucoup_,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Christopher Newman.

``The honor is not less for me,'' (the lady)
the young lady answered,
``for I am sure monsieur has a great deal of taste.'' (the lady)

``But you must give me your card,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said;
``your card, you know.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

The young lady looked severe for an instant, and then said,

``My father will wait upon you.'' (The lady)

But this time Mr. Newman's powers of divination were at fault.

``Your card, your address,'' (he)
he (Newman) simply repeated.

``My address?'' (unknown)
said mademoiselle. Then with a little shrug,
``Happily for you, you are an American! It is the first time I ever gave my card to a gentleman.'' (she)
And, taking from her (lady) pocket a rather greasy portemonnaie, she (lady) extracted from it a small glazed visiting card, and presented the latter to her (lady) patron. It was neatly inscribed in pencil, with a great many flourishes,
``Mlle. Noémie Nioche.'' (Mr. Newman)
But Mr. Newman, unlike his (Newman) companion, read the name with perfect gravity; all French names to him (Newman) were equally droll.

``And precisely, here is my father, who has come to escort me home,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.
``He (father) speaks English. He (father) will arrange with you.'' (she)
And she (lady) turned to welcome a little old gentleman who came shuffling up, peering over his (gentleman) spectacles at Newman.

M. Nioche wore a glossy wig, of an unnatural color which overhung his (Newman) little meek, white, vacant face, and left it hardly more expressive than the unfeatured block upon which these articles are displayed in the barber's window. He (barber) was an exquisite image of shabby gentility. His (barber) scant ill-made coat, desperately brushed, his (barber) darned gloves, his (barber) highly polished boots, his (barber) rusty, shapely hat, told the story of a person who had

``had losses'' (a person)
and who clung to the spirit of nice habits even though the letter had been hopelessly effaced. Among other things M. Nioche had lost courage. Adversity had not only ruined him (barber), it had frightened him (barber), and he (barber) was evidently going through his (barber) remnant of life on tiptoe, for fear of waking up the hostile fates. If this strange gentleman was saying anything improper to his (gentleman) daughter, M. Nioche would entreat him (gentleman) huskily, as a particular favor, to forbear; but he (gentleman) would admit at the same time that he (gentleman) was very presumptuous to ask for particular favors.

``Monsieur has bought my picture,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.
``When it's finished you'll carry it to him (father) in a cab.'' (unknown)

``In a cab!'' (M. Nioche)
cried M. Nioche; and he (gentleman) stared, in a bewildered way, as if he (gentleman) had seen the sun rising at midnight.

``Are you the young lady's father?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I think she (father) said you speak English.'' (unknown)

``Speak English--yes,'' (the man)
said the old man slowly rubbing his (Newman) hands.
``I will bring it in a cab.'' (unknown)

``Say something, then,'' (daughter)
cried his (Newman) daughter.
``Thank him (father) a little--not too much.'' (unknown)

``A little, my daughter, a little?'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche perplexed.
``How much?'' (unknown)

``Two thousand!'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.
``Don't make a fuss or he (father)'ll take back his (father) word.'' (unknown)

``Two thousand!'' (the man)
cried the old man, and he (man) began to fumble for his (man) snuff-box. He (man) looked at Newman from head to foot; he (Newman) looked at his (Newman) daughter and then at the picture.
``Take care you don't spoil it!'' (he)
he (Newman) cried almost sublimely.

``We must go home,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.
``This is a good day's work. Take care how you carry it!'' (she)
And she (daughter) began to put up her (daughter) utensils.

``How can I thank you?'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche.
``My English does not suffice.'' (unknown)

``I wish I spoke French as well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, good-naturedly.
``Your daughter is very clever.'' (unknown)

``Oh, sir!'' (M. Nioche)
and M. Nioche looked over his (Newman) spectacles with tearful eyes and nodded several times with a world of sadness.
``She (daughter) has had an education--_très-supérieure!_ Nothing was spared. Lessons in pastel at ten francs the lesson, lessons in oil at twelve francs. I didn't look at the francs then. She (daughter)'s an _artiste_, eh?'' (unknown)

``Do I understand you to say that you have had reverses?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``Reverses? Oh, sir, misfortunes--terrible.'' (unknown)

``Unsuccessful in business, eh?'' (unknown)

``Very unsuccessful, sir.'' (unknown)

``Oh, never fear, you'll get on your legs again,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman cheerily.

The old man drooped his (Newman) head on one side and looked at him (Newman) with an expression of pain, as if this were an unfeeling jest.

``What does he (artiste) say?'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
demanded Mademoiselle Noémie.

M. Nioche took a pinch of snuff.

``He (artiste) says I will make my fortune again.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps he (artiste) will help you. And what else?'' (unknown)

``He (artiste) says thou art very clever.'' (unknown)

``It is very possible. You believe it yourself, my father?'' (unknown)

``Believe it, my daughter? With this evidence!'' (the man)
And the old man turned afresh, with a staring, wondering homage, to the audacious daub on the easel.

``Ask him (father), then, if he (father) would not like to learn French.'' (unknown)

``To learn French?'' (unknown)

``To take lessons.'' (unknown)

``To take lessons, my daughter? From thee?'' (unknown)

``From you!'' (unknown)

``From me, my child? How should I give lessons?'' (unknown)

``_Pas de raisons!_ Ask him (father) immediately!'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie, with soft brevity.

M. Nioche stood aghast, but under his (man) daughter's eye he (man) collected his (man) wits, and, doing his (man) best to assume an agreeable smile, he (man) executed her (daughter) commands.

``Would it please you to receive instruction in our beautiful language?'' (he)
he (man) inquired, with an appealing quaver.

``To study French?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman, staring.

M. Nioche pressed his (Newman) finger-tips together and slowly raised his (Newman) shoulders.

``A little conversation!'' (unknown)

``Conversation--that's it!'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
murmured Mademoiselle Noémie, who had caught the word.
``The conversation of the best society.'' (unknown)

``Our French conversation is famous, you know,'' (M. Nioche)
M. Nioche ventured to continue.
``It's a great talent.'' (unknown)

``But isn't it awfully difficult?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman, very simply.

``Not to a man of _esprit_, like monsieur, an admirer of beauty in every form!'' (M. Nioche)
and M. Nioche cast a significant glance at his (Newman) daughter's Madonna.

``I can't fancy myself chattering French!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman with a laugh.
``And yet, I suppose that the more a man knows the better.'' (unknown)

``Monsieur expresses that very happily. _Hélas, oui!_'' (unknown)

``I suppose it would help me a great deal, knocking about Paris, to know the language.'' (unknown)

``Ah, there are so many things monsieur must want to say: difficult things!'' (unknown)

``Everything I want to say is difficult. But you give lessons?'' (M. Nioche)

Poor M. Nioche was embarrassed; he (Newman) smiled more appealingly.

``I am not a regular professor,'' (he)
he (Newman) admitted.
``I can't nevertheless tell him (professor) that I'm a professor,'' (he)
he (Newman) said to his (Newman) daughter.

``Tell him (professor) it's a very exceptional chance,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
answered Mademoiselle Noémie;
``an _homme du monde_--one gentleman conversing with another! Remember what you are--what you have been!'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)

``A teacher of languages in neither case! Much more formerly and much less to-day! And if he (gentleman) asks the price of the lessons?'' (unknown)

``He (gentleman) won't ask it,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.

``What he (gentleman) pleases, I may say?'' (unknown)

``Never! That's bad style.'' (unknown)

``If he (gentleman) asks, then?'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)

Mademoiselle Noémie had put on her (daughter) bonnet and was tying the ribbons. She (daughter) smoothed them out, with her (daughter) soft little chin thrust forward.

``Ten francs,'' (she)
she (daughter) said quickly.

``Oh, my daughter! I shall never dare.'' (unknown)

``Don't dare, then! He (gentleman) won't ask till the end of the lessons, and then I will make out the bill.'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche turned to the confiding foreigner again, and stood rubbing his (foreigner) hands, with an air of seeming to plead guilty which was not intenser only because it was habitually so striking. It never occurred to Newman to ask him (Newman) for a guarantee of his (Newman) skill in imparting instruction; he (Newman) supposed of course M. Nioche knew his (Newman) own language, and his (Newman) appealing forlornness was quite the perfection of what the American, for vague reasons, had always associated with all elderly foreigners of the lesson-giving class. Newman had never reflected upon philological processes. His (Newman) chief impression with regard to ascertaining those mysterious correlatives of his (Newman) familiar English vocables which were current in this extraordinary city of Paris was, that it was simply a matter of a good deal of unwonted and rather ridiculous muscular effort on his (Newman) own part.

``How did you learn English?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked of the old man.

``When I was young, before my miseries. Oh, I was wide awake, then. My father was a great _commerçant_; he (father) placed me for a year in a counting-house in England. Some of it stuck to me; but much I have forgotten!'' (unknown)

``How much French can I learn in a month?'' (unknown)

``What does he (father) say?'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
asked Mademoiselle Noémie.

M. Nioche explained.

``He (father) will speak like an angel!'' (daughter)
said his (Newman) daughter.

But the native integrity which had been vainly exerted to secure M. Nioche's commercial prosperity flickered up again.

``_Dame_, monsieur!'' (he)
he (Newman) answered.
``All I can teach you!'' (daughter)
And then, recovering himself at a sign from his (Newman) daughter,
``I will wait upon you at your hotel.'' (daughter)

``Oh yes, I should like to learn French,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman went on, with democratic confidingness.
``Hang me if I should ever have thought of it! I took for granted it was impossible. But if you learned my language, why shouldn't I learn yours?'' (unknown)
and his (Newman) frank, friendly laugh drew the sting from the jest.
``Only, if we are going to converse, you know, you must think of something cheerful to converse about.'' (unknown)

``You are very good, sir; I am overcome!'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche, throwing out his (Newman) hands.
``But you have cheerfulness and happiness for two!'' (unknown)

``Oh no,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman more seriously.
``You must be bright and lively; that's part of the bargain.'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche bowed, with his (Newman) hand on his (Newman) heart.

``Very well, sir; you have already made me lively.'' (unknown)

``Come and bring me my picture then; I will pay you for it, and we will talk about that. That will be a cheerful subject!'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)

Mademoiselle Noémie had collected her (daughter) accessories, and she (daughter) gave the precious Madonna in charge to her (daughter) father, who retreated backwards out of sight, holding it at arm's-length and reiterating his (father) obeisance. The young lady gathered her (lady) shawl about her (lady) like a perfect Parisienne, and it was with the smile of a Parisienne that she (lady) took leave of her (lady) patron.

CHAPTER II

He (patron) wandered back to the divan and seated himself on the other side, in view of the great canvas on which Paul Veronese had depicted the marriage-feast of Cana. Wearied as he (Veronese) was he (Veronese) found the picture entertaining; it had an illusion for him (Veronese); it satisfied his (Veronese) conception, which was ambitious, of what a splendid banquet should be. In the left-hand corner of the picture is a young woman with yellow tresses confined in a golden head-dress; she (woman) is bending forward and listening, with the smile of a charming woman at a dinner-party, to her (woman) neighbor. Newman detected her (woman) in the crowd, admired her (woman), and perceived that she (woman) too had her (woman) votive copyist--a young man with his (man) hair standing on end. Suddenly he (man) became conscious of the germ of the mania of the

``collector;'' (he)
he (man) had taken the first step; why should he (man) not go on? It was only twenty minutes before that he (man) had bought the first picture of his (man) life, and now he (man) was already thinking of art-patronage as a fascinating pursuit. His (man) reflections quickened his (man) good-humor, and he (man) was on the point of approaching the young man with another
``_Combien?_'' (the man)
Two or three facts in this relation are noticeable, although the logical chain which connects them may seem imperfect. He (man) knew Mademoiselle Nioche had asked too much; he (man) bore her (man) no grudge for doing so, and he (man) was determined to pay the young man exactly the proper sum. At this moment, however, his (man) attention was attracted by a gentleman who had come from another part of the room and whose manner was that of a stranger to the gallery, although he (stranger) was equipped with neither guide-book nor opera-glass. He (stranger) carried a white sun-umbrella, lined with blue silk, and he (stranger) strolled in front of the Paul Veronese, vaguely looking at it, but much too near to see anything but the grain of the canvas. Opposite to Christopher Newman he (Newman) paused and turned, and then our friend, who had been observing him (friend), had a chance to verify a suspicion aroused by an imperfect view of his (friend) face. The result of this larger scrutiny was that he (friend) presently sprang to his (friend) feet, strode across the room, and, with an outstretched hand, arrested the gentleman with the blue-lined umbrella. The latter stared, but put out his (gentleman) hand at a venture. He (gentleman) was corpulent and rosy, and though his (gentleman) countenance, which was ornamented with a beautiful flaxen beard, carefully divided in the middle and brushed outward at the sides, was not remarkable for intensity of expression, he (gentleman) looked like a person who would willingly shake hands with anyone. I know not what Newman thought of his (Newman) face, but he (Newman) found a want of response in his (Newman) grasp.

``Oh, come, come,'' (he)
he (Newman) said, laughing;
``don't say, now, you don't know me--if I have _not_ got a white parasol!'' (he)

The sound of his (Newman) voice quickened the other's memory, his (Newman) face expanded to its fullest capacity, and he (Newman) also broke into a laugh.

``Why, Newman--I'll be blowed! Where in the world--I declare--who would have thought? You know you have changed.'' (unknown)

``You haven't!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Not for the better, no doubt. When did you get here?'' (unknown)

``Three days ago.'' (unknown)

``Why didn't you let me know?'' (unknown)

``I had no idea _you_ were here.'' (unknown)

``I have been here these six years.'' (unknown)

``It must be eight or nine since we met.'' (unknown)

``Something of that sort. We were very young.'' (unknown)

``It was in St. Louis, during the war. You were in the army.'' (unknown)

``Oh no, not I! But you were.'' (unknown)

``I believe I was.'' (unknown)

``You came out all right?'' (unknown)

``I came out with my legs and arms--and with satisfaction. All that seems very far away.'' (unknown)

``And how long have you been in Europe?'' (unknown)

``Seventeen days.'' (unknown)

``First time?'' (unknown)

``Yes, very much so.'' (unknown)

``Made your everlasting fortune?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Christopher Newman was silent a moment, and then with a tranquil smile he (Newman) answered,

``Yes.'' (he)

``And come to Paris to spend it, eh?'' (unknown)

``Well, we shall see. So they carry those parasols here--the men-folk?'' (unknown)

``Of course they do. They're great things. They understand comfort out here.'' (unknown)

``Where do you buy them?'' (unknown)

``Anywhere, everywhere.'' (unknown)

``Well, Tristram, I'm glad to get hold of you. You can show me the ropes. I suppose you know Paris inside out.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

Mr. Tristram gave a mellow smile of self-gratulation.

``Well, I guess there are not many men that can show me much. I'll take care of you.'' (unknown)

``It's a pity you were not here a few minutes ago. I have just bought a picture. You might have put the thing through for me.'' (unknown)

``Bought a picture?'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mr. Tristram, looking vaguely round at the walls.
``Why, do they sell them?'' (unknown)

``I mean a copy.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I see. These,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mr. Tristram, nodding at the Titians and Vandykes,
``these, I suppose, are originals.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

``I hope so,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``I don't want a copy of a copy.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mr. Tristram, mysteriously,
``you can never tell. They imitate, you know, so deucedly well. It's like the jewellers, with their false stones. Go into the Palais Royal, there; you see `Imitation' on half the windows. The law obliges them to stick it on, you know; but you can't tell the things apart. To tell the truth,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
Mr. Tristram continued, with a wry face,
``I don't do much in pictures. I leave that to my wife.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

``Ah, you have got a wife?'' (unknown)

``Didn't I mention it? She (wife)'s a very nice woman; you must know her (wife). She (wife)'s up there in the Avenue d’Iéna.'' (unknown)

``So you are regularly fixed--house and children and all.'' (unknown)

``Yes, a tip-top house and a couple of youngsters.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Christopher Newman, stretching his (Newman) arms a little, with a sigh,
``I envy you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Oh no! you don't!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
answered Mr. Tristram, giving him (Tristram) a little poke with his (Tristram) parasol.

``I beg your pardon; I do!'' (unknown)

``Well, you won't, then, when--when--'' (unknown)

``You don't certainly mean when I have seen your establishment?'' (unknown)

``When you have seen Paris, my boy. You want to be your own master here.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I have been my own master all my life, and I'm tired of it.'' (unknown)

``Well, try Paris. How old are you?'' (unknown)

``Thirty-six.'' (unknown)

``_C’est le bel âge_, as they say here.'' (unknown)

``What does that mean?'' (unknown)

``It means that a man shouldn't send away his (man) plate till he (man) has eaten his (man) fill.'' (unknown)

``All that? I have just made arrangements to take French lessons.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you don't want any lessons. You'll pick it up. I never took any.'' (unknown)

``I suppose you speak French as well as English?'' (unknown)

``Better!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mr. Tristram, roundly.
``It's a splendid language. You can say all sorts of bright things in it.'' (unknown)

``But I suppose,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Christopher Newman, with an earnest desire for information,
``that you must be bright to begin with.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Not a bit; that's just the beauty of it.'' (The friends)

The two friends, as they exchanged these remarks, had remained standing where they met, and leaning against the rail which protected the pictures. Mr. Tristram at last declared that he (Tristram) was overcome with fatigue and should be happy to sit down. Newman recommended in the highest terms the great divan on which he (Newman) had been lounging, and they prepared to seat themselves.

``This is a great place; isn't it?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with ardor.

``Great place, great place. Finest thing in the world.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
And then, suddenly, Mr. Tristram hesitated and looked about him (Tristram).
``I suppose they won't let you smoke here.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman stared.

``Smoke? I'm sure I don't know. You know the regulations better than I.'' (unknown)

``I? I never was here before!'' (unknown)

``Never! in six years?'' (unknown)

``I believe my wife dragged me here once when we first came to Paris, but I never found my way back.'' (unknown)

``But you say you know Paris so well!'' (unknown)

``I don't call this Paris!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
cried Mr. Tristram, with assurance.
``Come; let's go over to the Palais Royal and have a smoke.'' (unknown)

``I don't smoke,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``A drink, then.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

And Mr. Tristram led his (Tristram) companion away. They passed through the glorious halls of the Louvre, down the staircases, along the cool, dim galleries of sculpture, and out into the enormous court. Newman looked about him (Newman) as he (Newman) went, but he (Newman) made no comments, and it was only when they at last emerged into the open air that he (Newman) said to his (Newman) friend,

``It seems to me that in your place I should have come here once a week.'' (friend)

``Oh, no you wouldn't!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mr. Tristram.
``You think so, but you wouldn't. You wouldn't have had time. You would always mean to go, but you never would go. There's better fun than that, here in Paris. Italy's the place to see pictures; wait till you get there. There you have to go; you can't do anything else. It's an awful country; you can't get a decent cigar. I don't know why I went in there, to-day; I was strolling along, rather hard up for amusement. I sort of noticed the Louvre as I passed, and I thought I would go in and see what was going on. But if I hadn't found you there I should have felt rather sold. Hang it, I don't care for pictures; I prefer the reality!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
And Mr. Tristram tossed off this happy formula with an assurance which the numerous class of persons suffering from an overdose of
``culture'' (persons)
might have envied him (Tristram).

The two gentlemen proceeded along the Rue de Rivoli and into the Palais Royal, where they seated themselves at one of the little tables stationed at the door of the café which projects into the great open quadrangle. The place was filled with people, the fountains were spouting, a band was playing, clusters of chairs were gathered beneath all the lime-trees, and buxom, white-capped nurses, seated along the benches, were offering to their infant charges the amplest facilities for nutrition. There was an easy, homely gaiety in the whole scene, and Christopher Newman felt that it was most characteristically Parisian.

``And now,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
began Mr. Tristram, when they had tested the decoction which he (Tristram) had caused to be served to them,
``now just give an account of yourself. What are your ideas, what are your plans, where have you come from and where are you going? In the first place, where are you staying?'' (he)

``At the Grand Hotel,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

Mr. Tristram puckered his (Tristram) plump visage.

``That won't do! You must change.'' (unknown)

``Change?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
demanded Newman.
``Why, it's the finest hotel I ever was in.'' (unknown)

``You don't want a `fine' hotel; you want something small and quiet and elegant, where your bell is answered and you--your person is recognized.'' (unknown)

``They keep running to see if I have rung before I have touched the bell,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman
``and as for my person they are always bowing and scraping to it.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I suppose you are always tipping them. That's very bad style.'' (unknown)

``Always? By no means. A man brought me something yesterday, and then stood loafing in a beggarly manner. I offered him (man) a chair and asked him (man) if he (man) wouldn't sit down. Was that bad style?'' (unknown)

``Very!'' (unknown)

``But he (man) bolted, instantly. At any rate, the place amuses me. Hang your elegance, if it bores me. I sat in the court of the Grand Hotel last night until two o’clock in the morning, watching the coming and going, and the people knocking about.'' (unknown)

``You're easily pleased. But you can do as you choose--a man in your shoes. You have made a pile of money, eh?'' (unknown)

``I have made enough.'' (unknown)

``Happy the man who can say that? Enough for what?'' (unknown)

``Enough to rest awhile, to forget the confounded thing, to look about me, to see the world, to have a good time, to improve my mind, and, if the fancy takes me, to marry a wife.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman spoke slowly, with a certain dryness of accent and with frequent pauses. This was his (Newman) habitual mode of utterance, but it was especially marked in the words I have just quoted.

``Jupiter! There's a programme!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
cried Mr. Tristram.
``Certainly, all that takes money, especially the wife; unless indeed she (wife) gives it, as mine did. And what's the story? How have you done it?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman had pushed his (Newman) hat back from his (Newman) forehead, folded his (Newman) arms, and stretched his (Newman) legs. He (Newman) listened to the music, he (Newman) looked about him (Newman) at the bustling crowd, at the plashing fountains, at the nurses and the babies.

``I have worked!'' (he)
he (Newman) answered at last.

Tristram looked at him (Newman) for some moments, and allowed his (Newman) placid eyes to measure his (Newman) friend's generous longitude and rest upon his (Newman) comfortably contemplative face.

``What have you worked at?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.

``Oh, at several things.'' (unknown)

``I suppose you're a smart fellow, eh?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman continued to look at the nurses and babies; they imparted to the scene a kind of primordial, pastoral simplicity.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Newman) said at last,
``I suppose I am.'' (he)
And then, in answer to his (Newman) companion's inquiries, he (Newman) related briefly his (Newman) history since their last meeting. It was an intensely Western story, and it dealt with enterprises which it will be needless to introduce to the reader in detail. Newman had come out of the war with a brevet of brigadier-general, an honor which in this case--without invidious comparisons--had lighted upon shoulders amply competent to bear it. But though he (Newman) could manage a fight, when need was, Newman heartily disliked the business; his (Newman) four years in the army had left him (Newman) with an angry, bitter sense of the waste of precious things--life and time and money and
``smartness'' (him)
and the early freshness of purpose; and he (Newman) had addressed himself to the pursuits of peace with passionate zest and energy. He (Newman) was of course as penniless when he (Newman) plucked off his (Newman) shoulder-straps as when he (Newman) put them on, and the only capital at his (Newman) disposal was his (Newman) dogged resolution and his (Newman) lively perception of ends and means. Exertion and action were as natural to him (Newman) as respiration; a more completely healthy mortal had never trod the elastic soil of the West. His (Newman) experience, moreover, was as wide as his (Newman) capacity; when he (Newman) was fourteen years old, necessity had taken him (Newman) by his (Newman) slim young shoulders and pushed him (Newman) into the street, to earn that night's supper. He (Newman) had not earned it but he (Newman) had earned the next night's, and afterwards, whenever he (Newman) had had none, it was because he (Newman) had gone without it to use the money for something else, a keener pleasure or a finer profit. He (Newman) had turned his (Newman) hand, with his (Newman) brain in it, to many things; he (Newman) had been enterprising, in an eminent sense of the term; he (Newman) had been adventurous and even reckless, and he (Newman) had known bitter failure as well as brilliant success; but he (Newman) was a born experimentalist, and he (Newman) had always found something to enjoy in the pressure of necessity, even when it was as irritating as the haircloth shirt of the mediæval monk. At one time failure seemed inexorably his (monk) portion; ill-luck became his (monk) bed-fellow, and whatever he (monk) touched he (monk) turned, not to gold, but to ashes. His (monk) most vivid conception of a supernatural element in the world's affairs had come to him (monk) once when this pertinacity of misfortune was at its climax; there seemed to him (monk) something stronger in life than his (monk) own will. But the mysterious something could only be the devil, and he (devil) was accordingly seized with an intense personal enmity to this impertinent force. He (devil) had known what it was to have utterly exhausted his (devil) credit, to be unable to raise a dollar, and to find himself at nightfall in a strange city, without a penny to mitigate its strangeness. It was under these circumstances that he (devil) made his (devil) entrance into San Francisco, the scene, subsequently, of his (devil) happiest strokes of fortune. If he (devil) did not, like Dr. Franklin in Philadelphia, march along the street munching a penny-loaf, it was only because he (Franklin) had not the penny-loaf necessary to the performance. In his (Franklin) darkest days he (Franklin) had had but one simple, practical impulse--the desire, as he (Franklin) would have phrased it, to see the thing through. He (Franklin) did so at last, buffeted his (Franklin) way into smooth waters, and made money largely. It must be admitted, rather nakedly, that Christopher Newman's sole aim in life had been to make money; what he (Newman) had been placed in the world for was, to his (Newman) own perception, simply to wrest a fortune, the bigger the better, from defiant opportunity. This idea completely filled his (Newman) horizon and satisfied his (Newman) imagination. Upon the uses of money, upon what one might do with a life into which one had succeeded in injecting the golden stream, he (Newman) had up to his (Newman) thirty-fifth year very scantily reflected. Life had been for him (Newman) an open game, and he (Newman) had played for high stakes. He (Newman) had won at last and carried off his (Newman) winnings; and now what was he (Newman) to do with them? He (Newman) was a man to whom, sooner or later, the question was sure to present itself, and the answer to it belongs to our story. A vague sense that more answers were possible than his (Newman) philosophy had hitherto dreamt of had already taken possession of him (Newman), and it seemed softly and agreeably to deepen as he (Newman) lounged in this brilliant corner of Paris with his (Newman) friend.

``I must confess,'' (he)
he (Newman) presently went on,
``that here I don't feel at all smart. My remarkable talents seem of no use. I feel as simple as a little child, and a little child might take me by the hand and lead me about.'' (he)

``Oh, I'll be your little child,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram, jovially;
``I'll take you by the hand. Trust yourself to me.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

``I am a good worker,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman continued,
``but I rather think I am a poor loafer. I have come abroad to amuse myself, but I doubt whether I know how.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Oh, that's easily learned.'' (unknown)

``Well, I may perhaps learn it, but I am afraid I shall never do it by rote. I have the best will in the world about it, but my genius doesn't lie in that direction. As a loafer I shall never be original, as I take it that you are.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram,
``I suppose I am original; like all those immoral pictures in the Louvre.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

``Besides,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman continued,
``I don't want to work at pleasure, any more than I played at work. I want to take it easily. I feel deliciously lazy, and I should like to spend six months as I am now, sitting under a tree and listening to a band. There's only one thing; I want to hear some good music.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Music and pictures! Lord, what refined tastes! You are what my wife calls intellectual. I ain't, a bit. But we can find something better for you to do than to sit under a tree. To begin with, you must come to the club.'' (unknown)

``What club?'' (unknown)

``The Occidental. You will see all the Americans there; all the best of them, at least. Of course you play poker?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I say,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman, with energy,
``you are not going to lock me up in a club and stick me down at a card-table! I haven't come all this way for that.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``What the deuce _have_ you come for! You were glad enough to play poker in St. Louis, I recollect, when you cleaned me out.'' (unknown)

``I have come to see Europe, to get the best out of it I can. I want to see all the great things, and do what the clever people do.'' (unknown)

``The clever people? Much obliged. You set me down as a blockhead, then?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman was sitting sidewise in his (Newman) chair, with his (Newman) elbow on the back and his (Newman) head leaning on his (Newman) hand. Without moving he (Newman) looked a while at his (Newman) companion with his (Newman) dry, guarded, half-inscrutable, and yet altogether good-natured smile.

``Introduce me to your wife!'' (he)
he (Newman) said at last.

Tristram bounced about in his (Tristram) chair.

``Upon my word, I won't. She (wife) doesn't want any help to turn up her (wife) nose at me, nor do you, either!'' (unknown)

``I don't turn up my nose at you, my dear fellow; nor at anyone, or anything. I'm not proud, I assure you I'm not proud. That's why I am willing to take example by the clever people.'' (unknown)

``Well, if I'm not the rose, as they say here, I have lived near it. I can show you some clever people, too. Do you know General Packard? Do you know C. P. Hatch? Do you know Miss Kitty Upjohn?'' (unknown)

``I shall be happy to make their acquaintance; I want to cultivate society.'' (unknown)

Tristram seemed restless and suspicious; he (Tristram) eyed his (Tristram) friend askance, and then,

``What are you up to, anyway?'' (friend)
he (Tristram) demanded.
``Are you going to write a book?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Christopher Newman twisted one end of his (Newman) moustache a while, in silence, and at last he (Newman) made answer.

``One day, a couple of months ago, something very curious happened to me. I had come on to New York on some important business; it was rather a long story--a question of getting ahead of another party, in a certain particular way, in the stock-market. This other party had once played me a very mean trick. I owed him (acquaintance) a grudge, I felt awfully savage at the time, and I vowed that, when I got a chance, I would, figuratively speaking, put his (acquaintance) nose out of joint. There was a matter of some sixty thousand dollars at stake. If I put it out of his (acquaintance) way, it was a blow the fellow would feel, and he (fellow) really deserved no quarter. I jumped into a hack and went about my business, and it was in this hack--this immortal, historical hack--that the curious thing I speak of occurred. It was a hack like any other, only a trifle dirtier, with a greasy line along the top of the drab cushions, as if it had been used for a great many Irish funerals. It is possible I took a nap; I had been traveling all night, and though I was excited with my errand, I felt the want of sleep. At all events I woke up suddenly, from a sleep or from a kind of a reverie, with the most extraordinary feeling in the world--a mortal disgust for the thing I was going to do. It came upon me like _that!_'' (he)
and he (Newman) snapped his (Newman) fingers--
``as abruptly as an old wound that begins to ache. I couldn't tell the meaning of it; I only felt that I loathed the whole business and wanted to wash my hands of it. The idea of losing that sixty thousand dollars, of letting it utterly slide and scuttle and never hearing of it again, seemed the sweetest thing in the world. And all this took place quite independently of my will, and I sat watching it as if it were a play at the theatre. I could feel it going on inside of me. You may depend upon it that there are things going on inside of us that we understand mighty little about.'' (he)

``Jupiter! you make my flesh creep!'' (unknown)
cried Tristram.
``And while you sat in your hack, watching the play, as you call it, the other man marched in and bagged your sixty thousand dollars?'' (unknown)

``I have not the least idea. I hope so, poor devil! but I never found out. We pulled up in front of the place I was going to in Wall Street, but I sat still in the carriage, and at last the driver scrambled down off his (driver) seat to see whether his (driver) carriage had not turned into a hearse. I couldn't have got out, any more than if I had been a corpse. What was the matter with me? Momentary idiocy, you'll say. What I wanted to get out of was Wall Street. I told the man to drive down to the Brooklyn ferry and to cross over. When we were over, I told him (man) to drive me out into the country. As I had told him (man) originally to drive for dear life down town, I suppose he (man) thought me insane. Perhaps I was, but in that case I am insane still. I spent the morning looking at the first green leaves on Long Island. I was sick of business; I wanted to throw it all up and break off short; I had money enough, or if I hadn't I ought to have. I seemed to feel a new man inside my old skin, and I longed for a new world. When you want a thing so very badly you had better treat yourself to it. I didn't understand the matter, not in the least; but I gave the old horse the bridle and let him (man) find his (man) way. As soon as I could get out of the game I sailed for Europe. That is how I come to be sitting here.'' (unknown)

``You ought to have bought up that hack,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram;
``it isn't a safe vehicle to have about. And you have really sold out, then; you have retired from business?'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

``I have made over my hand to a friend; when I feel disposed, I can take up the cards again. I dare say that a twelvemonth hence the operation will be reversed. The pendulum will swing back again. I shall be sitting in a gondola or on a dromedary, and all of a sudden I shall want to clear out. But for the present I am perfectly free. I have even bargained that I am to receive no business letters.'' (unknown)

``Oh, it's a real _caprice de prince_,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram.
``I back out; a poor devil like me can't help you to spend such very magnificent leisure as that. You should get introduced to the crowned heads.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman looked at him (Tristram) a moment, and then, with his (Tristram) easy smile,

``How does one do it?'' (him)
he (Tristram) asked.

``Come, I like that!'' (unknown)
cried Tristram.
``It shows you are in earnest.'' (unknown)

``Of course I am in earnest. Didn't I say I wanted the best? I know the best can't be had for mere money, but I rather think money will do a good deal. In addition, I am willing to take a good deal of trouble.'' (unknown)

``You are not bashful, eh?'' (unknown)

``I haven't the least idea. I want the biggest kind of entertainment a man can get. People, places, art, nature, everything! I want to see the tallest mountains, and the bluest lakes, and the finest pictures and the handsomest churches, and the most celebrated men, and the most beautiful women.'' (unknown)

``Settle down in Paris, then. There are no mountains that I know of, and the only lake is in the Bois du Boulogne, and not particularly blue. But there is everything else: plenty of pictures and churches, no end of celebrated men, and several beautiful women.'' (unknown)

``But I can't settle down in Paris at this season, just as summer is coming on.'' (unknown)

``Oh, for the summer go up to Trouville.'' (unknown)

``What is Trouville?'' (unknown)

``The French Newport. Half the Americans go.'' (unknown)

``Is it anywhere near the Alps?'' (unknown)

``About as near as Newport is to the Rocky Mountains.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I want to see Mont Blanc,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``and Amsterdam, and the Rhine, and a lot of places. Venice in particular. I have great ideas about Venice.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Ah,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mr. Tristram, rising,
``I see I shall have to introduce you to my wife!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

CHAPTER III

He (Tristram) performed this ceremony on the following day, when, by appointment, Christopher Newman went to dine with him (Newman). Mr. and Mrs. Tristram lived behind one of those chalk-colored façades which decorate with their pompous sameness the broad avenues manufactured by Baron Haussmann in the neighborhood of the Arc de Triomphe. Their apartment was rich in the modern conveniences, and Tristram lost no time in calling his (Tristram) visitor's attention to their principal household treasures, the gas-lamps and the furnace-holes.

``Whenever you feel homesick,'' (he)
he (Tristram) said,
``you must come up here. We'll stick you down before a register, under a good big burner, and--'' (he)

``And you will soon get over your homesickness,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.

Her (Tristram) husband stared; his (husband) wife often had a tone which he (husband) found inscrutable he (husband) could not tell for his (husband) life whether she (Tristram) was in jest or in earnest. The truth is that circumstances had done much to cultivate in Mrs. Tristram a marked tendency to irony. Her (Tristram) taste on many points differed from that of her (Tristram) husband, and though she (Tristram) made frequent concessions it must be confessed that her (Tristram) concessions were not always graceful. They were founded upon a vague project she (Tristram) had of some day doing something very positive, something a trifle passionate. What she (Tristram) meant to do she (Tristram) could by no means have told you; but meanwhile, nevertheless, she (Tristram) was buying a good conscience, by instalments.

It should be added, without delay, to anticipate misconception, that her (Tristram) little scheme of independence did not definitely involve the assistance of another person, of the opposite sex; she (Tristram) was not saving up virtue to cover the expenses of a flirtation. For this there were various reasons. To begin with, she (Tristram) had a very plain face and she (Tristram) was entirely without illusions as to her (Tristram) appearance. She (Tristram) had taken its measure to a hair's breadth, she (Tristram) knew the worst and the best, she (Tristram) had accepted herself. It had not been, indeed, without a struggle. As a young girl she (girl) had spent hours with her (girl) back to her (girl) mirror, crying her (girl) eyes out; and later she (girl) had from desperation and bravado adopted the habit of proclaiming herself the most ill-favored of women, in order that she (girl) might--as in common politeness was inevitable--be contradicted and reassured. It was since she (girl) had come to live in Europe that she (girl) had begun to take the matter philosophically. Her (girl) observation, acutely exercised here, had suggested to her (girl) that a woman's first duty is not to be beautiful, but to be pleasing, and she (girl) encountered so many women who pleased without beauty that she (girl) began to feel that she (girl) had discovered her (girl) mission. She (girl) had once heard an enthusiastic musician, out of patience with a gifted bungler, declare that a fine voice is really an obstacle to singing properly; and it occurred to her (girl) that it might perhaps be equally true that a beautiful face is an obstacle to the acquisition of charming manners. Mrs. Tristram, then, undertook to be exquisitely agreeable, and she (Tristram) brought to the task a really touching devotion. How well she (Tristram) would have succeeded I am unable to say; unfortunately she (Tristram) broke off in the middle. Her (Tristram) own excuse was the want of encouragement in her (Tristram) immediate circle. But I am inclined to think that she (Tristram) had not a real genius for the matter, or she (Tristram) would have pursued the charming art for itself. The poor lady was very incomplete. She (lady) fell back upon the harmonies of the toilet, which she (lady) thoroughly understood, and contented herself with dressing in perfection. She (lady) lived in Paris, which she (lady) pretended to detest, because it was only in Paris that one could find things to exactly suit one's complexion. Besides out of Paris it was always more or less of a trouble to get ten-button gloves. When she (lady) railed at this serviceable city and you asked her (lady) where she (lady) would prefer to reside, she (lady) returned some very unexpected answer. She (lady) would say in Copenhagen, or in Barcelona; having, while making the tour of Europe, spent a couple of days at each of these places. On the whole, with her (lady) poetic furbelows and her (lady) misshapen, intelligent little face, she (lady) was, when you knew her (lady), a decidedly interesting woman. She (woman) was naturally shy, and if she (woman) had been born a beauty, she (woman) would -LRB-having no vanity-RRB- probably have remained shy. Now, she (woman) was both diffident and importunate; extremely reserved sometimes with her (woman) friends, and strangely expansive with strangers. She (woman) despised her (woman) husband; despised him (husband) too much, for she (woman) had been perfectly at liberty not to marry him (husband). She (woman) had been in love with a clever man who had slighted her (woman), and she (woman) had married a fool in the hope that this thankless wit, reflecting on it, would conclude that she (woman) had no appreciation of merit, and that he (fool) had flattered himself in supposing that she (woman) cared for his (fool) own. Restless, discontented, visionary, without personal ambitions, but with a certain avidity of imagination, she (woman) was, as I have said before, eminently incomplete. She (woman) was full--both for good and for ill--of beginnings that came to nothing; but she (woman) had nevertheless, morally, a spark of the sacred fire.

Newman was fond, under all circumstances, of the society of women, and now that he (Newman) was out of his (Newman) native element and deprived of his (Newman) habitual interests, he (Newman) turned to it for compensation. He (Newman) took a great fancy to Mrs. Tristram; she (Tristram) frankly repaid it, and after their first meeting he (Newman) passed a great many hours in her (Tristram) drawing-room. After two or three talks they were fast friends. Newman's manner with women was peculiar, and it required some ingenuity on a lady's part to discover that he (Newman) admired her (lady). He (Newman) had no gallantry, in the usual sense of the term; no compliments, no graces, no speeches. Very fond of what is called chaffing, in his (Newman) dealings with men, he (Newman) never found himself on a sofa beside a member of the softer sex without feeling extremely serious. He (Newman) was not shy, and so far as awkwardness proceeds from a struggle with shyness, he (Newman) was not awkward; grave, attentive, submissive, often silent, he (Newman) was simply swimming in a sort of rapture of respect. This emotion was not at all theoretic, it was not even in a high degree sentimental; he (Newman) had thought very little about the

``position'' (he)
of women, and he (Newman) was not familiar either sympathetically or otherwise, with the image of a President in petticoats. His (President) attitude was simply the flower of his (President) general good-nature, and a part of his (President) instinctive and genuinely democratic assumption of everyone's right to lead an easy life. If a shaggy pauper had a right to bed and board and wages and a vote, women, of course, who were weaker than paupers, and whose physical tissue was in itself an appeal, should be maintained, sentimentally, at the public expense. Newman was willing to be taxed for this purpose, largely, in proportion to his (Newman) means. Moreover, many of the common traditions with regard to women were with him (Newman) fresh personal impressions; he (Newman) had never read a novel! He (Newman) had been struck with their acuteness, their subtlety, their tact, their felicity of judgment. They seemed to him (Newman) exquisitely organized. If it is true that one must always have in one's work here below a religion, or at least an ideal, of some sort, Newman found his (Newman) metaphysical inspiration in a vague acceptance of final responsibility to some illumined feminine brow.

He (Newman) spent a great deal of time in listening to advice from Mrs. Tristram; advice, it must be added, for which he (Newman) had never asked. He (Newman) would have been incapable of asking for it, for he (Newman) had no perception of difficulties, and consequently no curiosity about remedies. The complex Parisian world about him (Newman) seemed a very simple affair; it was an immense, amazing spectacle, but it neither inflamed his (Newman) imagination nor irritated his (Newman) curiosity. He (Newman) kept his (Newman) hands in his (Newman) pockets, looked on good-humoredly, desired to miss nothing important, observed a great many things narrowly, and never reverted to himself. Mrs. Tristram's

``advice'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
was a part of the show, and a more entertaining element, in her (Tristram) abundant gossip, than the others. He (Newman) enjoyed her (Tristram) talking about himself; it seemed a part of her (Tristram) beautiful ingenuity; but he (Newman) never made an application of anything she (Tristram) said, or remembered it when he (Newman) was away from her (Tristram). For herself, she (Tristram) appropriated him (Newman); he (Newman) was the most interesting thing she (Tristram) had had to think about in many a month. She (Tristram) wished to do something with him (Newman)--she (Tristram) hardly knew what. There was so much of him (Newman); he (Newman) was so rich and robust, so easy, friendly, well-disposed, that he (Newman) kept her (Tristram) fancy constantly on the alert. For the present, the only thing she (Tristram) could do was to like him (Newman). She (Tristram) told him (Newman) that he (Newman) was
``horribly Western,'' (he)
but in this compliment the adverb was tinged with insincerity. She (Tristram) led him (Newman) about with her (Tristram), introduced him (Newman) to fifty people, and took extreme satisfaction in her (Tristram) conquest. Newman accepted every proposal, shook hands universally and promiscuously, and seemed equally unfamiliar with trepidation or with elation. Tom Tristram complained of his (Tristram) wife's avidity, and declared that he (Tristram) could never have a clear five minutes with his (Tristram) friend. If he (Tristram) had known how things were going to turn out, he (Tristram) never would have brought him (Tristram) to the Avenue d’Iéna. The two men, formerly, had not been intimate, but Newman remembered his (Newman) earlier impression of his (Newman) host, and did Mrs. Tristram, who had by no means taken him (Newman) into her (Tristram) confidence, but whose secret he (Newman) presently discovered, the justice to admit that her (Tristram) husband was a rather degenerate mortal. At twenty-five he (husband) had been a good fellow, and in this respect he (husband) was unchanged; but of a man of his (husband) age one expected something more. People said he (husband) was sociable, but this was as much a matter of course as for a dipped sponge to expand; and it was not a high order of sociability. He (husband) was a great gossip and tattler, and to produce a laugh would hardly have spared the reputation of his (husband) aged mother. Newman had a kindness for old memories, but he (Newman) found it impossible not to perceive that Tristram was nowadays a very light weight. His (Tristram) only aspirations were to hold out at poker, at his (Tristram) club, to know the names of all the _cocottes_, to shake hands all round, to ply his (Tristram) rosy gullet with truffles and champagne, and to create uncomfortable eddies and obstructions among the constituent atoms of the American colony. He (Tristram) was shamefully idle, spiritless, sensual, snobbish. He (Tristram) irritated our friend by the tone of his (Tristram) allusions to their native country, and Newman was at a loss to understand why the United States were not good enough for Mr. Tristram. He (Tristram) had never been a very conscious patriot, but it vexed him (Tristram) to see them treated as little better than a vulgar smell in his (Tristram) friend's nostrils, and he (Tristram) finally broke out and swore that they were the greatest country in the world, that they could put all Europe into their breeches' pockets, and that an American who spoke ill of them ought to be carried home in irons and compelled to live in Boston. -LRB-This, for Newman was putting it very vindictively.-RRB- Tristram was a comfortable man to snub, he (Tristram) bore no malice, and he (Tristram) continued to insist on Newman's finishing his (Newman) evening at the Occidental Club.

Christopher Newman dined several times in the Avenue d’Iéna, and his (Newman) host always proposed an early adjournment to this institution. Mrs. Tristram protested, and declared that her (Tristram) husband exhausted his (husband) ingenuity in trying to displease her (Tristram).

``Oh no, I never try, my love,'' (he)
he (husband) answered.
``I know you loathe me quite enough when I take my chance.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman hated to see a husband and wife on these terms, and he (Newman) was sure one or other of them must be very unhappy. He (Newman) knew it was not Tristram. Mrs. Tristram had a balcony before her (Tristram) windows, upon which, during the June evenings, she (Tristram) was fond of sitting, and Newman used frankly to say that he (Newman) preferred the balcony to the club. It had a fringe of perfumed plants in tubs, and enabled you to look up the broad street and see the Arch of Triumph vaguely massing its heroic sculptures in the summer starlight. Sometimes Newman kept his (Newman) promise of following Mr. Tristram, in half an hour, to the Occidental, and sometimes he (Newman) forgot it. His (Newman) hostess asked him (Newman) a great many questions about himself, but on this subject he (Newman) was an indifferent talker. He (Newman) was not what is called subjective, though when he (Newman) felt that her (hostess) interest was sincere, he (Newman) made an almost heroic attempt to be. He (Newman) told her (hostess) a great many things he (Newman) had done, and regaled her (hostess) with anecdotes of Western life; she (hostess) was from Philadelphia, and with her (hostess) eight years in Paris, talked of herself as a languid Oriental. But some other person was always the hero of the tale, by no means always to his (hero) advantage; and Newman's own emotions were but scantily chronicled. She (hostess) had an especial wish to know whether he (Newman) had ever been in love--seriously, passionately--and, failing to gather any satisfaction from his (Newman) allusions, she (hostess) at last directly inquired. He (Newman) hesitated a while, and at last he (Newman) said,

``No!'' (he)
She (hostess) declared that she (hostess) was delighted to hear it, as it confirmed her (hostess) private conviction that he (Newman) was a man of no feeling.

``Really?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked, very gravely.
``Do you think so? How do you recognize a man of feeling?'' (unknown)

``I can't make out,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram,
``whether you are very simple or very deep.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``I'm very deep. That's a fact.'' (unknown)

``I believe that if I were to tell you with a certain air that you have no feeling, you would implicitly believe me.'' (unknown)

``A certain air?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Try it and see.'' (unknown)

``You would believe me, but you would not care,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.

``You have got it all wrong. I should care immensely, but I shouldn't believe you. The fact is I have never had time to feel things. I have had to _do_ them, to make myself felt.'' (unknown)

``I can imagine that you may have done that tremendously, sometimes.'' (unknown)

``Yes, there's no mistake about that.'' (unknown)

``When you are in a fury it can't be pleasant.'' (unknown)

``I am never in a fury.'' (unknown)

``Angry, then, or displeased.'' (unknown)

``I am never angry, and it is so long since I have been displeased that I have quite forgotten it.'' (unknown)

``I don't believe,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram,
``that you are never angry. A man ought to be angry sometimes, and you are neither good enough nor bad enough always to keep your temper.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``I lose it perhaps once in five years.'' (unknown)

``The time is coming round, then,'' (hostess)
said his (Newman) hostess.
``Before I have known you six months I shall see you in a fine fury.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean to put me into one?'' (unknown)

``I should not be sorry. You take things too coolly. It exasperates me. And then you are too happy. You have what must be the most agreeable thing in the world, the consciousness of having bought your pleasure beforehand and paid for it. You have not a day of reckoning staring you in the face. Your reckonings are over.'' (unknown)

``Well, I suppose I am happy,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, meditatively.

``You have been odiously successful.'' (unknown)

``Successful in copper,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``only so-so in railroads, and a hopeless fizzle in oil.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``It is very disagreeable to know how Americans have made their money. Now you have the world before you. You have only to enjoy.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I suppose I am very well off,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Only I am tired of having it thrown up at me. Besides, there are several drawbacks. I am not intellectual.'' (unknown)

``One doesn't expect it of you,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Mrs. Tristram answered. Then in a moment,
``Besides, you are!'' (unknown)

``Well, I mean to have a good time, whether or no,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I am not cultivated, I am not even educated; I know nothing about history, or art, or foreign tongues, or any other learned matters. But I am not a fool, either, and I shall undertake to know something about Europe by the time I have done with it. I feel something under my ribs here,'' (he)
he (Newman) added in a moment,
``that I can't explain--a sort of a mighty hankering, a desire to stretch out and haul in.'' (he)

``Bravo!'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram,
``that is very fine. You are the great Western Barbarian, stepping forth in his (Bravo) innocence and might, gazing a while at this poor effete Old World and then swooping down on it.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``Oh, come,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I am not a barbarian, by a good deal. I am very much the reverse. I have seen barbarians; I know what they are.'' (unknown)

``I don't mean that you are a Comanche chief, or that you wear a blanket and feathers. There are different shades.'' (unknown)

``I am a highly civilized man,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I stick to that. If you don't believe it, I should like to prove it to you.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Mrs. Tristram was silent a while.

``I should like to make you prove it,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said, at last.
``I should like to put you in a difficult place.'' (unknown)

``Pray do,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``That has a little conceited sound!'' (companion)
his (Newman) companion rejoined.

``Oh,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I have a very good opinion of myself.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I wish I could put it to the test. Give me time and I will.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
And Mrs. Tristram remained silent for some time afterwards, as if she (Tristram) was trying to keep her (Tristram) pledge. It did not appear that evening that she (Tristram) succeeded; but as he (Newman) was rising to take his (Newman) leave she (Tristram) passed suddenly, as she (Tristram) was very apt to do, from the tone of unsparing persiflage to that of almost tremulous sympathy.
``Speaking seriously,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said,
``I believe in you, Mr. Newman. You flatter my patriotism.'' (she)

``Your patriotism?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Christopher demanded.

``Even so. It would take too long to explain, and you probably would not understand. Besides, you might take it--really, you might take it for a declaration. But it has nothing to do with you personally; it's what you represent. Fortunately you don't know all that, or your conceit would increase insufferably.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman stood staring and wondering what under the sun he (Newman)

``represented.'' (he)

``Forgive all my meddlesome chatter and forget my advice. It is very silly in me to undertake to tell you what to do. When you are embarrassed, do as you think best, and you will do very well. When you are in a difficulty, judge for yourself.'' (unknown)

``I shall remember everything you have told me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``There are so many forms and ceremonies over here--'' (unknown)

``Forms and ceremonies are what I mean, of course.'' (unknown)

``Ah, but I want to observe them,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Haven't I as good a right as another? They don't scare me, and you needn't give me leave to violate them. I won't take it.'' (unknown)

``That is not what I mean. I mean, observe them in your own way. Settle nice questions for yourself. Cut the knot or untie it, as you choose.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I am sure I shall never fumble over it!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

The next time that he (Newman) dined in the Avenue d’Iéna was a Sunday, a day on which Mr. Tristram left the cards unshuffled, so that there was a trio in the evening on the balcony. The talk was of many things, and at last Mrs. Tristram suddenly observed to Christopher Newman that it was high time he (Newman) should take a wife.

``Listen to her (I); she (I) has the audacity!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram, who on Sunday evenings was always rather acrimonious.

``I don't suppose you have made up your mind not to marry?'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Mrs. Tristram continued.

``Heaven forbid!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``I am sternly resolved on it.'' (unknown)

``It's very easy,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram;
``fatally easy!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

``Well, then, I suppose you do not mean to wait till you are fifty.'' (unknown)

``On the contrary, I am in a great hurry.'' (unknown)

``One would never suppose it. Do you expect a lady to come and propose to you?'' (unknown)

``No; I am willing to propose. I think a great deal about it.'' (unknown)

``Tell me some of your thoughts.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, slowly,
``I want to marry very well.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Marry a woman of sixty, then,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram.

```Well' in what sense?''

``In every sense. I shall be hard to please.'' (unknown)

``You must remember that, as the French proverb says, the most beautiful girl in the world can give but what she (girl) has.'' (unknown)

``Since you ask me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I will say frankly that I want extremely to marry. It is time, to begin with: before I know it I shall be forty. And then I'm lonely and helpless and dull. But if I marry now, so long as I didn't do it in hot haste when I was twenty, I must do it with my eyes open. I want to do the thing in handsome style. I do not only want to make no mistakes, but I want to make a great hit. I want to take my pick. My wife must be a magnificent woman.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``_Voilà ce qui s'appelle parler!_'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
cried Mrs. Tristram.
