``Oh, I have thought an immense deal about it.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps you think too much. The best thing is simply to fall in love.'' (unknown)

``When I find the woman who pleases me, I shall love her (woman) enough. My wife shall be very comfortable.'' (unknown)

``You are superb! There's a chance for the magnificent women.'' (unknown)

``You are not fair.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman rejoined.
``You draw a fellow out and put him (fellow) off guard, and then you laugh at him (fellow).'' (unknown)

``I assure you,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram,
``that I am very serious. To prove it, I will make you a proposal. Should you like me, as they say here, to marry you?'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``To hunt up a wife for me?'' (unknown)

``She (wife) is already found. I will bring you together.'' (unknown)

``Oh, come,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram,
``we don't keep a matrimonial bureau. He (fellow) will think you want your commission.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

``Present me to a woman who comes up to my notions,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``and I will marry her (woman) tomorrow.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``You have a strange tone about it, and I don't quite understand you. I didn't suppose you would be so coldblooded and calculating.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman was silent a while.

``Well,'' (he)
he (Newman) said, at last,
``I want a great woman. I stick to that. That's one thing I _can_ treat myself to, and if it is to be had I mean to have it. What else have I toiled and struggled for, all these years? I have succeeded, and now what am I to do with my success? To make it perfect, as I see it, there must be a beautiful woman perched on the pile, like a statue on a monument. She (woman) must be as good as she (woman) is beautiful, and as clever as she (woman) is good. I can give my wife a good deal, so I am not afraid to ask a good deal myself. She (woman) shall have everything a woman can desire; I shall not even object to her (woman) being too good for me; she (woman) may be cleverer and wiser than I can understand, and I shall only be the better pleased. I want to possess, in a word, the best article in the market.'' (he)

``Why didn't you tell a fellow all this at the outset?'' (unknown)
Tristram demanded.
``I have been trying so to make you fond of _me!_'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``This is very interesting,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.
``I like to see a man know his (man) own mind.'' (unknown)

``I have known mine for a long time,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman went on.
``I made up my mind tolerably early in life that a beautiful wife was the thing best worth having, here below. It is the greatest victory over circumstances. When I say beautiful, I mean beautiful in mind and in manners, as well as in person. It is a thing every man has an equal right to; he (man) may get it if he (man) can. He (man) doesn't have to be born with certain faculties, on purpose; he (man) needs only to be a man. Then he (man) needs only to use his (man) will, and such wits as he (man) has, and to try.'' (unknown)

``It strikes me that your marriage is to be rather a matter of vanity.'' (unknown)

``Well, it is certain,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``that if people notice my wife and admire her (wife), I shall be mightily tickled.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``After this,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
cried Mrs. Tristram,
``call any man modest!'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``But none of them will admire her (wife) so much as I.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I see you have a taste for splendor.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman hesitated a little; and then,

``I honestly believe I have!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
he (Newman) said.

``And I suppose you have already looked about you a good deal.'' (unknown)

``A good deal, according to opportunity.'' (unknown)

``And you have seen nothing that satisfied you?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, half reluctantly,
``I am bound to say in honesty that I have seen nothing that really satisfied me.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``You remind me of the heroes of the French romantic poets, Rolla and Fortunio and all those other insatiable gentlemen for whom nothing in this world was handsome enough. But I see you are in earnest, and I should like to help you.'' (unknown)

``Who the deuce is it, darling, that you are going to put upon him (heroes)?'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
Tristram cried.
``We know a good many pretty girls, thank Heaven, but magnificent women are not so common.'' (unknown)

``Have you any objections to a foreigner?'' (wife)
his (Tristram) wife continued, addressing Newman, who had tilted back his (Newman) chair and, with his (Newman) feet on a bar of the balcony railing and his (Newman) hands in his (Newman) pockets, was looking at the stars.

``No Irish need apply,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram.

Newman meditated a while.

``As a foreigner, no,'' (he)
he (Newman) said at last;
``I have no prejudices.'' (he)

``My dear fellow, you have no suspicions!'' (unknown)
cried Tristram.
``You don't know what terrible customers these foreign women are; especially the `magnificent' ones. How should you like a fair Circassian, with a dagger in her (I) belt?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman administered a vigorous slap to his (Newman) knee.

``I would marry a Japanese, if she (I) pleased me,'' (he)
he (Newman) affirmed.

``We had better confine ourselves to Europe,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.
``The only thing is, then, that the person be in herself to your taste?'' (unknown)

``She (I) is going to offer you an unappreciated governess!'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
Tristram groaned.

``Assuredly. I won't deny that, other things being equal, I should prefer one of my own countrywomen. We should speak the same language, and that would be a comfort. But I am not afraid of a foreigner. Besides, I rather like the idea of taking in Europe, too. It enlarges the field of selection. When you choose from a greater number, you can bring your choice to a finer point!'' (unknown)

``You talk like Sardanapalus!'' (unknown)
exclaimed Tristram.

``You say all this to the right person,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman's hostess.
``I happen to number among my friends the loveliest woman in the world. Neither more nor less. I don't say a very charming person or a very estimable woman or a very great beauty; I say simply the loveliest woman in the world.'' (unknown)

``The deuce!'' (unknown)
cried Tristram,
``you have kept very quiet about her (woman). Were you afraid of me?'' (unknown)

``You have seen her (woman),'' (wife)
said his (Newman) wife,
``but you have no perception of such merit as Claire's.'' (wife)

``Ah, her (Claire) name is Claire? I give it up.'' (unknown)

``Does your friend wish to marry?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``Not in the least. It is for you to make her (Claire) change her (Claire) mind. It will not be easy; she (Claire) has had one husband, and he (husband) gave her (Claire) a low opinion of the species.'' (unknown)

``Oh, she (Claire) is a widow, then?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Are you already afraid? She (Claire) was married at eighteen, by her (Claire) parents, in the French fashion, to a disagreeable old man. But he (man) had the good taste to die a couple of years afterward, and she (Claire) is now twenty-five.'' (unknown)

``So she (Claire) is French?'' (unknown)

``French by her (Claire) father, English by her (Claire) mother. She (Claire) is really more English than French, and she (Claire) speaks English as well as you or I--or rather much better. She (Claire) belongs to the very top of the basket, as they say here. Her (Claire) family, on each side, is of fabulous antiquity; her (Claire) mother is the daughter of an English Catholic earl. Her (Claire) father is dead, and since her (Claire) widowhood she (Claire) has lived with her (Claire) mother and a married brother. There is another brother, younger, who I believe is wild. They have an old hotel in the Rue de l’Université, but their fortune is small, and they make a common household, for economy's sake. When I was a girl I was put into a convent here for my education, while my father made the tour of Europe. It was a silly thing to do with me, but it had the advantage that it made me acquainted with Claire de Bellegarde. She (Claire) was younger than I but we became fast friends. I took a tremendous fancy to her (Claire), and she (Claire) returned my passion as far as she (Claire) could. They kept such a tight rein on her (Claire) that she (Claire) could do very little, and when I left the convent she (Claire) had to give me up. I was not of her (Claire) _monde_; I am not now, either, but we sometimes meet. They are terrible people--her (Claire) _monde_; all mounted upon stilts a mile high, and with pedigrees long in proportion. It is the skim of the milk of the old _noblesse_. Do you know what a Legitimist is, or an Ultramontane? Go into Madame de Cintré's drawing-room some afternoon, at five o’clock, and you will see the best preserved specimens. I say go, but no one is admitted who can't show his (you) fifty quarterings.'' (unknown)

``And this is the lady you propose to me to marry?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.
``A lady I can't even approach?'' (unknown)

``But you said just now that you recognized no obstacles.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman looked at Mrs. Tristram a while, stroking his (Newman) moustache.

``Is she (lady) a beauty?'' (he)
he (Newman) demanded.

``No.'' (unknown)

``Oh, then it's no use--'' (unknown)

``She (lady) is not a beauty, but she (lady) is beautiful, two very different things. A beauty has no faults in her (lady) face, the face of a beautiful woman may have faults that only deepen its charm.'' (unknown)

``I remember Madame de Cintré, now,'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram.
``She (lady) is as plain as a pike-staff. A man wouldn't look at her (lady) twice.'' (unknown)

``In saying that _he (man)_ would not look at her (lady) twice, my husband sufficiently describes her (lady),'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Mrs. Tristram rejoined.

``Is she (lady) good; is she (lady) clever?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

``She (lady) is perfect! I won't say more than that. When you are praising a person to another who is to know her (lady), it is bad policy to go into details. I won't exaggerate. I simply recommend her (lady). Among all women I have known she (lady) stands alone; she (lady) is of a different clay.'' (unknown)

``I should like to see her (lady),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, simply.

``I will try to manage it. The only way will be to invite her (lady) to dinner. I have never invited her (lady) before, and I don't know that she (lady) will come. Her (lady) old feudal countess of a mother rules the family with an iron hand, and allows her (lady) to have no friends but of her (lady) own choosing, and to visit only in a certain sacred circle. But I can at least ask her (lady).'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

At this moment Mrs. Tristram was interrupted; a servant stepped out upon the balcony and announced that there were visitors in the drawing-room. When Newman's hostess had gone in to receive her (hostess) friends, Tom Tristram approached his (Tristram) guest.

``Don't put your foot into _this_, my boy,'' (he)
he (Tristram) said, puffing the last whiffs of his (Tristram) cigar.
``There's nothing in it!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman looked askance at him (Newman), inquisitive.

``You tell another story, eh?'' (unknown)

``I say simply that Madame de Cintré is a great white doll of a woman, who cultivates quiet haughtiness.'' (unknown)

``Ah, she (woman)'s haughty, eh?'' (unknown)

``She (woman) looks at you as if you were so much thin air, and cares for you about as much.'' (unknown)

``She (woman) is very proud, eh?'' (unknown)

``Proud? As proud as I'm humble.'' (unknown)

``And not good-looking?'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

Tristram shrugged his (Tristram) shoulders:

``It's a kind of beauty you must be _intellectual_ to understand. But I must go in and amuse the company.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)

Some time elapsed before Newman followed his (Newman) friends into the drawing-room. When he (Newman) at last made his (Newman) appearance there he (Newman) remained but a short time, and during this period sat perfectly silent, listening to a lady to whom Mrs. Tristram had straightway introduced him (Newman) and who chattered, without a pause, with the full force of an extraordinarily high-pitched voice. Newman gazed and attended. Presently he (Newman) came to bid good-night to Mrs. Tristram.

``Who is that lady?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.

``Miss Dora Finch. How do you like her (Finch)?'' (unknown)

``She (Finch)'s too noisy.'' (unknown)

``She (Finch) is thought so bright! Certainly, you are fastidious,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.

Newman stood a moment, hesitating. Then at last,

``Don't forget about your friend,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``Madame What's-her-name? the proud beauty. Ask her (Finch) to dinner, and give me a good notice.'' (he)
And with this he (Newman) departed.

Some days later he (Newman) came back; it was in the afternoon. He (Newman) found Mrs. Tristram in her (Tristram) drawing-room; with her (Tristram) was a visitor, a woman young and pretty, dressed in white. The two ladies had risen and the visitor was apparently taking her (Tristram) leave. As Newman approached, he (Newman) received from Mrs. Tristram a glance of the most vivid significance, which he (Newman) was not immediately able to interpret.

``This is a good friend of ours,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said, turning to her (Tristram) companion,
``Mr. Christopher Newman. I have spoken of you to him (Newman) and he (Newman) has an extreme desire to make your acquaintance. If you had consented to come and dine, I should have offered him (Newman) an opportunity.'' (companion)

The stranger turned her (Tristram) face toward Newman, with a smile. He (Newman) was not embarrassed, for his (Newman) unconscious _sang-froid_ was boundless; but as he (Newman) became aware that this was the proud and beautiful Madame de Cintré, the loveliest woman in the world, the promised perfection, the proposed ideal, he (Newman) made an instinctive movement to gather his (Newman) wits together. Through the slight preoccupation that it produced he (Newman) had a sense of a long, fair face, and of two eyes that were both brilliant and mild.

``I should have been most happy,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.
``Unfortunately, as I have been telling Mrs. Tristram, I go on Monday to the country.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman had made a solemn bow.

``I am very sorry,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

``Paris is getting too warm,'' (Madame)
Madame de Cintré added, taking her (woman) friend's hand again in farewell.

Mrs. Tristram seemed to have formed a sudden and somewhat venturesome resolution, and she (Tristram) smiled more intensely, as women do when they take such resolution.

``I want Mr. Newman to know you,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said, dropping her (Tristram) head on one side and looking at Madame de Cintré's bonnet ribbons.

Christopher Newman stood gravely silent, while his (Newman) native penetration admonished him (Newman). Mrs. Tristram was determined to force her (Tristram) friend to address him (friend) a word of encouragement which should be more than one of the common formulas of politeness; and if she (Tristram) was prompted by charity, it was by the charity that begins at home. Madame de Cintré was her (Tristram) dearest Claire, and her (Tristram) especial admiration but Madame de Cintré had found it impossible to dine with her (Tristram) and Madame de Cintré should for once be forced gently to render tribute to Mrs. Tristram.

``It would give me great pleasure,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said, looking at Mrs. Tristram.

``That's a great deal,'' (unknown)
cried the latter,
``for Madame de Cintré to say!'' (unknown)

``I am very much obliged to you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Mrs. Tristram can speak better for me than I can speak for myself.'' (Madame)

Madame de Cintré looked at him (Newman) again, with the same soft brightness.

``Are you to be long in Paris?'' (she)
she (Tristram) asked.

``We shall keep him (Newman),'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.

``But you are keeping _me!_'' (Madame de Cintré)
and Madame de Cintré shook her (Tristram) friend's hand.

``A moment longer,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.

Madame de Cintré looked at Newman again; this time without her (Tristram) smile. Her (Tristram) eyes lingered a moment.

``Will you come and see me?'' (she)
she (Tristram) asked.

Mrs. Tristram kissed her (Tristram). Newman expressed his (Newman) thanks, and she (Tristram) took her (Tristram) leave. Her (Tristram) hostess went with her (Tristram) to the door, and left Newman alone a moment. Presently she (Tristram) returned, rubbing her (Tristram) hands.

``It was a fortunate chance,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said.
``She (Tristram) had come to decline my invitation. You triumphed on the spot, making her (Tristram) ask you, at the end of three minutes, to her (Tristram) house.'' (unknown)

``It was you who triumphed,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You must not be too hard upon her (Tristram).'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Mrs. Tristram stared.

``What do you mean?'' (unknown)

``She (Tristram) did not strike me as so proud. I should say she (Tristram) was shy.'' (unknown)

``You are very discriminating. And what do you think of her (Tristram) face?'' (unknown)

``It's handsome!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I should think it was! Of course you will go and see her (Tristram).'' (unknown)

``To-morrow!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.

``No, not to-morrow; the next day. That will be Sunday; she (Tristram) leaves Paris on Monday. If you don't see her (Tristram); it will at least be a beginning.'' (she)
And she (Tristram) gave him (Newman) Madame de Cintré's address.

He (Cintré) walked across the Seine, late in the summer afternoon, and made his (Cintré) way through those gray and silent streets of the Faubourg St. Germain whose houses present to the outer world a face as impassive and as suggestive of the concentration of privacy within as the blank walls of Eastern seraglios. Newman thought it a queer way for rich people to live; his (Newman) ideal of grandeur was a splendid façade diffusing its brilliancy outward too, irradiating hospitality. The house to which he (Newman) had been directed had a dark, dusty, painted portal, which swung open in answer to his (Newman) ring. It admitted him (Newman) into a wide, gravelled court, surrounded on three sides with closed windows, and with a doorway facing the street, approached by three steps and surmounted by a tin canopy. The place was all in the shade; it answered to Newman's conception of a convent. The portress could not tell him (Newman) whether Madame de Cintré was visible; he (Cintré) would please to apply at the farther door. He (Cintré) crossed the court; a gentleman was sitting, bareheaded, on the steps of the portico, playing with a beautiful pointer. He (Cintré) rose as Newman approached, and, as he (Newman) laid his (Newman) hand upon the bell, said with a smile, in English, that he (Newman) was afraid Newman would be kept waiting; the servants were scattered, he (Newman) himself had been ringing, he (Newman) didn't know what the deuce was in them. He (Newman) was a young man, his (Newman) English was excellent, and his (Newman) smile very frank. Newman pronounced the name of Madame de Cintré.

``I think,'' (the man)
said the young man,
``that my sister is visible. Come in, and if you will give me your card I will carry it to her (sister) myself.'' (the man)

Newman had been accompanied on his (Newman) present errand by a slight sentiment, I will not say of defiance--a readiness for aggression or defence, as they might prove needful--but of reflection, good-humored suspicion. He (Newman) took from his (Newman) pocket, while he (Newman) stood on the portico, a card upon which, under his (Newman) name, he (Newman) had written the words

``San Francisco,'' (he)
and while he (Newman) presented it he (Newman) looked warily at his (Newman) interlocutor. His (Newman) glance was singularly reassuring; he (Newman) liked the young man's face; it strongly resembled that of Madame de Cintré. He (Newman) was evidently her (Newman) brother. The young man, on his (man) side, had made a rapid inspection of Newman's person. He (Newman) had taken the card and was about to enter the house with it when another figure appeared on the threshold--an older man, of a fine presence, wearing evening dress. He (man) looked hard at Newman, and Newman looked at him (Newman).
``Madame de Cintré,'' (the man)
the younger man repeated, as an introduction of the visitor. The other took the card from his (Newman) hand, read it in a rapid glance, looked again at Newman from head to foot, hesitated a moment, and then said, gravely but urbanely,
``Madame de Cintré is not at home.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

The younger man made a gesture, and then, turning to Newman,

``I am very sorry, sir,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
he (Newman) said.

Newman gave him (Newman) a friendly nod, to show that he (Newman) bore him (Newman) no malice, and retraced his (Newman) steps. At the porter's lodge he (Newman) stopped; the two men were still standing on the portico.

``Who is the gentleman with the dog?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked of the old woman who reappeared. He (Newman) had begun to learn French.

``That is Monsieur le Comte.'' (unknown)

``And the other?'' (unknown)

``That is Monsieur le Marquis.'' (unknown)

``A marquis?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Christopher in English, which the old woman fortunately did not understand.
``Oh, then he (Marquis)'s not the butler!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

CHAPTER IV

Early one morning, before Christopher Newman was dressed, a little old man was ushered into his (Newman) apartment, followed by a youth in a blouse, bearing a picture in a brilliant frame. Newman, among the distractions of Paris, had forgotten M. Nioche and his (Newman) accomplished daughter; but this was an effective reminder.

``I am afraid you had given me up, sir,'' (the man)
said the old man, after many apologies and salutations.
``We have made you wait so many days. You accused us, perhaps, of inconstancy, of bad faith. But behold me at last! And behold also the pretty Madonna. Place it on a chair, my friend, in a good light, so that monsieur may admire it.'' (M. Nioche)
And M. Nioche, addressing his (man) companion, helped him (man) to dispose the work of art.

It had been endued with a layer of varnish an inch thick and its frame, of an elaborate pattern, was at least a foot wide. It glittered and twinkled in the morning light, and looked, to Newman's eyes, wonderfully splendid and precious. It seemed to him (Newman) a very happy purchase, and he (Newman) felt rich in the possession of it. He (Newman) stood looking at it complacently, while he (Newman) proceeded with his (Newman) toilet, and M. Nioche, who had dismissed his (Newman) own attendant, hovered near, smiling and rubbing his (Newman) hands.

``It has wonderful _finesse_,'' (he)
he (Newman) murmured, caressingly.
``And here and there are marvelous touches, you probably perceive them, sir. It attracted great attention on the Boulevard, as we came along. And then a gradation of tones! That's what it is to know how to paint. I don't say it because I am her (Madonna) father, sir; but as one man of taste addressing another I cannot help observing that you have there an exquisite work. It is hard to produce such things and to have to part with them. If our means only allowed us the luxury of keeping it! I really may say, sir--'' (M. Nioche)
and M. Nioche gave a little feebly insinuating laugh--
``I really may say that I envy you! You see,'' (M. Nioche)
he (Newman) added in a moment,
``we have taken the liberty of offering you a frame. It increases by a trifle the value of the work, and it will save you the annoyance--so great for a person of your delicacy--of going about to bargain at the shops.'' (he)

The language spoken by M. Nioche was a singular compound, which I shrink from the attempt to reproduce in its integrity. He (Newman) had apparently once possessed a certain knowledge of English, and his (Newman) accent was oddly tinged with the cockneyism of the British metropolis. But his (Newman) learning had grown rusty with disuse, and his (Newman) vocabulary was defective and capricious. He (Newman) had repaired it with large patches of French, with words anglicized by a process of his (Newman) own, and with native idioms literally translated. The result, in the form in which he (Newman) in all humility presented it, would be scarcely comprehensible to the reader, so that I have ventured to trim and sift it. Newman only half understood it, but it amused him (Newman), and the old man's decent forlornness appealed to his (Newman) democratic instincts. The assumption of a fatality in misery always irritated his (Newman) strong good nature--it was almost the only thing that did so; and he (Newman) felt the impulse to wipe it out, as it were, with the sponge of his (Newman) own prosperity. The papa of Mademoiselle Noémie, however, had apparently on this occasion been vigorously indoctrinated, and he (Newman) showed a certain tremulous eagerness to cultivate unexpected opportunities.

``How much do I owe you, then, with the frame?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``It will make in all three thousand francs,'' (the man)
said the old man, smiling agreeably, but folding his (man) hands in instinctive suppliance.

``Can you give me a receipt?'' (unknown)

``I have brought one,'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche.
``I took the liberty of drawing it up, in case monsieur should happen to desire to discharge his (you) debt.'' (he)
And he (man) drew a paper from his (man) pocket-book and presented it to his (man) patron. The document was written in a minute, fantastic hand, and couched in the choicest language.

Newman laid down the money, and M. Nioche dropped the napoleons one by one, solemnly and lovingly, into an old leathern purse.

``And how is your young lady?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.
``She (lady) made a great impression on me.'' (unknown)

``An impression? Monsieur is very good. Monsieur admires her (lady) appearance?'' (unknown)

``She (lady) is very pretty, certainly.'' (unknown)

``Alas, yes, she (lady) is very pretty!'' (unknown)

``And what is the harm in her (lady) being pretty?'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche fixed his (Newman) eyes upon a spot on the carpet and shook his (Newman) head. Then looking up at Newman with a gaze that seemed to brighten and expand,

``Monsieur knows what Paris is. She (lady) is dangerous to beauty, when beauty hasn't the sou.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Ah, but that is not the case with your daughter. She (daughter) is rich, now.'' (unknown)

``Very true; we are rich for six months. But if my daughter were a plain girl I should sleep better all the same.'' (unknown)

``You are afraid of the young men?'' (unknown)

``The young and the old!'' (unknown)

``She (daughter) ought to get a husband.'' (unknown)

``Ah, monsieur, one doesn't get a husband for nothing. Her (daughter) husband must take her (daughter) as she (daughter) is; I can't give her (daughter) a sou. But the young men don't see with that eye.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``her (daughter) talent is in itself a dowry.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Ah, sir, it needs first to be converted into specie!'' (M. Nioche)
and M. Nioche slapped his (Newman) purse tenderly before he (Newman) stowed it away.
``The operation doesn't take place every day.'' (unknown)

``Well, your young men are very shabby,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``that's all I can say. They ought to pay for your daughter, and not ask money themselves.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Those are very noble ideas, monsieur; but what will you have? They are not the ideas of this country. We want to know what we are about when we marry.'' (unknown)

``How big a portion does your daughter want?'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche stared, as if he (Newman) wondered what was coming next; but he (Newman) promptly recovered himself, at a venture, and replied that he (Newman) knew a very nice young man, employed by an insurance company, who would content himself with fifteen thousand francs.

``Let your daughter paint half a dozen pictures for me, and she (daughter) shall have her (daughter) dowry.'' (unknown)

``Half a dozen pictures--her (daughter) dowry! Monsieur is not speaking inconsiderately?'' (unknown)

``If she (daughter) will make me six or eight copies in the Louvre as pretty as that Madonna, I will pay her (Madonna) the same price,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

Poor M. Nioche was speechless a moment, with amazement and gratitude, and then he (Newman) seized Newman's hand, pressed it between his (Newman) own ten fingers, and gazed at him (Newman) with watery eyes.

``As pretty as that? They shall be a thousand times prettier--they shall be magnificent, sublime. Ah, if I only knew how to paint, myself, sir, so that I might lend a hand! What can I do to thank you? _Voyons!_'' (he)
And he (Newman) pressed his (Newman) forehead while he (Newman) tried to think of something.

``Oh, you have thanked me enough,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Ah, here it is, sir!'' (M. Nioche)
cried M. Nioche.
``To express my gratitude, I will charge you nothing for the lessons in French conversation.'' (unknown)

``The lessons? I had quite forgotten them. Listening to your English,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
added Newman, laughing,
``is almost a lesson in French.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Ah, I don't profess to teach English, certainly,'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche.
``But for my own admirable tongue I am still at your service.'' (unknown)

``Since you are here, then,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``we will begin. This is a very good hour. I am going to have my coffee; come every morning at half-past nine and have yours with me.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Monsieur offers me my coffee, also?'' (M. Nioche)
cried M. Nioche.
``Truly, my _beaux jours_ are coming back.'' (unknown)

``Come,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``let us begin. The coffee is almighty hot. How do you say that in French?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Every day, then, for the following three weeks, the minutely respectable figure of M. Nioche made its appearance, with a series of little inquiring and apologetic obeisances, among the aromatic fumes of Newman's morning beverage. I don't know how much French our friend learned, but, as he (friend) himself said, if the attempt did him (friend) no good, it could at any rate do him (friend) no harm. And it amused him (friend); it gratified that irregularly sociable side of his (friend) nature which had always expressed itself in a relish for ungrammatical conversation, and which often, even in his (friend) busy and preoccupied days, had made him (friend) sit on rail fences in young Western towns, in the twilight, in gossip hardly less than fraternal with humorous loafers and obscure fortune-seekers. He (friend) had notions, wherever he (friend) went, about talking with the natives; he (friend) had been assured, and his (friend) judgment approved the advice, that in traveling abroad it was an excellent thing to look into the life of the country. M. Nioche was very much of a native and, though his (friend) life might not be particularly worth looking into, he (friend) was a palpable and smoothly-rounded unit in that picturesque Parisian civilization which offered our hero so much easy entertainment and propounded so many curious problems to his (hero) inquiring and practical mind. Newman was fond of statistics; he (Newman) liked to know how things were done; it gratified him (Newman) to learn what taxes were paid, what profits were gathered, what commercial habits prevailed, how the battle of life was fought. M. Nioche, as a reduced capitalist, was familiar with these considerations, and he (capitalist) formulated his (capitalist) information, which he (capitalist) was proud to be able to impart, in the neatest possible terms and with a pinch of snuff between finger and thumb. As a Frenchman--quite apart from Newman's napoleons--M. Nioche loved conversation, and even in his (Newman) decay his (Newman) urbanity had not grown rusty. As a Frenchman, too, he (Newman) could give a clear account of things, and--still as a Frenchman--when his (Frenchman) knowledge was at fault he (Frenchman) could supply its lapses with the most convenient and ingenious hypotheses. The little shrunken financier was intensely delighted to have questions asked him (financier), and he (financier) scraped together information, by frugal processes, and took notes, in his (financier) little greasy pocket-book, of incidents which might interest his (financier) munificent friend. He (financier) read old almanacs at the book-stalls on the quays, and he (financier) began to frequent another _café_, where more newspapers were taken and his (financier) postprandial _demitasse_ cost him (financier) a penny extra, and where he (financier) used to con the tattered sheets for curious anecdotes, freaks of nature, and strange coincidences. He (financier) would relate with solemnity the next morning that a child of five years of age had lately died at Bordeaux, whose brain had been found to weigh sixty ounces--the brain of a Napoleon or a Washington! or that Madame P--, _charcutière_ in the Rue de Clichy, had found in the wadding of an old petticoat the sum of three hundred and sixty francs, which she (financier) had lost five years before. He (Napoleon) pronounced his (Napoleon) words with great distinctness and sonority, and Newman assured him (Newman) that his (Newman) way of dealing with the French tongue was very superior to the bewildering chatter that he (Newman) heard in other mouths. Upon this M. Nioche's accent became more finely trenchant than ever, he (Newman) offered to read extracts from Lamartine, and he (Newman) protested that, although he (Newman) did endeavor according to his (Newman) feeble lights to cultivate refinement of diction, monsieur, if he (Newman) wanted the real thing, should go to the Théâtre Français.

Newman took an interest in French thriftiness and conceived a lively admiration for Parisian economies. His (Newman) own economic genius was so entirely for operations on a larger scale, and, to move at his (Newman) ease, he (Newman) needed so imperatively the sense of great risks and great prizes, that he (Newman) found an ungrudging entertainment in the spectacle of fortunes made by the aggregation of copper coins, and in the minute subdivision of labor and profit. He (Newman) questioned M. Nioche about his (Newman) own manner of life, and felt a friendly mixture of compassion and respect over the recital of his (Newman) delicate frugalities. The worthy man told him (Newman) how, at one period, he (Newman) and his (Newman) daughter had supported existence comfortably upon the sum of fifteen sous _per diem_; recently, having succeeded in hauling ashore the last floating fragments of the wreck of his (Newman) fortune, his (Newman) budget had been a trifle more ample. But they still had to count their sous very narrowly, and M. Nioche intimated with a sigh that Mademoiselle Noémie did not bring to this task that zealous cooperation which might have been desired.

``But what will you have?''' he (your) asked, philosophically.

``One is young, one is pretty, one needs new dresses and fresh gloves; one can't wear shabby gowns among the splendors of the Louvre.'' (unknown)

``But your daughter earns enough to pay for her (daughter) own clothes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

M. Nioche looked at him (Newman) with weak, uncertain eyes. He (Newman) would have liked to be able to say that his (Newman) daughter's talents were appreciated, and that her (daughter) crooked little daubs commanded a market; but it seemed a scandal to abuse the credulity of this free-handed stranger, who, without a suspicion or a question, had admitted him (stranger) to equal social rights. He (stranger) compromised, and declared that while it was obvious that Mademoiselle Noémie's reproductions of the old masters had only to be seen to be coveted, the prices which, in consideration of their altogether peculiar degree of finish, she (daughter) felt obliged to ask for them had kept purchasers at a respectful distance.

``Poor little one!'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche, with a sigh;
``it is almost a pity that her (daughter) work is so perfect! It would be in her (daughter) interest to paint less well.'' (M. Nioche)

``But if Mademoiselle Noémie has this devotion to her (daughter) art,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman once observed,
``why should you have those fears for her (daughter) that you spoke of the other day?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

M. Nioche meditated: there was an inconsistency in his (Newman) position; it made him (Newman) chronically uncomfortable. Though he (Newman) had no desire to destroy the goose with the golden eggs--Newman's benevolent confidence--he (Newman) felt a tremulous impulse to speak out all his (Newman) trouble.

``Ah, she (daughter) is an artist, my dear sir, most assuredly,'' (he)
he (Newman) declared.
``But, to tell you the truth, she (daughter) is also a _franche coquette_. I am sorry to say,'' (he)
he (Newman) added in a moment, shaking his (Newman) head with a world of harmless bitterness,
``that she (daughter) comes honestly by it. Her (daughter) mother was one before her (daughter)!'' (he)

``You were not happy with your wife?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

M. Nioche gave half a dozen little backward jerks of his (Newman) head.

``She (daughter) was my purgatory, monsieur!'' (unknown)

``She (daughter) deceived you?'' (unknown)

``Under my nose, year after year. I was too stupid, and the temptation was too great. But I found her (daughter) out at last. I have only been once in my life a man to be afraid of; I know it very well; it was in that hour! Nevertheless I don't like to think of it. I loved her (daughter)--I can't tell you how much. She (daughter) was a bad woman.'' (unknown)

``She (daughter) is not living?'' (unknown)

``She (daughter) has gone to her (daughter) account.'' (unknown)

``Her (daughter) influence on your daughter, then,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman encouragingly,
``is not to be feared.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``She (daughter) cared no more for her (daughter) daughter than for the sole of her (daughter) shoe! But Noémie has no need of influence. She (daughter) is sufficient to herself. She (daughter) is stronger than I.'' (unknown)

``She (daughter) doesn't obey you, eh?'' (unknown)

``She (daughter) can't obey, monsieur, since I don't command. What would be the use? It would only irritate her (daughter) and drive her (daughter) to some _coup de tête_. She (daughter) is very clever, like her (daughter) mother; she (daughter) would waste no time about it. As a child--when I was happy, or supposed I was--she (daughter) studied drawing and painting with first-class professors, and they assured me she (daughter) had a talent. I was delighted to believe it, and when I went into society I used to carry her (daughter) pictures with me in a portfolio and hand them round to the company. I remember, once, a lady thought I was offering them for sale, and I took it very ill. We don't know what we may come to! Then came my dark days, and my explosion with Madame Nioche. Noémie had no more twenty-franc lessons; but in the course of time, when she (lady) grew older, and it became highly expedient that she (lady) should do something that would help to keep us alive, she (lady) bethought herself of her (lady) palette and brushes. Some of our friends in the _quartier_ pronounced the idea fantastic: they recommended her (lady) to try bonnet making, to get a situation in a shop, or--if she (lady) was more ambitious--to advertise for a place of _dame de compagnie_. She (lady) did advertise, and an old lady wrote her (lady) a letter and bade her (lady) come and see her (lady). The old lady liked her (lady), and offered her (lady) her (lady) living and six hundred francs a year; but Noémie discovered that she (lady) passed her (lady) life in her (lady) armchair and had only two visitors, her (lady) confessor and her (lady) nephew: the confessor very strict, and the nephew a man of fifty, with a broken nose and a government clerkship of two thousand francs. She (lady) threw her (lady) old lady over, bought a paint-box, a canvas, and a new dress, and went and set up her (lady) easel in the Louvre. There in one place and another, she (lady) has passed the last two years; I can't say it has made us millionaires. But Noémie tells me that Rome was not built in a day, that she (lady) is making great progress, that I must leave her (lady) to her (lady) own devices. The fact is, without prejudice to her (lady) genius, that she (lady) has no idea of burying herself alive. She (lady) likes to see the world, and to be seen. She (lady) says, herself, that she (lady) can't work in the dark. With her (lady) appearance it is very natural. Only, I can't help worrying and trembling and wondering what may happen to her (lady) there all alone, day after day, amid all that coming and going of strangers. I can't be always at her (lady) side. I go with her (lady) in the morning, and I come to fetch her (lady) away, but she (lady) won't have me near her (lady) in the interval; she (lady) says I make her (lady) nervous. As if it didn't make me nervous to wander about all day without her (lady)! Ah, if anything were to happen to her (lady)!'' (M. Nioche)
cried M. Nioche, clenching his (Newman) two fists and jerking back his (Newman) head again, portentously.

``Oh, I guess nothing will happen,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I believe I should shoot her (lady)!'' (the man)
said the old man, solemnly.

``Oh, we'll marry her (lady),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``since that's how you manage it; and I will go and see her (lady) tomorrow at the Louvre and pick out the pictures she (lady) is to copy for me.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

M. Nioche had brought Newman a message from his (Newman) daughter, in acceptance of his (Newman) magnificent commission, the young lady declaring herself his (Newman) most devoted servant, promising her (lady) most zealous endeavor, and regretting that the proprieties forbade her (lady) coming to thank him (Newman) in person. The morning after the conversation just narrated, Newman reverted to his (Newman) intention of meeting Mademoiselle Noémie at the Louvre. M. Nioche appeared preoccupied, and left his (Newman) budget of anecdotes unopened; he (Newman) took a great deal of snuff, and sent certain oblique, appealing glances toward his (Newman) stalwart pupil. At last, when he (Newman) was taking his (Newman) leave, he (Newman) stood a moment, after he (Newman) had polished his (Newman) hat with his (Newman) calico pocket-handkerchief, with his (Newman) small, pale eyes fixed strangely upon Newman.

``What's the matter?'' (hero)
our hero demanded.

``Excuse the solicitude of a father's heart!'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche.
``You inspire me with boundless confidence, but I can't help giving you a warning. After all, you are a man, you are young and at liberty. Let me beseech you, then, to respect the innocence of Mademoiselle Nioche!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman had wondered what was coming, and at this he (Newman) broke into a laugh. He (Newman) was on the point of declaring that his (Newman) own innocence struck him (Newman) as the more exposed, but he (Newman) contented himself with promising to treat the young girl with nothing less than veneration. He (Newman) found her (girl) waiting for him (Newman), seated upon the great divan in the Salon Carré. She (girl) was not in her (girl) working-day costume, but wore her (girl) bonnet and gloves and carried her (girl) parasol, in honor of the occasion. These articles had been selected with unerring taste, and a fresher, prettier image of youthful alertness and blooming discretion was not to be conceived. She (girl) made Newman a most respectful curtsey and expressed her (girl) gratitude for his (Newman) liberality in a wonderfully graceful little speech. It annoyed him (Newman) to have a charming young girl stand there thanking him (Newman), and it made him (Newman) feel uncomfortable to think that this perfect young lady, with her (lady) excellent manners and her (lady) finished intonation, was literally in his (Newman) pay. He (Newman) assured her (lady), in such French as he (Newman) could muster, that the thing was not worth mentioning, and that he (Newman) considered her (lady) services a great favor.

``Whenever you please, then,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie,
``we will pass the review.'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)

They walked slowly round the room, then passed into the others and strolled about for half an hour. Mademoiselle Noémie evidently relished her (lady) situation, and had no desire to bring her (lady) public interview with her (lady) striking-looking patron to a close. Newman perceived that prosperity agreed with her (lady). The little thin-lipped, peremptory air with which she (lady) had addressed her (lady) father on the occasion of their former meeting had given place to the most lingering and caressing tones.

``What sort of pictures do you desire?'' (she)
she (lady) asked.
``Sacred, or profane?'' (unknown)

``Oh, a few of each,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But I want something bright and gay.'' (unknown)

``Something gay? There is nothing very gay in this solemn old Louvre. But we will see what we can find. You speak French to-day like a charm. My father has done wonders.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I am a bad subject,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I am too old to learn a language.'' (unknown)

``Too old? _Quelle folie!_'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
cried Mademoiselle Noémie, with a clear, shrill laugh.
``You are a very young man. And how do you like my father?'' (unknown)

``He (father) is a very nice old gentleman. He (father) never laughs at my blunders.'' (unknown)

``He (father) is very _comme il faut_, my papa,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie,
``and as honest as the day. Oh, an exceptional probity! You could trust him (papa) with millions.'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)

``Do you always obey him (papa)?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``Obey him (papa)?'' (unknown)

``Do you do what he (papa) bids you?'' (The girl)

The young girl stopped and looked at him (Newman); she (girl) had a spot of color in either cheek, and in her (girl) expressive French eye, which projected too much for perfect beauty, there was a slight gleam of audacity.

``Why do you ask me that?'' (she)
she (girl) demanded.

``Because I want to know.'' (unknown)

``You think me a bad girl?'' (she)
And she (girl) gave a strange smile.

Newman looked at her (girl) a moment; he (Newman) saw that she (girl) was pretty, but he (Newman) was not in the least dazzled. He (Newman) remembered poor M. Nioche's solicitude for her (girl)

``innocence,'' (M. Nioche)
and he (Newman) laughed as his (Newman) eyes met hers. Her (girl) face was the oddest mixture of youth and maturity, and beneath her (girl) candid brow her (girl) searching little smile seemed to contain a world of ambiguous intentions. She (girl) was pretty enough, certainly to make her (girl) father nervous; but, as regards her (girl) innocence, Newman felt ready on the spot to affirm that she (girl) had never parted with it. She (girl) had simply never had any; she (girl) had been looking at the world since she (girl) was ten years old, and he (Newman) would have been a wise man who could tell her (girl) any secrets. In her (girl) long mornings at the Louvre she (girl) had not only studied Madonnas and St. Johns; she (girl) had kept an eye upon all the variously embodied human nature around her (girl), and she (girl) had formed her (girl) conclusions. In a certain sense, it seemed to Newman, M. Nioche might be at rest; his (Newman) daughter might do something very audacious, but she (daughter) would never do anything foolish. Newman, with his (Newman) long-drawn, leisurely smile, and his (Newman) even, unhurried utterance, was always, mentally, taking his (Newman) time; and he (Newman) asked himself, now, what she (daughter) was looking at him (Newman) in that way for. He (Newman) had an idea that she (daughter) would like him (Newman) to confess that he (Newman) did think her (daughter) a bad girl.

``Oh, no,'' (he)
he (Newman) said at last;
``it would be very bad manners in me to judge you that way. I don't know you.'' (he)

``But my father has complained to you,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.

``He (father) says you are a coquette.'' (unknown)

``He (father) shouldn't go about saying such things to gentlemen! But you don't believe it?'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman gravely,
``I don't believe it.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

She (daughter) looked at him (Newman) again, gave a shrug and a smile, and then pointed to a small Italian picture, a Marriage of St. Catherine.

``How should you like that?'' (she)
she (Catherine) asked.

``It doesn't please me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``The young lady in the yellow dress is not pretty.'' (unknown)

``Ah, you are a great connoisseur,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
murmured Mademoiselle Noémie.

``In pictures? Oh, no; I know very little about them.'' (unknown)

``In pretty women, then.'' (unknown)

``In that I am hardly better.'' (unknown)

``What do you say to that, then?'' (the girl)
the young girl asked, indicating a superb Italian portrait of a lady.
``I will do it for you on a smaller scale.'' (unknown)

``On a smaller scale? Why not as large as the original?'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)

Mademoiselle Noémie glanced at the glowing splendor of the Venetian masterpiece and gave a little toss of her (lady) head.

``I don't like that woman. She (woman) looks stupid.'' (unknown)

``I do like her (woman),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Decidedly, I must have her (woman), as large as life. And just as stupid as she (woman) is there.'' (The girl)

The young girl fixed her (girl) eyes on him (Newman) again, and with her (girl) mocking smile,

``It certainly ought to be easy for me to make her (woman) look stupid!'' (him)
she (girl) said.

``What do you mean?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman, puzzled.

She (girl) gave another little shrug.

``Seriously, then, you want that portrait--the golden hair, the purple satin, the pearl necklace, the two magnificent arms?'' (unknown)

``Everything--just as it is.'' (unknown)

``Would nothing else do, instead?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I want some other things, but I want that too.'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)

Mademoiselle Noémie turned away a moment, walked to the other side of the hall, and stood there, looking vaguely about her (girl). At last she (girl) came back.

``It must be charming to be able to order pictures at such a rate. Venetian portraits, as large as life! You go at it _en prince_. And you are going to travel about Europe that way?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I intend to travel,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Ordering, buying, spending money?'' (unknown)

``Of course I shall spend some money.'' (unknown)

``You are very happy to have it. And you are perfectly free?'' (unknown)

``How do you mean, free?'' (unknown)

``You have nothing to bother you--no family, no wife, no _fiancée?_'' (unknown)

``Yes, I am tolerably free.'' (unknown)

``You are very happy,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie, gravely.

``_Je le veux bien!_'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, proving that he (Newman) had learned more French than he (Newman) admitted.

``And how long shall you stay in Paris?'' (the girl)
the young girl went on.

``Only a few days more.'' (unknown)

``Why do you go away?'' (unknown)

``It is getting hot, and I must go to Switzerland.'' (unknown)

``To Switzerland? That's a fine country. I would give my new parasol to see it! Lakes and mountains, romantic valleys and icy peaks! Oh, I congratulate you. Meanwhile, I shall sit here through all the hot summer, daubing at your pictures.'' (unknown)

``Oh, take your time about it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Do them at your convenience.'' (a dozen)

They walked farther and looked at a dozen other things. Newman pointed out what pleased him (Newman), and Mademoiselle Noémie generally criticised it, and proposed something else. Then suddenly she (girl) diverged and began to talk about some personal matter.

``What made you speak to me the other day in the Salon Carré?'' (she)
she (girl) abruptly asked.

``I admired your picture.'' (unknown)

``But you hesitated a long time.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I do nothing rashly,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Yes, I saw you watching me. But I never supposed you were going to speak to me. I never dreamed I should be walking about here with you to-day. It's very curious.'' (unknown)

``It is very natural,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
observed Newman.

``Oh, I beg your pardon; not to me. Coquette as you think me, I have never walked about in public with a gentleman before. What was my father thinking of, when he (father) consented to our interview?'' (unknown)

``He (father) was repenting of his (father) unjust accusations,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
replied Newman.

Mademoiselle Noémie remained silent; at last she (girl) dropped into a seat.

``Well then, for those five it is fixed,'' (she)
she (girl) said.
``Five copies as brilliant and beautiful as I can make them. We have one more to choose. Shouldn't you like one of those great Rubenses--the marriage of Marie de Médicis? Just look at it and see how handsome it is.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes; I should like that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Finish off with that.'' (unknown)

``Finish off with that--good!'' (she)
And she (girl) laughed. She (girl) sat a moment, looking at him (Newman), and then she (girl) suddenly rose and stood before him (Newman), with her (girl) hands hanging and clasped in front of her (girl).
``I don't understand you,'' (she)
she (girl) said with a smile.
``I don't understand how a man can be so ignorant.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I am ignorant, certainly,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, putting his (Newman) hands into his (Newman) pockets.

``It's ridiculous! I don't know how to paint.'' (unknown)

``You don't know how?'' (unknown)

``I paint like a cat; I can't draw a straight line. I never sold a picture until you bought that thing the other day.'' (she)
And as she (girl) offered this surprising information she (girl) continued to smile.

Newman burst into a laugh.

``Why do you tell me this?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.

``Because it irritates me to see a clever man blunder so. My pictures are grotesque.'' (unknown)

``And the one I possess--'' (unknown)

``That one is rather worse than usual.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I like it all the same!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

She (girl) looked at him (Newman) askance.

``That is a very pretty thing to say,'' (she)
she (girl) answered;
``but it is my duty to warn you before you go farther. This order of yours is impossible, you know. What do you take me for? It is work for ten men. You pick out the six most difficult pictures in the Louvre, and you expect me to go to work as if I were sitting down to hem a dozen pocket handkerchiefs. I wanted to see how far you would go.'' (she)

Newman looked at the young girl in some perplexity. In spite of the ridiculous blunder of which he (Newman) stood convicted, he (Newman) was very far from being a simpleton, and he (Newman) had a lively suspicion that Mademoiselle Noémie's sudden frankness was not essentially more honest than her (girl) leaving him (Newman) in error would have been. She (girl) was playing a game; she (girl) was not simply taking pity on his (Newman) æsthetic verdancy. What was it she (girl) expected to win? The stakes were high and the risk was great; the prize therefore must have been commensurate. But even granting that the prize might be great, Newman could not resist a movement of admiration for his (Newman) companion's intrepidity. She (girl) was throwing away with one hand, whatever she (girl) might intend to do with the other, a very handsome sum of money.

``Are you joking,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``or are you serious?'' (he)

``Oh, serious!'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
cried Mademoiselle Noémie, but with her (girl) extraordinary smile.

``I know very little about pictures or how they are painted. If you can't do all that, of course you can't. Do what you can, then.'' (unknown)

``It will be very bad,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.

``Oh,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing,
``if you are determined it shall be bad, of course it will. But why do you go on painting badly?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I can do nothing else; I have no real talent.'' (unknown)

``You are deceiving your father, then.'' (The girl)

The young girl hesitated a moment.

``He (father) knows very well!'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman declared;
``I am sure he (father) believes in you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``He (father) is afraid of me. I go on painting badly, as you say, because I want to learn. I like it, at any rate. And I like being here; it is a place to come to, every day; it is better than sitting in a little dark, damp room, on a court, or selling buttons and whalebones over a counter.'' (unknown)

``Of course it is much more amusing,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But for a poor girl isn't it rather an expensive amusement?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I am very wrong, there is no doubt about that,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.
``But rather than earn my living as some girls do--toiling with a needle, in little black holes, out of the world--I would throw myself into the Seine.'' (unknown)

``There is no need of that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered;
``your father told you my offer?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Your offer?'' (unknown)

``He (father) wants you to marry, and I told him (father) I would give you a chance to earn your _dot_.'' (unknown)

``He (father) told me all about it, and you see the account I make of it! Why should you take such an interest in my marriage?'' (unknown)

``My interest was in your father. I hold to my offer; do what you can, and I will buy what you paint.'' (She)

She (girl) stood for some time, meditating, with her (girl) eyes on the ground. At last, looking up,

``What sort of a husband can you get for twelve thousand francs?'' (she)
she (girl) asked.

``Your father tells me he (father) knows some very good young men.'' (unknown)

``Grocers and butchers and little _maîtres de cafés!_ I will not marry at all if I can't marry well.'' (unknown)

``I would advise you not to be too fastidious,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``That's all the advice I can give you.'' (unknown)

``I am very much vexed at what I have said!'' (the girl)
cried the young girl.
``It has done me no good. But I couldn't help it.'' (unknown)

``What good did you expect it to do you?'' (unknown)

``I couldn't help it, simply.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman looked at her (girl) a moment.

``Well, your pictures may be bad,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``but you are too clever for me, nevertheless. I don't understand you. Good-bye!'' (he)
And he (Newman) put out his (Newman) hand.

She (girl) made no response, and offered him (Newman) no farewell. She (girl) turned away and seated herself sidewise on a bench, leaning her (girl) head on the back of her (girl) hand, which clasped the rail in front of the pictures. Newman stood a moment and then turned on his (Newman) heel and retreated. He (Newman) had understood her (girl) better than he (Newman) confessed; this singular scene was a practical commentary upon her (girl) father's statement that she (girl) was a frank coquette.

CHAPTER V

When Newman related to Mrs. Tristram his (Newman) fruitless visit to Madame de Cintré, she (Tristram) urged him (Newman) not to be discouraged, but to carry out his (Newman) plan of

``seeing Europe'' (him)
during the summer, and return to Paris in the autumn and settle down comfortably for the winter.
``Madame de Cintré will keep,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said;
``she (It) is not a woman who will marry from one day to another.'' (she)
Newman made no distinct affirmation that he (Newman) would come back to Paris; he (Newman) even talked about Rome and the Nile, and abstained from professing any especial interest in Madame de Cintré's continued widowhood. This circumstance was at variance with his (Newman) habitual frankness, and may perhaps be regarded as characteristic of the incipient stage of that passion which is more particularly known as the mysterious one. The truth is that the expression of a pair of eyes that were at once brilliant and mild had become very familiar to his (Newman) memory, and he (Newman) would not easily have resigned himself to the prospect of never looking into them again. He (Newman) communicated to Mrs. Tristram a number of other facts, of greater or less importance, as you choose; but on this particular point he (Newman) kept his (Newman) own counsel. He (Newman) took a kindly leave of M. Nioche, having assured him (Newman) that, so far as he (Newman) was concerned, the blue-cloaked Madonna herself might have been present at his (Newman) interview with Mademoiselle Noémie; and left the old man nursing his (Newman) breast-pocket, in an ecstasy which the acutest misfortune might have been defied to dissipate. Newman then started on his (Newman) travels, with all his (Newman) usual appearance of slow-strolling leisure, and all his (Newman) essential directness and intensity of aim. No man seemed less in a hurry, and yet no man achieved more in brief periods. He (man) had certain practical instincts which served him (man) excellently in his (man) trade of tourist. He (man) found his (man) way in foreign cities by divination, his (man) memory was excellent when once his (man) attention had been at all cordially given, and he (man) emerged from dialogues in foreign tongues, of which he (man) had, formally, not understood a word, in full possession of the particular fact he (man) had desired to ascertain. His (man) appetite for facts was capacious, and although many of those which he (man) noted would have seemed woefully dry and colorless to the ordinary sentimental traveler, a careful inspection of the list would have shown that he (traveler) had a soft spot in his (traveler) imagination. In the charming city of Brussels--his (traveler) first stopping-place after leaving Paris--he (traveler) asked a great many questions about the street-cars, and took extreme satisfaction in the reappearance of this familiar symbol of American civilization; but he (traveler) was also greatly struck with the beautiful Gothic tower of the Hôtel de Ville, and wondered whether it would not be possible to
``get up'' (he)
something like it in San Francisco. He (Francisco) stood for half an hour in the crowded square before this edifice, in imminent danger from carriage-wheels, listening to a toothless old cicerone mumble in broken English the touching history of Counts Egmont and Horn; and he (Horn) wrote the names of these gentlemen--for reasons best known to himself--on the back of an old letter.

At the outset, on his (Horn) leaving Paris, his (Horn) curiosity had not been intense; passive entertainment, in the Champs Élysées and at the theatres, seemed about as much as he (Horn) need expect of himself, and although, as he (Horn) had said to Tristram, he (Horn) wanted to see the mysterious, satisfying _best_, he (Horn) had not the Grand Tour in the least on his (Horn) conscience, and was not given to cross-questioning the amusement of the hour. He (Horn) believed that Europe was made for him (Horn), and not he (Horn) for Europe. He (Horn) had said that he (Horn) wanted to improve his (Horn) mind, but he (Horn) would have felt a certain embarrassment, a certain shame, even--a false shame, possibly--if he (Horn) had caught himself looking intellectually into the mirror. Neither in this nor in any other respect had Newman a high sense of responsibility; it was his (Newman) prime conviction that a man's life should be easy, and that he (Newman) should be able to resolve privilege into a matter of course. The world, to his (Newman) sense, was a great bazaar, where one might stroll about and purchase handsome things; but he (Newman) was no more conscious, individually, of social pressure than he (Newman) admitted the existence of such a thing as an obligatory purchase. He (Newman) had not only a dislike, but a sort of moral mistrust, of uncomfortable thoughts, and it was both uncomfortable and slightly contemptible to feel obliged to square one's self with a standard. One's standard was the ideal of one's own good-humored prosperity, the prosperity which enabled one to give as well as take. To expand, without bothering about it--without shiftless timidity on one side, or loquacious eagerness on the other--to the full compass of what he (Newman) would have called a

``pleasant'' (he)
experience, was Newman's most definite programme of life. He (Newman) had always hated to hurry to catch railroad trains, and yet he (Newman) had always caught them; and just so an undue solicitude for
``culture'' (he)
seemed a sort of silly dawdling at the station, a proceeding properly confined to women, foreigners, and other unpractical persons. All this admitted, Newman enjoyed his (Newman) journey, when once he (Newman) had fairly entered the current, as profoundly as the most zealous _dilettante_. One's theories, after all, matter little; it is one's humor that is the great thing. Our friend was intelligent, and he (friend) could not help that. He (friend) lounged through Belgium and Holland and the Rhineland, through Switzerland and Northern Italy, planning about nothing, but seeing everything. The guides and _valets de place_ found him (friend) an excellent subject. He (friend) was always approachable, for he (friend) was much addicted to standing about in the vestibules and porticos of inns, and he (friend) availed himself little of the opportunities for impressive seclusion which are so liberally offered in Europe to gentlemen who travel with long purses. When an excursion, a church, a gallery, a ruin, was proposed to him (friend), the first thing Newman usually did, after surveying his (Newman) postulant in silence, from head to foot, was to sit down at a little table and order something to drink. The cicerone, during this process, usually retreated to a respectful distance; otherwise I am not sure that Newman would not have bidden him (Newman) sit down and have a glass also, and tell him (Newman) as an honest fellow whether his (Newman) church or his (Newman) gallery was really worth a man's trouble. At last he (Newman) rose and stretched his (Newman) long legs, beckoned to the man of monuments, looked at his (Newman) watch, and fixed his (Newman) eye on his (Newman) adversary.
``What is it?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.
``How far?'' (he)
And whatever the answer was, although he (Newman) sometimes seemed to hesitate, he (Newman) never declined. He (Newman) stepped into an open cab, made his (Newman) conductor sit beside him (Newman) to answer questions, bade the driver go fast -LRB-he (driver) had a particular aversion to slow driving-RRB- and rolled, in all probability through a dusty suburb, to the goal of his (driver) pilgrimage. If the goal was a disappointment, if the church was meagre, or the ruin a heap of rubbish, Newman never protested or berated his (Newman) cicerone; he (Newman) looked with an impartial eye upon great monuments and small, made the guide recite his (Newman) lesson, listened to it religiously, asked if there was nothing else to be seen in the neighborhood, and drove back again at a rattling pace. It is to be feared that his (Newman) perception of the difference between good architecture and bad was not acute, and that he (Newman) might sometimes have been seen gazing with culpable serenity at inferior productions. Ugly churches were a part of his (Newman) pastime in Europe, as well as beautiful ones, and his (Newman) tour was altogether a pastime. But there is sometimes nothing like the imagination of these people who have none, and Newman, now and then, in an unguided stroll in a foreign city, before some lonely, sad-towered church, or some angular image of one who had rendered civic service in an unknown past, had felt a singular inward tremor. It was not an excitement or a perplexity; it was a placid, fathomless sense of diversion.

He (Newman) encountered by chance in Holland a young American, with whom, for a time, he (Newman) formed a sort of traveler's partnership. They were men of a very different cast, but each, in his (Newman) way, was so good a fellow that, for a few weeks at least, it seemed something of a pleasure to share the chances of the road. Newman's comrade, whose name was Babcock, was a young Unitarian minister, a small, spare, neatly-attired man, with a strikingly candid physiognomy. He (man) was a native of Dorchester, Massachusetts, and had spiritual charge of a small congregation in another suburb of the New England metropolis. His (man) digestion was weak and he (man) lived chiefly on Graham bread and hominy--a regimen to which he (man) was so much attached that his (man) tour seemed to him (man) destined to be blighted when, on landing on the Continent, he (man) found that these delicacies did not flourish under the _table d’hôte_ system. In Paris he (man) had purchased a bag of hominy at an establishment which called itself an American Agency, and at which the New York illustrated papers were also to be procured, and he (man) had carried it about with him (man), and shown extreme serenity and fortitude in the somewhat delicate position of having his (man) hominy prepared for him (man) and served at anomalous hours, at the hotels he (man) successively visited. Newman had once spent a morning, in the course of business, at Mr. Babcock's birthplace, and, for reasons too recondite to unfold, his (Babcock) visit there always assumed in his (Babcock) mind a jocular cast. To carry out his (Babcock) joke, which certainly seems poor so long as it is not explained, he (Babcock) used often to address his (Babcock) companion as

``Dorchester.'' (companion)
Fellow-travelers very soon grow intimate but it is highly improbable that at home these extremely dissimilar characters would have found any very convenient points of contact. They were, indeed, as different as possible. Newman, who never reflected on such matters, accepted the situation with great equanimity, but Babcock used to meditate over it privately; used often, indeed, to retire to his (Babcock) room early in the evening for the express purpose of considering it conscientiously and impartially. He (Babcock) was not sure that it was a good thing for him (Babcock) to associate with our hero, whose way of taking life was so little his (Babcock) own. Newman was an excellent, generous fellow; Mr. Babcock sometimes said to himself that he (Babcock) was a _noble_ fellow, and, certainly, it was impossible not to like him (Babcock). But would it not be desirable to try to exert an influence upon him (Babcock), to try to quicken his (Babcock) moral life and sharpen his (Babcock) sense of duty? He (Babcock) liked everything, he (Babcock) accepted everything, he (Babcock) found amusement in everything; he (Babcock) was not discriminating, he (Babcock) had not a high tone. The young man from Dorchester accused Newman of a fault which he (Newman) considered very grave, and which he (Newman) did his (Newman) best to avoid: what he (Newman) would have called a want of
``moral reaction.'' (he)
Poor Mr. Babcock was extremely fond of pictures and churches, and carried Mrs. Jameson's works about in his (Babcock) trunk; he (Babcock) delighted in æsthetic analysis, and received peculiar impressions from everything he (Babcock) saw. But nevertheless in his (Babcock) secret soul he (Babcock) detested Europe, and he (Babcock) felt an irritating need to protest against Newman's gross intellectual hospitality. Mr. Babcock's moral _malaise_, I am afraid, lay deeper than where any definition of mine can reach it. He (Babcock) mistrusted the European temperament, he (Babcock) suffered from the European climate, he (Babcock) hated the European dinner-hour; European life seemed to him (Babcock) unscrupulous and impure. And yet he (Babcock) had an exquisite sense of beauty; and as beauty was often inextricably associated with the above displeasing conditions, as he (Babcock) wished, above all, to be just and dispassionate, and as he (Babcock) was, furthermore, extremely devoted to
``culture,'' (he)
he (Babcock) could not bring himself to decide that Europe was utterly bad. But he (Babcock) thought it was very bad indeed, and his (Babcock) quarrel with Newman was that this unregulated epicure had a sadly insufficient perception of the bad. Babcock himself really knew as little about the bad, in any quarter of the world, as a nursing infant, his (Babcock) most vivid realization of evil had been the discovery that one of his (Babcock) college classmates, who was studying architecture in Paris had a love affair with a young woman who did not expect him (Babcock) to marry her (woman). Babcock had related this incident to Newman, and our hero had applied an epithet of an unflattering sort to the young girl. The next day his (Newman) companion asked him (Newman) whether he (Newman) was very sure he (Newman) had used exactly the right word to characterize the young architect's mistress. Newman stared and laughed.
``There are a great many words to express that idea,'' (he)
he (Newman) said;
``you can take your choice!'' (he)

``Oh, I mean,'' (Babcock/Mr. Babcock)
said Babcock,
``was she (It) possibly not to be considered in a different light? Don't you think she (It) _really_ expected him (I) to marry her (It)?'' (Babcock/Mr. Babcock)

``I am sure I don't know,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Very likely she (It) did; I have no doubt she (It) is a grand woman.'' (he)
And he (Newman) began to laugh again.

``I didn't mean that either,'' (Babcock/Mr. Babcock)
said Babcock,
``I was only afraid that I might have seemed yesterday not to remember--not to consider; well, I think I will write to Percival about it.'' (Babcock/Mr. Babcock)

And he (Babcock) had written to Percival -LRB-who answered him (Babcock) in a really impudent fashion-RRB-, and he (Babcock) had reflected that it was somehow, raw and reckless in Newman to assume in that off-hand manner that the young woman in Paris might be

``grand.'' (the woman)
The brevity of Newman's judgments very often shocked and discomposed him (Newman). He (Newman) had a way of damning people without farther appeal, or of pronouncing them capital company in the face of uncomfortable symptoms, which seemed unworthy of a man whose conscience had been properly cultivated. And yet poor Babcock liked him (Babcock), and remembered that even if he (Babcock) was sometimes perplexing and painful, this was not a reason for giving him (Babcock) up. Goethe recommended seeing human nature in the most various forms, and Mr. Babcock thought Goethe perfectly splendid. He (Babcock) often tried, in odd half-hours of conversation to infuse into Newman a little of his (Newman) own spiritual starch, but Newman's personal texture was too loose to admit of stiffening. His (Newman) mind could no more hold principles than a sieve can hold water. He (Newman) admired principles extremely, and thought Babcock a mighty fine little fellow for having so many. He (Babcock) accepted all that his (Babcock) high-strung companion offered him (Babcock), and put them away in what he (Babcock) supposed to be a very safe place; but poor Babcock never afterwards recognized his (Babcock) gifts among the articles that Newman had in daily use.

They traveled together through Germany and into Switzerland, where for three or four weeks they trudged over passes and lounged upon blue lakes. At last they crossed the Simplon and made their way to Venice. Mr. Babcock had become gloomy and even a trifle irritable; he (Babcock) seemed moody, absent, preoccupied; he (Babcock) got his (Babcock) plans into a tangle, and talked one moment of doing one thing and the next of doing another. Newman led his (Newman) usual life, made acquaintances, took his (Newman) ease in the galleries and churches, spent an unconscionable amount of time in strolling in the Piazza San Marco, bought a great many bad pictures, and for a fortnight enjoyed Venice grossly. One evening, coming back to his (Marco) inn, he (Marco) found Babcock waiting for him (Babcock) in the little garden beside it. The young man walked up to him (Babcock), looking very dismal, thrust out his (Babcock) hand, and said with solemnity that he (Babcock) was afraid they must part. Newman expressed his (Newman) surprise and regret, and asked why a parting had become necessary.

``Don't be afraid I'm tired of you,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

``You are not tired of me?'' (Babcock/Mr. Babcock)
demanded Babcock, fixing him (Babcock) with his (Babcock) clear gray eye.

``Why the deuce should I be? You are a very plucky fellow. Besides, I don't grow tired of things.'' (unknown)

``We don't understand each other,'' (the minister)
said the young minister.
