``Don't I understand you?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``Why, I hoped I did. But what if I don't; where's the harm?'' (unknown)

``I don't understand _you_,'' (Babcock/Mr. Babcock)
said Babcock. And he (Babcock) sat down and rested his (Babcock) head on his (Babcock) hand, and looked up mournfully at his (Babcock) immeasurable friend.

``Oh Lord, I don't mind that!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman, with a laugh.

``But it's very distressing to me. It keeps me in a state of unrest. It irritates me; I can't settle anything. I don't think it's good for me.'' (unknown)

``You worry too much; that's what's the matter with you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Of course it must seem so to you. You think I take things too hard, and I think you take things too easily. We can never agree.'' (unknown)

``But we have agreed very well all along.'' (unknown)

``No, I haven't agreed,'' (Babcock/Mr. Babcock)
said Babcock, shaking his (Babcock) head.
``I am very uncomfortable. I ought to have separated from you a month ago.'' (unknown)

``Oh, horrors! I'll agree to anything!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.

Mr. Babcock buried his (Babcock) head in both hands. At last looking up,

``I don't think you appreciate my position,'' (he)
he (Babcock) said.
``I try to arrive at the truth about everything. And then you go too fast. For me, you are too passionate, too extravagant. I feel as if I ought to go over all this ground we have traversed again, by myself, alone. I am afraid I have made a great many mistakes.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you needn't give so many reasons,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You are simply tired of my company. You have a good right to be.'' (unknown)

``No, no, I am not tired!'' (unknown)
cried the pestered young divine.
``It is very wrong to be tired.'' (unknown)

``I give it up!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
laughed Newman.
``But of course it will never do to go on making mistakes. Go your way, by all means. I shall miss you; but you have seen I make friends very easily. You will be lonely yourself; but drop me a line, when you feel like it, and I will wait for you anywhere.'' (unknown)

``I think I will go back to Milan. I am afraid I didn't do justice to Luini.'' (unknown)

``Poor Luini!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I mean that I am afraid I overestimated him (it). I don't think that he (it) is a painter of the first rank.'' (unknown)

``Luini?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman exclaimed;
``why, he (it)'s enchanting--he (it)'s magnificent! There is something in his (it) genius that is like a beautiful woman. It gives one the same feeling.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Mr. Babcock frowned and winced. And it must be added that this was, for Newman, an unusually metaphysical flight; but in passing through Milan he (Newman) had taken a great fancy to the painter.

``There you are again!'' (Babcock/Mr. Babcock)
said Mr. Babcock.
``Yes, we had better separate.'' (he)
And on the morrow he (Babcock) retraced his (Babcock) steps and proceeded to tone down his (Babcock) impressions of the great Lombard artist.

A few days afterwards Newman received a note from his (Newman) late companion which ran as follows:--

My Dear Mr. Newman,--I am afraid that my conduct at Venice, a week ago, seemed to you strange and ungrateful, and I wish to explain my position, which, as I said at the time, I do not think you appreciate. I had long had it on my mind to propose that we should part company, and this step was not really so abrupt as it seemed. In the first place, you know, I am traveling in Europe on funds supplied by my congregation, who kindly offered me a vacation and an opportunity to enrich my mind with the treasures of nature and art in the Old World. I feel, therefore, as if I ought to use my time to the very best advantage. I have a high sense of responsibility. You appear to care only for the pleasure of the hour, and you give yourself up to it with a violence which I confess I am not able to emulate. I feel as if I must arrive at some conclusion and fix my belief on certain points. Art and life seem to me intensely serious things, and in our travels in Europe we should especially remember the immense seriousness of Art. You seem to hold that if a thing amuses you for the moment, that is all you need ask for it, and your relish for mere amusement is also much higher than mine. You put, however, a kind of reckless confidence into your pleasure which at times, I confess, has seemed to me--shall I say it?--almost cynical. Your way at any rate is not my way, and it is unwise that we should attempt any longer to pull together. And yet, let me add that I know there is a great deal to be said for your way; I have felt its attraction, in your society, very strongly. But for this I should have left you long ago. But I was so perplexed. I hope I have not done wrong. I feel as if I had a great deal of lost time to make up. I beg you take all this as I mean it, which, Heaven knows, is not invidiously. I have a great personal esteem for you and hope that some day, when I have recovered my balance, we shall meet again. I hope you will continue to enjoy your travels, only _do_ remember that Life and Art _are_ extremely serious. Believe me your sincere friend and well-wisher,

BENJAMIN BABCOCK

P. S. I am greatly perplexed by Luini.

This letter produced in Newman's mind a singular mixture of exhilaration and awe. At first, Mr. Babcock's tender conscience seemed to him (Babcock) a capital farce, and his (Babcock) traveling back to Milan only to get into a deeper muddle appeared, as the reward of his (Babcock) pedantry, exquisitely and ludicrously just. Then Newman reflected that these are mighty mysteries, that possibly he (Newman) himself was indeed that baleful and barely mentionable thing, a cynic, and that his (Newman) manner of considering the treasures of art and the privileges of life was probably very base and immoral. Newman had a great contempt for immorality, and that evening, for a good half hour, as he (Newman) sat watching the star-sheen on the warm Adriatic, he (Newman) felt rebuked and depressed. He (Newman) was at a loss how to answer Babcock's letter. His (Babcock) good nature checked his (Babcock) resenting the young minister's lofty admonitions, and his (Babcock) tough, inelastic sense of humor forbade his (Babcock) taking them seriously. He (Babcock) wrote no answer at all but a day or two afterward he (Babcock) found in a curiosity shop a grotesque little statuette in ivory, of the sixteenth century, which he (Babcock) sent off to Babcock without a commentary. It represented a gaunt, ascetic-looking monk, in a tattered gown and cowl, kneeling with clasped hands and pulling a portentously long face. It was a wonderfully delicate piece of carving, and in a moment, through one of the rents of his (Babcock) gown, you espied a fat capon hung round the monk's waist. In Newman's intention what did the figure symbolize? Did it mean that he (Newman) was going to try to be as

``high-toned'' (he)
as the monk looked at first, but that he (Newman) feared he (Newman) should succeed no better than the friar, on a closer inspection, proved to have done? It is not supposable that he (Newman) intended a satire upon Babcock's own asceticism, for this would have been a truly cynical stroke. He (Babcock) made his (Babcock) late companion, at any rate, a very valuable little present.

Newman, on leaving Venice, went through the Tyrol to Vienna, and then returned westward, through Southern Germany. The autumn found him (Newman) at Baden-Baden, where he (Newman) spent several weeks. The place was charming, and he (Newman) was in no hurry to depart; besides, he (Newman) was looking about him (Newman) and deciding what to do for the winter. His (Newman) summer had been very full, and he (Newman) sat under the great trees beside the miniature river that trickles past the Baden flower-beds, he (Newman) slowly rummaged it over. He (Newman) had seen and done a great deal, enjoyed and observed a great deal; he (Newman) felt older, and yet he (Newman) felt younger too. He (Newman) remembered Mr. Babcock and his (Babcock) desire to form conclusions, and he (Babcock) remembered also that he (Babcock) had profited very little by his (Babcock) friend's exhortation to cultivate the same respectable habit. Could he (Babcock) not scrape together a few conclusions? Baden-Baden was the prettiest place he (Babcock) had seen yet, and orchestral music in the evening, under the stars, was decidedly a great institution. This was one of his (Babcock) conclusions! But he (Babcock) went on to reflect that he (Babcock) had done very wisely to pull up stakes and come abroad; this seeing of the world was a very interesting thing. He (Babcock) had learned a great deal; he (Babcock) couldn't say just what, but he (Babcock) had it there under his (Babcock) hat-band. He (Babcock) had done what he (Babcock) wanted; he (Babcock) had seen the great things, and he (Babcock) had given his (Babcock) mind a chance to

``improve,'' (he)
if it would. He (Babcock) cheerfully believed that it had improved. Yes, this seeing of the world was very pleasant, and he (Babcock) would willingly do a little more of it. Thirty-six years old as he (Babcock) was, he (Babcock) had a handsome stretch of life before him (Babcock) yet, and he (Babcock) need not begin to count his (Babcock) weeks. Where should he (Babcock) take the world next? I have said he (Babcock) remembered the eyes of the lady whom he (Babcock) had found standing in Mrs. Tristram's drawing-room; four months had elapsed, and he (Babcock) had not forgotten them yet. He (Babcock) had looked--he (Babcock) had made a point of looking--into a great many other eyes in the interval, but the only ones he (Babcock) thought of now were Madame de Cintré's. If he (Babcock) wanted to see more of the world, should he (Babcock) find it in Madame de Cintré's eyes? He (Babcock) would certainly find something there, call it this world or the next. Throughout these rather formless meditations he (Babcock) sometimes thought of his (Babcock) past life and the long array of years -LRB-they had begun so early-RRB- during which he (Babcock) had had nothing in his (Babcock) head but
``enterprise.'' (he)
They seemed far away now, for his (Babcock) present attitude was more than a holiday, it was almost a rupture. He (Babcock) had told Tristram that the pendulum was swinging back and it appeared that the backward swing had not yet ended. Still
``enterprise,'' (unknown)
which was over in the other quarter wore to his (Babcock) mind a different aspect at different hours. In its train a thousand forgotten episodes came trooping back into his (Babcock) memory. Some of them he (Babcock) looked complacently enough in the face; from some he (Babcock) averted his (Babcock) head. They were old efforts, old exploits, antiquated examples of
``smartness'' (unknown)
and sharpness. Some of them, as he (Babcock) looked at them, he (Babcock) felt decidedly proud of; he (Babcock) admired himself as if he (Babcock) had been looking at another man. And, in fact, many of the qualities that make a great deed were there: the decision, the resolution, the courage, the celerity, the clear eye, and the strong hand. Of certain other achievements it would be going too far to say that he (Babcock) was ashamed of them for Newman had never had a stomach for dirty work. He (Newman) was blessed with a natural impulse to disfigure with a direct, unreasoning blow the comely visage of temptation. And certainly, in no man could a want of integrity have been less excusable. Newman knew the crooked from the straight at a glance, and the former had cost him (Newman), first and last, a great many moments of lively disgust. But none the less some of his (Newman) memories seemed to wear at present a rather graceless and sordid mien, and it struck him (Newman) that if he (Newman) had never done anything very ugly, he (Newman) had never, on the other hand, done anything particularly beautiful. He (Newman) had spent his (Newman) years in the unremitting effort to add thousands to thousands, and, now that he (Newman) stood well outside of it, the business of money-getting appeared tolerably dry and sterile. It is very well to sneer at money-getting after you have filled your pockets, and Newman, it may be said, should have begun somewhat earlier to moralize thus delicately. To this it may be answered that he (Newman) might have made another fortune, if he (Newman) chose; and we ought to add that he (Newman) was not exactly moralizing. It had come back to him (Newman) simply that what he (Newman) had been looking at all summer was a very rich and beautiful world, and that it had not all been made by sharp railroad men and stock-brokers.

During his (Newman) stay at Baden-Baden he (Newman) received a letter from Mrs. Tristram, scolding him (Newman) for the scanty tidings he (Newman) had sent to his (Newman) friends of the Avenue d’Iéna, and begging to be definitely informed that he (Newman) had not concocted any horrid scheme for wintering in outlying regions, but was coming back sanely and promptly to the most comfortable city in the world. Newman's answer ran as follows:--

``I supposed you knew I was a miserable letter-writer, and didn't expect anything of me. I don't think I have written twenty letters of pure friendship in my whole life; in America I conducted my correspondence altogether by telegrams. This is a letter of pure friendship; you have got hold of a curiosity, and I hope you will value it. You want to know everything that has happened to me these three months. The best way to tell you, I think, would be to send you my half dozen guide-books, with my pencil-marks in the margin. Wherever you find a scratch or a cross, or a `Beautiful!' or a `So true!' or a `Too thin!' you may know that I have had a sensation of some sort or other. That has been about my history, ever since I left you. Belgium, Holland, Switzerland, Germany, Italy--I have been through the whole list, and I don't think I am any the worse for it. I know more about Madonnas and church-steeples than I supposed any man could. I have seen some very pretty things, and shall perhaps talk them over this winter, by your fireside. You see, my face is not altogether set against Paris. I have had all kinds of plans and visions, but your letter has blown most of them away. `_L’appétit vient en mangeant_,' says the French proverb, and I find that the more I see of the world the more I want to see. Now that I am in the shafts, why shouldn't I trot to the end of the course? Sometimes I think of the far East, and keep rolling the names of Eastern cities under my tongue: Damascus and Bagdad, Medina and Mecca. I spent a week last month in the company of a returned missionary, who told me I ought to be ashamed to be loafing about Europe when there are such big things to be seen out there. I do want to explore, but I think I would rather explore over in the Rue de l’Université. Do you ever hear from that pretty lady? If you can get her (lady) to promise she (lady) will be at home the next time I call, I will go back to Paris straight. I am more than ever in the state of mind I told you about that evening; I want a first-class wife. I have kept an eye on all the pretty girls I have come across this summer, but none of them came up to my notion, or anywhere near it. I should have enjoyed all this a thousand times more if I had had the lady just mentioned by my side. The nearest approach to her (lady) was a Unitarian minister from Boston, who very soon demanded a separation, for incompatibility of temper. He (minister) told me I was low-minded, immoral, a devotee of `art for art'--whatever that is: all of which greatly afflicted me, for he (minister) was really a sweet little fellow. But shortly afterwards I met an Englishman, with whom I struck up an acquaintance which at first seemed to promise well--a very bright man, who writes in the London papers and knows Paris nearly as well as Tristram. We knocked about for a week together, but he (man) very soon gave me up in disgust. I was too virtuous by half; I was too stern a moralist. He (man) told me, in a friendly way, that I was cursed with a conscience; that I judged things like a Methodist and talked about them like an old lady. This was rather bewildering. Which of my two critics was I to believe? I didn't worry about it and very soon made up my mind they were both idiots. But there is one thing in which no one will ever have the impudence to pretend I am wrong, that is, in being your faithful friend,

``C. N.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

CHAPTER VI

Newman gave up Damascus and Bagdad and returned to Paris before the autumn was over. He (Newman) established himself in some rooms selected for him (Newman) by Tom Tristram, in accordance with the latter's estimate of what he (Tristram) called his (Tristram) social position. When Newman learned that his (Newman) social position was to be taken into account, he (Newman) professed himself utterly incompetent, and begged Tristram to relieve him (Newman) of the care.

``I didn't know I had a social position,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``and if I have, I haven't the smallest idea what it is. Isn't a social position knowing some two or three thousand people and inviting them to dinner? I know you and your wife and little old Mr. Nioche, who gave me French lessons last spring. Can I invite you to dinner to meet each other? If I can, you must come to-morrow.'' (he)

``That is not very grateful to me,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram,
``who introduced you last year to every creature I know.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``So you did; I had quite forgotten. But I thought you wanted me to forget,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with that tone of simple deliberateness which frequently marked his (Newman) utterance, and which an observer would not have known whether to pronounce a somewhat mysteriously humorous affection of ignorance or a modest aspiration to knowledge;
``you told me you disliked them all.'' (an observer)

``Ah, the way you remember what I say is at least very flattering. But in future,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
added Mrs. Tristram,
``pray forget all the wicked things and remember only the good ones. It will be easily done, and it will not fatigue your memory. But I forewarn you that if you trust my husband to pick out your rooms, you are in for something hideous.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``Hideous, darling?'' (unknown)
cried Tristram.

``To-day I must say nothing wicked; otherwise I should use stronger language.'' (unknown)

``What do you think she (your) would say, Newman?'' (unknown)
asked Tristram.
``If she (your) really tried, now? She (your) can express displeasure, volubly, in two or three languages; that's what it is to be intellectual. It gives her (your) the start of me completely, for I can't swear, for the life of me, except in English. When I get mad I have to fall back on our dear old mother tongue. There's nothing like it, after all.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman declared that he (Newman) knew nothing about tables and chairs, and that he (Newman) would accept, in the way of a lodging, with his (Newman) eyes shut, anything that Tristram should offer him (Newman). This was partly veracity on our hero's part, but it was also partly charity. He (Newman) knew that to pry about and look at rooms, and make people open windows, and poke into sofas with his (Newman) cane, and gossip with landladies, and ask who lived above and who below--he (Newman) knew that this was of all pastimes the dearest to Tristram's heart, and he (Newman) felt the more disposed to put it in his (Newman) way as he (Newman) was conscious that, as regards his (Newman) obliging friend, he (Newman) had suffered the warmth of ancient good-fellowship somewhat to abate. Besides, he (Newman) had no taste for upholstery; he (Newman) had even no very exquisite sense of comfort or convenience. He (Newman) had a relish for luxury and splendor, but it was satisfied by rather gross contrivances. He (Newman) scarcely knew a hard chair from a soft one, and he (Newman) possessed a talent for stretching his (Newman) legs which quite dispensed with adventitious facilities. His (Newman) idea of comfort was to inhabit very large rooms, have a great many of them, and be conscious of their possessing a number of patented mechanical devices--half of which he (Newman) should never have occasion to use. The apartments should be light and brilliant and lofty; he (Newman) had once said that he (Newman) liked rooms in which you wanted to keep your hat on. For the rest, he (Newman) was satisfied with the assurance of any respectable person that everything was

``handsome.'' (any person)
Tristram accordingly secured for him (Newman) an apartment to which this epithet might be lavishly applied. It was situated on the Boulevard Haussmann, on the first floor, and consisted of a series of rooms, gilded from floor to ceiling a foot thick, draped in various light shades of satin, and chiefly furnished with mirrors and clocks. Newman thought them magnificent, thanked Tristram heartily, immediately took possession, and had one of his (Newman) trunks standing for three months in his (Newman) drawing-room.

One day Mrs. Tristram told him (Newman) that her (Tristram) beautiful friend, Madame de Cintré, had returned from the country; that she (Tristram) had met her (Tristram) three days before, coming out of the Church of St. Sulpice; she (Tristram) herself having journeyed to that distant quarter in quest of an obscure lace-mender, of whose skill she (Tristram) had heard high praise.

``And how were those eyes?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

``Those eyes were red with weeping, if you please!'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.
``She (mother) had been to confession.'' (unknown)

``It doesn't tally with your account of her (mother),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``that she (mother) should have sins to confess.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``They were not sins; they were sufferings.'' (unknown)

``How do you know that?'' (unknown)

``She (mother) asked me to come and see her (mother); I went this morning.'' (unknown)

``And what does she (mother) suffer from?'' (unknown)

``I didn't ask her (mother). With her (mother), somehow, one is very discreet. But I guessed, easily enough. She (mother) suffers from her (mother) wicked old mother and her (mother) Grand Turk of a brother. They persecute her (mother). But I can almost forgive them, because, as I told you, she (mother) is a saint, and a persecution is all that she (mother) needs to bring out her (mother) saintliness and make her (mother) perfect.'' (unknown)

``That's a comfortable theory for her (mother). I hope you will never impart it to the old folks. Why does she (mother) let them bully her (mother)? Is she (mother) not her (mother) own mistress?'' (unknown)

``Legally, yes, I suppose; but morally, no. In France you must never say nay to your mother, whatever she (mother) requires of you. She (mother) may be the most abominable old woman in the world, and make your life a purgatory; but, after all, she (mother) is _ma mère_, and you have no right to judge her (mother). You have simply to obey. The thing has a fine side to it. Madame de Cintré bows her (mother) head and folds her (mother) wings.'' (unknown)

``Can't she (mother) at least make her (mother) brother leave off?'' (unknown)

``Her (mother) brother is the _chef de la famille_, as they say; he (brother) is the head of the clan. With those people the family is everything; you must act, not for your own pleasure, but for the advantage of the family.'' (unknown)

``I wonder what _my_ family would like me to do!'' (unknown)
exclaimed Tristram.

``I wish you had one!'' (wife)
said his (Newman) wife.

``But what do they want to get out of that poor lady?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

``Another marriage. They are not rich, and they want to bring more money into the family.'' (unknown)

``There's your chance, my boy!'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram.

``And Madame de Cintré objects,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman continued.

``She (lady) has been sold once; she (lady) naturally objects to being sold again. It appears that the first time they made rather a poor bargain; M. de Cintré left a scanty property.'' (unknown)

``And to whom do they want to marry her (lady) now?'' (unknown)

``I thought it best not to ask; but you may be sure it is to some horrid old nabob, or to some dissipated little duke.'' (unknown)

``There's Mrs. Tristram, as large as life!'' (husband)
cried her (Tristram) husband.
``Observe the richness of her (Tristram) imagination. She (Tristram) has not a single question--it's vulgar to ask questions--and yet she (Tristram) knows everything. She (Tristram) has the history of Madame de Cintré's marriage at her (Tristram) fingers' ends. She (Tristram) has seen the lovely Claire on her (Tristram) knees, with loosened tresses and streaming eyes, and the rest of them standing over her (Tristram) with spikes and goads and red-hot irons, ready to come down on her (Tristram) if she (Tristram) refuses the tipsy duke. The simple truth is that they made a fuss about her (Tristram) milliner's bill or refused her (Tristram) an opera-box.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman looked from Tristram to his (Newman) wife with a certain mistrust in each direction.

``Do you really mean,'' (he)
he (Newman) asked of Mrs. Tristram,
``that your friend is being forced into an unhappy marriage?'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``I think it extremely probable. Those people are very capable of that sort of thing.'' (unknown)

``It is like something in a play,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``that dark old house over there looks as if wicked things had been done in it, and might be done again.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``They have a still darker old house in the country Madame de Cintré tells me, and there, during the summer this scheme must have been hatched.'' (unknown)

``_Must_ have been; mind that!'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram.

``After all,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
suggested Newman, after a silence,
``she (me) may be in trouble about something else.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``If it is something else, then it is something worse,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram, with rich decision.

Newman was silent a while, and seemed lost in meditation.

``Is it possible,'' (he)
he (Newman) asked at last,
``that they do that sort of thing over here? that helpless women are bullied into marrying men they hate?'' (he)

``Helpless women, all over the world, have a hard time of it,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.
``There is plenty of bullying everywhere.'' (unknown)

``A great deal of that kind of thing goes on in New York,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Tristram.
``Girls are bullied or coaxed or bribed, or all three together, into marrying nasty fellows. There is no end of that always going on in the Fifth Avenue, and other bad things besides. The Mysteries of the Fifth Avenue! Someone ought to show them up.'' (unknown)

``I don't believe it!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, very gravely.
``I don't believe that, in America, girls are ever subjected to compulsion. I don't believe there have been a dozen cases of it since the country began.'' (unknown)

``Listen to the voice of the spread eagle!'' (unknown)
cried Tristram.

``The spread eagle ought to use his (dozen) wings,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.
``Fly to the rescue of Madame de Cintré!'' (unknown)

``To her (dozen) rescue?'' (unknown)

``Pounce down, seize her (dozen) in your talons, and carry her (dozen) off. Marry her (dozen) yourself.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman, for some moments, answered nothing; but presently,

``I should suppose she (dozen) had heard enough of marrying,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
he (Newman) said.
``The kindest way to treat her (dozen) would be to admire her (dozen), and yet never to speak of it. But that sort of thing is infamous,'' (he)
he (Newman) added;
``it makes me feel savage to hear of it.'' (he)

He (Newman) heard of it, however, more than once afterward. Mrs. Tristram again saw Madame de Cintré, and again found her (Tristram) looking very sad. But on these occasions there had been no tears; her (Tristram) beautiful eyes were clear and still.

``She (dozen) is cold, calm, and hopeless,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Mrs. Tristram declared, and she (Tristram) added that on her (Tristram) mentioning that her (Tristram) friend Mr. Newman was again in Paris and was faithful in his (Newman) desire to make Madame de Cintré's acquaintance, this lovely woman had found a smile in her (woman) despair, and declared that she (woman) was sorry to have missed his (Cintré) visit in the spring and that she (woman) hoped he (Cintré) had not lost courage.
``I told her (dozen) something about you,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.

``That's a comfort,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, placidly.
``I like people to know about me.'' (he)

A few days after this, one dusky autumn afternoon, he (Newman) went again to the Rue de l’Université. The early evening had closed in as he (Newman) applied for admittance at the stoutly guarded _Hôtel de Bellegarde_. He (Newman) was told that Madame de Cintré was at home; he (Cintré) crossed the court, entered the farther door, and was conducted through a vestibule, vast, dim, and cold, up a broad stone staircase with an ancient iron balustrade, to an apartment on the second floor. Announced and ushered in, he (Cintré) found himself in a sort of paneled boudoir, at one end of which a lady and gentleman were seated before the fire. The gentleman was smoking a cigarette; there was no light in the room save that of a couple of candles and the glow from the hearth. Both persons rose to welcome Newman, who, in the firelight, recognized Madame de Cintré. She (lady) gave him (Newman) her (lady) hand with a smile which seemed in itself an illumination, and, pointing to her (lady) companion, said softly,

``My brother.'' (companion)
The gentleman offered Newman a frank, friendly greeting, and our hero then perceived him (Newman) to be the young man who had spoken to him (Newman) in the court of the hotel on his (Newman) former visit and who had struck him (Newman) as a good fellow.

``Mrs. Tristram has spoken to me a great deal of you,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré gently, as she (lady) resumed her (lady) former place.

Newman, after he (Newman) had seated himself, began to consider what, in truth, was his (Newman) errand. He (Newman) had an unusual, unexpected sense of having wandered into a strange corner of the world. He (Newman) was not given, as a general thing, to anticipating danger, or forecasting disaster, and he (Newman) had had no social tremors on this particular occasion. He (Newman) was not timid and he (Newman) was not impudent. He (Newman) felt too kindly toward himself to be the one, and too good-naturedly toward the rest of the world to be the other. But his (Newman) native shrewdness sometimes placed his (Newman) ease of temper at its mercy; with every disposition to take things simply, it was obliged to perceive that some things were not so simple as others. He (Newman) felt as one does in missing a step, in an ascent, where one expected to find it. This strange, pretty woman, sitting in fire-side talk with her (woman) brother, in the gray depths of her (woman) inhospitable-looking house--what had he (brother) to say to her (woman)? She (woman) seemed enveloped in a sort of fantastic privacy; on what grounds had he (brother) pulled away the curtain? For a moment he (brother) felt as if he (brother) had plunged into some medium as deep as the ocean, and as if he (brother) must exert himself to keep from sinking. Meanwhile he (brother) was looking at Madame de Cintré, and she (woman) was settling herself in her (woman) chair and drawing in her (woman) long dress and turning her (woman) face towards him (brother). Their eyes met; a moment afterwards she (woman) looked away and motioned to her (woman) brother to put a log on the fire. But the moment, and the glance which traversed it, had been sufficient to relieve Newman of the first and the last fit of personal embarrassment he (Newman) was ever to know. He (Newman) performed the movement which was so frequent with him (Newman), and which was always a sort of symbol of his (Newman) taking mental possession of a scene--he (Newman) extended his (Newman) legs. The impression Madame de Cintré had made upon him (Newman) on their first meeting came back in an instant; it had been deeper than he (Newman) knew. She (Newman) was pleasing, she (Newman) was interesting; he (Newman) had opened a book and the first lines held his (Newman) attention.

She (Newman) asked him (Newman) several questions: how lately he (Newman) had seen Mrs. Tristram, how long he (Newman) had been in Paris, how long he (Newman) expected to remain there, how he (Newman) liked it. She (Tristram) spoke English without an accent, or rather with that distinctively British accent which, on his (Newman) arrival in Europe, had struck Newman as an altogether foreign tongue, but which, in women, he (Newman) had come to like extremely. Here and there Madame de Cintré's utterance had a faint shade of strangeness but at the end of ten minutes Newman found himself waiting for these soft roughnesses. He (Newman) enjoyed them, and he (Newman) marveled to see that gross thing, error, brought down to so fine a point.

``You have a beautiful country,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré, presently.

``Oh, magnificent!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You ought to see it.'' (unknown)

``I shall never see it,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré with a smile.

``Why not?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``I don't travel; especially so far.'' (unknown)

``But you go away sometimes; you are not always here?'' (unknown)

``I go away in summer, a little way, to the country.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman wanted to ask her (Newman) something more, something personal, he (Newman) hardly knew what.

``Don't you find it rather--rather quiet here?'' (he)
he (Newman) said;
``so far from the street?'' (he)
Rather
``gloomy,'' (he)
he (Newman) was going to say, but he (Newman) reflected that that would be impolite.

``Yes, it is very quiet,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré;
``but we like that.'' (Madame de Cintré)

``Ah, you like that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
repeated Newman, slowly.

``Besides, I have lived here all my life.'' (unknown)

``Lived here all your life,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, in the same way.

``I was born here, and my father was born here before me, and my grandfather, and my great-grandfathers. Were they not, Valentin?'' (she)
and she (Newman) appealed to her (Newman) brother.

``Yes, it's a family habit to be born here!'' (the man)
the young man said with a laugh, and rose and threw the remnant of his (Newman) cigarette into the fire, and then remained leaning against the chimney-piece. An observer would have perceived that he (Newman) wished to take a better look at Newman, whom he (Newman) covertly examined, while he (Newman) stood stroking his (Newman) moustache.

``Your house is tremendously old, then,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``How old is it, brother?'' (Madame)
asked Madame de Cintré.

The young man took the two candles from the mantel-shelf, lifted one high in each hand, and looked up toward the cornice of the room, above the chimney-piece. This latter feature of the apartment was of white marble, and in the familiar rococo style of the last century; but above it was a paneling of an earlier date, quaintly carved, painted white, and gilded here and there. The white had turned to yellow, and the gilding was tarnished. On the top, the figures ranged themselves into a sort of shield, on which an armorial device was cut. Above it, in relief, was a date--1627.

``There you have it,'' (the man)
said the young man.
``That is old or new, according to your point of view.'' (unknown)

``Well, over here,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``one's point of view gets shifted round considerably.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) threw back his (Newman) head and looked about the room.
``Your house is of a very curious style of architecture,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

``Are you interested in architecture?'' (the man)
asked the young man at the chimney-piece.

``Well, I took the trouble, this summer,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``to examine--as well as I can calculate--some four hundred and seventy churches. Do you call that interested?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Perhaps you are interested in theology,'' (the man)
said the young man.

``Not particularly. Are you a Roman Catholic, madam?'' (he)
And he (Newman) turned to Madame de Cintré.

``Yes, sir,'' (she)
she (man) answered, gravely.

Newman was struck with the gravity of her (man) tone; he (Newman) threw back his (Newman) head and began to look round the room again.

``Had you never noticed that number up there?'' (he)
he (Newman) presently asked.

She (man) hesitated a moment, and then,

``In former years,'' (She)
she (man) said.

Her (man) brother had been watching Newman's movement.

``Perhaps you would like to examine the house,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

Newman slowly brought down his (Newman) eyes and looked at him (Newman); he (Newman) had a vague impression that the young man at the chimney-piece was inclined to irony. He (man) was a handsome fellow, his (man) face wore a smile, his (man) moustaches were curled up at the ends, and there was a little dancing gleam in his (man) eye.

``Damn his (you) French impudence!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman was on the point of saying to himself.
``What the deuce is he (you) grinning at?'' (He)
He (Newman) glanced at Madame de Cintré; she (man) was sitting with her (man) eyes fixed on the floor. She (man) raised them, they met his (Newman), and she (man) looked at her (man) brother. Newman turned again to this young man and observed that he (Newman) strikingly resembled his (Newman) sister. This was in his (Newman) favor, and our hero's first impression of the Count Valentin, moreover, had been agreeable. His (Valentin) mistrust expired, and he (Valentin) said he (Valentin) would be very glad to see the house.

The young man gave a frank laugh, and laid his (man) hand on one of the candlesticks.

``Good, good!'' (he)
he (man) exclaimed.
``Come, then.'' (Madame)

But Madame de Cintré rose quickly and grasped his (man) arm,

``Ah, Valentin!'' (Madame)
she (sister) said.
``What do you mean to do?'' (unknown)

``To show Mr. Newman the house. It will be very amusing.'' (She)

She (sister) kept her (sister) hand on his (man) arm, and turned to Newman with a smile.

``Don't let him (Newman) take you,'' (she)
she (sister) said;
``you will not find it amusing. It is a musty old house, like any other.'' (she)

``It is full of curious things,'' (unknown)
said the count, resisting.
``Besides, I want to do it; it is a rare chance.'' (unknown)

``You are very wicked, brother,'' (unknown)
Madame de Cintré answered.

``Nothing venture, nothing have!'' (the man)
cried the young man.
``Will you come?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Madame de Cintré stepped toward Newman, gently clasping her (sister) hands and smiling softly.

``Would you not prefer my society, here, by my fire, to stumbling about dark passages after my brother?'' (unknown)

``A hundred times!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``We will see the house some other day.'' (The man sir)

The young man put down his (Newman) candlestick with mock solemnity, and, shaking his (Newman) head,

``Ah, you have defeated a great scheme, sir!'' (The man sir)
he (Newman) said.

``A scheme? I don't understand,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``You would have played your part in it all the better. Perhaps some day I shall have a chance to explain it.'' (unknown)

``Be quiet, and ring for the tea,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.

The young man obeyed, and presently a servant brought in the tea, placed the tray on a small table, and departed. Madame de Cintré, from her (sister) place, busied herself with making it. She (sister) had but just begun when the door was thrown open and a lady rushed in, making a loud rustling sound. She (lady) stared at Newman, gave a little nod and a

``Monsieur!'' (Newman)
and then quickly approached Madame de Cintré and presented her (lady) forehead to be kissed. Madame de Cintré saluted her (lady), and continued to make tea. The new-comer was young and pretty, it seemed to Newman; she (lady) wore her (lady) bonnet and cloak, and a train of royal proportions. She (lady) began to talk rapidly in French.
``Oh, give me some tea, my beautiful one, for the love of God! I'm exhausted, mangled, massacred.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman found himself quite unable to follow her (lady); she (lady) spoke much less distinctly than M. Nioche.

``That is my sister-in-law,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said the Count Valentin, leaning towards him (Valentin).

``She (sister-in-law) is very pretty,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Exquisite,'' (the man)
answered the young man, and this time, again, Newman suspected him (Newman) of irony.

His (Newman) sister-in-law came round to the other side of the fire with her (sister-in-law) cup of tea in her (sister-in-law) hand, holding it out at arm's-length, so that she (sister-in-law) might not spill it on her (sister-in-law) dress, and uttering little cries of alarm. She (sister-in-law) placed the cup on the mantel-shelf and begun to unpin her (sister-in-law) veil and pull off her (sister-in-law) gloves, looking meanwhile at Newman.

``Is there anything I can do for you, my dear lady?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
the Count Valentin asked, in a sort of mock-caressing tone.

``Present monsieur,'' (sister-in-law)
said his (Valentin) sister-in-law.

The young man answered,

``Mr. Newman!'' (The man Newman)

``I can't courtesy to you, monsieur, or I shall spill my tea,'' (the lady)
said the lady.
``So Claire receives strangers, like that?'' (she)
she (lady) added, in a low voice, in French, to her (lady) brother-in-law.

``Apparently!'' (he)
he (brother-in-law) answered with a smile. Newman stood a moment, and then he (Newman) approached Madame de Cintré. She (lady) looked up at him (Newman) as if she (lady) were thinking of something to say. But she (lady) seemed to think of nothing; so she (lady) simply smiled. He (Newman) sat down near her (lady) and she (lady) handed him (Newman) a cup of tea. For a few moments they talked about that, and meanwhile he (Newman) looked at her (lady). He (Newman) remembered what Mrs. Tristram had told him (Newman) of her (Tristram)
``perfection'' (him)
and of her (Tristram) having, in combination, all the brilliant things that he (Newman) dreamed of finding. This made him (Newman) observe her (Tristram) not only without mistrust, but without uneasy conjectures; the presumption, from the first moment he (Newman) looked at her (Tristram), had been in her (Tristram) favor. And yet, if she (Tristram) was beautiful, it was not a dazzling beauty. She (Tristram) was tall and moulded in long lines; she (Tristram) had thick fair hair, a wide forehead, and features with a sort of harmonious irregularity. Her (Tristram) clear gray eyes were strikingly expressive; they were both gentle and intelligent, and Newman liked them immensely; but they had not those depths of splendor--those many-colored rays--which illumine the brows of famous beauties. Madame de Cintré was rather thin, and she (Tristram) looked younger than probably she (Tristram) was. In her (Tristram) whole person there was something both youthful and subdued, slender and yet ample, tranquil yet shy; a mixture of immaturity and repose, of innocence and dignity. What had Tristram meant, Newman wondered, by calling her (Tristram) proud? She (Tristram) was certainly not proud now, to him (Newman); or if she (Tristram) was, it was of no use, it was lost upon him (Newman); she (Tristram) must pile it up higher if she (Tristram) expected him (Newman) to mind it. She (Tristram) was a beautiful woman, and it was very easy to get on with her (Tristram). Was she (Tristram) a countess, a _marquise_, a kind of historical formation? Newman, who had rarely heard these words used, had never been at pains to attach any particular image to them; but they occurred to him (Newman) now and seemed charged with a sort of melodious meaning. They signified something fair and softly bright, that had easy motions and spoke very agreeably.

``Have you many friends in Paris; do you go out?'' (Madame de Cintré)
asked Madame de Cintré, who had at last thought of something to say.

``Do you mean do I dance, and all that?'' (unknown)

``Do you go _dans le monde_ , as we say?'' (unknown)

``I have seen a good many people. Mrs. Tristram has taken me about. I do whatever she (Tristram) tells me.'' (unknown)

``By yourself, you are not fond of amusements?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, of some sorts. I am not fond of dancing, and that sort of thing; I am too old and sober. But I want to be amused; I came to Europe for that.'' (unknown)

``But you can be amused in America, too.'' (unknown)

``I couldn't; I was always at work. But after all, that was my amusement.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

At this moment Madame de Bellegarde came back for another cup of tea, accompanied by the Count Valentin. Madame de Cintré, when she (Newman) had served her (Newman), began to talk again with Newman, and recalling what he (Newman) had last said,

``In your own country you were very much occupied?'' (he)
she (Newman) asked.

``I was in business. I have been in business since I was fifteen years old.'' (unknown)

``And what was your business?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
asked Madame de Bellegarde, who was decidedly not so pretty as Madame de Cintré.

``I have been in everything,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``At one time I sold leather; at one time I manufactured wash-tubs.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

Madame de Bellegarde made a little grimace.

``Leather? I don't like that. Wash-tubs are better. I prefer the smell of soap. I hope at least they made your fortune.'' (She)
She (Newman) rattled this off with the air of a woman who had the reputation of saying everything that came into her (Newman) head, and with a strong French accent.

Newman had spoken with cheerful seriousness, but Madame de Bellegarde's tone made him (Bellegarde) go on, after a meditative pause, with a certain light grimness of jocularity.

``No, I lost money on wash-tubs, but I came out pretty square on leather.'' (unknown)

``I have made up my mind, after all,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde,
``that the great point is--how do you call it?--to come out square. I am on my knees to money; I don't deny it. If you have it, I ask no questions. For that I am a real democrat--like you, monsieur. Madame de Cintré is very proud; but I find that one gets much more pleasure in this sad life if one doesn't look too close.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``Just Heaven, dear madam, how you go at it,'' (the Count Valentin)
said the Count Valentin, lowering his (Valentin) voice.

``He (democrat)'s a man one can speak to, I suppose, since my sister receives him (democrat),'' (the lady)
the lady answered.
``Besides, it's very true; those are my ideas.'' (unknown)

``Ah, you call them ideas,'' (the man)
murmured the young man.

``But Mrs. Tristram told me you had been in the army--in your war,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.

``Yes, but that is not business!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Very true!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde.
``Otherwise perhaps I should not be penniless.'' (unknown)

``Is it true,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman in a moment,
``that you are so proud? I had already heard it.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Madame de Cintré smiled.

``Do you find me so?'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I am no judge. If you are proud with me, you will have to tell me. Otherwise I shall not know it.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Madame de Cintré began to laugh.

``That would be pride in a sad position!'' (she)
she (lady) said.

``It would be partly,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman went on,
``because I shouldn't want to know it. I want you to treat me well.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Madame de Cintré, whose laugh had ceased, looked at him (Newman) with her (lady) head half averted, as if she (lady) feared what he (Newman) was going to say.

``Mrs. Tristram told you the literal truth,'' (he)
he (Newman) went on;
``I want very much to know you. I didn't come here simply to call to-day; I came in the hope that you might ask me to come again.'' (he)

``Oh, pray come often,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.

``But will you be at home?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman insisted. Even to himself he (Newman) seemed a trifle
``pushing,'' (he)
but he (Newman) was, in truth, a trifle excited.

``I hope so!'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.

Newman got up.

``Well, we shall see,'' (he)
he (Newman) said smoothing his (Newman) hat with his (Newman) coat-cuff.

``Brother,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré,
``invite Mr. Newman to come again.'' (Madame de Cintré)

The Count Valentin looked at our hero from head to foot with his (Valentin) peculiar smile, in which impudence and urbanity seemed perplexingly commingled.

``Are you a brave man?'' (he)
he (Valentin) asked, eying him (Valentin) askance.

``Well, I hope so,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I rather suspect so. In that case, come again.'' (unknown)

``Ah, what an invitation!'' (Madame)
murmured Madame de Cintré, with something painful in her (Newman) smile.

``Oh, I want Mr. Newman to come--particularly,'' (the man)
said the young man.
``It will give me great pleasure. I shall be desolate if I miss one of his (Newman) visits. But I maintain he (Newman) must be brave. A stout heart, sir!'' (he)
And he (man) offered Newman his (Newman) hand.

``I shall not come to see you; I shall come to see Madame de Cintré,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``You will need all the more courage.'' (unknown)

``Ah, Valentin!'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré, appealingly.

``Decidedly,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
cried Madame de Bellegarde,
``I am the only person here capable of saying something polite! Come to see me; you will need no courage,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
she (Newman) said.

Newman gave a laugh which was not altogether an assent, and took his (Newman) leave. Madame de Cintré did not take up her (Newman) sister's challenge to be gracious, but she (Newman) looked with a certain troubled air at the retreating guest.

CHAPTER VII

One evening very late, about a week after his (Cintré) visit to Madame de Cintré, Newman's servant brought him (Newman) a card. It was that of young M. de Bellegarde. When, a few moments later, he (Bellegarde) went to receive his (Bellegarde) visitor, he (Bellegarde) found him (Bellegarde) standing in the middle of his (Bellegarde) great gilded parlor and eying it from cornice to carpet. M. de Bellegarde's face, it seemed to Newman, expressed a sense of lively entertainment.

``What the devil is he (devil) laughing at now?'' (hero)
our hero asked himself. But he (Newman) put the question without acrimony, for he (Newman) felt that Madame de Cintré's brother was a good fellow, and he (Cintré) had a presentiment that on this basis of good fellowship they were destined to understand each other. Only, if there was anything to laugh at, he (Cintré) wished to have a glimpse of it too.

``To begin with,'' (the man)
said the young man, as he (man) extended his (man) hand,
``have I come too late?'' (he)

``Too late for what?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``To smoke a cigar with you.'' (unknown)

``You would have to come early to do that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I don't smoke.'' (unknown)

``Ah, you are a strong man!'' (unknown)

``But I keep cigars,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman added.
``Sit down.'' (unknown)

``Surely, I may not smoke here,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde.

``What is the matter? Is the room too small?'' (unknown)

``It is too large. It is like smoking in a ball-room, or a church.'' (unknown)

``That is what you were laughing at just now?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked;
``the size of my room?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``It is not size only,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
replied M. de Bellegarde,
``but splendor, and harmony, and beauty of detail. It was the smile of admiration.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Newman looked at him (Newman) a moment, and then,

``So it _is_ very ugly?'' (him)
he (Newman) inquired.

``Ugly, my dear sir? It is magnificent.'' (unknown)

``That is the same thing, I suppose,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Make yourself comfortable. Your coming to see me, I take it, is an act of friendship. You were not obliged to. Therefore, if anything around here amuses you, it will be all in a pleasant way. Laugh as loud as you please; I like to see my visitors cheerful. Only, I must make this request: that you explain the joke to me as soon as you can speak. I don't want to lose anything, myself.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

M. de Bellegarde stared, with a look of unresentful perplexity. He (Newman) laid his (Newman) hand on Newman's sleeve and seemed on the point of saying something, but he (Newman) suddenly checked himself, leaned back in his (Newman) chair, and puffed at his (Newman) cigar. At last, however, breaking silence,--

``Certainly,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``my coming to see you is an act of friendship. Nevertheless I was in a measure obliged to do so. My sister asked me to come, and a request from my sister is, for me, a law. I was near you, and I observed lights in what I supposed were your rooms. It was not a ceremonious hour for making a call, but I was not sorry to do something that would show I was not performing a mere ceremony.'' (he)

``Well, here I am as large as life,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, extending his (Newman) legs.

``I don't know what you mean,'' (the man)
the young man went on
``by giving me unlimited leave to laugh. Certainly I am a great laugher, and it is better to laugh too much than too little. But it is not in order that we may laugh together--or separately--that I have, I may say, sought your acquaintance. To speak with almost impudent frankness, you interest me!'' (the man)
All this was uttered by M. de Bellegarde with the modulated smoothness of the man of the world, and in spite of his (Bellegarde) excellent English, of the Frenchman; but Newman, at the same time that he (Newman) sat noting its harmonious flow, perceived that it was not mere mechanical urbanity. Decidedly, there was something in his (Newman) visitor that he (Newman) liked. M. de Bellegarde was a foreigner to his (Bellegarde) finger-tips, and if Newman had met him (Newman) on a Western prairie he (Newman) would have felt it proper to address him (Newman) with a
``How-d’ye-do, Mosseer?'' (him)
But there was something in his (Newman) physiognomy which seemed to cast a sort of aerial bridge over the impassable gulf produced by difference of race. He (Newman) was below the middle height, and robust and agile in figure. Valentin de Bellegarde, Newman afterwards learned, had a mortal dread of the robustness overtaking the agility; he (Bellegarde) was afraid of growing stout; he (Bellegarde) was too short, as he (Bellegarde) said, to afford a belly. He (Bellegarde) rode and fenced and practiced gymnastics with unremitting zeal, and if you greeted him (Bellegarde) with a
``How well you are looking'' (him)
he (Bellegarde) started and turned pale. In your _well_ he (Bellegarde) read a grosser monosyllable. He (Bellegarde) had a round head, high above the ears, a crop of hair at once dense and silky, a broad, low forehead, a short nose, of the ironical and inquiring rather than of the dogmatic or sensitive cast, and a moustache as delicate as that of a page in a romance. He (Bellegarde) resembled his (Bellegarde) sister not in feature, but in the expression of his (Bellegarde) clear, bright eye, completely void of introspection, and in the way he (Bellegarde) smiled. The great point in his (Bellegarde) face was that it was intensely alive--frankly, ardently, gallantly alive. The look of it was like a bell, of which the handle might have been in the young man's soul: at a touch of the handle it rang with a loud, silver sound. There was something in his (man) quick, light brown eye which assured you that he (man) was not economizing his (man) consciousness. He (man) was not living in a corner of it to spare the furniture of the rest. He (man) was squarely encamped in the centre and he (man) was keeping open house. When he (man) smiled, it was like the movement of a person who in emptying a cup turns it upside down: he (man) gave you the last drop of his (man) jollity. He (man) inspired Newman with something of the same kindness that our hero used to feel in his (hero) earlier years for those of his (hero) companions who could perform strange and clever tricks--make their joints crack in queer places or whistle at the back of their mouths.

``My sister told me,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
M. de Bellegarde continued,
``that I ought to come and remove the impression that I had taken such great pains to produce upon you; the impression that I am a lunatic. Did it strike you that I behaved very oddly the other day?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``Rather so,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``So my sister tells me.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
And M. de Bellegarde watched his (Bellegarde) host for a moment through his (Bellegarde) smoke-wreaths.
``If that is the case, I think we had better let it stand. I didn't try to make you think I was a lunatic, at all; on the contrary, I wanted to produce a favorable impression. But if, after all, I made a fool of myself, it was the intention of Providence. I should injure myself by protesting too much, for I should seem to set up a claim for wisdom which, in the sequel of our acquaintance, I could by no means justify. Set me down as a lunatic with intervals of sanity.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I guess you know what you are about,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``When I am sane, I am very sane; that I admit,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
M. de Bellegarde answered.
``But I didn't come here to talk about myself. I should like to ask you a few questions. You allow me?'' (unknown)

``Give me a specimen,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``You live here all alone?'' (unknown)

``Absolutely. With whom should I live?'' (unknown)

``For the moment,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde with a smile
``I am asking questions, not answering them. You have come to Paris for your pleasure?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Newman was silent a while. Then, at last,

``Everyone asks me that!'' (he)
he (Newman) said with his (Newman) mild slowness.
``It sounds so awfully foolish.'' (unknown)

``But at any rate you had a reason.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I came for my pleasure!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Though it is foolish, it is true.'' (unknown)

``And you are enjoying it?'' (any American)

Like any other good American, Newman thought it as well not to truckle to the foreigner.

``Oh, so-so,'' (he)
he (Newman) answered.

M. de Bellegarde puffed his (Bellegarde) cigar again in silence.

``For myself,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said at last,
``I am entirely at your service. Anything I can do for you I shall be very happy to do. Call upon me at your convenience. Is there anyone you desire to know--anything you wish to see? It is a pity you should not enjoy Paris.'' (he)

``Oh, I do enjoy it!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, good-naturedly.
``I'm much obliged to you.'' (unknown)

``Honestly speaking,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
M. de Bellegarde went on,
``there is something absurd to me in hearing myself make you these offers. They represent a great deal of goodwill, but they represent little else. You are a successful man and I am a failure, and it's a turning of the tables to talk as if I could lend you a hand.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``In what way are you a failure?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``Oh, I'm not a tragical failure!'' (the man)
cried the young man with a laugh.
``I have fallen from a height, and my fiasco has made no noise. You, evidently, are a success. You have made a fortune, you have built up an edifice, you are a financial, commercial power, you can travel about the world until you have found a soft spot, and lie down in it with the consciousness of having earned your rest. Is not that true? Well, imagine the exact reverse of all that, and you have me. I have done nothing--I can do nothing!'' (unknown)

``Why not?'' (unknown)

``It's a long story. Some day I will tell you. Meanwhile, I'm right, eh? You are a success? You have made a fortune? It's none of my business, but, in short, you are rich?'' (unknown)

``That's another thing that it sounds foolish to say,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Hang it, no man is rich!'' (unknown)

``I have heard philosophers affirm,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
laughed M. de Bellegarde,
``that no man was poor; but your formula strikes me as an improvement. As a general thing, I confess, I don't like successful people, and I find clever men who have made great fortunes very offensive. They tread on my toes; they make me uncomfortable. But as soon as I saw you, I said to myself. `Ah, there is a man with whom I shall get on. He (man) has the good-nature of success and none of the _morgue_; he (man) has not our confoundedly irritable French vanity.' In short, I took a fancy to you. We are very different, I'm sure; I don't believe there is a subject on which we think or feel alike. But I rather think we shall get on, for there is such a thing, you know, as being too different to quarrel.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``Oh, I never quarrel,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Never! Sometimes it's a duty--or at least it's a pleasure. Oh, I have had two or three delicious quarrels in my day!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
and M. de Bellegarde's handsome smile assumed, at the memory of these incidents, an almost voluptuous intensity.

With the preamble embodied in his (Newman) share of the foregoing fragment of dialogue, he (Newman) paid our hero a long visit; as the two men sat with their heels on Newman's glowing hearth, they heard the small hours of the morning striking larger from a far-off belfry. Valentin de Bellegarde was, by his (Bellegarde) own confession, at all times a great chatterer, and on this occasion he (Bellegarde) was evidently in a particularly loquacious mood. It was a tradition of his (Bellegarde) race that people of its blood always conferred a favor by their smiles, and as his (Bellegarde) enthusiasms were as rare as his (Bellegarde) civility was constant, he (Bellegarde) had a double reason for not suspecting that his (Bellegarde) friendship could ever be importunate. Moreover, the flower of an ancient stem as he (Bellegarde) was, tradition -LRB-since I have used the word-RRB- had in his (Bellegarde) temperament nothing of disagreeable rigidity. It was muffled in sociability and urbanity, as an old dowager in her (their) laces and strings of pearls. Valentin was what is called in France a _gentilhomme_, of the purest source, and his (Valentin) rule of life, so far as it was definite, was to play the part of a _gentilhomme_. This, it seemed to him (Valentin), was enough to occupy comfortably a young man of ordinary good parts. But all that he (man) was he (man) was by instinct and not by theory, and the amiability of his (man) character was so great that certain of the aristocratic virtues, which in some aspects seem rather brittle and trenchant, acquired in his (man) application of them an extreme geniality. In his (man) younger years he (man) had been suspected of low tastes, and his (man) mother had greatly feared he (man) would make a slip in the mud of the highway and bespatter the family shield. He (man) had been treated, therefore, to more than his (man) share of schooling and drilling, but his (man) instructors had not succeeded in mounting him (man) upon stilts. They could not spoil his (man) safe spontaneity, and he (man) remained the least cautious and the most lucky of young nobles. He (man) had been tied with so short a rope in his (man) youth that he (man) had now a mortal grudge against family discipline. He (man) had been known to say, within the limits of the family, that, light-headed as he (man) was, the honor of the name was safer in his (man) hands than in those of some of its other members, and that if a day ever came to try it, they should see. His (man) talk was an odd mixture of almost boyish garrulity and of the reserve and discretion of the man of the world, and he (man) seemed to Newman, as afterwards young members of the Latin races often seemed to him (man), now amusingly juvenile and now appallingly mature. In America, Newman reflected, lads of twenty-five and thirty have old heads and young hearts, or at least young morals; here they have young heads and very aged hearts, morals the most grizzled and wrinkled.

``What I envy you is your liberty,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
observed M. de Bellegarde,
``your wide range, your freedom to come and go, your not having a lot of people, who take themselves awfully seriously, expecting something of you. I live,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
he (Bellegarde) added with a sigh,
``beneath the eyes of my admirable mother.'' (he)

``It is your own fault; what is to hinder your ranging?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``There is a delightful simplicity in that remark! Everything is to hinder me. To begin with, I have not a penny.'' (unknown)

``I had not a penny when I began to range.'' (unknown)

``Ah, but your poverty was your capital. Being an American, it was impossible you should remain what you were born, and being born poor--do I understand it?--it was therefore inevitable that you should become rich. You were in a position that makes one's mouth water; you looked round you and saw a world full of things you had only to step up to and take hold of. When I was twenty, I looked around me and saw a world with everything ticketed `Hands off!' and the deuce of it was that the ticket seemed meant only for me. I couldn't go into business, I couldn't make money, because I was a Bellegarde. I couldn't go into politics, because I was a Bellegarde--the Bellegardes don't recognize the Bonapartes. I couldn't go into literature, because I was a dunce. I couldn't marry a rich girl, because no Bellegarde had ever married a _roturière_, and it was not proper that I should begin. We shall have to come to it, yet. Marriageable heiresses, _de notre bord_, are not to be had for nothing; it must be name for name, and fortune for fortune. The only thing I could do was to go and fight for the Pope. That I did, punctiliously, and received an apostolic flesh-wound at Castlefidardo. It did neither the Holy Father nor me any good, that I could see. Rome was doubtless a very amusing place in the days of Caligula, but it has sadly fallen off since. I passed three years in the Castle of St. Angelo, and then came back to secular life.'' (unknown)

``So you have no profession--you do nothing,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I do nothing! I am supposed to amuse myself, and, to tell the truth, I have amused myself. One can, if one knows how. But you can't keep it up forever. I am good for another five years, perhaps, but I foresee that after that I shall lose my appetite. Then what shall I do? I think I shall turn monk. Seriously, I think I shall tie a rope round my waist and go into a monastery. It was an old custom, and the old customs were very good. People understood life quite as well as we do. They kept the pot boiling till it cracked, and then they put it on the shelf altogether.'' (unknown)

``Are you very religious?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman, in a tone which gave the inquiry a grotesque effect.

M. de Bellegarde evidently appreciated the comical element in the question, but he (Bellegarde) looked at Newman a moment with extreme soberness.

``I am a very good Catholic. I respect the Church. I adore the blessed Virgin. I fear the Devil.'' (unknown)

``Well, then,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``you are very well fixed. You have got pleasure in the present and religion in the future; what do you complain of?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``It's a part of one's pleasure to complain. There is something in your own circumstances that irritates me. You are the first man I have ever envied. It's singular, but so it is. I have known many men who, besides any factitious advantages that I may possess, had money and brains into the bargain; but somehow they have never disturbed my good-humor. But you have got something that I should have liked to have. It is not money, it is not even brains--though no doubt yours are excellent. It is not your six feet of height, though I should have rather liked to be a couple of inches taller. It's a sort of air you have of being thoroughly at home in the world. When I was a boy, my father told me that it was by such an air as that that people recognized a Bellegarde. He (father) called my attention to it. He (father) didn't advise me to cultivate it; he (father) said that as we grew up it always came of itself. I supposed it had come to me, because I think I have always had the feeling. My place in life was made for me, and it seemed easy to occupy it. But you who, as I understand it, have made your own place, you who, as you told us the other day, have manufactured wash-tubs--you strike me, somehow, as a man who stands at his (man) ease, who looks at things from a height. I fancy you going about the world like a man traveling on a railroad in which he (man) owns a large amount of stock. You make me feel as if I had missed something. What is it?'' (unknown)

``It is the proud consciousness of honest toil--of having manufactured a few wash-tubs,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, at once jocose and serious.

``Oh no; I have seen men who had done even more, men who had made not only wash-tubs, but soap--strong-smelling yellow soap, in great bars; and they never made me the least uncomfortable.'' (unknown)

``Then it's the privilege of being an American citizen,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``That sets a man up.'' (unknown)

``Possibly,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
rejoined M. de Bellegarde.
``But I am forced to say that I have seen a great many American citizens who didn't seem at all set up or in the least like large stock-holders. I never envied them. I rather think the thing is an accomplishment of your own.'' (unknown)

``Oh, come,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``you will make me proud!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``No, I shall not. You have nothing to do with pride, or with humility--that is a part of this easy manner of yours. People are proud only when they have something to lose, and humble when they have something to gain.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what I have to lose,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``but I certainly have something to gain.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``What is it?'' (visitor)
asked his (Newman) visitor.

Newman hesitated a while.

``I will tell you when I know you better.'' (unknown)

``I hope that will be soon! Then, if I can help you to gain it, I shall be happy.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps you may,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Don't forget, then, that I am your servant,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
M. de Bellegarde answered; and shortly afterwards he (Bellegarde) took his (Bellegarde) departure.

During the next three weeks Newman saw Bellegarde several times, and without formally swearing an eternal friendship the two men established a sort of comradeship. To Newman, Bellegarde was the ideal Frenchman, the Frenchman of tradition and romance, so far as our hero was concerned with these mystical influences. Gallant, expansive, amusing, more pleased himself with the effect he (Gallant) produced than those -LRB-even when they were well pleased-RRB- for whom he (Gallant) produced it; a master of all the distinctively social virtues and a votary of all agreeable sensations; a devotee of something mysterious and sacred to which he (devotee) occasionally alluded in terms more ecstatic even than those in which he (devotee) spoke of the last pretty woman, and which was simply the beautiful though somewhat superannuated image of _honor_; he (devotee) was irresistibly entertaining and enlivening, and he (devotee) formed a character to which Newman was as capable of doing justice when he (Newman) had once been placed in contact with it, as he (Newman) was unlikely, in musing upon the possible mixtures of our human ingredients, mentally to have foreshadowed it. Bellegarde did not in the least cause him (Bellegarde) to modify his (Bellegarde) needful premise that all Frenchmen are of a frothy and imponderable substance; he (Bellegarde) simply reminded him (Bellegarde) that light materials may be beaten up into a most agreeable compound. No two companions could be more different, but their differences made a capital basis for a friendship of which the distinctive characteristic was that it was extremely amusing to each.

Valentin de Bellegarde lived in the basement of an old house in the Rue d’Anjou St. Honoré, and his (Bellegarde) small apartments lay between the court of the house and an old garden which spread itself behind it--one of those large, sunless humid gardens into which you look unexpectingly in Paris from back windows, wondering how among the grudging habitations they find their space. When Newman returned Bellegarde's visit, he (Newman) hinted that _his (Newman)_ lodging was at least as much a laughing matter as his (Newman) own. But its oddities were of a different cast from those of our hero's gilded saloons on the Boulevard Haussmann: the place was low, dusky, contracted, and crowded with curious bric-à-brac. Bellegarde, penniless patrician as he (Bellegarde) was, was an insatiable collector, and his (Bellegarde) walls were covered with rusty arms and ancient panels and platters, his (Bellegarde) doorways draped in faded tapestries, his (Bellegarde) floors muffled in the skins of beasts. Here and there was one of those uncomfortable tributes to elegance in which the upholsterer's art, in France, is so prolific; a curtain recess with a sheet of looking-glass in which, among the shadows, you could see nothing; a divan on which, for its festoons and furbelows, you could not sit; a fireplace draped, flounced, and frilled to the complete exclusion of fire. The young man's possessions were in picturesque disorder, and his (man) apartment was pervaded by the odor of cigars, mingled with perfumes more inscrutable. Newman thought it a damp, gloomy place to live in, and was puzzled by the obstructive and fragmentary character of the furniture.

Bellegarde, according to the custom of his (Bellegarde) country talked very generously about himself, and unveiled the mysteries of his (Bellegarde) private history with an unsparing hand. Inevitably, he (Bellegarde) had a vast deal to say about women, and he (Bellegarde) used frequently to indulge in sentimental and ironical apostrophes to these authors of his (Bellegarde) joys and woes.

``Oh, the women, the women, and the things they have made me do!'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) would exclaim with a lustrous eye.
``_C’est égal_, of all the follies and stupidities I have committed for them I would not have missed one!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
On this subject Newman maintained an habitual reserve; to expatiate largely upon it had always seemed to him (Newman) a proceeding vaguely analogous to the cooing of pigeons and the chattering of monkeys, and even inconsistent with a fully developed human character. But Bellegarde's confidences greatly amused him (Bellegarde), and rarely displeased him (Bellegarde), for the generous young Frenchman was not a cynic.
``I really think,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) had once said,
``that I am not more depraved than most of my contemporaries. They are tolerably depraved, my contemporaries!'' (he)
He (Bellegarde) said wonderfully pretty things about his (Bellegarde) female friends, and, numerous and various as they had been, declared that on the whole there was more good in them than harm.
``But you are not to take that as advice,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) added.
``As an authority I am very untrustworthy. I'm prejudiced in their favor; I'm an _idealist!_'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman listened to him (Newman) with his (Newman) impartial smile, and was glad, for his (Newman) own sake, that he (Newman) had fine feelings; but he (Newman) mentally repudiated the idea of a Frenchman having discovered any merit in the amiable sex which he (Newman) himself did not suspect. M. de Bellegarde, however, did not confine his (Bellegarde) conversation to the autobiographical channel; he (Bellegarde) questioned our hero largely as to the events of his (Bellegarde) own life, and Newman told him (Newman) some better stories than any that Bellegarde carried in his (Bellegarde) budget.
