He (Bellegarde) narrated his (Bellegarde) career, in fact, from the beginning, through all its variations, and whenever his (Bellegarde) companion's credulity, or his (Bellegarde) habits of gentility, appeared to protest, it amused him (Bellegarde) to heighten the color of the episode. Newman had sat with Western humorists in knots, round cast-iron stoves, and seen
``tall'' (humorists stoves)
stories grow taller without toppling over, and his (Newman) own imagination had learned the trick of piling up consistent wonders. Bellegarde's regular attitude at last became that of laughing self-defense; to maintain his (Bellegarde) reputation as an all-knowing Frenchman, he (Bellegarde) doubted of everything, wholesale. The result of this was that Newman found it impossible to convince him (Newman) of certain time-honored verities.

``But the details don't matter,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde.
``You have evidently had some surprising adventures; you have seen some strange sides of life, you have revolved to and fro over a whole continent as I walked up and down the Boulevard. You are a man of the world with a vengeance! You have spent some deadly dull hours, and you have done some extremely disagreeable things: you have shoveled sand, as a boy, for supper, and you have eaten roast dog in a gold-diggers' camp. You have stood casting up figures for ten hours at a time, and you have sat through Methodist sermons for the sake of looking at a pretty girl in another pew. All that is rather stiff, as we say. But at any rate you have done something and you are something; you have used your will and you have made your fortune. You have not stupified yourself with debauchery and you have not mortgaged your fortune to social conveniences. You take things easily, and you have fewer prejudices even than I, who pretend to have none, but who in reality have three or four. Happy man, you are strong and you are free. But what the deuce,'' (the man)
demanded the young man in conclusion,
``do you propose to do with such advantages? Really to use them you need a better world than this. There is nothing worth your while here.'' (the man)

``Oh, I think there is something,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``What is it?'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
murmured Newman,
``I will tell you some other time!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

In this way our hero delayed from day to day broaching a subject which he (Newman) had very much at heart. Meanwhile, however, he (Newman) was growing practically familiar with it; in other words, he (Newman) had called again, three times, on Madame de Cintré. On only two of these occasions had he (Newman) found her (Newman) at home, and on each of them she (Newman) had other visitors. Her (Newman) visitors were numerous and extremely loquacious, and they exacted much of their hostess's attention. She (Newman) found time, however, to bestow a little of it on Newman, in an occasional vague smile, the very vagueness of which pleased him (Newman), allowing him (Newman) as it did to fill it out mentally, both at the time and afterwards, with such meanings as most pleased him (Newman). He (Newman) sat by without speaking, looking at the entrances and exits, the greetings and chatterings, of Madame de Cintré's visitors. He (Newman) felt as if he (Newman) were at the play, and as if his (Newman) own speaking would be an interruption; sometimes he (Newman) wished he (Newman) had a book, to follow the dialogue; he (Newman) half expected to see a woman in a white cap and pink ribbons come and offer him (Newman) one for two francs. Some of the ladies looked at him (Newman) very hard--or very soft, as you please; others seemed profoundly unconscious of his (Newman) presence. The men looked only at Madame de Cintré. This was inevitable; for whether one called her (woman) beautiful or not, she (woman) entirely occupied and filled one's vision, just as an agreeable sound fills one's ear. Newman had but twenty distinct words with her (woman), but he (Newman) carried away an impression to which solemn promises could not have given a higher value. She (woman) was part of the play that he (Newman) was seeing acted, quite as much as her (woman) companions; but how she (woman) filled the stage and how much better she (woman) did it! Whether she (woman) rose or seated herself; whether she (woman) went with her (woman) departing friends to the door and lifted up the heavy curtain as they passed out, and stood an instant looking after them and giving them the last nod; or whether she (woman) leaned back in her (woman) chair with her (woman) arms crossed and her (woman) eyes resting, listening and smiling; she (woman) gave Newman the feeling that he (Newman) should like to have her (woman) always before him (Newman), moving slowly to and fro along the whole scale of expressive hospitality. If it might be _to_ him (Newman), it would be well; if it might be _for_ him (Newman), it would be still better! She (woman) was so tall and yet so light, so active and yet so still, so elegant and yet so simple, so frank and yet so mysterious! It was the mystery--it was what she (woman) was off the stage, as it were--that interested Newman most of all. He (Newman) could not have told you what warrant he (Newman) had for talking about mysteries; if it had been his (Newman) habit to express himself in poetic figures he (Newman) might have said that in observing Madame de Cintré he (Newman) seemed to see the vague circle which sometimes accompanies the partly-filled disk of the moon. It was not that she (woman) was reserved; on the contrary, she (woman) was as frank as flowing water. But he (Newman) was sure she (woman) had qualities which she (woman) herself did not suspect.

He (Newman) had abstained for several reasons from saying some of these things to Bellegarde. One reason was that before proceeding to any act he (Bellegarde) was always circumspect, conjectural, contemplative; he (Bellegarde) had little eagerness, as became a man who felt that whenever he (Bellegarde) really began to move he (Bellegarde) walked with long steps. And then, it simply pleased him (Bellegarde) not to speak--it occupied him (Bellegarde), it excited him (Bellegarde). But one day Bellegarde had been dining with him (Bellegarde), at a restaurant, and they had sat long over their dinner. On rising from it, Bellegarde proposed that, to help them through the rest of the evening, they should go and see Madame Dandelard. Madame Dandelard was a little Italian lady who had married a Frenchman who proved to be a rake and a brute and the torment of her (lady) life. Her (lady) husband had spent all her (lady) money, and then, lacking the means of obtaining more expensive pleasures, had taken, in his (husband) duller hours, to beating her (lady). She (lady) had a blue spot somewhere, which she (lady) showed to several persons, including Bellegarde. She (lady) had obtained a separation from her (lady) husband, collected the scraps of her (lady) fortune -LRB-they were very meagre-RRB- and come to live in Paris, where she (lady) was staying at a _hôtel garni_. She (lady) was always looking for an apartment, and visiting, inquiringly, those of other people. She (lady) was very pretty, very childlike, and she (lady) made very extraordinary remarks. Bellegarde had made her (lady) acquaintance, and the source of his (Bellegarde) interest in her (lady) was, according to his (Bellegarde) own declaration, a curiosity as to what would become of her (lady).

``She (you) is poor, she (you) is pretty, and she (you) is silly,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said,
``it seems to me she (you) can go only one way. It's a pity, but it can't be helped. I will give her (you) six months. She (you) has nothing to fear from me, but I am watching the process. I am curious to see just how things will go. Yes, I know what you are going to say: this horrible Paris hardens one's heart. But it quickens one's wits, and it ends by teaching one a refinement of observation! To see this little woman's little drama play itself out, now, is, for me, an intellectual pleasure.'' (he)

``If she (woman) is going to throw herself away,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman had said,
``you ought to stop her (woman).'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Stop her (woman)? How stop her (woman)?'' (unknown)

``Talk to her (woman); give her (woman) some good advice.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde laughed.

``Heaven deliver us both! Imagine the situation! Go and advise her (woman) yourself.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

It was after this that Newman had gone with Bellegarde to see Madame Dandelard. When they came away, Bellegarde reproached his (Bellegarde) companion.

``Where was your famous advice?'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) asked.
``I didn't hear a word of it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I give it up,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, simply.

``Then you are as bad as I!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde.

``No, because I don't take an `intellectual pleasure' in her (woman) prospective adventures. I don't in the least want to see her (woman) going down hill. I had rather look the other way. But why,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) asked, in a moment,
``don't you get your sister to go and see her (sister)?'' (he)

Bellegarde stared.

``Go and see Madame Dandelard--my sister?'' (unknown)

``She (sister) might talk to her (sister) to very good purpose.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde shook his (Bellegarde) head with sudden gravity.

``My sister can't see that sort of person. Madame Dandelard is nothing at all; they would never meet.'' (unknown)

``I should think,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``that your sister might see whom she (sister) pleased.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) privately resolved that after he (Newman) knew her (lady) a little better he (Newman) would ask Madame de Cintré to go and talk to the foolish little Italian lady.

After his (Cintré) dinner with Bellegarde, on the occasion I have mentioned, he (Bellegarde) demurred to his (Bellegarde) companion's proposal that they should go again and listen to Madame Dandelard describe her (lady) sorrows and her (lady) bruises.

``I have something better in mind,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said;
``come home with me and finish the evening before my fire.'' (he)

Bellegarde always welcomed the prospect of a long stretch of conversation, and before long the two men sat watching the great blaze which scattered its scintillations over the high adornments of Newman's ball-room.

CHAPTER VIII

``Tell me something about your sister,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman began abruptly.

Bellegarde turned and gave him (Bellegarde) a quick look.

``Now that I think of it, you have never yet asked me a question about her (sister).'' (unknown)

``I know that very well.'' (unknown)

``If it is because you don't trust me, you are very right,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde.
``I can't talk of her (sister) rationally. I admire her (sister) too much.'' (unknown)

``Talk of her (sister) as you can,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
rejoined Newman.
``Let yourself go.'' (unknown)

``Well, we are very good friends; we are such a brother and sister as have not been seen since Orestes and Electra. You have seen her (Electra); you know what she (Electra) is: tall, thin, light, imposing, and gentle, half a _grande dame_ and half an angel; a mixture of pride and humility, of the eagle and the dove. She (Electra) looks like a statue which had failed as stone, resigned itself to its grave defects, and come to life as flesh and blood, to wear white capes and long trains. All I can say is that she (Electra) really possesses every merit that her (Electra) face, her (Electra) glance, her (Electra) smile, the tone of her (Electra) voice, lead you to expect; it is saying a great deal. As a general thing, when a woman seems very charming, I should say `Beware!' But in proportion as Claire seems charming you may fold your arms and let yourself float with the current; you are safe. She (Claire) is so good! I have never seen a woman half so perfect or so complete. She (Claire) has everything; that is all I can say about her (Claire). There!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
Bellegarde concluded;
``I told you I should rhapsodize.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Newman was silent a while, as if he (Newman) were turning over his (Newman) companion's words.

``She (Claire) is very good, eh?'' (he)
he (Newman) repeated at last.

``Divinely good!'' (unknown)

``Kind, charitable, gentle, generous?'' (unknown)

``Generosity itself; kindness double-distilled!'' (unknown)

``Is she (Claire) clever?'' (unknown)

``She (Claire) is the most intelligent woman I know. Try her (Claire), some day, with something difficult, and you will see.'' (unknown)

``Is she (Claire) fond of admiration?'' (unknown)

``_Parbleu!_'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
cried Bellegarde;
``what woman is not?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``Ah, when they are too fond of admiration they commit all kinds of follies to get it.'' (unknown)

``I did not say she (woman) was too fond!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
Bellegarde exclaimed.
``Heaven forbid I should say anything so idiotic. She (woman) is not _too_ anything! If I were to say she (woman) was ugly, I should not mean she (woman) was too ugly. She (woman) is fond of pleasing, and if you are pleased she (woman) is grateful. If you are not pleased, she (woman) lets it pass and thinks the worst neither of you nor of herself. I imagine, though, she (woman) hopes the saints in heaven are, for I am sure she (woman) is incapable of trying to please by any means of which they would disapprove.'' (unknown)

``Is she (woman) grave or gay?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``She (woman) is both; not alternately, for she (woman) is always the same. There is gravity in her (woman) gaiety, and gaiety in her (woman) gravity. But there is no reason why she (woman) should be particularly gay.'' (unknown)

``Is she (woman) unhappy?'' (unknown)

``I won't say that, for unhappiness is according as one takes things, and Claire takes them according to some receipt communicated to her (Claire) by the Blessed Virgin in a vision. To be unhappy is to be disagreeable, which, for her (Claire), is out of the question. So she (Claire) has arranged her (Claire) circumstances so as to be happy in them.'' (unknown)

``She (Claire) is a philosopher,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``No, she (Claire) is simply a very nice woman.'' (unknown)

``Her (Claire) circumstances, at any rate, have been disagreeable?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde hesitated a moment--a thing he (Bellegarde) very rarely did.

``Oh, my dear fellow, if I go into the history of my family I shall give you more than you bargain for.'' (unknown)

``No, on the contrary, I bargain for that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``We shall have to appoint a special séance, then, beginning early. Suffice it for the present that Claire has not slept on roses. She (Claire) made at eighteen a marriage that was expected to be brilliant, but that turned out like a lamp that goes out; all smoke and bad smell. M. de Cintré was sixty years old, and an odious old gentleman. He (Cintré) lived, however, but a short time, and after his (Cintré) death his (Cintré) family pounced upon his (Cintré) money, brought a lawsuit against his (Cintré) widow, and pushed things very hard. Their case was a good one, for M. de Cintré, who had been trustee for some of his (Cintré) relatives, appeared to have been guilty of some very irregular practices. In the course of the suit some revelations were made as to his (Cintré) private history which my sister found so displeasing that she (sister) ceased to defend herself and washed her (sister) hands of the property. This required some pluck, for she (sister) was between two fires, her (sister) husband's family opposing her (sister) and her (sister) own family forcing her (sister). My mother and my brother wished her (mother) to cleave to what they regarded as her (mother) rights. But she (mother) resisted firmly, and at last bought her (mother) freedom--obtained my mother's assent to dropping the suit at the price of a promise.'' (unknown)

``What was the promise?'' (unknown)

``To do anything else, for the next ten years, that was asked of her (mother)--anything, that is, but marry.'' (unknown)

``She (mother) had disliked her (mother) husband very much?'' (unknown)

``No one knows how much!'' (unknown)

``The marriage had been made in your horrible French way,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman continued,
``made by the two families, without her (mother) having any voice?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``It was a chapter for a novel. She (mother) saw M. de Cintré for the first time a month before the wedding, after everything, to the minutest detail, had been arranged. She (mother) turned white when she (mother) looked at him (husband), and white she (mother) remained till her (mother) wedding-day. The evening before the ceremony she (mother) swooned away, and she (mother) spent the whole night in sobs. My mother sat holding her (mother) two hands, and my brother walked up and down the room. I declared it was revolting and told my sister publicly that if she (sister) would refuse, downright, I would stand by her (sister). I was told to go about my business, and she (sister) became Comtesse de Cintré.'' (unknown)

``Your brother,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, reflectively,
``must be a very nice young man.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``He (man) is very nice, though he (man) is not young. He (man) is upward of fifty, fifteen years my senior. He (man) has been a father to my sister and me. He (man) is a very remarkable man; he (man) has the best manners in France. He (man) is extremely clever; indeed he (man) is very learned. He (man) is writing a history of The Princesses of France Who Never Married.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
This was said by Bellegarde with extreme gravity, looking straight at Newman, and with an eye that betokened no mental reservation; or that, at least, almost betokened none.

Newman perhaps discovered there what little there was, for he (Newman) presently said,

``You don't love your brother.'' (he)

``I beg your pardon,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde, ceremoniously;
``well-bred people always love their brothers.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``Well, I don't love him (brother), then!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered.

``Wait till you know him (brother)!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
rejoined Bellegarde, and this time he (Newman) smiled.

``Is your mother also very remarkable?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked, after a pause.

``For my mother,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde, now with intense gravity,
``I have the highest admiration. She (mother) is a very extraordinary woman. You cannot approach her (mother) without perceiving it.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``She (mother) is the daughter, I believe, of an English nobleman.'' (unknown)

``Of the Earl of St. Dunstan's.'' (unknown)

``Is the Earl of St. Dunstan's a very old family?'' (unknown)

``So-so; the sixteenth century. It is on my father's side that we go back--back, back, back. The family antiquaries themselves lose breath. At last they stop, panting and fanning themselves, somewhere in the ninth century, under Charlemagne. That is where we begin.'' (unknown)

``There is no mistake about it?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I'm sure I hope not. We have been mistaken at least for several centuries.'' (unknown)

``And you have always married into old families?'' (unknown)

``As a rule; though in so long a stretch of time there have been some exceptions. Three or four Bellegardes, in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, took wives out of the _bourgeoisie_--married lawyers' daughters.'' (unknown)

``A lawyer's daughter; that's very bad, is it?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``Horrible! one of us, in the Middle Ages, did better: he (lawyer) married a beggar-maid, like King Cophetua. That was really better; it was like marrying a bird or a monkey; one didn't have to think about her (daughter) family at all. Our women have always done well; they have never even gone into the _petite noblesse_. There is, I believe, not a case on record of a misalliance among the women.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman turned this over for a while, and, then at last he (Newman) said,

``You offered, the first time you came to see me to render me any service you could. I told you that some time I would mention something you might do. Do you remember?'' (he)

``Remember? I have been counting the hours.'' (unknown)

``Very well; here's your chance. Do what you can to make your sister think well of me.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde stared, with a smile.

``Why, I'm sure she (sister) thinks as well of you as possible, already.'' (unknown)

``An opinion founded on seeing me three or four times? That is putting me off with very little. I want something more. I have been thinking of it a good deal, and at last I have decided to tell you. I should like very much to marry Madame de Cintré.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde had been looking at him (Bellegarde) with quickened expectancy, and with the smile with which he (Bellegarde) had greeted Newman's allusion to his (Newman) promised request. At this last announcement he (Newman) continued to gaze; but his (Newman) smile went through two or three curious phases. It felt, apparently, a momentary impulse to broaden; but this it immediately checked. Then it remained for some instants taking counsel with itself, at the end of which it decreed a retreat. It slowly effaced itself and left a look of seriousness modified by the desire not to be rude. Extreme surprise had come into the Count Valentin's face; but he (Valentin) had reflected that it would be uncivil to leave it there. And yet, what the deuce was he (Valentin) to do with it? He (Valentin) got up, in his (Valentin) agitation, and stood before the chimney-piece, still looking at Newman. He (Newman) was a longer time thinking what to say than one would have expected.

``If you can't render me the service I ask,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``say it out!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Let me hear it again, distinctly,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde.
``It's very important, you know. I shall plead your cause with my sister, because you want--you want to marry her (sister)? That's it, eh?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't say plead my cause, exactly; I shall try and do that myself. But say a good word for me, now and then--let her (sister) know that you think well of me.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

At this, Bellegarde gave a little light laugh.

``What I want chiefly, after all,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman went on,
``is just to let you know what I have in mind. I suppose that is what you expect, isn't it? I want to do what is customary over here. If there is anything particular to be done, let me know and I will do it. I wouldn't for the world approach Madame de Cintré without all the proper forms. If I ought to go and tell your mother, why I will go and tell her (mother). I will go and tell your brother, even. I will go and tell anyone you please. As I don't know anyone else, I begin by telling you. But that, if it is a social obligation, is a pleasure as well.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Yes, I see--I see,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde, lightly stroking his (Bellegarde) chin.
``You have a very right feeling about it, but I'm glad you have begun with me.'' (He)
He (Bellegarde) paused, hesitated, and then turned away and walked slowly the length of the room. Newman got up and stood leaning against the mantel-shelf, with his (Newman) hands in his (Newman) pockets, watching Bellegarde's promenade. The young Frenchman came back and stopped in front of him (Frenchman).
``I give it up,'' (he)
he (Frenchman) said;
``I will not pretend I am not surprised. I am--hugely! _Ouf!_ It's a relief.'' (he)

``That sort of news is always a surprise,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``No matter what you have done, people are never prepared. But if you are so surprised, I hope at least you are pleased.'' (unknown)

``Come!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde.
``I am going to be tremendously frank. I don't know whether I am pleased or horrified.'' (unknown)

``If you are pleased, I shall be glad,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``and I shall be--encouraged. If you are horrified, I shall be sorry, but I shall not be discouraged. You must make the best of it.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``That is quite right--that is your only possible attitude. You are perfectly serious?'' (unknown)

``Am I a Frenchman, that I should not be?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.
``But why is it, by the bye, that you should be horrified?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde raised his (Bellegarde) hand to the back of his (Bellegarde) head and rubbed his (Bellegarde) hair quickly up and down, thrusting out the tip of his (Bellegarde) tongue as he (Bellegarde) did so.

``Why, you are not noble, for instance,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.

``The devil I am not!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
exclaimed Newman.

``Oh,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde a little more seriously,
``I did not know you had a title.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``A title? What do you mean by a title?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.
``A count, a duke, a marquis? I don't know anything about that, I don't know who is and who is not. But I say I am noble. I don't exactly know what you mean by it, but it's a fine word and a fine idea; I put in a claim to it.'' (unknown)

``But what have you to show, my dear fellow, what proofs?'' (unknown)

``Anything you please! But you don't suppose I am going to undertake to prove that I am noble. It is for you to prove the contrary.'' (unknown)

``That's easily done. You have manufactured wash-tubs.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman stared a moment.

``Therefore I am not noble? I don't see it. Tell me something I have _not_ done--something I cannot do.'' (unknown)

``You cannot marry a woman like Madame de Cintré for the asking.'' (unknown)

``I believe you mean,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman slowly,
``that I am not good enough.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Brutally speaking--yes!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde had hesitated a moment, and while he (Newman) hesitated Newman's attentive glance had grown somewhat eager. In answer to these last words he (Newman) for a moment said nothing. He (Newman) simply blushed a little. Then he (Newman) raised his (Newman) eyes to the ceiling and stood looking at one of the rosy cherubs that was painted upon it.

``Of course I don't expect to marry any woman for the asking,'' (he)
he (Newman) said at last;
``I expect first to make myself acceptable to her (woman). She (woman) must like me, to begin with. But that I am not good enough to make a trial is rather a surprise.'' (he)

Bellegarde wore a look of mingled perplexity, sympathy, and amusement.

``You should not hesitate, then, to go up to-morrow and ask a duchess to marry you?'' (unknown)

``Not if I thought she (duchess) would suit me. But I am very fastidious; she (duchess) might not at all.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde's amusement began to prevail.

``And you should be surprised if she (duchess) refused you?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman hesitated a moment.

``It sounds conceited to say yes, but nevertheless I think I should. For I should make a very handsome offer.'' (unknown)

``What would it be?'' (unknown)

``Everything she (duchess) wishes. If I get hold of a woman that comes up to my standard, I shall think nothing too good for her (duchess). I have been a long time looking, and I find such women are rare. To combine the qualities I require seems to be difficult, but when the difficulty is vanquished it deserves a reward. My wife shall have a good position, and I'm not afraid to say that I shall be a good husband.'' (unknown)

``And these qualities that you require--what are they?'' (unknown)

``Goodness, beauty, intelligence, a fine education, personal elegance--everything, in a word, that makes a splendid woman.'' (unknown)

``And noble birth, evidently,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde.

``Oh, throw that in, by all means, if it's there. The more the better!'' (unknown)

``And my sister seems to you to have all these things?'' (unknown)

``She (sister) is exactly what I have been looking for. She (sister) is my dream realized.'' (unknown)

``And you would make her (sister) a very good husband?'' (unknown)

``That is what I wanted you to tell her (sister).'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde laid his (Bellegarde) hand on his (Bellegarde) companion's arm a moment, looked at him (Bellegarde) with his (Bellegarde) head on one side, from head to foot, and then, with a loud laugh, and shaking the other hand in the air, turned away. He (Bellegarde) walked again the length of the room, and again he (Bellegarde) came back and stationed himself in front of Newman.

``All this is very interesting--it is very curious. In what I said just now I was speaking, not for myself, but for my tradition, my superstitions. For myself, really, your proposal tickles me. It startled me at first, but the more I think of it the more I see in it. It's no use attempting to explain anything; you won't understand me. After all, I don't see why you need; it's no great loss.'' (unknown)

``Oh, if there is anything more to explain, try it! I want to proceed with my eyes open. I will do my best to understand.'' (unknown)

``No,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde,
``it's disagreeable to me; I give it up. I liked you the first time I saw you, and I will abide by that. It would be quite odious for me to come talking to you as if I could patronize you. I have told you before that I envy you; _vous m'imposez_, as we say. I didn't know you much until within five minutes. So we will let things go, and I will say nothing to you that, if our positions were reversed, you would not say to me.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

I do not know whether in renouncing the mysterious opportunity to which he (Bellegarde) alluded, Bellegarde felt that he (Bellegarde) was doing something very generous. If so, he (Bellegarde) was not rewarded; his (Bellegarde) generosity was not appreciated. Newman quite failed to recognize the young Frenchman's power to wound his (Newman) feelings, and he (Newman) had now no sense of escaping or coming off easily. He (Newman) did not thank his (Newman) companion even with a glance.

``My eyes are open, though,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``so far as that you have practically told me that your family and your friends will turn up their noses at me. I have never thought much about the reasons that make it proper for people to turn up their noses, and so I can only decide the question off-hand. Looking at it in that way I can't see anything in it. I simply think, if you want to know, that I'm as good as the best. Who the best are, I don't pretend to say. I have never thought much about that either. To tell the truth, I have always had rather a good opinion of myself; a man who is successful can't help it. But I will admit that I was conceited. What I don't say yes to is that I don't stand high--as high as anyone else. This is a line of speculation I should not have chosen, but you must remember you began it yourself. I should never have dreamed that I was on the defensive, or that I had to justify myself; but if your people will have it so, I will do my best.'' (he)

``But you offered, a while ago, to make your court as we say, to my mother and my brother.'' (unknown)

``Damn it!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman,
``I want to be polite.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Good!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
rejoined Bellegarde;
``this will go far, it will be very entertaining. Excuse my speaking of it in that cold-blooded fashion, but the matter must, of necessity, be for me something of a spectacle. It's positively exciting. But apart from that I sympathize with you, and I shall be actor, so far as I can, as well as spectator. You are a capital fellow; I believe in you and I back you. The simple fact that you appreciate my sister will serve as the proof I was asking for. All men are equal--especially men of taste!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``Do you think,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman presently,
``that Madame de Cintré is determined not to marry?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``That is my impression. But that is not against you; it's for you to make her (sister) change her (sister) mind.'' (unknown)

``I am afraid it will be hard,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, gravely.

``I don't think it will be easy. In a general way I don't see why a widow should ever marry again. She (widow) has gained the benefits of matrimony--freedom and consideration--and she (widow) has got rid of the drawbacks. Why should she (widow) put her (widow) head into the noose again? Her (widow) usual motive is ambition: if a man can offer her (widow) a great position, make her (widow) a princess or an ambassadress she (widow) may think the compensation sufficient.'' (unknown)

``And--in that way--is Madame de Cintré ambitious?'' (unknown)

``Who knows?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde, with a profound shrug.
``I don't pretend to say all that she (widow) is or all that she (widow) is not. I think she (widow) might be touched by the prospect of becoming the wife of a great man. But in a certain way, I believe, whatever she (widow) does will be the _improbable_. Don't be too confident, but don't absolutely doubt. Your best chance for success will be precisely in being, to her (widow) mind, unusual, unexpected, original. Don't try to be anyone else; be simply yourself, out and out. Something or other can't fail to come of it; I am very curious to see what.'' (unknown)

``I am much obliged to you for your advice,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``And,'' (he)
he (Newman) added with a smile,
``I am glad, for your sake, I am going to be so amusing.'' (he)

``It will be more than amusing,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde;
``it will be inspiring. I look at it from my point of view, and you from yours. After all, anything for a change! And only yesterday I was yawning so as to dislocate my jaw, and declaring that there was nothing new under the sun! If it isn't new to see you come into the family as a suitor, I am very much mistaken. Let me say that, my dear fellow; I won't call it anything else, bad or good; I will simply call it _new_.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
And overcome with a sense of the novelty thus foreshadowed, Valentin de Bellegarde threw himself into a deep armchair before the fire, and, with a fixed, intense smile, seemed to read a vision of it in the flame of the logs. After a while he (Bellegarde) looked up.
``Go ahead, my boy; you have my good wishes,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.
``But it is really a pity you don't understand me, that you don't know just what I am doing.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing,
``don't do anything wrong. Leave me to myself, rather, or defy me, out and out. I wouldn't lay any load on your conscience.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Bellegarde sprang up again; he (Bellegarde) was evidently excited; there was a warmer spark even than usual in his (Bellegarde) eye.

``You never will understand--you never will know,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said;
``and if you succeed, and I turn out to have helped you, you will never be grateful, not as I shall deserve you should be. You will be an excellent fellow always, but you will not be grateful. But it doesn't matter, for I shall get my own fun out of it.'' (he)
And he (Bellegarde) broke into an extravagant laugh.
``You look puzzled,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) added;
``you look almost frightened.'' (he)

``It _is_ a pity,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``that I don't understand you. I shall lose some very good jokes.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I told you, you remember, that we were very strange people,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
Bellegarde went on.
``I give you warning again. We are! My mother is strange, my brother is strange, and I verily believe that I am stranger than either. You will even find my sister a little strange. Old trees have crooked branches, old houses have queer cracks, old races have odd secrets. Remember that we are eight hundred years old!'' (unknown)

``Very good,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``that's the sort of thing I came to Europe for. You come into my programme.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``_Touchez-là_, then,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde, putting out his (Bellegarde) hand.
``It's a bargain: I accept you; I espouse your cause. It's because I like you, in a great measure; but that is not the only reason!'' (he)
And he (Bellegarde) stood holding Newman's hand and looking at him (Newman) askance.

``What is the other one?'' (unknown)

``I am in the Opposition. I dislike someone else.'' (unknown)

``Your brother?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman, in his (Newman) unmodulated voice.

Bellegarde laid his (Bellegarde) fingers upon his (Bellegarde) lips with a whispered _hush!_

``Old races have strange secrets!'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.
``Put yourself into motion, come and see my sister, and be assured of my sympathy!'' (he)
And on this he (Bellegarde) took his (Bellegarde) leave.

Newman dropped into a chair before his (Newman) fire, and sat a long time staring into the blaze.

CHAPTER IX

He (Newman) went to see Madame de Cintré the next day, and was informed by the servant that she (Bellegarde) was at home. He (servant) passed as usual up the large, cold staircase and through a spacious vestibule above, where the walls seemed all composed of small door panels, touched with long-faded gilding; whence he (servant) was ushered into the sitting-room in which he (servant) had already been received. It was empty, and the servant told him (servant) that Madame la Comtesse would presently appear. He (servant) had time, while he (servant) waited, to wonder whether Bellegarde had seen his (Bellegarde) sister since the evening before, and whether in this case he (Bellegarde) had spoken to her (sister) of their talk. In this case Madame de Cintré's receiving him (Cintré) was an encouragement. He (Cintré) felt a certain trepidation as he (Cintré) reflected that she (sister) might come in with the knowledge of his (Cintré) supreme admiration and of the project he (Cintré) had built upon it in her (sister) eyes; but the feeling was not disagreeable. Her (sister) face could wear no look that would make it less beautiful, and he (Cintré) was sure beforehand that however she (sister) might take the proposal he (Cintré) had in reserve, she (sister) would not take it in scorn or in irony. He (Cintré) had a feeling that if she (sister) could only read the bottom of his (Cintré) heart and measure the extent of his (Cintré) good will toward her (sister), she (sister) would be entirely kind.

She (sister) came in at last, after so long an interval that he (Cintré) wondered whether she (sister) had been hesitating. She (sister) smiled with her (sister) usual frankness, and held out her (sister) hand; she (sister) looked at him (Cintré) straight with her (sister) soft and luminous eyes, and said, without a tremor in her (sister) voice, that she (sister) was glad to see him (Cintré) and that she (sister) hoped he (Cintré) was well. He (Cintré) found in her (sister) what he (Cintré) had found before--that faint perfume of a personal shyness worn away by contact with the world, but the more perceptible the more closely you approached her (sister). This lingering diffidence seemed to give a peculiar value to what was definite and assured in her (sister) manner; it made it seem like an accomplishment, a beautiful talent, something that one might compare to an exquisite touch in a pianist. It was, in fact, Madame de Cintré's

``authority,'' (Madame de Cintré)
as they say of artists, that especially impressed and fascinated Newman; he (Newman) always came back to the feeling that when he (Newman) should complete himself by taking a wife, that was the way he (Newman) should like his (Newman) wife to interpret him (Newman) to the world. The only trouble, indeed, was that when the instrument was so perfect it seemed to interpose too much between you and the genius that used it. Madame de Cintré gave Newman the sense of an elaborate education, of her (wife) having passed through mysterious ceremonies and processes of culture in her (wife) youth, of her (wife) having been fashioned and made flexible to certain exalted social needs. All this, as I have affirmed, made her (wife) seem rare and precious--a very expensive article, as he (Newman) would have said, and one which a man with an ambition to have everything about him (Newman) of the best would find it highly agreeable to possess. But looking at the matter with an eye to private felicity, Newman wondered where, in so exquisite a compound, nature and art showed their dividing line. Where did the special intention separate from the habit of good manners? Where did urbanity end and sincerity begin? Newman asked himself these questions even while he (Newman) stood ready to accept the admired object in all its complexity; he (Newman) felt that he (Newman) could do so in profound security, and examine its mechanism afterwards, at leisure.

``I am very glad to find you alone,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``You know I have never had such good luck before.'' (unknown)

``But you have seemed before very well contented with your luck,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.
``You have sat and watched my visitors with an air of quiet amusement. What have you thought of them?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I have thought the ladies were very elegant and very graceful, and wonderfully quick at repartee. But what I have chiefly thought has been that they only helped me to admire you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
This was not gallantry on Newman's part--an art in which he (Newman) was quite unversed. It was simply the instinct of the practical man, who had made up his (man) mind what he (man) wanted, and was now beginning to take active steps to obtain it.

Madame de Cintré started slightly, and raised her (Newman) eyebrows; she (Newman) had evidently not expected so fervid a compliment.

``Oh, in that case,'' (she)
she (Newman) said with a laugh,
``your finding me alone is not good luck for me. I hope someone will come in quickly.'' (she)

``I hope not,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I have something particular to say to you. Have you seen your brother?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I saw him (brother) an hour ago.'' (unknown)

``Did he (brother) tell you that he (brother) had seen me last night?'' (unknown)

``He (brother) said so.'' (unknown)

``And did he (brother) tell you what we had talked about?'' (unknown)

Madame de Cintré hesitated a moment. As Newman asked these questions she (Newman) had grown a little pale, as if she (Newman) regarded what was coming as necessary, but not as agreeable.

``Did you give him (brother) a message to me?'' (she)
she (Newman) asked.

``It was not exactly a message--I asked him (brother) to render me a service.'' (unknown)

``The service was to sing your praises, was it not?'' (she)
And she (Newman) accompanied this question with a little smile, as if to make it easier to herself.

``Yes, that is what it really amounts to,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Did he (brother) sing my praises?'' (unknown)

``He (brother) spoke very well of you. But when I know that it was by your special request, of course I must take his (brother) eulogy with a grain of salt.'' (unknown)

``Oh, that makes no difference,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Your brother would not have spoken well of me unless he (brother) believed what he (brother) was saying. He (brother) is too honest for that.'' (unknown)

``Are you very deep?'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.
``Are you trying to please me by praising my brother? I confess it is a good way.'' (unknown)

``For me, any way that succeeds will be good. I will praise your brother all day, if that will help me. He (brother) is a noble little fellow. He (brother) has made me feel, in promising to do what he (brother) can to help me, that I can depend upon him (brother).'' (unknown)

``Don't make too much of that,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.
``He (brother) can help you very little.'' (unknown)

``Of course I must work my way myself. I know that very well; I only want a chance to. In consenting to see me, after what he (brother) told you, you almost seem to be giving me a chance.'' (unknown)

``I am seeing you,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré, slowly and gravely,
``because I promised my brother I would.'' (Madame de Cintré)

``Blessings on your brother's head!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``What I told him (brother) last evening was this: that I admired you more than any woman I had ever seen, and that I should like immensely to make you my wife.'' (He)
He (Cintré) uttered these words with great directness and firmness, and without any sense of confusion. He (Cintré) was full of his (Cintré) idea, he (Cintré) had completely mastered it, and he (Cintré) seemed to look down on Madame de Cintré, with all her (Newman) gathered elegance, from the height of his (Cintré) bracing good conscience. It is probable that this particular tone and manner were the very best he (Cintré) could have hit upon. Yet the light, just visibly forced smile with which his (Cintré) companion had listened to him (Cintré) died away, and she (Newman) sat looking at him (Cintré) with her (Newman) lips parted and her (Newman) face as solemn as a tragic mask. There was evidently something very painful to her (Newman) in the scene to which he (Cintré) was subjecting her (Newman), and yet her (Newman) impatience of it found no angry voice. Newman wondered whether he (Newman) was hurting her (Newman); he (Newman) could not imagine why the liberal devotion he (Newman) meant to express should be disagreeable. He (Newman) got up and stood before her (Newman), leaning one hand on the chimney-piece.
``I know I have seen you very little to say this,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``so little that it may make what I say seem disrespectful. That is my misfortune! I could have said it the first time I saw you. Really, I had seen you before; I had seen you in imagination; you seemed almost an old friend. So what I say is not mere gallantry and compliments and nonsense--I can't talk that way, I don't know how, and I wouldn't, to you, if I could. It's as serious as such words can be. I feel as if I knew you and knew what a beautiful, admirable woman you are. I shall know better, perhaps, some day, but I have a general notion now. You are just the woman I have been looking for, except that you are far more perfect. I won't make any protestations and vows, but you can trust me. It is very soon, I know, to say all this; it is almost offensive. But why not gain time if one can? And if you want time to reflect--of course you do--the sooner you begin, the better for me. I don't know what you think of me; but there is no great mystery about me; you see what I am. Your brother told me that my antecedents and occupations were against me; that your family stands, somehow, on a higher level than I do. That is an idea which of course I don't understand and don't accept. But you don't care anything about that. I can assure you that I am a very solid fellow, and that if I give my mind to it I can arrange things so that in a very few years I shall not need to waste time in explaining who I am and what I am. You will decide for yourself whether you like me or not. What there is you see before you. I honestly believe I have no hidden vices or nasty tricks. I am kind, kind, kind! Everything that a man can give a woman I will give you. I have a large fortune, a very large fortune; some day, if you will allow me, I will go into details. If you want brilliancy, everything in the way of brilliancy that money can give you, you shall have. And as regards anything you may give up, don't take for granted too much that its place cannot be filled. Leave that to me; I'll take care of you; I shall know what you need. Energy and ingenuity can arrange everything. I'm a strong man! There, I have said what I had on my heart! It was better to get it off. I am very sorry if it's disagreeable to you; but think how much better it is that things should be clear. Don't answer me now, if you don't wish it. Think about it, think about it as slowly as you please. Of course I haven't said, I can't say, half I mean, especially about my admiration for you. But take a favorable view of me; it will only be just.'' (he)

During this speech, the longest that Newman had ever made, Madame de Cintré kept her (Newman) gaze fixed upon him (Cintré), and it expanded at the last into a sort of fascinated stare. When he (Cintré) ceased speaking she (Newman) lowered her (Newman) eyes and sat for some moments looking down and straight before her (Newman). Then she (Newman) slowly rose to her (Newman) feet, and a pair of exceptionally keen eyes would have perceived that she (Newman) was trembling a little in the movement. She (Newman) still looked extremely serious.

``I am very much obliged to you for your offer,'' (she)
she (Newman) said.
``It seems very strange, but I am glad you spoke without waiting any longer. It is better the subject should be dismissed. I appreciate all you say; you do me great honor. But I have decided not to marry.'' (unknown)

``Oh, don't say that!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman, in a tone absolutely _naïf_ from its pleading and caressing cadence. She (Newman) had turned away, and it made her (Newman) stop a moment with her (Newman) back to him (Newman).
``Think better of that. You are too young, too beautiful, too much made to be happy and to make others happy. If you are afraid of losing your freedom, I can assure you that this freedom here, this life you now lead, is a dreary bondage to what I will offer you. You shall do things that I don't think you have ever thought of. I will take you anywhere in the wide world that you propose. Are you unhappy? You give me a feeling that you _are_ unhappy. You have no right to be, or to be made so. Let me come in and put an end to it.'' (him)

Madame de Cintré stood there a moment longer, looking away from him (Newman). If she (Newman) was touched by the way he (Newman) spoke, the thing was conceivable. His (Newman) voice, always very mild and interrogative, gradually became as soft and as tenderly argumentative as if he (Newman) had been talking to a much-loved child. He (Newman) stood watching her (Newman), and she (Newman) presently turned round again, but this time she (Newman) did not look at him (Newman), and she (Newman) spoke in a quietness in which there was a visible trace of effort.

``There are a great many reasons why I should not marry,'' (she)
she (Newman) said,
``more than I can explain to you. As for my happiness, I am very happy. Your offer seems strange to me, for more reasons also than I can say. Of course you have a perfect right to make it. But I cannot accept it--it is impossible. Please never speak of this matter again. If you cannot promise me this, I must ask you not to come back.'' (she)

``Why is it impossible?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman demanded.
``You may think it is, at first, without its really being so. I didn't expect you to be pleased at first, but I do believe that if you will think of it a good while, you may be satisfied.'' (unknown)

``I don't know you,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.
``Think how little I know you.'' (unknown)

``Very little, of course, and therefore I don't ask for your ultimatum on the spot. I only ask you not to say no, and to let me hope. I will wait as long as you desire. Meanwhile you can see more of me and know me better, look at me as a possible husband--as a candidate--and make up your mind.'' (Madame)

Something was going on, rapidly, in Madame de Cintré's thoughts; she (Newman) was weighing a question there, beneath Newman's eyes, weighing it and deciding it.

``From the moment I don't very respectfully beg you to leave the house and never return,'' (she)
she (Newman) said,
``I listen to you, I seem to give you hope. I _have_ listened to you--against my judgment. It is because you are eloquent. If I had been told this morning that I should consent to consider you as a possible husband, I should have thought my informant a little crazy. I _am_ listening to you, you see!'' (she)
And she (Newman) threw her (Newman) hands out for a moment and let them drop with a gesture in which there was just the slightest expression of appealing weakness.

``Well, as far as saying goes, I have said everything,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I believe in you, without restriction, and I think all the good of you that it is possible to think of a human creature. I firmly believe that in marrying me you will be _safe_. As I said just now,'' (he)
he (Newman) went on with a smile,
``I have no bad ways. I can _do_ so much for you. And if you are afraid that I am not what you have been accustomed to, not refined and delicate and punctilious, you may easily carry that too far. I _am_ delicate! You shall see!'' (he)

Madame de Cintré walked some distance away, and paused before a great plant, an azalea, which was flourishing in a porcelain tub before her (Newman) window. She (Newman) plucked off one of the flowers and, twisting it in her (Newman) fingers, retraced her (Newman) steps. Then she (Newman) sat down in silence, and her (Newman) attitude seemed to be a consent that Newman should say more.

``Why should you say it is impossible you should marry?'' (he)
he (Newman) continued.
``The only thing that could make it really impossible would be your being already married. Is it because you have been unhappy in marriage? That is all the more reason! Is it because your family exert a pressure upon you, interfere with you, annoy you? That is still another reason; you ought to be perfectly free, and marriage will make you so. I don't say anything against your family--understand that!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
added Newman, with an eagerness which might have made a perspicacious observer smile.
``Whatever way you feel toward them is the right way, and anything that you should wish me to do to make myself agreeable to them I will do as well as I know how. Depend upon that!'' (Madame)

Madame de Cintré rose again and came toward the fireplace, near which Newman was standing. The expression of pain and embarrassment had passed out of her (Newman) face, and it was illuminated with something which, this time at least, Newman need not have been perplexed whether to attribute to habit or to intention, to art or to nature. She (Newman) had the air of a woman who has stepped across the frontier of friendship and, looking around her (Newman), finds the region vast. A certain checked and controlled exaltation seemed mingled with the usual level radiance of her (Newman) glance.

``I will not refuse to see you again,'' (she)
she (Newman) said,
``because much of what you have said has given me pleasure. But I will see you only on this condition: that you say nothing more in the same way for a long time.'' (she)

``For how long?'' (unknown)

``For six months. It must be a solemn promise.'' (unknown)

``Very well, I promise.'' (unknown)

``Good-bye, then,'' (she)
she (Newman) said, and extended her (Newman) hand.

He (Newman) held it a moment, as if he (Newman) were going to say something more. But he (Newman) only looked at her (Newman); then he (Newman) took his (Newman) departure.

That evening, on the Boulevard, he (Newman) met Valentin de Bellegarde. After they had exchanged greetings, Newman told him (Newman) that he (Newman) had seen Madame de Cintré a few hours before.

``I know it,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde.
``I dined in the Rue de l’Université.'' (both men)
And then, for some moments, both men were silent. Newman wished to ask Bellegarde what visible impression his (Newman) visit had made and the Count Valentin had a question of his (Valentin) own. Bellegarde spoke first.

``It's none of my business, but what the deuce did you say to my sister?'' (unknown)

``I am willing to tell you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``that I made her (sister) an offer of marriage.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Already!'' (the man)
And the young man gave a whistle. ```Time is money!' Is that what you say in America? And Madame de Cintré?'' he (Newman) added, with an interrogative inflection.

``She (sister) did not accept my offer.'' (unknown)

``She (sister) couldn't, you know, in that way.'' (unknown)

``But I'm to see her (sister) again,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Oh, the strangeness of woman!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
exclaimed Bellegarde. Then he (Newman) stopped, and held Newman off at arms'-length.
``I look at you with respect!'' (he)
he (Newman) exclaimed.
``You have achieved what we call a personal success! Immediately, now, I must present you to my brother.'' (unknown)

``Whenever you please!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

CHAPTER X

Newman continued to see his (Newman) friends the Tristrams with a good deal of frequency, though if you had listened to Mrs. Tristram's account of the matter you would have supposed that they had been cynically repudiated for the sake of grander acquaintance.

``We were all very well so long as we had no rivals--we were better than nothing. But now that you have become the fashion, and have your pick every day of three invitations to dinner, we are tossed into the corner. I am sure it is very good of you to come and see us once a month; I wonder you don't send us your cards in an envelope. When you do, pray have them with black edges; it will be for the death of my last illusion.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
It was in this incisive strain that Mrs. Tristram moralized over Newman's so-called neglect, which was in reality a most exemplary constancy. Of course she (Tristram) was joking, but there was always something ironical in her (Tristram) jokes, as there was always something jocular in her (Tristram) gravity.

``I know no better proof that I have treated you very well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman had said,
``than the fact that you make so free with my character. Familiarity breeds contempt; I have made myself too cheap. If I had a little proper pride I would stay away a while, and when you asked me to dinner say I was going to the Princess Borealska's. But I have not any pride where my pleasure is concerned, and to keep you in the humor to see me--if you must see me only to call me bad names--I will agree to anything you choose; I will admit that I am the biggest snob in Paris.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman, in fact, had declined an invitation personally given by the Princess Borealska, an inquiring Polish lady to whom he (Newman) had been presented, on the ground that on that particular day he (Newman) always dined at Mrs. Tristram's; and it was only a tenderly perverse theory of his (Newman) hostess of the Avenue d’Iéna that he (Newman) was faithless to his (Newman) early friendships. She (hostess) needed the theory to explain a certain moral irritation by which she (hostess) was often visited; though, if this explanation was unsound, a deeper analyst than I must give the right one. Having launched our hero upon the current which was bearing him (hero) so rapidly along, she (hostess) appeared but half-pleased at its swiftness. She (hostess) had succeeded too well; she (hostess) had played her (hostess) game too cleverly and she (hostess) wished to mix up the cards. Newman had told her (hostess), in due season, that her (hostess) friend was
``satisfactory.'' (friend)
The epithet was not romantic, but Mrs. Tristram had no difficulty in perceiving that, in essentials, the feeling which lay beneath it was. Indeed, the mild, expansive brevity with which it was uttered, and a certain look, at once appealing and inscrutable, that issued from Newman's half-closed eyes as he (Newman) leaned his (Newman) head against the back of his (Newman) chair, seemed to her (Tristram) the most eloquent attestation of a mature sentiment that she (Tristram) had ever encountered. Newman was, according to the French phrase, only abounding in her (Tristram) own sense, but his (Newman) temperate raptures exerted a singular effect upon the ardor which she (Tristram) herself had so freely manifested a few months before. She (Tristram) now seemed inclined to take a purely critical view of Madame de Cintré, and wished to have it understood that she (Tristram) did not in the least answer for her (Tristram) being a compendium of all the virtues.
``No woman was ever so good as that woman seems,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said.
``Remember what Shakespeare calls Desdemona; `a supersubtle Venetian.' Madame de Cintré is a supersubtle Parisian. She (woman) is a charming woman, and she (woman) has five hundred merits; but you had better keep that in mind.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Was Mrs. Tristram simply finding out that she (Tristram) was jealous of her (Tristram) dear friend on the other side of the Seine, and that in undertaking to provide Newman with an ideal wife she (wife) had counted too much on her (wife) own disinterestedness? We may be permitted to doubt it. The inconsistent little lady of the Avenue d’Iéna had an insuperable need of changing her (lady) place, intellectually. She (lady) had a lively imagination, and she (lady) was capable, at certain times, of imagining the direct reverse of her (lady) most cherished beliefs, with a vividness more intense than that of conviction. She (lady) got tired of thinking aright; but there was no serious harm in it, as she (lady) got equally tired of thinking wrong. In the midst of her (lady) mysterious perversities she (lady) had admirable flashes of justice. One of these occurred when Newman related to her (lady) that he (Newman) had made a formal proposal to Madame de Cintré. He (Newman) repeated in a few words what he (Newman) had said, and in a great many what she (lady) had answered. Mrs. Tristram listened with extreme interest.

``But after all,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``there is nothing to congratulate me upon. It is not a triumph.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I beg your pardon,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram;
``it is a great triumph. It is a great triumph that she (woman) did not silence you at the first word, and request you never to speak to her (woman) again.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``I don't see that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
observed Newman.

``Of course you don't; Heaven forbid you should! When I told you to go on your own way and do what came into your head, I had no idea you would go over the ground so fast. I never dreamed you would offer yourself after five or six morning-calls. As yet, what had you done to make her (woman) like you? You had simply sat--not very straight--and stared at her (woman). But she (woman) does like you.'' (unknown)

``That remains to be seen.'' (unknown)

``No, that is proved. What will come of it remains to be seen. That you should propose to marry her (woman), without more ado, could never have come into her (woman) head. You can form very little idea of what passed through her (woman) mind as you spoke; if she (woman) ever really marries you, the affair will be characterized by the usual justice of all human beings towards women. You will think you take generous views of her (woman); but you will never begin to know through what a strange sea of feeling she (woman) passed before she (woman) accepted you. As she (woman) stood there in front of you the other day, she (woman) plunged into it. She (woman) said `Why not?' to something which, a few hours earlier, had been inconceivable. She (woman) turned about on a thousand gathered prejudices and traditions as on a pivot, and looked where she (woman) had never looked hitherto. When I think of it--when I think of Claire de Cintré and all that she (woman) represents, there seems to me something very fine in it. When I recommended you to try your fortune with her (woman) I of course thought well of you, and in spite of your sins I think so still. But I confess I don't see quite what you are and what you have done, to make such a woman do this sort of thing for you.'' (unknown)

``Oh, there is something very fine in it!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman with a laugh, repeating her (Tristram) words. He (Newman) took an extreme satisfaction in hearing that there was something fine in it. He (Newman) had not the least doubt of it himself, but he (Newman) had already begun to value the world's admiration of Madame de Cintré, as adding to the prospective glory of possession.

It was immediately after this conversation that Valentin de Bellegarde came to conduct his (Bellegarde) friend to the Rue de l’Université to present him (Bellegarde) to the other members of his (Bellegarde) family.

``You are already introduced,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said,
``and you have begun to be talked about. My sister has mentioned your successive visits to my mother, and it was an accident that my mother was present at none of them. I have spoken of you as an American of immense wealth, and the best fellow in the world, who is looking for something very superior in the way of a wife.'' (he)

``Do you suppose,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman,
``that Madame de Cintré has related to your mother the last conversation I had with her (mother)?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I am very certain that she (mother) has not; she (mother) will keep her (mother) own counsel. Meanwhile you must make your way with the rest of the family. Thus much is known about you: you have made a great fortune in trade, you are a little eccentric, and you frankly admire our dear Claire. My sister-in-law, whom you remember seeing in Madame de Cintré's sitting-room, took, it appears, a fancy to you; she (Claire) has described you as having _beaucoup de cachet_. My mother, therefore, is curious to see you.'' (unknown)

``She (mother) expects to laugh at me, eh?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``She (mother) never laughs. If she (mother) does not like you, don't hope to purchase favor by being amusing. Take warning by me!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

This conversation took place in the evening, and half an hour later Valentin ushered his (Valentin) companion into an apartment of the house of the Rue de l’Université into which he (Valentin) had not yet penetrated, the salon of the dowager Marquise de Bellegarde. It was a vast, high room, with elaborate and ponderous mouldings, painted a whitish gray, along the upper portion of the walls and the ceiling; with a great deal of faded and carefully repaired tapestry in the doorways and chair-backs; a Turkey carpet in light colors, still soft and deep, in spite of great antiquity, on the floor, and portraits of each of Madame de Bellegarde's children, at the age of ten, suspended against an old screen of red silk. The room was illumined, exactly enough for conversation, by half a dozen candles, placed in odd corners, at a great distance apart. In a deep armchair, near the fire, sat an old lady in black; at the other end of the room another person was seated at the piano, playing a very expressive waltz. In this latter person Newman recognized the young Marquise de Bellegarde.

Valentin presented his (Valentin) friend, and Newman walked up to the old lady by the fire and shook hands with her (lady). He (Newman) received a rapid impression of a white, delicate, aged face, with a high forehead, a small mouth, and a pair of cold blue eyes which had kept much of the freshness of youth. Madame de Bellegarde looked hard at him (Bellegarde), and returned his (Bellegarde) hand-shake with a sort of British positiveness which reminded him (Bellegarde) that she (lady) was the daughter of the Earl of St. Dunstan's. Her (lady) daughter-in-law stopped playing and gave him (Dunstan) an agreeable smile. Newman sat down and looked about him (Newman), while Valentin went and kissed the hand of the young marquise.

``I ought to have seen you before,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``You have paid several visits to my daughter.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, smiling;
``Madame de Cintré and I are old friends by this time.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``You have gone fast,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.

``Not so fast as I should like,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, bravely.

``Oh, you are very ambitious,'' (the lady)
answered the old lady.

``Yes, I confess I am,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, smiling.

Madame de Bellegarde looked at him (Bellegarde) with her (lady) cold fine eyes, and he (Bellegarde) returned her (lady) gaze, reflecting that she (lady) was a possible adversary and trying to take her (lady) measure. Their eyes remained in contact for some moments. Then Madame de Bellegarde looked away, and without smiling,

``I am very ambitious, too,'' (Madame)
she (lady) said.

Newman felt that taking her (lady) measure was not easy; she (lady) was a formidable, inscrutable little woman. She (lady) resembled her (lady) daughter, and yet she (lady) was utterly unlike her (lady). The coloring in Madame de Cintré was the same, and the high delicacy of her (lady) brow and nose was hereditary. But her (lady) face was a larger and freer copy, and her (lady) mouth in especial a happy divergence from that conservative orifice, a little pair of lips at once plump and pinched, that looked, when closed, as if they could not open wider than to swallow a gooseberry or to emit an

``Oh, dear, no!'' (Lady)
which probably had been thought to give the finishing touch to the aristocratic prettiness of the Lady Emmeline Atheling as represented, forty years before, in several Books of Beauty. Madame de Cintré's face had, to Newman's eye, a range of expression as delightfully vast as the wind-streaked, cloud-flecked distance on a Western prairie. But her (Lady) mother's white, intense, respectable countenance, with its formal gaze, and its circumscribed smile, suggested a document signed and sealed; a thing of parchment, ink, and ruled lines.
``She (daughter) is a woman of conventions and proprieties,'' (he)
he (Newman) said to himself as he (Newman) looked at her (Lady);
``her (daughter) world is the world of things immutably decreed. But how she (daughter) is at home in it, and what a paradise she (daughter) finds it. She (daughter) walks about in it as if it were a blooming park, a Garden of Eden; and when she (daughter) sees `This is genteel,' or `This is improper,' written on a mile-stone she (daughter) stops ecstatically, as if she (daughter) were listening to a nightingale or smelling a rose.'' (he)
Madame de Bellegarde wore a little black velvet hood tied under her (Lady) chin, and she (Lady) was wrapped in an old black cashmere shawl.

``You are an American?'' (she)
she (Lady) said presently.
``I have seen several Americans.'' (unknown)

``There are several in Paris,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman jocosely.

``Oh, really?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``It was in England I saw these, or somewhere else; not in Paris. I think it must have been in the Pyrenees, many years ago. I am told your ladies are very pretty. One of these ladies was very pretty! such a wonderful complexion! She (daughter) presented me a note of introduction from someone--I forgot whom--and she (daughter) sent with it a note of her (daughter) own. I kept her (daughter) letter a long time afterwards, it was so strangely expressed. I used to know some of the phrases by heart. But I have forgotten them now, it is so many years ago. Since then I have seen no more Americans. I think my daughter-in-law has; she (daughter-in-law) is a great gad-about, she (daughter-in-law) sees everyone.'' (this the lady)

At this the younger lady came rustling forward, pinching in a very slender waist, and casting idly preoccupied glances over the front of her (lady) dress, which was apparently designed for a ball. She (lady) was, in a singular way, at once ugly and pretty; she (lady) had protuberant eyes, and lips strangely red. She (lady) reminded Newman of his (Newman) friend, Mademoiselle Nioche; this was what that much-obstructed young lady would have liked to be. Valentin de Bellegarde walked behind her (lady) at a distance, hopping about to keep off the far-spreading train of her (lady) dress.

``You ought to show more of your shoulders behind,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said very gravely.
``You might as well wear a standing ruff as such a dress as that.'' (The woman)

The young woman turned her (woman) back to the mirror over the chimney-piece, and glanced behind her (woman), to verify Valentin's assertion. The mirror descended low, and yet it reflected nothing but a large unclad flesh surface. The young marquise put her (woman) hands behind her (woman) and gave a downward pull to the waist of her (woman) dress.

``Like that, you mean?'' (she)
she (woman) asked.

``That is a little better,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said Bellegarde in the same tone,
``but it leaves a good deal to be desired.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``Oh, I never go to extremes,'' (sister-in-law)
said his (Bellegarde) sister-in-law. And then, turning to Madame de Bellegarde,
``What were you calling me just now, madame?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``I called you a gad-about,'' (the lady)
said the old lady.
``But I might call you something else, too.'' (unknown)

``A gad-about? What an ugly word! What does it mean?'' (unknown)

``A very beautiful person,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman ventured to say, seeing that it was in French.

``That is a pretty compliment but a bad translation,'' (the marquise)
said the young marquise. And then, looking at him (marquise) a moment,
``Do you dance?'' (him)

``Not a step.'' (unknown)

``You are very wrong,'' (she)
she (lady) said, simply. And with another look at her (lady) back in the mirror she (lady) turned away.

``Do you like Paris?'' (the lady)
asked the old lady, who was apparently wondering what was the proper way to talk to an American.

``Yes, rather,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman. And then he (Newman) added with a friendly intonation,
``Don't you?'' (he)

``I can't say I know it. I know my house--I know my friends--I don't know Paris.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you lose a great deal,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, sympathetically.

Madame de Bellegarde stared; it was presumably the first time she (lady) had been condoled with on her (lady) losses.

``I am content with what I have,'' (she)
she (lady) said with dignity.

Newman's eyes, at this moment, were wandering round the room, which struck him (Newman) as rather sad and shabby; passing from the high casements, with their small, thickly-framed panes, to the sallow tints of two or three portraits in pastel, of the last century, which hung between them. He (Newman) ought, obviously, to have answered that the contentment of his (Newman) hostess was quite natural--she (hostess) had a great deal; but the idea did not occur to him (Newman) during the pause of some moments which followed.

``Well, my dear mother,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, coming and leaning against the chimney-piece,
``what do you think of my dear friend Newman? Is he (Newman) not the excellent fellow I told you?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``My acquaintance with Mr. Newman has not gone very far,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``I can as yet only appreciate his (Newman) great politeness.'' (unknown)

``My mother is a great judge of these matters,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin to Newman.
``If you have satisfied her (mother), it is a triumph.'' (unknown)

``I hope I shall satisfy you, some day,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, looking at the old lady.
``I have done nothing yet.'' (unknown)

``You must not listen to my son; he (son) will bring you into trouble. He (son) is a sad scatterbrain.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I like him (son)--I like him (son),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, genially.

``He (son) amuses you, eh?'' (unknown)

``Yes, perfectly.'' (unknown)

``Do you hear that, Valentin?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``You amuse Mr. Newman.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps we shall all come to that!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin exclaimed.

``You must see my other son,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``He (son) is much better than this one. But he (son) will not amuse you.'' (unknown)

``I don't know--I don't know!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
murmured Valentin, reflectively.
``But we shall very soon see. Here comes _Monsieur mon frère_.'' (a gentleman)

The door had just opened to give ingress to a gentleman who stepped forward and whose face Newman remembered. He (Newman) had been the author of our hero's discomfiture the first time he (Newman) tried to present himself to Madame de Cintré.
