Valentin de Bellegarde went to meet his (Bellegarde) brother, looked at him (Bellegarde) a moment, and then, taking him (Bellegarde) by the arm, led him (Bellegarde) up to Newman.

``This is my excellent friend Mr. Newman,'' (he)
he (Newman) said very blandly.
``You must know him (Newman).'' (unknown)

``I am delighted to know Mr. Newman,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis with a low bow, but without offering his (Newman) hand.

``He (Newman) is the old woman at second-hand,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said to himself, as he (Newman) returned M. de Bellegarde's greeting. And this was the starting-point of a speculative theory, in his (Newman) mind, that the late marquis had been a very amiable foreigner, with an inclination to take life easily and a sense that it was difficult for the husband of the stilted little lady by the fire to do so. But if he (husband) had taken little comfort in his (husband) wife he (husband) had taken much in his (husband) two younger children, who were after his (husband) own heart, while Madame de Bellegarde had paired with her (wife) eldest-born.

``My brother has spoken to me of you,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde;
``and as you are also acquainted with my sister, it was time we should meet.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
He (Bellegarde) turned to his (Bellegarde) mother and gallantly bent over her (mother) hand, touching it with his (Bellegarde) lips, and then he (Bellegarde) assumed an attitude before the chimney-piece. With his (Bellegarde) long, lean face, his (Bellegarde) high-bridged nose and his (Bellegarde) small, opaque eye he (Bellegarde) looked much like an Englishman. His (Bellegarde) whiskers were fair and glossy, and he (Bellegarde) had a large dimple, of unmistakably British origin, in the middle of his (Bellegarde) handsome chin. He (Bellegarde) was
``distinguished'' (He)
to the tips of his (Bellegarde) polished nails, and there was not a movement of his (Bellegarde) fine, perpendicular person that was not noble and majestic. Newman had never yet been confronted with such an incarnation of the art of taking one's self seriously; he (Newman) felt a sort of impulse to step backward, as you do to get a view of a great façade.

``Urbain,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said young Madame de Bellegarde, who had apparently been waiting for her (Bellegarde) husband to take her (Bellegarde) to her (Bellegarde) ball,
``I call your attention to the fact that I am dressed.'' (her)

``That is a good idea,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
murmured Valentin.

``I am at your orders, my dear friend,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde.
``Only, you must allow me first the pleasure of a little conversation with Mr. Newman.'' (unknown)

``Oh, if you are going to a party, don't let me keep you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
objected Newman.
``I am very sure we shall meet again. Indeed, if you would like to converse with me I will gladly name an hour.'' (He)
He (Newman) was eager to make it known that he (Newman) would readily answer all questions and satisfy all exactions.

M. de Bellegarde stood in a well-balanced position before the fire, caressing one of his (Bellegarde) fair whiskers with one of his (Bellegarde) white hands, and looking at Newman, half askance, with eyes from which a particular ray of observation made its way through a general meaningless smile.

``It is very kind of you to make such an offer,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``If I am not mistaken, your occupations are such as to make your time precious. You are in--a--as we say, _dans les affaires_.'' (unknown)

``In business, you mean? Oh no, I have thrown business overboard for the present. I am `loafing,' as _we_ say. My time is quite my own.'' (unknown)

``Ah, you are taking a holiday,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
rejoined M. de Bellegarde. ```Loafing.' Yes, I have heard that expression.''

``Mr. Newman is American,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.

``My brother is a great ethnologist,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.

``An ethnologist?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Ah, you collect negroes' skulls, and that sort of thing.'' (The marquis)

The marquis looked hard at his (Newman) brother, and began to caress his (Newman) other whisker. Then, turning to Newman, with sustained urbanity,

``You are traveling for your pleasure?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
he (Newman) asked.'

``Oh, I am knocking about to pick up one thing and another. Of course I get a good deal of pleasure out of it.'' (unknown)

``What especially interests you?'' (the marquis)
inquired the marquis.

``Well, everything interests me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I am not particular. Manufactures are what I care most about.'' (unknown)

``That has been your specialty?'' (unknown)

``I can't say I have any specialty. My specialty has been to make the largest possible fortune in the shortest possible time.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman made this last remark very deliberately; he (Newman) wished to open the way, if it were necessary, to an authoritative statement of his (Newman) means.

M. de Bellegarde laughed agreeably.

``I hope you have succeeded,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.

``Yes, I have made a fortune in a reasonable time. I am not so old, you see.'' (unknown)

``Paris is a very good place to spend a fortune. I wish you great enjoyment of yours.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
And M. de Bellegarde drew forth his (Bellegarde) gloves and began to put them on.

Newman for a few moments watched him (Newman) sliding his (Newman) white hands into the white kid, and as he (Newman) did so his (Newman) feelings took a singular turn. M. de Bellegarde's good wishes seemed to descend out of the white expanse of his (Bellegarde) sublime serenity with the soft, scattered movement of a shower of snow-flakes. Yet Newman was not irritated; he (Newman) did not feel that he (Newman) was being patronized; he (Newman) was conscious of no especial impulse to introduce a discord into so noble a harmony. Only he (Newman) felt himself suddenly in personal contact with the forces with which his (Newman) friend Valentin had told him (Valentin) that he (Valentin) would have to contend, and he (Valentin) became sensible of their intensity. He (Valentin) wished to make some answering manifestation, to stretch himself out at his (Valentin) own length, to sound a note at the uttermost end of _his (Valentin)_ scale. It must be added that if this impulse was not vicious or malicious, it was by no means void of humorous expectancy. Newman was quite as ready to give play to that loosely-adjusted smile of his (Newman), if his (Newman) hosts should happen to be shocked, as he (Newman) was far from deliberately planning to shock them.

``Paris is a very good place for idle people,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``or it is a very good place if your family has been settled here for a long time, and you have made acquaintances and got your relations round you; or if you have got a good big house like this, and a wife and children and mother and sister, and everything comfortable. I don't like that way of living all in rooms next door to each other. But I am not an idler. I try to be, but I can't manage it; it goes against the grain. My business habits are too deep-seated. Then, I haven't any house to call my own, or anything in the way of a family. My sisters are five thousand miles away, my mother died when I was a youngster, and I haven't any wife; I wish I had! So, you see, I don't exactly know what to do with myself. I am not fond of books, as you are, sir, and I get tired of dining out and going to the opera. I miss my business activity. You see, I began to earn my living when I was almost a baby, and until a few months ago I have never had my hand off the plow. Elegant leisure comes hard.'' (he)

This speech was followed by a profound silence of some moments, on the part of Newman's entertainers. Valentin stood looking at him (Valentin) fixedly, with his (Valentin) hands in his (Valentin) pockets, and then he (Valentin) slowly, with a half-sidling motion, went out of the door. The marquis continued to draw on his (Valentin) gloves and to smile benignantly.

``You began to earn your living when you were a mere baby?'' (the marquise)
said the marquise.

``Hardly more--a small boy.'' (unknown)

``You say you are not fond of books,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde;
``but you must do yourself the justice to remember that your studies were interrupted early.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``That is very true; on my tenth birthday I stopped going to school. I thought it was a grand way to keep it. But I picked up some information afterwards,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, reassuringly.

``You have some sisters?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
asked old Madame de Bellegarde.

``Yes, two sisters. Splendid women!'' (unknown)

``I hope that for them the hardships of life commenced less early.'' (unknown)

``They married very early, if you call that a hardship, as girls do in our Western country. One of them is married to the owner of the largest india-rubber house in the West.'' (unknown)

``Ah, you make houses also of india-rubber?'' (the marquise)
inquired the marquise.

``You can stretch them as your family increases,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said young Madame de Bellegarde, who was muffling herself in a long white shawl.

Newman indulged in a burst of hilarity, and explained that the house in which his (Newman) brother-in-law lived was a large wooden structure, but that he (Newman) manufactured and sold india-rubber on a colossal scale.

``My children have some little india-rubber shoes which they put on when they go to play in the Tuileries in damp weather,'' (the marquise)
said the young marquise.
``I wonder whether your brother-in-law made them.'' (unknown)

``Very likely,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``if he (brother-in-law) did, you may be very sure they are well made.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Well, you must not be discouraged,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde, with vague urbanity.

``Oh, I don't mean to be. I have a project which gives me plenty to think about, and that is an occupation.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And then Newman was silent a moment, hesitating, yet thinking rapidly; he (Newman) wished to make his (Newman) point, and yet to do so forced him (Newman) to speak out in a way that was disagreeable to him (Newman). Nevertheless he (Newman) continued, addressing himself to old Madame de Bellegarde,
``I will tell you my project; perhaps you can help me. I want to take a wife.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``It is a very good project, but I am no matchmaker,'' (the lady)
said the old lady.

Newman looked at her (lady) an instant, and then, with perfect sincerity,

``I should have thought you were,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
he (Newman) declared.

Madame de Bellegarde appeared to think him (Bellegarde) too sincere. She (lady) murmured something sharply in French, and fixed her (lady) eyes on her (lady) son. At this moment the door of the room was thrown open, and with a rapid step Valentin reappeared.

``I have a message for you,'' (he)
he (Valentin) said to his (Valentin) sister-in-law.
``Claire bids me to request you not to start for your ball. She (Claire) will go with you.'' (unknown)

``Claire will go with us!'' (the marquise)
cried the young marquise.
``_En voilà, du nouveau!_'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``She (Claire) has changed her (Claire) mind; she (Claire) decided half an hour ago, and she (Claire) is sticking the last diamond into her (Claire) hair,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.

``What has taken possession of my daughter?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
demanded Madame de Bellegarde, sternly.
``She (Claire) has not been into the world these three years. Does she (Claire) take such a step at half an hour's notice, and without consulting me?'' (unknown)

``She (Claire) consulted me, dear mother, five minutes since,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``and I told her (Claire) that such a beautiful woman--she (Claire) is beautiful, you will see--had no right to bury herself alive.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``You should have referred Claire to her (Claire) mother, my brother,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde, in French.
``This is very strange.'' (unknown)

``I refer her (Claire) to the whole company!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``Here she (Claire) comes!'' (he)
And he (Valentin) went to the open door, met Madame de Cintré on the threshold, took her (sister-in-law) by the hand, and led her (sister-in-law) into the room. She (sister-in-law) was dressed in white; but a long blue cloak, which hung almost to her (sister-in-law) feet, was fastened across her (sister-in-law) shoulders by a silver clasp. She (sister-in-law) had tossed it back, however, and her (sister-in-law) long white arms were uncovered. In her (sister-in-law) dense, fair hair there glittered a dozen diamonds. She (sister-in-law) looked serious and, Newman thought, rather pale; but she (sister-in-law) glanced round her (sister-in-law), and, when she (sister-in-law) saw him (Newman), smiled and put out her (sister-in-law) hand. He (Newman) thought her (sister-in-law) tremendously handsome. He (Newman) had a chance to look at her (sister-in-law) full in the face, for she (sister-in-law) stood a moment in the centre of the room, hesitating, apparently, what she (sister-in-law) should do, without meeting his (Newman) eyes. Then she (sister-in-law) went up to her (sister-in-law) mother, who sat in her (sister-in-law) deep chair by the fire, looking at Madame de Cintré almost fiercely. With her (sister-in-law) back turned to the others, Madame de Cintré held her (sister-in-law) cloak apart to show her (sister-in-law) dress.

``What do you think of me?'' (she)
she (sister-in-law) asked.

``I think you are audacious,'' (the marquise)
said the marquise.
``It was but three days ago, when I asked you, as a particular favor to myself, to go to the Duchess de Lusignan's, that you told me you were going nowhere and that one must be consistent. Is this your consistency? Why should you distinguish Madame Robineau? Who is it you wish to please to-night?'' (unknown)

``I wish to please myself, dear mother,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré. And she (sister-in-law) bent over and kissed the old lady.

``I don't like surprises, my sister,'' (Urbain/Urbain de Bellegarde)
said Urbain de Bellegarde;
``especially when one is on the point of entering a drawing-room.'' (Urbain/Urbain de Bellegarde)

Newman at this juncture felt inspired to speak.

``Oh, if you are going into a room with Madame de Cintré, you needn't be afraid of being noticed yourself!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

M. de Bellegarde turned to his (Bellegarde) sister with a smile too intense to be easy.

``I hope you appreciate a compliment that is paid you at your brother's expense,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.
``Come, come, madame.'' (Madame de Cintré)
And offering Madame de Cintré his (Cintré) arm he (Cintré) led her (sister) rapidly out of the room. Valentin rendered the same service to young Madame de Bellegarde, who had apparently been reflecting on the fact that the ball-dress of her (sister) sister-in-law was much less brilliant than her (sister) own, and yet had failed to derive absolute comfort from the reflection. With a farewell smile she (sister) sought the complement of her (sister) consolation in the eyes of the American visitor, and perceiving in them a certain mysterious brilliancy, it is not improbable that she (sister) may have flattered herself she (sister) had found it.

Newman, left alone with old Madame de Bellegarde, stood before her (sister) a few moments in silence.

``Your daughter is very beautiful,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said at last.

``She (daughter) is very strange,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.

``I am glad to hear it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman rejoined, smiling.
``It makes me hope.'' (unknown)

``Hope what?'' (unknown)

``That she (daughter) will consent, some day, to marry me.'' (The lady)

The old lady slowly rose to her (lady) feet.

``That really is your project, then?'' (unknown)

``Yes; will you favor it?'' (unknown)

``Favor it?'' (Madame)
Madame de Bellegarde looked at him (Bellegarde) a moment and then shook her (lady) head.
``No!'' (she)
she (lady) said, softly.

``Will you suffer it, then? Will you let it pass?'' (unknown)

``You don't know what you ask. I am a very proud and meddlesome old woman.'' (unknown)

``Well, I am very rich,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

Madame de Bellegarde fixed her (lady) eyes on the floor, and Newman thought it probable she (lady) was weighing the reasons in favor of resenting the brutality of this remark. But at last, looking up, she (lady) said simply,

``How rich?'' (she)

Newman expressed his (Newman) income in a round number which had the magnificent sound that large aggregations of dollars put on when they are translated into francs. He (Newman) added a few remarks of a financial character, which completed a sufficiently striking presentment of his (Newman) resources.

Madame de Bellegarde listened in silence.

``You are very frank,'' (she)
she (lady) said finally.
``I will be the same. I would rather favor you, on the whole, than suffer you. It will be easier.'' (unknown)

``I am thankful for any terms,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But, for the present, you have suffered me long enough. Good night!'' (he)
And he (Newman) took his (Newman) leave.

CHAPTER XI

Newman, on his (Newman) return to Paris, had not resumed the study of French conversation with M. Nioche; he (Newman) found that he (Newman) had too many other uses for his (Newman) time. M. Nioche, however, came to see him (Newman) very promptly, having learned his (Newman) whereabouts by a mysterious process to which his (Newman) patron never obtained the key. The shrunken little capitalist repeated his (Newman) visit more than once. He (Newman) seemed oppressed by a humiliating sense of having been overpaid, and wished apparently to redeem his (Newman) debt by the offer of grammatical and statistical information in small installments. He (Newman) wore the same decently melancholy aspect as a few months before; a few months more or less of brushing could make little difference in the antique lustre of his (Newman) coat and hat. But the poor old man's spirit was a trifle more threadbare; it seemed to have received some hard rubs during the summer. Newman inquired with interest about Mademoiselle Noémie; and M. Nioche, at first, for answer, simply looked at him (Newman) in lachrymose silence.

``Don't ask me, sir,'' (he)
he (Newman) said at last.
``I sit and watch her (woman), but I can do nothing.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean that she (woman) misconducts herself?'' (unknown)

``I don't know, I am sure. I can't follow her (woman). I don't understand her (woman). She (woman) has something in her (woman) head; I don't know what she (woman) is trying to do. She (woman) is too deep for me.'' (unknown)

``Does she (woman) continue to go to the Louvre? Has she (woman) made any of those copies for me?'' (unknown)

``She (woman) goes to the Louvre, but I see nothing of the copies. She (woman) has something on her (woman) easel; I suppose it is one of the pictures you ordered. Such a magnificent order ought to give her (woman) fairy-fingers. But she (woman) is not in earnest. I can't say anything to her (woman); I am afraid of her (woman). One evening, last summer, when I took her (woman) to walk in the Champs Élysées, she (woman) said some things to me that frightened me.'' (unknown)

``What were they?'' (unknown)

``Excuse an unhappy father from telling you,'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche, unfolding his (Newman) calico pocket-handkerchief.

Newman promised himself to pay Mademoiselle Noémie another visit at the Louvre. He (Newman) was curious about the progress of his (Newman) copies, but it must be added that he (Newman) was still more curious about the progress of the young lady herself. He (Newman) went one afternoon to the great museum, and wandered through several of the rooms in fruitless quest of her (lady). He (Newman) was bending his (Newman) steps to the long hall of the Italian masters, when suddenly he (Newman) found himself face to face with Valentin de Bellegarde. The young Frenchman greeted him (Frenchman) with ardor, and assured him (Frenchman) that he (Frenchman) was a godsend. He (Frenchman) himself was in the worst of humors and he (Frenchman) wanted someone to contradict.

``In a bad humor among all these beautiful things?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I thought you were so fond of pictures, especially the old black ones. There are two or three here that ought to keep you in spirits.'' (unknown)

``Oh, to-day,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
answered Valentin,
``I am not in a mood for pictures, and the more beautiful they are the less I like them. Their great staring eyes and fixed positions irritate me. I feel as if I were at some big, dull party, in a room full of people I shouldn't wish to speak to. What should I care for their beauty? It's a bore, and, worse still, it's a reproach. I have a great many _ennuis_; I feel vicious.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``If the Louvre has so little comfort for you, why in the world did you come here?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

``That is one of my _ennuis_. I came to meet my cousin--a dreadful English cousin, a member of my mother's family--who is in Paris for a week for her (mother) husband, and who wishes me to point out the `principal beauties.' Imagine a woman who wears a green crape bonnet in December and has straps sticking out of the ankles of her (woman) interminable boots! My mother begged I would do something to oblige them. I have undertaken to play _valet de place_ this afternoon. They were to have met me here at two o’clock, and I have been waiting for them twenty minutes. Why doesn't she (mother) arrive? She (mother) has at least a pair of feet to carry her (mother). I don't know whether to be furious at their playing me false, or delighted to have escaped them.'' (unknown)

``I think in your place I would be furious,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``because they may arrive yet, and then your fury will still be of use to you. Whereas if you were delighted and they were afterwards to turn up, you might not know what to do with your delight.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``You give me excellent advice, and I already feel better. I will be furious; I will let them go to the deuce and I myself will go with you--unless by chance you too have a rendezvous.'' (unknown)

``It is not exactly a rendezvous,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But I have in fact come to see a person, not a picture.'' (unknown)

``A woman, presumably?'' (unknown)

``A young lady.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``I hope for you with all my heart that she (lady) is not clothed in green tulle and that her (lady) feet are not too much out of focus.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``I don't know much about her (lady) feet, but she (lady) has very pretty hands.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin gave a sigh.

``And on that assurance I must part with you?'' (unknown)

``I am not certain of finding my young lady,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``and I am not quite prepared to lose your company on the chance. It does not strike me as particularly desirable to introduce you to her (lady), and yet I should rather like to have your opinion of her (lady).'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Is she (lady) pretty?'' (unknown)

``I guess you will think so.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Bellegarde passed his (Newman) arm into that of his (Newman) companion.

``Conduct me to her (lady) on the instant! I should be ashamed to make a pretty woman wait for my verdict.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman suffered himself to be gently propelled in the direction in which he (Newman) had been walking, but his (Newman) step was not rapid. He (Newman) was turning something over in his (Newman) mind. The two men passed into the long gallery of the Italian masters, and Newman, after having scanned for a moment its brilliant vista, turned aside into the smaller apartment devoted to the same school, on the left. It contained very few persons, but at the farther end of it sat Mademoiselle Nioche, before her (Newman) easel. She (Newman) was not at work; her (Newman) palette and brushes had been laid down beside her (Newman), her (Newman) hands were folded in her (Newman) lap, and she (Newman) was leaning back in her (Newman) chair and looking intently at two ladies on the other side of the hall, who, with their backs turned to her (Newman), had stopped before one of the pictures. These ladies were apparently persons of high fashion; they were dressed with great splendor, and their long silken trains and furbelows were spread over the polished floor. It was at their dresses Mademoiselle Noémie was looking, though what she (Newman) was thinking of I am unable to say. I hazard the supposition that she (Newman) was saying to herself that to be able to drag such a train over a polished floor was a felicity worth any price. Her (Newman) reflections, at any rate, were disturbed by the advent of Newman and his (Newman) companion. She (Newman) glanced at them quickly, and then, coloring a little, rose and stood before her (Newman) easel.

``I came here on purpose to see you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman in his (Newman) bad French, offering to shake hands. And then, like a good American, he (Newman) introduced Valentin formally:
``Allow me to make you acquainted with the Comte Valentin de Bellegarde.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin made a bow which must have seemed to Mademoiselle Noémie quite in harmony with the impressiveness of his (Valentin) title, but the graceful brevity of her (Newman) own response made no concession to underbred surprise. She (Newman) turned to Newman, putting up her (Newman) hands to her (Newman) hair and smoothing its delicately-felt roughness. Then, rapidly, she (Newman) turned the canvas that was on her (Newman) easel over upon its face.

``You have not forgotten me?'' (she)
she (Newman) asked.

``I shall never forget you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You may be sure of that.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (the girl)
said the young girl,
``there are a great many different ways of remembering a person.'' (the girl)
And she (girl) looked straight at Valentin de Bellegarde, who was looking at her (girl) as a gentleman may when a
``verdict'' (a gentleman)
is expected of him (Bellegarde).

``Have you painted anything for me?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Have you been industrious?'' (unknown)

``No, I have done nothing.'' (she)
And taking up her (girl) palette, she (girl) began to mix her (girl) colors at hazard.

``But your father tells me you have come here constantly.'' (unknown)

``I have nowhere else to go! Here, all summer, it was cool, at least.'' (unknown)

``Being here, then,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``you might have tried something.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I told you before,'' (she)
she (girl) answered, softly,
``that I don't know how to paint.'' (she)

``But you have something charming on your easel, now,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``if you would only let me see it.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

She (girl) spread out her (girl) two hands, with the fingers expanded, over the back of the canvas--those hands which Newman had called pretty, and which, in spite of several paint-stains, Valentin could now admire.

``My painting is not charming,'' (she)
she (girl) said.

``It is the only thing about you that is not, then, mademoiselle,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
quoth Valentin, gallantly.

She (girl) took up her (girl) little canvas and silently passed it to him (Valentin). He (Valentin) looked at it, and in a moment she (girl) said,

``I am sure you are a judge.'' (she)

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Valentin) answered,
``I am.'' (he)

``You know, then, that that is very bad.'' (unknown)

``_Mon Dieu_,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, shrugging his (Valentin) shoulders
``let us distinguish.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``You know that I ought not to attempt to paint,'' (the girl)
the young girl continued.

``Frankly, then, mademoiselle, I think you ought not.'' (She)

She (girl) began to look at the dresses of the two splendid ladies again--a point on which, having risked one conjecture, I think I may risk another. While she (girl) was looking at the ladies she (girl) was seeing Valentin de Bellegarde. He (Bellegarde), at all events, was seeing her (girl). He (Bellegarde) put down the roughly-besmeared canvas and addressed a little click with his (Bellegarde) tongue, accompanied by an elevation of the eyebrows, to Newman.

``Where have you been all these months?'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
asked Mademoiselle Noémie of our hero.
``You took those great journeys, you amused yourself well?'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I amused myself well enough.'' (unknown)

``I am very glad,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie with extreme gentleness, and she (girl) began to dabble in her (girl) colors again. She (girl) was singularly pretty, with the look of serious sympathy that she (girl) threw into her (girl) face.

Valentin took advantage of her (girl) downcast eyes to telegraph again to his (Valentin) companion. He (Valentin) renewed his (Valentin) mysterious physiognomical play, making at the same time a rapid tremulous movement in the air with his (Valentin) fingers. He (Valentin) was evidently finding Mademoiselle Noémie extremely interesting; the blue devils had departed, leaving the field clear.

``Tell me something about your travels,'' (the girl)
murmured the young girl.

``Oh, I went to Switzerland,--to Geneva and Zermatt and Zürich and all those places you know; and down to Venice, and all through Germany, and down the Rhine, and into Holland and Belgium--the regular round. How do you say that, in French--the regular round?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked of Valentin.

Mademoiselle Nioche fixed her (girl) eyes an instant on Bellegarde, and then with a little smile,

``I don't understand monsieur,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
she (girl) said,
``when he (I) says so much at once. Would you be so good as to translate?'' (she)

``I would rather talk to you out of my own head,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin declared.

``No,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, gravely, still in his (Newman) bad French,
``you must not talk to Mademoiselle Nioche, because you say discouraging things. You ought to tell her (You) to work, to persevere.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``And we French, mademoiselle,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``are accused of being false flatterers!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``I don't want any flattery, I want only the truth. But I know the truth.'' (unknown)

``All I say is that I suspect there are some things that you can do better than paint,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.

``I know the truth--I know the truth,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
Mademoiselle Noémie repeated. And, dipping a brush into a clot of red paint, she (girl) drew a great horizontal daub across her (girl) unfinished picture.

``What is that?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

Without answering, she (girl) drew another long crimson daub, in a vertical direction, down the middle of her (girl) canvas, and so, in a moment, completed the rough indication of a cross.

``It is the sign of the truth,'' (she)
she (girl) said at last.

The two men looked at each other, and Valentin indulged in another flash of physiognomical eloquence.

``You have spoiled your picture,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I know that very well. It was the only thing to do with it. I had sat looking at it all day without touching it. I had begun to hate it. It seemed to me something was going to happen.'' (unknown)

``I like it better that way than as it was before,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``Now it is more interesting. It tells a story. Is it for sale?'' (unknown)

``Everything I have is for sale,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.

``How much is this thing?'' (unknown)

``Ten thousand francs,'' (the girl)
said the young girl, without a smile.

``Everything that Mademoiselle Nioche may do at present is mine in advance,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``It makes part of an order I gave her (it) some months ago. So you can't have this.'' (unknown)

``Monsieur will lose nothing by it,'' (the girl)
said the young girl, looking at Valentin. And she (girl) began to put up her (girl) utensils.

``I shall have gained a charming memory,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``You are going away? your day is over?'' (unknown)

``My father is coming to fetch me,'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
said Mademoiselle Noémie.

She (girl) had hardly spoken when, through the door behind her (girl), which opens on one of the great white stone staircases of the Louvre, M. Nioche made his (Valentin) appearance. He (Valentin) came in with his (Valentin) usual even, patient shuffle, and he (Valentin) made a low salute to the two gentlemen who were standing before his (Valentin) daughter's easel. Newman shook his (Newman) hands with muscular friendliness, and Valentin returned his (Valentin) greeting with extreme deference. While the old man stood waiting for Noémie to make a parcel of her (daughter) implements, he (Valentin) let his (Valentin) mild, oblique gaze hover toward Bellegarde, who was watching Mademoiselle Noémie put on her (daughter) bonnet and mantle. Valentin was at no pains to disguise his (Valentin) scrutiny. He (Valentin) looked at a pretty girl as he (Valentin) would have listened to a piece of music. Attention, in each case, was simple good manners. M. Nioche at last took his (Valentin) daughter's paint-box in one hand and the bedaubed canvas, after giving it a solemn, puzzled stare, in the other, and led the way to the door. Mademoiselle Noémie made the young men the salute of a duchess, and followed her (duchess) father.

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``what do you think of her (it)?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``She (it) is very remarkable. _Diable, diable, diable!_'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
repeated M. de Bellegarde, reflectively;
``she (it) is very remarkable.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``I am afraid she (it) is a sad little adventuress,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Not a little one--a great one. She (it) has the material.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
And Valentin began to walk away slowly, looking vaguely at the pictures on the walls, with a thoughtful illumination in his (Valentin) eye. Nothing could have appealed to his (Valentin) imagination more than the possible adventures of a young lady endowed with the
``material'' (a lady)
of Mademoiselle Nioche.
``She (it) is very interesting,'' (he)
he (Valentin) went on.
``She (it) is a beautiful type.'' (unknown)

``A beautiful type? What the deuce do you mean?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``I mean from the artistic point of view. She (it) is an artist,--outside of her (it) painting, which obviously is execrable.'' (unknown)

``But she (it) is not beautiful. I don't even think her (it) very pretty.'' (unknown)

``She (it) is quite pretty enough for her (it) purposes, and it is a face and figure on which everything tells. If she (it) were prettier she (it) would be less intelligent, and her (it) intelligence is half of her (it) charm.'' (unknown)

``In what way,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman, who was much amused at his (Newman) companion's immediate philosophisation of Mademoiselle Nioche,
``does her (it) intelligence strike you as so remarkable?'' (Mademoiselle Nioche)

``She (it) has taken the measure of life, and she (it) has determined to _be_ something--to succeed at any cost. Her (it) painting, of course, is a mere trick to gain time. She (it) is waiting for her (it) chance; she (it) wishes to launch herself, and to do it well. She (it) knows her (it) Paris. She (it) is one of fifty thousand, so far as the mere ambition goes; but I am very sure that in the way of resolution and capacity she (it) is a rarity. And in one gift--perfect heartlessness--I will warrant she (it) is unsurpassed. She (it) has not as much heart as will go on the point of a needle. That is an immense virtue. Yes, she (it) is one of the celebrities of the future.'' (unknown)

``Heaven help us!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``how far the artistic point of view may take a man! But in this case I must request that you don't let it take you too far. You have learned a wonderful deal about Mademoiselle Noémie in a quarter of an hour. Let that suffice; don't follow up your researches.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``My dear fellow,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
cried Bellegarde with warmth,
``I hope I have too good manners to intrude.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``You are not intruding. The girl is nothing to me. In fact, I rather dislike her (girl). But I like her (girl) poor old father, and for his (father) sake I beg you to abstain from any attempt to verify your theories.'' (unknown)

``For the sake of that seedy old gentleman who came to fetch her (girl)?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
demanded Valentin, stopping short. And on Newman's assenting,
``Ah no, ah no,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
he (Newman) went on with a smile.
``You are quite wrong, my dear fellow; you needn't mind him (gentleman).'' (unknown)

``I verily believe that you are accusing the poor gentleman of being capable of rejoicing in his (gentleman) daughter's dishonor.'' (unknown)

``_Voyons!_'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin;
``who is he (gentleman)? what is he (gentleman)?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``He (gentleman) is what he (gentleman) looks like: as poor as a rat, but very high-toned.'' (unknown)

``Exactly. I noticed him (gentleman) perfectly; be sure I do him (gentleman) justice. He (gentleman) has had losses, _des malheurs_, as we say. He (gentleman) is very low-spirited, and his (gentleman) daughter is too much for him (gentleman). He (gentleman) is the pink of respectability, and he (gentleman) has sixty years of honesty on his (gentleman) back. All this I perfectly appreciate. But I know my fellow-men and my fellow-Parisians, and I will make a bargain with you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman gave ear to his (Newman) bargain and he (Newman) went on.
``He (gentleman) would rather his (gentleman) daughter were a good girl than a bad one, but if the worst comes to the worst, the old man will not do what Virginius did. Success justifies everything. If Mademoiselle Noémie makes a figure, her (daughter) papa will feel--well, we will call it relieved. And she (daughter) will make a figure. The old gentleman's future is assured.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what Virginius did, but M. Nioche will shoot Miss Noémie,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``After that, I suppose his (gentleman) future will be assured in some snug prison.'' (unknown)

``I am not a cynic; I am simply an observer,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin rejoined.
``Mademoiselle Noémie interests me; she (daughter) is extremely remarkable. If there is a good reason, in honor or decency, for dismissing her (daughter) from my thoughts forever, I am perfectly willing to do it. Your estimate of the papa's sensibilities is a good reason until it is invalidated. I promise you not to look at the young girl again until you tell me that you have changed your mind about the papa. When he (papa) has given distinct proof of being a philosopher, you will raise your interdict. Do you agree to that?'' (unknown)

``Do you mean to bribe him (papa)?'' (unknown)

``Oh, you admit, then, that he (papa) is bribable? No, he (papa) would ask too much, and it would not be exactly fair. I mean simply to wait. You will continue, I suppose, to see this interesting couple, and you will give me the news yourself.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``if the old man turns out a humbug, you may do what you please. I wash my hands of the matter. For the girl herself, you may be at rest. I don't know what harm she (girl) may do to me, but I certainly can't hurt her (girl). It seems to me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``that you are very well matched. You are both hard cases, and M. Nioche and I, I believe, are the only virtuous men to be found in Paris.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Soon after this M. de Bellegarde, in punishment for his (Bellegarde) levity, received a stern poke in the back from a pointed instrument. Turning quickly round he (Bellegarde) found the weapon to be a parasol wielded by a lady in green gauze bonnet. Valentin's English cousins had been drifting about unpiloted, and evidently deemed that they had a grievance. Newman left him (Newman) to their mercies, but with a boundless faith in his (Newman) power to plead his (Newman) cause.

CHAPTER XII

Three days after his (Newman) introduction to the family of Madame de Cintré, Newman, coming in toward evening, found upon his (Newman) table the card of the Marquis de Bellegarde. On the following day he (Newman) received a note informing him (Newman) that the Marquise de Bellegarde would be grateful for the honor of his (Bellegarde) company at dinner.

He (Bellegarde) went, of course, though he (Bellegarde) had to break another engagement to do it. He (Bellegarde) was ushered into the room in which Madame de Bellegarde had received him (Bellegarde) before, and here he (Bellegarde) found his (Bellegarde) venerable hostess, surrounded by her (hostess) entire family. The room was lighted only by the crackling fire, which illuminated the very small pink slippers of a lady who, seated in a low chair, was stretching out her (lady) toes before it. This lady was the younger Madame de Bellegarde. Madame de Cintré was seated at the other end of the room, holding a little girl against her (girl) knee, the child of her (girl) brother Urbain, to whom she (girl) was apparently relating a wonderful story. Valentin was sitting on a puff, close to his (Valentin) sister-in-law, into whose ear he (Valentin) was certainly distilling the finest nonsense. The marquis was stationed before the fire, with his (marquis) head erect and his (marquis) hands behind him (marquis), in an attitude of formal expectancy.

Old Madame de Bellegarde stood up to give Newman her (sister-in-law) greeting, and there was that in the way she (sister-in-law) did so which seemed to measure narrowly the extent of her (sister-in-law) condescension.

``We are all alone, you see, we have asked no one else,'' (she)
she (sister-in-law) said austerely.

``I am very glad you didn't; this is much more sociable,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Good evening, sir,'' (he)
and he (Newman) offered his (Newman) hand to the marquis.

M. de Bellegarde was affable, but in spite of his (Bellegarde) dignity he (Bellegarde) was restless. He (Bellegarde) began to pace up and down the room, he (Bellegarde) looked out of the long windows, he (Bellegarde) took up books and laid them down again. Young Madame de Bellegarde gave Newman her (sister-in-law) hand without moving and without looking at him (Bellegarde).

``You may think that is coldness,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
exclaimed Valentin;
``but it is not, it is warmth. It shows she (It) is treating you as an intimate. Now she (It) detests me, and yet she (It) is always looking at me.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``No wonder I detest you if I am always looking at you!'' (the lady)
cried the lady.
``If Mr. Newman does not like my way of shaking hands, I will do it again.'' (hero)

But this charming privilege was lost upon our hero, who was already making his (Valentin) way across the room to Madame de Cintré. She (lady) looked at him (Valentin) as she (lady) shook hands, but she (lady) went on with the story she (lady) was telling her (lady) little niece. She (lady) had only two or three phrases to add, but they were apparently of great moment. She (lady) deepened her (lady) voice, smiling as she (lady) did so, and the little girl gazed at her (girl) with round eyes.

``But in the end the young prince married the beautiful Florabella,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré,
``and carried her (It) off to live with him (prince) in the Land of the Pink Sky. There she (It) was so happy that she (It) forgot all her (It) troubles, and went out to drive every day of her (It) life in an ivory coach drawn by five hundred white mice. Poor Florabella,'' (Madame de Cintré)
she (girl) exclaimed to Newman,
``had suffered terribly.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``She (It) had had nothing to eat for six months,'' (Blanche)
said little Blanche.

``Yes, but when the six months were over, she (It) had a plum-cake as big as that ottoman,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.
``That quite set her (It) up again.'' (unknown)

``What a checkered career!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Are you very fond of children?'' (He)
He (Newman) was certain that she (Blanche) was, but he (Newman) wished to make her (Blanche) say it.

``I like to talk with them,'' (she)
she (Blanche) answered;
``we can talk with them so much more seriously than with grown persons. That is great nonsense that I have been telling Blanche, but it is a great deal more serious than most of what we say in society.'' (she)

``I wish you would talk to me, then, as if I were Blanche's age,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing.
``Were you happy at your ball the other night?'' (unknown)

``Ecstatically!'' (unknown)

``Now you are talking the nonsense that we talk in society,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I don't believe that.'' (unknown)

``It was my own fault if I was not happy. The ball was very pretty, and everyone very amiable.'' (unknown)

``It was on your conscience,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``that you had annoyed your mother and your brother.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Madame de Cintré looked at him (Newman) a moment without answering.

``That is true,'' (she)
she (Blanche) replied at last.
``I had undertaken more than I could carry out. I have very little courage; I am not a heroine.'' (She)
She (Blanche) said this with a certain soft emphasis; but then, changing her (Blanche) tone,
``I could never have gone through the sufferings of the beautiful Florabella,'' (She)
she (Blanche) added, not even for her (Blanche) prospective rewards.

Dinner was announced, and Newman betook himself to the side of the old Madame de Bellegarde. The dining-room, at the end of a cold corridor, was vast and sombre; the dinner was simple and delicately excellent. Newman wondered whether Madame de Cintré had had something to do with ordering the repast and greatly hoped she (Blanche) had. Once seated at table, with the various members of the ancient house of Bellegarde around him (Bellegarde), he (Bellegarde) asked himself the meaning of his (Bellegarde) position. Was the old lady responding to his (Bellegarde) advances? Did the fact that he (Bellegarde) was a solitary guest augment his (Bellegarde) credit or diminish it? Were they ashamed to show him (Bellegarde) to other people, or did they wish to give him (Bellegarde) a sign of sudden adoption into their last reserve of favor? Newman was on his (Newman) guard; he (Newman) was watchful and conjectural; and yet at the same time he (Newman) was vaguely indifferent. Whether they gave him (Newman) a long rope or a short one he (Newman) was there now, and Madame de Cintré was opposite to him (Cintré). She (lady) had a tall candlestick on each side of her (lady); she (lady) would sit there for the next hour, and that was enough. The dinner was extremely solemn and measured; he (Cintré) wondered whether this was always the state of things in

``old families.'' (he)
Madame de Bellegarde held her (lady) head very high, and fixed her (lady) eyes, which looked peculiarly sharp in her (lady) little, finely-wrinkled white face, very intently upon the table-service. The marquis appeared to have decided that the fine arts offered a safe subject of conversation, as not leading to startling personal revelations. Every now and then, having learned from Newman that he (Newman) had been through the museums of Europe, he (Newman) uttered some polished aphorism upon the flesh-tints of Rubens and the good taste of Sansovino. His (Rubens) manners seemed to indicate a fine, nervous dread that something disagreeable might happen if the atmosphere were not purified by allusions of a thoroughly superior cast.
``What under the sun is the man afraid of?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked himself.
``Does he (man) think I am going to offer to swap jack-knives with him (man)?'' (the marquis)
It was useless to shut his (Newman) eyes to the fact that the marquis was profoundly disagreeable to him (Newman). He (Newman) had never been a man of strong personal aversions; his (Newman) nerves had not been at the mercy of the mystical qualities of his (Newman) neighbors. But here was a man towards whom he (man) was irresistibly in opposition; a man of forms and phrases and postures; a man full of possible impertinences and treacheries. M. de Bellegarde made him (Bellegarde) feel as if he (Bellegarde) were standing bare-footed on a marble floor; and yet, to gain his (Bellegarde) desire, Newman felt perfectly able to stand. He (Newman) wondered what Madame de Cintré thought of his (Cintré) being accepted, if accepted it was. There was no judging from her (Bellegarde) face, which expressed simply the desire to be gracious in a manner which should require as little explicit recognition as possible. Young Madame de Bellegarde had always the same manners; she (Bellegarde) was always preoccupied, distracted, listening to everything and hearing nothing, looking at her (Bellegarde) dress, her (Bellegarde) rings, her (Bellegarde) finger-nails, seeming rather bored, and yet puzzling you to decide what was her (Bellegarde) ideal of social diversion. Newman was enlightened on this point later. Even Valentin did not quite seem master of his (Valentin) wits; his (Valentin) vivacity was fitful and forced, yet Newman observed that in the lapses of his (Newman) talk he (Newman) appeared excited. His (Newman) eyes had an intenser spark than usual. The effect of all this was that Newman, for the first time in his (Newman) life, was not himself; that he (Newman) measured his (Newman) movements, and counted his (Newman) words, and resolved that if the occasion demanded that he (Newman) should appear to have swallowed a ramrod, he (Newman) would meet the emergency.

After dinner M. de Bellegarde proposed to his (Bellegarde) guest that they should go into the smoking-room, and he (Bellegarde) led the way toward a small, somewhat musty apartment, the walls of which were ornamented with old hangings of stamped leather and trophies of rusty arms. Newman refused a cigar, but he (Newman) established himself upon one of the divans, while the marquis puffed his (Newman) own weed before the fire-place, and Valentin sat looking through the light fumes of a cigarette from one to the other.

``I can't keep quiet any longer,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, at last.
``I must tell you the news and congratulate you. My brother seems unable to come to the point; he (brother) revolves around his (brother) announcement like the priest around the altar. You are accepted as a candidate for the hand of our sister.'' (unknown)

``Valentin, be a little proper!'' (the marquis)
murmured the marquis, with a look of the most delicate irritation contracting the bridge of his (Valentin) high nose.

``There has been a family council,'' (the man)
the young man continued;
``my mother and Urbain have put their heads together, and even my testimony has not been altogether excluded. My mother and the marquis sat at a table covered with green cloth; my sister-in-law and I were on a bench against the wall. It was like a committee at the Corps Législatif. We were called up, one after the other, to testify. We spoke of you very handsomely. Madame de Bellegarde said that if she (sister-in-law) had not been told who you were, she (sister-in-law) would have taken you for a duke--an American duke, the Duke of California. I said that I could warrant you grateful for the smallest favors--modest, humble, unassuming. I was sure that you would know your own place, always, and never give us occasion to remind you of certain differences. After all, you couldn't help it if you were not a duke. There were none in your country; but if there had been, it was certain that, smart and active as you are, you would have got the pick of the titles. At this point I was ordered to sit down, but I think I made an impression in your favor.'' (the man)

M. de Bellegarde looked at his (Bellegarde) brother with dangerous coldness, and gave a smile as thin as the edge of a knife. Then he (Bellegarde) removed a spark of cigar-ash from the sleeve of his (Bellegarde) coat; he (Bellegarde) fixed his (Bellegarde) eyes for a while on the cornice of the room, and at last he (Bellegarde) inserted one of his (Bellegarde) white hands into the breast of his (Bellegarde) waistcoat.

``I must apologize to you for the deplorable levity of my brother,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said,
``and I must notify you that this is probably not the last time that his (brother) want of tact will cause you serious embarrassment.'' (he)

``No, I confess I have no tact,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``Is your embarrassment really painful, Newman? The marquis will put you right again; his (Newman) own touch is deliciously delicate.'' (unknown)

``Valentin, I am sorry to say,'' (the marquis)
the marquis continued,
``has never possessed the tone, the manner, that belongs to a young man in his (man) position. It has been a great affliction to his (man) mother, who is very fond of the old traditions. But you must remember that he (man) speaks for no one but himself.'' (the marquis)

``Oh, I don't mind him (man), sir,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, good-humoredly.
``I know what he (man) amounts to.'' (unknown)

``In the good old times,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``marquises and counts used to have their appointed fools and jesters, to crack jokes for them. Nowadays we see a great strapping democrat keeping a count about him (democrat) to play the fool. It's a good situation, but I certainly am very degenerate.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

M. de Bellegarde fixed his (Bellegarde) eyes for some time on the floor.

``My mother informed me,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said presently,
``of the announcement that you made to her (mother) the other evening.'' (he)

``That I desired to marry your sister?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``That you wished to arrange a marriage,'' (the marquis Cintré)
said the marquis, slowly,
``with my sister, the Comtesse de Cintré. The proposal was serious, and required, on my mother's part, a great deal of reflection. She (mother) naturally took me into her (mother) counsels, and I gave my most zealous attention to the subject. There was a great deal to be considered; more than you appear to imagine. We have viewed the question on all its faces, we have weighed one thing against another. Our conclusion has been that we favor your suit. My mother has desired me to inform you of our decision. She (mother) will have the honor of saying a few words to you on the subject herself. Meanwhile, by us, the heads of the family, you are accepted.'' (the marquis Cintré)

Newman got up and came nearer to the marquis.

``You will do nothing to hinder me, and all you can to help me, eh?'' (unknown)

``I will recommend my sister to accept you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman passed his (Newman) hand over his (Newman) face, and pressed it for a moment upon his (Newman) eyes. This promise had a great sound, and yet the pleasure he (Newman) took in it was embittered by his (Newman) having to stand there so and receive his (Newman) passport from M. de Bellegarde. The idea of having this gentleman mixed up with his (gentleman) wooing and wedding was more and more disagreeable to him (gentleman). But Newman had resolved to go through the mill, as he (Newman) imagined it, and he (Newman) would not cry out at the first turn of the wheel. He (Newman) was silent a while, and then he (Newman) said, with a certain dryness which Valentin told him (Valentin) afterwards had a very grand air,

``I am much obliged to you.'' (him)

``I take note of the promise,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``I register the vow.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

M. de Bellegarde began to gaze at the cornice again; he (Bellegarde) apparently had something more to say.

``I must do my mother the justice,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) resumed,
``I must do myself the justice, to say that our decision was not easy. Such an arrangement was not what we had expected. The idea that my sister should marry a gentleman--ah--in business was something of a novelty.'' (he)

``So I told you, you know,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin raising his (Valentin) finger at Newman.

``The novelty has not quite worn away, I confess,'' (the marquis)
the marquis went on;
``perhaps it never will, entirely. But possibly that is not altogether to be regretted,'' (the marquis)
and he (Newman) gave his (Newman) thin smile again.
``It may be that the time has come when we should make some concession to novelty. There had been no novelties in our house for a great many years. I made the observation to my mother, and she (mother) did me the honor to admit that it was worthy of attention.'' (unknown)

``My dear brother,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
interrupted Valentin, ``is not your memory just here leading you the least bit astray? Our mother is, I may say, distinguished for her (mother) small respect of abstract reasoning. Are you very sure that she (mother) replied to your striking proposition in the gracious manner you describe? You know how terribly incisive she (mother) is sometimes. Didn't she (mother), rather, do you the honor to say, `A fiddlestick for your phrases! There are better reasons than that?'''

``Other reasons were discussed,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis, without looking at Valentin, but with an audible tremor in his (Valentin) voice;
``some of them possibly were better. We are conservative, Mr. Newman, but we are not also bigots. We judged the matter liberally. We have no doubt that everything will be comfortable.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Newman had stood listening to these remarks with his (Newman) arms folded and his (Newman) eyes fastened upon M. de Bellegarde,

``Comfortable?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
he (Bellegarde) said, with a sort of grim flatness of intonation.
``Why shouldn't we be comfortable? If you are not, it will be your own fault; I have everything to make _me_ so.'' (unknown)

``My brother means that with the lapse of time you may get used to the change'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
--and Valentin paused, to light another cigarette.

``What change?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman in the same tone.

``Urbain,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, very gravely,
``I am afraid that Mr. Newman does not quite realize the change. We ought to insist upon that.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``My brother goes too far,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde.
``It is his (brother) fatal want of tact again. It is my mother's wish, and mine, that no such allusions should be made. Pray never make them yourself. We prefer to assume that the person accepted as the possible husband of my sister is one of ourselves, and that he (husband) should have no explanations to make. With a little discretion on both sides, everything, I think, will be easy. That is exactly what I wished to say--that we quite understand what we have undertaken, and that you may depend upon our adhering to our resolution.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin shook his (Valentin) hands in the air and then buried his (Valentin) face in them.

``I have less tact than I might have, no doubt; but oh, my brother, if you knew what you yourself were saying!'' (he)
And he (Valentin) went off into a long laugh.

M. de Bellegarde's face flushed a little, but he (Bellegarde) held his (Bellegarde) head higher, as if to repudiate this concession to vulgar perturbability.

``I am sure you understand me,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said to Newman.

``Oh no, I don't understand you at all,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But you needn't mind that. I don't care. In fact, I think I had better not understand you. I might not like it. That wouldn't suit me at all, you know. I want to marry your sister, that's all; to do it as quickly as possible, and to find fault with nothing. I don't care how I do it. I am not marrying you, you know, sir. I have got my leave, and that is all I want.'' (unknown)

``You had better receive the last word from my mother,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis.

``Very good; I will go and get it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman; and he (Newman) prepared to return to the drawing-room.

M. de Bellegarde made a motion for him (Bellegarde) to pass first, and when Newman had gone out he (Newman) shut himself into the room with Valentin. Newman had been a trifle bewildered by the audacious irony of the younger brother, and he (Newman) had not needed its aid to point the moral of M. de Bellegarde's transcendent patronage. He (Bellegarde) had wit enough to appreciate the force of that civility which consists in calling your attention to the impertinences it spares you. But he (Bellegarde) had felt warmly the delicate sympathy with himself that underlay Valentin's fraternal irreverence, and he (Valentin) was most unwilling that his (Valentin) friend should pay a tax upon it. He (Valentin) paused a moment in the corridor, after he (Valentin) had gone a few steps, expecting to hear the resonance of M. de Bellegarde's displeasure; but he (Bellegarde) detected only a perfect stillness. The stillness itself seemed a trifle portentous; he (Bellegarde) reflected however that he (Bellegarde) had no right to stand listening, and he (Bellegarde) made his (Bellegarde) way back to the salon. In his (Bellegarde) absence several persons had come in. They were scattered about the room in groups, two or three of them having passed into a small boudoir, next to the drawing-room, which had now been lighted and opened. Old Madame de Bellegarde was in her (Bellegarde) place by the fire, talking to a very old gentleman in a wig and a profuse white neck cloth of the fashion of 1820. Madame de Cintré was bending a listening head to the historic confidences of an old lady who was presumably the wife of the old gentleman in the neckcloth, an old lady in a red satin dress and an ermine cape, who wore across her (lady) forehead a band with a topaz set in it. Young Madame de Bellegarde, when Newman came in, left some people among whom she (lady) was sitting, and took the place that she (lady) had occupied before dinner. Then she (lady) gave a little push to the puff that stood near her (lady), and by a glance at Newman seemed to indicate that she (lady) had placed it in position for him (Newman). He (Newman) went and took possession of it; the marquis's wife amused and puzzled him (Newman).

``I know your secret,'' (she)
she (wife) said, in her (wife) bad but charming English;
``you need make no mystery of it. You wish to marry my sister-in-law. _C’est un beau choix_. A man like you ought to marry a tall, thin woman. You must know that I have spoken in your favor; you owe me a famous taper!'' (she)

``You have spoken to Madame de Cintré?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Oh no, not that. You may think it strange, but my sister-in-law and I are not so intimate as that. No; I spoke to my husband and my mother-in-law; I said I was sure we could do what we chose with you.'' (unknown)

``I am much obliged to you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing;
``but you can't.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I know that very well; I didn't believe a word of it. But I wanted you to come into the house; I thought we should be friends.'' (unknown)

``I am very sure of it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Don't be too sure. If you like Madame de Cintré so much, perhaps you will not like me. We are as different as blue and pink. But you and I have something in common. I have come into this family by marriage; you want to come into it in the same way.'' (unknown)

``Oh no, I don't!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
interrupted Newman.
``I only want to take Madame de Cintré out of it.'' (unknown)

``Well, to cast your nets you have to go into the water. Our positions are alike; we shall be able to compare notes. What do you think of my husband? It's a strange question, isn't it? But I shall ask you some stranger ones yet.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps a stranger one will be easier to answer,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You might try me.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you get off very well; the old Comte de la Rochefidèle, yonder, couldn't do it better. I told them that if we only gave you a chance you would be a perfect _talon rouge_. I know something about men. Besides, you and I belong to the same camp. I am a ferocious democrat. By birth I am _vieille roche_; a good little bit of the history of France is the history of my family. Oh, you never heard of us, of course! _Ce que c’est que la gloire!_ We are much better than the Bellegardes, at any rate. But I don't care a pin for my pedigree; I want to belong to my time. I'm a revolutionist, a radical, a child of the age! I am sure I go beyond you. I like clever people, wherever they come from, and I take my amusement wherever I find it. I don't pout at the Empire; here all the world pouts at the Empire. Of course I have to mind what I say; but I expect to take my revenge with you.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
Madame de Bellegarde discoursed for some time longer in this sympathetic strain, with an eager abundance which seemed to indicate that her (wife) opportunities for revealing her (wife) esoteric philosophy were indeed rare. She (wife) hoped that Newman would never be afraid of her (wife), however he (Newman) might be with the others, for, really, she (wife) went very far indeed.
``Strong people'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
--_le gens forts_--were in her (wife) opinion equal, all the world over. Newman listened to her (wife) with an attention at once beguiled and irritated. He (Newman) wondered what the deuce she (wife), too, was driving at, with her (wife) hope that he (Newman) would not be afraid of her (wife) and her (wife) protestations of equality. In so far as he (Newman) could understand her (wife), she (wife) was wrong; a silly, rattling woman was certainly not the equal of a sensible man, preoccupied with an ambitious passion. Madame de Bellegarde stopped suddenly, and looked at him (Bellegarde) sharply, shaking her (woman) fan.
``I see you don't believe me,'' (she)
she (woman) said,
``you are too much on your guard. You will not form an alliance, offensive or defensive? You are very wrong; I could help you.'' (she)

Newman answered that he (Newman) was very grateful and that he (Newman) would certainly ask for help; she (woman) should see.

``But first of all,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``I must help myself.'' (he)
And he (Newman) went to join Madame de Cintré.

``I have been telling Madame de la Rochefidèle that you are an American,'' (she)
she (woman) said, as he (Newman) came up.
``It interests her (I) greatly. Her (I) father went over with the French troops to help you in your battles in the last century, and she (I) has always, in consequence, wanted greatly to see an American. But she (I) has never succeeded till to-night. You are the first--to her (I) knowledge--that she (I) has ever looked at.'' (Madame)

Madame de la Rochefidèle had an aged, cadaverous face, with a falling of the lower jaw which prevented her (woman) from bringing her (woman) lips together, and reduced her (woman) conversations to a series of impressive but inarticulate gutturals. She (woman) raised an antique eyeglass, elaborately mounted in chased silver, and looked at Newman from head to foot. Then she (woman) said something to which he (Newman) listened deferentially, but which he (Newman) completely failed to understand.

``Madame de la Rochefidèle says that she (I) is convinced that she (I) must have seen Americans without knowing it,'' (Madame)
Madame de Cintré explained. Newman thought it probable she (woman) had seen a great many things without knowing it; and the old lady, again addressing herself to utterance, declared--as interpreted by Madame de Cintré--that she (lady) wished she (lady) had known it.

At this moment the old gentleman who had been talking to the elder Madame de Bellegarde drew near, leading the marquise on his (Bellegarde) arm. His (Bellegarde) wife pointed out Newman to him (Newman), apparently explaining his (Newman) remarkable origin. M. de la Rochefidèle, whose old age was rosy and rotund, spoke very neatly and clearly, almost as prettily, Newman thought, as M. Nioche. When he (Newman) had been enlightened, he (Newman) turned to Newman with an inimitable elderly grace.

``Monsieur is by no means the first American that I have seen,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``Almost the first person I ever saw--to notice him (I)--was an American.'' (unknown)

``Ah?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, sympathetically.

``The great Dr. Franklin,'' (M. de la Rochefidèle/Rochefidèle)
said M. de la Rochefidèle.
``Of course I was very young. He (Franklin) was received very well in our _monde._'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``Not better than Mr. Newman,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``I beg he (Newman) will offer his (Newman) arm into the other room. I could have offered no higher privilege to Dr. Franklin.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman, complying with Madame de Bellegarde's request, perceived that her (wife) two sons had returned to the drawing-room. He (Newman) scanned their faces an instant for traces of the scene that had followed his (Newman) separation from them, but the marquis seemed neither more nor less frigidly grand than usual, and Valentin was kissing ladies' hands with at least his (Valentin) habitual air of self-abandonment to the act. Madame de Bellegarde gave a glance at her (wife) eldest son, and by the time she (wife) had crossed the threshold of her (wife) boudoir he (Bellegarde) was at her (wife) side. The room was now empty and offered a sufficient degree of privacy. The old lady disengaged herself from Newman's arm and rested her (lady) hand on the arm of the marquis; and in this position she (lady) stood a moment, holding her (lady) head high and biting her (lady) small under-lip. I am afraid the picture was lost upon Newman, but Madame de Bellegarde was, in fact, at this moment a striking image of the dignity which--even in the case of a little time-shrunken old lady--may reside in the habit of unquestioned authority and the absoluteness of a social theory favorable to yourself.

``My son has spoken to you as I desired,'' (she)
she (lady) said,
``and you understand that we shall not interfere. The rest will lie with yourself.'' (she)

``M. de Bellegarde told me several things I didn't understand,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``but I made out that. You will leave me open field. I am much obliged.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I wish to add a word that my son probably did not feel at liberty to say,'' (the marquise)
the marquise rejoined.
``I must say it for my own peace of mind. We are stretching a point; we are doing you a great favor.'' (unknown)

``Oh, your son said it very well; didn't you?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Not so well as my mother,'' (the marquis)
declared the marquis.

``I can only repeat--I am much obliged.'' (unknown)

``It is proper I should tell you,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
Madame de Bellegarde went on,
``that I am very proud, and that I hold my head very high. I may be wrong, but I am too old to change. At least I know it, and I don't pretend to anything else. Don't flatter yourself that my daughter is not proud. She (daughter) is proud in her (daughter) own way--a somewhat different way from mine. You will have to make your terms with that. Even Valentin is proud, if you touch the right spot--or the wrong one. Urbain is proud; that you see for yourself. Sometimes I think he (Urbain) is a little too proud; but I wouldn't change him (Urbain). He (Urbain) is the best of my children; he (Urbain) cleaves to his (Urbain) old mother. But I have said enough to show you that we are all proud together. It is well that you should know the sort of people you have come among.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I can only say, in return, that I am _not_ proud; I shan't mind you! But you speak as if you intended to be very disagreeable.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I shall not enjoy having my daughter marry you, and I shall not pretend to enjoy it. If you don't mind that, so much the better.'' (unknown)

``If you stick to your own side of the contract we shall not quarrel; that is all I ask of you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Keep your hands off, and give me an open field. I am very much in earnest, and there is not the slightest danger of my getting discouraged or backing out. You will have me constantly before your eyes; if you don't like it, I am sorry for you. I will do for your daughter, if she (daughter) will accept me, everything that a man can do for a woman. I am happy to tell you that, as a promise--a pledge. I consider that on your side you make me an equal pledge. You will not back out, eh?'' (unknown)

``I don't know what you mean by `backing out,''' said the marquise.

``It suggests a movement of which I think no Bellegarde has ever been guilty.'' (unknown)

``Our word is our word,'' (Urbain/Urbain de Bellegarde)
said Urbain.
``We have given it.'' (unknown)

``Well, now,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I am very glad you are so proud. It makes me believe that you will keep it.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

The marquise was silent a moment, and then, suddenly,

``I shall always be polite to you, Mr. Newman,'' (The marquise)
she (lady) declared,
``but, decidedly, I shall never like you.'' (she)

``Don't be too sure,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing.

``I am so sure that I will ask you to take me back to my armchair without the least fear of having my sentiments modified by the service you render me.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
And Madame de Bellegarde took his (Bellegarde) arm, and returned to the salon and to her (lady) customary place.

M. de la Rochefidèle and his (Bellegarde) wife were preparing to take their leave, and Madame de Cintré's interview with the mumbling old lady was at an end. She (lady) stood looking about her (lady), asking herself, apparently to whom she (lady) should next speak, when Newman came up to her (lady).

``Your mother has given me leave--very solemnly--to come here often,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``I mean to come often.'' (unknown)

``I shall be glad to see you,'' (she)
she (lady) answered simply. And then, in a moment:
``You probably think it very strange that there should be such a solemnity--as you say--about your coming.'' (unknown)

``Well, yes; I do, rather.'' (unknown)

``Do you remember what my brother Valentin said, the first time you came to see me--that we were a strange, strange family?'' (unknown)

``It was not the first time I came, but the second,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Very true. Valentin annoyed me at the time, but now I know you better, I may tell you he (Valentin) was right. If you come often, you will see!'' (Madame)
and Madame de Cintré turned away.

Newman watched her (lady) a while, talking with other people, and then he (Newman) took his (Newman) leave. He (Newman) shook hands last with Valentin de Bellegarde, who came out with him (Bellegarde) to the top of the staircase.

``Well, you have got your permit,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``I hope you liked the process.'' (unknown)

``I like your sister, more than ever. But don't worry your brother any more for my sake,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman added.
``I don't mind him (brother). I am afraid he (brother) came down on you in the smoking-room, after I went out.'' (unknown)

``When my brother comes down on me,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``he (brother) falls hard. I have a peculiar way of receiving him (brother). I must say,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
he (Valentin) continued,
``that they came up to the mark much sooner than I expected. I don't understand it, they must have had to turn the screw pretty tight. It's a tribute to your millions.'' (he)

``Well, it's the most precious one they have ever received,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

He (Newman) was turning away when Valentin stopped him (Valentin), looking at him (Valentin) with a brilliant, softly-cynical glance.

``I should like to know whether, within a few days, you have seen your venerable friend M. Nioche.'' (unknown)

``He (friend) was yesterday at my rooms,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered.

``What did he (friend) tell you?'' (unknown)

``Nothing particular.'' (unknown)
