Newman observed the change in her (Noémie) appearance. She (Noémie) was very elegant and prettier than before; she (Noémie) looked a year or two older, and it was noticeable that, to the eye, she (Noémie) had only gained in respectability. She (Noémie) looked

``lady-like.'' (She)
She (Noémie) was dressed in quiet colors, and wore her (Noémie) expensively unobtrusive toilet with a grace that might have come from years of practice. Her (Noémie) present self-possession and _aplomb_ struck Newman as really infernal, and he (Newman) inclined to agree with Valentin de Bellegarde that the young lady was very remarkable.
``No, to tell the truth, I didn't come for you,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said,
``and I didn't expect to find you. I was told,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) added in a moment
``that you had left your father.'' (he)

``_Quelle horreur!_'' (Mademoiselle Nioche)
cried Mademoiselle Nioche with a smile.
``Does one leave one's father? You have the proof of the contrary.'' (unknown)

``Yes, convincing proof,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman glancing at M. Nioche. The old man caught his (Newman) glance obliquely, with his (man) faded, deprecating eye, and then, lifting his (man) empty glass, pretended to drink again.

``Who told you that?'' (unknown)
Noémie demanded.
``I know very well. It was M. de Bellegarde. Why don't you say yes? You are not polite.'' (unknown)

``I am embarrassed,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I set you a better example. I know M. de Bellegarde told you. He (Bellegarde) knows a great deal about me--or he (Bellegarde) thinks he (Bellegarde) does. He (Bellegarde) has taken a great deal of trouble to find out, but half of it isn't true. In the first place, I haven't left my father; I am much too fond of him (father). Isn't it so, little father? M. de Bellegarde is a charming young man; it is impossible to be cleverer. I know a good deal about him (Bellegarde) too; you can tell him (Bellegarde) that when you next see him (Bellegarde).'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with a sturdy grin;
``I won't carry any messages for you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Just as you please,'' (Mademoiselle Nioche)
said Mademoiselle Nioche,
``I don't depend upon you, nor does M. de Bellegarde either. He (Bellegarde) is very much interested in me; he (Bellegarde) can be left to his (Bellegarde) own devices. He (Bellegarde) is a contrast to you.'' (Mademoiselle Nioche)

``Oh, he (Bellegarde) is a great contrast to me, I have no doubt'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But I don't exactly know how you mean it.'' (unknown)

``I mean it in this way. First of all, he (Bellegarde) never offered to help me to a _dot_ and a husband.'' (Mademoiselle Nioche)
And Mademoiselle Nioche paused, smiling.
``I won't say that is in his (Bellegarde) favor, for I do you justice. What led you, by the way, to make me such a queer offer? You didn't care for me.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes, I did,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``How so?'' (unknown)

``It would have given me real pleasure to see you married to a respectable young fellow.'' (unknown)

``With six thousand francs of income!'' (Mademoiselle Nioche)
cried Mademoiselle Nioche.
``Do you call that caring for me? I'm afraid you know little about women. You were not _galant_; you were not what you might have been.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman flushed a trifle fiercely.

``Come!'' (he)
he (Newman) exclaimed
``that's rather strong. I had no idea I had been so shabby.'' (he)

Mademoiselle Nioche smiled as she (lady) took up her (lady) muff.

``It is something, at any rate, to have made you angry.'' (father)

Her (lady) father had leaned both his (father) elbows on the table, and his (father) head, bent forward, was supported in his (father) hands, the thin white fingers of which were pressed over his (father) ears. In his (father) position he (father) was staring fixedly at the bottom of his (father) empty glass, and Newman supposed he (Newman) was not hearing. Mademoiselle Noémie buttoned her (lady) furred jacket and pushed back her (lady) chair, casting a glance charged with the consciousness of an expensive appearance first down over her (lady) flounces and then up at Newman.

``You had better have remained an honest girl,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said quietly.

M. Nioche continued to stare at the bottom of his (Newman) glass, and his (Newman) daughter got up, still bravely smiling.

``You mean that I look so much like one? That's more than most women do nowadays. Don't judge me yet awhile,'' (she)
she (daughter) added.
``I mean to succeed; that's what I mean to do. I leave you; I don't mean to be seen in cafés, for one thing. I can't think what you want of my poor father; he (father)'s very comfortable now. It isn't his (father) fault, either. _Au revoir_, little father.'' (she)
And she (daughter) tapped the old man on the head with her (daughter) muff. Then she (daughter) stopped a minute, looking at Newman.
``Tell M. de Bellegarde, when he (Bellegarde) wants news of me, to come and get it from _me!_'' (she)
And she (daughter) turned and departed, the white-aproned waiter, with a bow, holding the door wide open for her (daughter).

M. Nioche sat motionless, and Newman hardly knew what to say to him (Newman). The old man looked dismally foolish.

``So you determined not to shoot her (I), after all,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said presently.

M. Nioche, without moving, raised his (Newman) eyes and gave him (Newman) a long, peculiar look. It seemed to confess everything, and yet not to ask for pity, nor to pretend, on the other hand, to a rugged ability to do without it. It might have expressed the state of mind of an innocuous insect, flat in shape and conscious of the impending pressure of a boot-sole, and reflecting that he (Newman) was perhaps too flat to be crushed. M. Nioche's gaze was a profession of moral flatness.

``You despise me terribly,'' (he)
he (Newman) said, in the weakest possible voice.

``Oh no,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``it is none of my business. It's a good plan to take things easily.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I made you too many fine speeches,'' (M. Nioche)
M. Nioche added.
``I meant them at the time.'' (unknown)

``I am sure I am very glad you didn't shoot her (I),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I was afraid you might have shot yourself. That is why I came to look you up.'' (he)
And he (Newman) began to button his (Newman) coat.

``Neither,'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche.
``You despise me, and I can't explain to you. I hoped I shouldn't see you again.'' (unknown)

``Why, that's rather shabby,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You shouldn't drop your friends that way. Besides, the last time you came to see me I thought you particularly jolly.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I remember,'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche musingly;
``I was in a fever. I didn't know what I said, what I did. It was delirium.'' (M. Nioche)

``Ah, well, you are quieter now.'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche was silent a moment.

``As quiet as the grave,'' (he)
he (Newman) whispered softly.

``Are you very unhappy?'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche rubbed his (Newman) forehead slowly, and even pushed back his (Newman) wig a little, looking askance at his (Newman) empty glass.

``Yes--yes. But that's an old story. I have always been unhappy. My daughter does what she (daughter) will with me. I take what she (daughter) gives me, good or bad. I have no spirit, and when you have no spirit you must keep quiet. I shan't trouble you any more.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, rather disgusted at the smooth operation of the old man's philosophy,
``that's as you please.'' (the man)

M. Nioche seemed to have been prepared to be despised but nevertheless he (Newman) made a feeble movement of appeal from Newman's faint praise.

``After all,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``she (daughter) is my daughter, and I can still look after her (daughter). If she (daughter) will do wrong, why she (daughter) will. But there are many different paths, there are degrees. I can give her (daughter) the benefit--give her (daughter) the benefit'' (he)
--and M. Nioche paused, staring vaguely at Newman, who began to suspect that his (Newman) brain had softened--
``the benefit of my experience,'' (Newman)
M. Nioche added.

``Your experience?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
inquired Newman, both amused and amazed.

``My experience of business,'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche, gravely.

``Ah, yes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing,
``that will be a great advantage to her (daughter)!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And then he (Newman) said good-bye, and offered the poor, foolish old man his (Newman) hand.

M. Nioche took it and leaned back against the wall, holding it a moment and looking up at him (Newman).

``I suppose you think my wits are going,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``Very likely; I have always a pain in my head. That's why I can't explain, I can't tell you. And she (daughter)'s so strong, she (daughter) makes me walk as she (daughter) will, anywhere! But there's this--there's this.'' (he)
And he (Newman) stopped, still staring up at Newman. His (Newman) little white eyes expanded and glittered for a moment like those of a cat in the dark.
``It's not as it seems. I haven't forgiven her (daughter). Oh, no!'' (unknown)

``That's right; don't,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``She (daughter)'s a bad case.'' (unknown)

``It's horrible, it's horrible,'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche;
``but do you want to know the truth? I hate her (daughter)! I take what she (daughter) gives me, and I hate her (daughter) more. To-day she (daughter) brought me three hundred francs; they are here in my waistcoat pocket. Now I hate her (daughter) almost cruelly. No, I haven't forgiven her (daughter).'' (M. Nioche)

``Why did you accept the money?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

``If I hadn't,'' (M. Nioche)
said M. Nioche,
``I should have hated her (daughter) still more. That's what misery is. No, I haven't forgiven her (daughter).'' (M. Nioche)

``Take care you don't hurt her (daughter)!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing again. And with this he (Newman) took his (Newman) leave. As he (Newman) passed along the glazed side of the café, on reaching the street, he (Newman) saw the old man motioning the waiter, with a melancholy gesture, to replenish his (Newman) glass.

One day, a week after his (Newman) visit to the Café de la Patrie, he (Newman) called upon Valentin de Bellegarde, and by good fortune found him (Newman) at home. Newman spoke of his (Newman) interview with M. Nioche and his (Newman) daughter, and said he (Newman) was afraid Valentin had judged the old man correctly. He (Valentin) had found the couple hobnobbing together in all amity; the old gentleman's rigor was purely theoretic. Newman confessed that he (Newman) was disappointed; he (Newman) should have expected to see M. Nioche take high ground.

``High ground, my dear fellow,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, laughing;
``there is no high ground for him (they) to take. The only perceptible eminence in M. Nioche's horizon is Montmartre, which is not an edifying quarter. You can't go mountaineering in a flat country.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``He (they) remarked, indeed,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``that he (they) has not forgiven her (daughter). But she (daughter)'ll never find it out.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``We must do him (they) the justice to suppose he (they) doesn't like the thing,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin rejoined.
``Mademoiselle Nioche is like the great artists whose biographies we read, who at the beginning of their career have suffered opposition in the domestic circle. Their vocation has not been recognized by their families, but the world has done it justice. Mademoiselle Nioche has a vocation.'' (unknown)

``Oh, come,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, impatiently,
``you take the little baggage too seriously.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I know I do; but when one has nothing to think about, one must think of little baggages. I suppose it is better to be serious about light things than not to be serious at all. This little baggage entertains me.'' (unknown)

``Oh, she (Their) has discovered that. She (Their) knows you have been hunting her (Their) up and asking questions about her (Their). She (Their) is very much tickled by it. That's rather annoying.'' (unknown)

``Annoying, my dear fellow,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
laughed Valentin;
``not the least!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``Hanged if I should want to have a greedy little adventuress like that know I was giving myself such pains about her (Their)!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``A pretty woman is always worth one's pains,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
objected Valentin.
``Mademoiselle Nioche is welcome to be tickled by my curiosity, and to know that I am tickled that she (Their) is tickled. She (Their) is not so much tickled, by the way.'' (unknown)

``You had better go and tell her (Their),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman rejoined.
``She (Their) gave me a message for you of some such drift.'' (unknown)

``Bless your quiet imagination,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``I have been to see her (Their)--three times in five days. She (Their) is a charming hostess; we talk of Shakespeare and the musical glasses. She (Their) is extremely clever and a very curious type; not at all coarse or wanting to be coarse; determined not to be. She (Their) means to take very good care of herself. She (Their) is extremely perfect; she (Their) is as hard and clear-cut as some little figure of a sea-nymph in an antique intaglio, and I will warrant that she (Their) has not a grain more of sentiment or heart than if she (Their) was scooped out of a big amethyst. You can't scratch her (Their) even with a diamond. Extremely pretty,--really, when you know her (Their), she (Their) is wonderfully pretty,--intelligent, determined, ambitious, unscrupulous, capable of looking at a man strangled without changing color, she (Their) is upon my honor, extremely entertaining.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``It's a fine list of attractions,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman; ``they would serve as a police-detective's description of a favorite criminal. I should sum them up by another word than `entertaining.'''

``Why, that is just the word to use. I don't say she (Their) is laudable or lovable. I don't want her (Their) as my wife or my sister. But she (sister) is a very curious and ingenious piece of machinery; I like to see it in operation.'' (unknown)

``Well, I have seen some very curious machines too,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``and once, in a needle factory, I saw a gentleman from the city, who had stopped too near one of them, picked up as neatly as if he (gentleman) had been prodded by a fork, swallowed down straight, and ground into small pieces.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Re-entering his (Newman) domicile, late in the evening, three days after Madame de Bellegarde had made her (Valentin) bargain with him (Bellegarde)--the expression is sufficiently correct--touching the entertainment at which she (Valentin) was to present him (Bellegarde) to the world, he (Bellegarde) found on his (Bellegarde) table a card of goodly dimensions bearing an announcement that this lady would be at home on the 27th of the month, at ten o’clock in the evening. He (Bellegarde) stuck it into the frame of his (Bellegarde) mirror and eyed it with some complacency; it seemed an agreeable emblem of triumph, documentary evidence that his (Bellegarde) prize was gained. Stretched out in a chair, he (Bellegarde) was looking at it lovingly, when Valentin de Bellegarde was shown into the room. Valentin's glance presently followed the direction of Newman's, and he (Newman) perceived his (Newman) mother's invitation.

``And what have they put into the corner?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked. ``Not the customary `music,' `dancing,' or _`tableaux vivants'?_ They ought at least to put `An American.'''

``Oh, there are to be several of us,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Mrs. Tristram told me to-day that she (Tristram) had received a card and sent an acceptance.'' (unknown)

``Ah, then, with Mrs. Tristram and her (Tristram) husband you will have support. My mother might have put on her (mother) card `Three Americans.' But I suspect you will not lack amusement. You will see a great many of the best people in France. I mean the long pedigrees and the high noses, and all that. Some of them are awful idiots; I advise you to take them up cautiously.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I guess I shall like them,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I am prepared to like every one and everything in these days; I am in high good-humor.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin looked at him (Newman) a moment in silence and then dropped himself into a chair with an unwonted air of weariness.

``Happy man!'' (he)
he (Newman) said with a sigh.
``Take care you don't become offensive.'' (unknown)

``If anyone chooses to take offense, he (man) may. I have a good conscience,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``So you are really in love with my sister.'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, after a pause.

``And she (sister) also?'' (unknown)

``I guess she (sister) likes me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``What is the witchcraft you have used?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin asked.
``How do _you_ make love?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I haven't any general rules,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``In any way that seems acceptable.'' (unknown)

``I suspect that, if one knew it,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, laughing,
``you are a terrible customer. You walk in seven-league boots.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``There is something the matter with you to-night,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said in response to this.
``You are vicious. Spare me all discordant sounds until after my marriage. Then, when I have settled down for life, I shall be better able to take things as they come.'' (unknown)

``And when does your marriage take place?'' (unknown)

``About six weeks hence.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin was silent a while, and then he (Valentin) said,

``And you feel very confident about the future?'' (he)

``Confident. I knew what I wanted, exactly, and I know what I have got.'' (unknown)

``You are sure you are going to be happy?'' (unknown)

``Sure?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``So foolish a question deserves a foolish answer. Yes!'' (unknown)

``You are not afraid of anything?'' (unknown)

``What should I be afraid of? You can't hurt me unless you kill me by some violent means. That I should indeed consider a tremendous sell. I want to live and I mean to live. I can't die of illness, I am too ridiculously tough; and the time for dying of old age won't come round yet a while. I can't lose my wife, I shall take too good care of her (wife). I may lose my money, or a large part of it; but that won't matter, for I shall make twice as much again. So what have I to be afraid of?'' (unknown)

``You are not afraid it may be rather a mistake for an American man of business to marry a French countess?'' (unknown)

``For the countess, possibly; but not for the man of business, if you mean me! But my countess shall not be disappointed; I answer for her (countess) happiness!'' (he)
And as if he (Newman) felt the impulse to celebrate his (Newman) happy certitude by a bonfire, he (Newman) got up to throw a couple of logs upon the already blazing hearth. Valentin watched for a few moments the quickened flame, and then, with his (Valentin) head leaning on his (Valentin) hand, gave a melancholy sigh.
``Got a headache?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

``_Je suis triste_,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, with Gallic simplicity.

``You are sad, eh? It is about the lady you said the other night that you adored and that you couldn't marry?'' (unknown)

``Did I really say that? It seemed to me afterwards that the words had escaped me. Before Claire it was bad taste. But I felt gloomy as I spoke, and I feel gloomy still. Why did you ever introduce me to that girl?'' (unknown)

``Oh, it's Noémie, is it? Lord deliver us! You don't mean to say you are lovesick about her (girl)?'' (unknown)

``Lovesick, no; it's not a grand passion. But the cold-blooded little demon sticks in my thoughts; she (girl) has bitten me with those even little teeth of hers; I feel as if I might turn rabid and do something crazy in consequence. It's very low, it's disgustingly low. She (girl)'s the most mercenary little jade in Europe. Yet she (girl) really affects my peace of mind; she (girl) is always running in my head. It's a striking contrast to your noble and virtuous attachment--a vile contrast! It is rather pitiful that it should be the best I am able to do for myself at my present respectable age. I am a nice young man, eh, _en somme?_ You can't warrant my future, as you do your own.'' (unknown)

``Drop that girl, short,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``don't go near her (girl) again, and your future will do. Come over to America and I will get you a place in a bank.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``It is easy to say drop her (girl),'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, with a light laugh.
``You can't drop a pretty woman like that. One must be polite, even with Noémie. Besides, I'll not have her (woman) suppose I am afraid of her (woman).'' (unknown)

``So, between politeness and vanity, you will get deeper into the mud? Keep them both for something better. Remember, too, that I didn't want to introduce you to her (woman); you insisted. I had a sort of uneasy feeling about it.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't reproach you,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``Heaven forbid! I wouldn't for the world have missed knowing her (woman). She (woman) is really extraordinary. The way she (woman) has already spread her (woman) wings is amazing. I don't know when a woman has amused me more. But excuse me,'' (he)
he (Valentin) added in an instant;
``she (woman) doesn't amuse you, at second hand, and the subject is an impure one. Let us talk of something else.'' (he)
Valentin introduced another topic, but within five minutes Newman observed that, by a bold transition, he (Newman) had reverted to Mademoiselle Nioche, and was giving pictures of her (Valentin) manners and quoting specimens of her (Valentin) _mots_. These were very witty, and, for a young woman who six months before had been painting the most artless madonnas, startlingly cynical. But at last, abruptly, he (Newman) stopped, became thoughtful, and for some time afterwards said nothing. When he (Newman) rose to go it was evident that his (Newman) thoughts were still running upon Mademoiselle Nioche.
``Yes, she (woman)'s a frightful little monster!'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

CHAPTER XVI

The next ten days were the happiest that Newman had ever known. He (Newman) saw Madame de Cintré every day, and never saw either old Madame de Bellegarde or the elder of his (Newman) prospective brothers-in-law. Madame de Cintré at last seemed to think it becoming to apologize for their never being present.

``They are much taken up,'' (she)
she (Newman) said,
``with doing the honors of Paris to Lord Deepmere.'' (she)
There was a smile in her (Newman) gravity as she (Newman) made this declaration, and it deepened as she (Newman) added,
``He (Lord) is our seventh cousin, you know, and blood is thicker than water. And then, he (Lord) is so interesting!'' (she)
And with this she (Newman) laughed.

Newman met young Madame de Bellegarde two or three times, always roaming about with graceful vagueness, as if in search of an unattainable ideal of amusement. She (Newman) always reminded him (Newman) of a painted perfume-bottle with a crack in it; but he (Newman) had grown to have a kindly feeling for her (Newman), based on the fact of her (Newman) owing conjugal allegiance to Urbain de Bellegarde. He (Bellegarde) pitied M. de Bellegarde's wife, especially since she (wife) was a silly, thirstily-smiling little brunette, with a suggestion of an unregulated heart. The small marquise sometimes looked at him (marquise) with an intensity too marked not to be innocent, for coquetry is more finely shaded. She (wife) apparently wanted to ask him (marquise) something or tell him (marquise) something; he (marquise) wondered what it was. But he (marquise) was shy of giving her (wife) an opportunity, because, if her (wife) communication bore upon the aridity of her (wife) matrimonial lot, he (marquise) was at a loss to see how he (marquise) could help her (wife). He (marquise) had a fancy, however, of her (wife) coming up to him (marquise) some day and saying -LRB-after looking around behind her (wife)-RRB- with a little passionate hiss,

``I know you detest my husband; let me have the pleasure of assuring you for once that you are right. Pity a poor woman who is married to a clock-image in _papier-mâché!_'' (him)
Possessing, however, in default of a competent knowledge of the principles of etiquette, a very downright sense of the
``meanness'' (him)
of certain actions, it seemed to him (marquise) to belong to his (marquise) position to keep on his (marquise) guard; he (marquise) was not going to put it into the power of these people to say that in their house he (marquise) had done anything unpleasant. As it was, Madame de Bellegarde used to give him (Bellegarde) news of the dress she (wife) meant to wear at his (Bellegarde) wedding, and which had not yet, in her (wife) creative imagination, in spite of many interviews with the tailor, resolved itself into its composite totality.
``I told you pale blue bows on the sleeves, at the elbows,'' (she)
she (wife) said.
``But to-day I don't see my blue bows at all. I don't know what has become of them. To-day I see pink--a tender pink. And then I pass through strange, dull phases in which neither blue nor pink says anything to me. And yet I must have the bows.'' (unknown)

``Have them green or yellow,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``_Malheureux!_'' (the marquise)
the little marquise would cry.
``Green bows would break your marriage--your children would be illegitimate!'' (Madame)

Madame de Cintré was calmly happy before the world, and Newman had the felicity of fancying that before him (Newman), when the world was absent, she (wife) was almost agitatedly happy. She (wife) said very tender things.

``I take no pleasure in you. You never give me a chance to scold you, to correct you. I bargained for that, I expected to enjoy it. But you won't do anything dreadful; you are dismally inoffensive. It is very stupid; there is no excitement for me; I might as well be marrying someone else.'' (unknown)

``I am afraid it's the worst I can do,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman would say in answer to this.
``Kindly overlook the deficiency.'' (He)
He (Newman) assured her (wife) that he (Newman), at least, would never scold her (wife); she (wife) was perfectly satisfactory.
``If you only knew,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``how exactly you are what I coveted! And I am beginning to understand why I coveted it; the having it makes all the difference that I expected. Never was a man so pleased with his (man) good fortune. You have been holding your head for a week past just as I wanted my wife to hold hers. You say just the things I want her (wife) to say. You walk about the room just as I want her (wife) to walk. You have just the taste in dress that I want her (wife) to have. In short, you come up to the mark, and, I can tell you, my mark was high.'' (he)

These observations seemed to make Madame de Cintré rather grave. At last she (wife) said,

``Depend upon it, I don't come up to the mark; your mark is too high. I am not all that you suppose; I am a much smaller affair. She (wife) is a magnificent woman, your ideal. Pray, how did she (wife) come to such perfection?'' (she)

``She (wife) was never anything else,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said.

``I really believe,'' (Madame)
Madame de Cintré went on,
``that she (wife) is better than my own ideal. Do you know that is a very handsome compliment? Well, sir, I will make her (wife) my own!'' (Madame)

Mrs. Tristram came to see her (Tristram) dear Claire after Newman had announced his (Newman) engagement, and she (Tristram) told our hero the next day that his (Newman) good fortune was simply absurd.

``For the ridiculous part of it is,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said,
``that you are evidently going to be as happy as if you were marrying Miss Smith or Miss Thompson. I call it a brilliant match for you, but you get brilliancy without paying any tax upon it. Those things are usually a compromise, but here you have everything, and nothing crowds anything else out. You will be brilliantly happy as well.'' (she)
Newman thanked her (Tristram) for her (Tristram) pleasant, encouraging way of saying things; no woman could encourage or discourage better. Tristram's way of saying things was different; he (Newman) had been taken by his (Newman) wife to call upon Madame de Cintré, and he (Cintré) gave an account of the expedition.

``You don't catch me giving an opinion on your countess this time,'' (he)
he (Cintré) said;
``I put my foot in it once. That's a d--d underhand thing to do, by the way--coming round to sound a fellow upon the woman you are going to marry. You deserve anything you get. Then of course you rush and tell her (woman), and she (woman) takes care to make it pleasant for the poor spiteful wretch the first time he (fellow) calls. I will do you the justice to say, however, that you don't seem to have told Madame de Cintré; or if you have, she (woman)'s uncommonly magnanimous. She (woman) was very nice; she (woman) was tremendously polite. She (woman) and Lizzie sat on the sofa, pressing each other's hands and calling each other _chère belle_, and Madame de Cintré sent me with every third word a magnificent smile, as if to give me to understand that I too was a handsome dear. She (woman) quite made up for past neglect, I assure you; she (woman) was very pleasant and sociable. Only in an evil hour it came into her (woman) head to say that she (woman) must present us to her (woman) mother--her (woman) mother wished to know your friends. I didn't want to know her (woman) mother, and I was on the point of telling Lizzie to go in alone and let me wait for her (Lizzie) outside. But Lizzie, with her (Lizzie) usual infernal ingenuity, guessed my purpose and reduced me by a glance of her (Lizzie) eye. So they marched off arm in arm, and I followed as I could. We found the old lady in her (lady) armchair, twiddling her (lady) aristocratic thumbs. She (lady) looked at Lizzie from head to foot; but at that game Lizzie, to do her (Lizzie) justice, was a match for her (Lizzie). My wife told her (wife) we were great friends of Mr. Newman. The marquise started a moment, and then said, `Oh, Mr. Newman! My daughter has made up her (daughter) mind to marry a Mr. Newman.' Then Madame de Cintré began to fondle Lizzie again, and said it was this dear lady that had planned the match and brought them together. `Oh, `tis you I have to thank for my American son-in-law,' the old lady said to Mrs. Tristram. `It was a very clever thought of yours. Be sure of my gratitude.' And then she (Tristram) began to look at me and presently said, `Pray, are you engaged in some species of manufacture?' I wanted to say that I manufactured broom-sticks for old witches to ride on, but Lizzie got in ahead of me. `My husband, Madame la Marquise,' she (Lizzie) said, `belongs to that unfortunate class of persons who have no profession and no business, and do very little good in the world.' To get her (Lizzie) poke at the old woman she (Lizzie) didn't care where she (Lizzie) shoved me. `Dear me,' said the marquise, `we all have our duties.' `I am sorry mine compel me to take leave of you,' said Lizzie. And we bundled out again. But you have a mother-in-law, in all the force of the term.'' (he)

``Oh,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``my mother-in-law desires nothing better than to let me alone.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Betimes, on the evening of the 27th, he (Newman) went to Madame de Bellegarde's ball. The old house in the Rue de l’Université looked strangely brilliant. In the circle of light projected from the outer gate a detachment of the populace stood watching the carriages roll in; the court was illumined with flaring torches and the portico carpeted with crimson. When Newman arrived there were but a few people present. The marquise and her (Cintré) two daughters were at the top of the staircase, where the sallow old nymph in the angle peeped out from a bower of plants. Madame de Bellegarde, in purple and fine laces, looked like an old lady painted by Vandyke; Madame de Cintré was dressed in white. The old lady greeted Newman with majestic formality, and looking round her (lady), called several of the persons who were standing near. They were elderly gentlemen, of what Valentin de Bellegarde had designated as the high-nosed category; two or three of them wore cordons and stars. They approached with measured alertness, and the marquise said that she (lady) wished to present them to Mr. Newman, who was going to marry her (lady) daughter. Then she (lady) introduced successively three dukes, three counts, and a baron. These gentlemen bowed and smiled most agreeably, and Newman indulged in a series of impartial hand-shakes, accompanied by a

``Happy to make your acquaintance, sir.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
He (Newman) looked at Madame de Cintré, but she (lady) was not looking at him (Newman). If his (Newman) personal self-consciousness had been of a nature to make him (Newman) constantly refer to her (lady), as the critic before whom, in company, he (critic) played his (critic) part, he (critic) might have found it a flattering proof of her (lady) confidence that he (critic) never caught her (lady) eyes resting upon him (critic). It is a reflection Newman did not make, but we nevertheless risk it, that in spite of this circumstance she (lady) probably saw every movement of his (Newman) little finger. Young Madame de Bellegarde was dressed in an audacious toilet of crimson crape, bestrewn with huge silver moons--thin crescent and full disks.

``You don't say anything about my dress,'' (she)
she (lady) said to Newman.

``I feel,'' (he)
he (Newman) answered,
``as if I were looking at you through a telescope. It is very strange.'' (he)

``If it is strange it matches the occasion. But I am not a heavenly body.'' (unknown)

``I never saw the sky at midnight that particular shade of crimson,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``That is my originality; anyone could have chosen blue. My sister-in-law would have chosen a lovely shade of blue, with a dozen little delicate moons. But I think crimson is much more amusing. And I give my idea, which is moonshine.'' (unknown)

``Moonshine and bloodshed,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``A murder by moonlight,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
laughed Madame de Bellegarde.
``What a delicious idea for a toilet! To make it complete, there is the silver dagger, you see, stuck into my hair. But here comes Lord Deepmere,'' (she)
she (lady) added in a moment.
``I must find out what he (Lord) thinks of it.'' (Lord Deepmere)
Lord Deepmere came up, looking very red in the face, and laughing.
``Lord Deepmere can't decide which he (Lord) prefers, my sister-in-law or me,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``He (Lord) likes Claire because she (Claire) is his (Lord) cousin, and me because I am not. But he (Lord) has no right to make love to Claire, whereas I am perfectly _disponible_. It is very wrong to make love to a woman who is engaged, but it is very wrong not to make love to a woman who is married.'' (unknown)

``Oh, it's very jolly making love to married women,'' (Lord Deepmere)
said Lord Deepmere,
``because they can't ask you to marry them.'' (Lord Deepmere)

``Is that what the others do, the spinsters?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman inquired.

``Oh dear, yes,'' (Lord)
said Lord Deepmere;
``in England all the girls ask a fellow to marry them.'' (Lord)

``And a fellow brutally refuses,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.

``Why, really, you know, a fellow can't marry any girl that asks him (fellow),'' (lordship)
said his (Bellegarde) lordship.

``Your cousin won't ask you. She (girl) is going to marry Mr. Newman.'' (unknown)

``Oh, that's a very different thing!'' (Lord)
laughed Lord Deepmere.

``You would have accepted _her (girl)_, I suppose. That makes me hope that after all you prefer me.'' (unknown)

``Oh, when things are nice I never prefer one to the other,'' (the Englishman)
said the young Englishman.
``I take them all.'' (unknown)

``Ah, what a horror! I won't be taken in that way; I must be kept apart,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
cried Madame de Bellegarde.
``Mr. Newman is much better; he (Newman) knows how to choose. Oh, he (Newman) chooses as if he (Newman) were threading a needle. He (Newman) prefers Madame de Cintré to any conceivable creature or thing.'' (unknown)

``Well, you can't help my being her (I) cousin,'' (Lord)
said Lord Deepmere to Newman, with candid hilarity.

``Oh, no, I can't help that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing back;
``neither can she (I)!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``And you can't help my dancing with her (I),'' (Lord Deepmere)
said Lord Deepmere, with sturdy simplicity.

``I could prevent that only by dancing with her (I) myself,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But unfortunately I don't know how to dance.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you may dance without knowing how; may you not, milord?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde. But to this Lord Deepmere replied that a fellow ought to know how to dance if he (Deepmere) didn't want to make an ass of himself; and at this moment Urbain de Bellegarde joined the group, slow-stepping and with his (Bellegarde) hands behind him (Bellegarde).

``This is a very splendid entertainment,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, cheerfully.
``The old house looks very bright.'' (unknown)

``If _you_ are pleased, we are content,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis, lifting his (Newman) shoulders and bending them forward.

``Oh, I suspect everyone is pleased,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``How can they help being pleased when the first thing they see as they come in is your sister, standing there as beautiful as an angel?'' (unknown)

``Yes, she (sister) is very beautiful,'' (the marquis)
rejoined the marquis, solemnly.
``But that is not so great a source of satisfaction to other people, naturally, as to you.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I am satisfied, marquis, I am satisfied,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with his (Newman) protracted enunciation.
``And now tell me,'' (he)
he (Newman) added, looking round,
``who some of your friends are.'' (he)

M. de Bellegarde looked about him (Bellegarde) in silence, with his (Bellegarde) head bent and his (Bellegarde) hand raised to his (Bellegarde) lower lip, which he (Bellegarde) slowly rubbed. A stream of people had been pouring into the salon in which Newman stood with his (Newman) host, the rooms were filling up and the spectacle had become brilliant. It borrowed its splendor chiefly from the shining shoulders and profuse jewels of the women, and from the voluminous elegance of their dresses. There were no uniforms, as Madame de Bellegarde's door was inexorably closed against the myrmidons of the upstart power which then ruled the fortunes of France, and the great company of smiling and chattering faces was not graced by any very frequent suggestions of harmonious beauty. It is a pity, nevertheless, that Newman had not been a physiognomist, for a great many of the faces were irregularly agreeable, expressive, and suggestive. If the occasion had been different they would hardly have pleased him (Newman); he (Newman) would have thought the women not pretty enough and the men too smirking; but he (Newman) was now in a humor to receive none but agreeable impressions, and he (Newman) looked no more narrowly than to perceive that everyone was brilliant, and to feel that the sun of their brilliancy was a part of his (Newman) credit.

``I will present you to some people,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde after a while.
``I will make a point of it, in fact. You will allow me?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I will shake hands with anyone you want,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Your mother just introduced me to half a dozen old gentlemen. Take care you don't pick up the same parties again.'' (unknown)

``Who are the gentlemen to whom my mother presented you?'' (unknown)

``Upon my word, I forgot them,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing.
``The people here look very much alike.'' (unknown)

``I suspect they have not forgotten you,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis. And he (Newman) began to walk through the rooms. Newman, to keep near him (Newman) in the crowd, took his (Newman) arm; after which for some time, the marquis walked straight along, in silence. At last, reaching the farther end of the suite of reception-rooms, Newman found himself in the presence of a lady of monstrous proportions, seated in a very capacious armchair, with several persons standing in a semicircle round her (lady). This little group had divided as the marquis came up, and M. de Bellegarde stepped forward and stood for an instant silent and obsequious, with his (Bellegarde) hat raised to his (Bellegarde) lips, as Newman had seen some gentlemen stand in churches as soon as they entered their pews. The lady, indeed, bore a very fair likeness to a reverend effigy in some idolatrous shrine. She (lady) was monumentally stout and imperturbably serene. Her (lady) aspect was to Newman almost formidable; he (Newman) had a troubled consciousness of a triple chin, a small piercing eye, a vast expanse of uncovered bosom, a nodding and twinkling tiara of plumes and gems, and an immense circumference of satin petticoat. With her (lady) little circle of beholders this remarkable woman reminded him (Newman) of the Fat Lady at a fair. She (Lady) fixed her (Lady) small, unwinking eyes at the new-comers.

``Dear duchess,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis,
``let me present you our good friend Mr. Newman, of whom you have heard us speak. Wishing to make Mr. Newman known to those who are dear to us, I could not possibly fail to begin with you.'' (the marquis)

``Charmed, dear friend; charmed, monsieur,'' (the duchess)
said the duchess in a voice which, though small and shrill, was not disagreeable, while Newman executed his (Newman) obeisance.
``I came on purpose to see monsieur. I hope he (friend) appreciates the compliment. You have only to look at me to do so, sir,'' (she)
she (duchess) continued, sweeping her (duchess) person with a much-encompassing glance. Newman hardly knew what to say, though it seemed that to a duchess who joked about her (duchess) corpulence one might say almost anything. On hearing that the duchess had come on purpose to see Newman, the gentlemen who surrounded her (duchess) turned a little and looked at him (Newman) with sympathetic curiosity. The marquis with supernatural gravity mentioned to him (Newman) the name of each, while the gentleman who bore it bowed; they were all what are called in France _beaux noms_.
``I wanted extremely to see you,'' (the duchess)
the duchess went on.
``_C’est positif_. In the first place, I am very fond of the person you are going to marry; she (friend) is the most charming creature in France. Mind you treat her (friend) well, or you shall hear some news of me. But you look as if you were good. I am told you are very remarkable. I have heard all sorts of extraordinary things about you. _Voyons_, are they true?'' (unknown)

``I don't know what you can have heard,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Oh, you have your _légende_. We have heard that you have had a career the most checkered, the most _bizarre_. What is that about your having founded a city some ten years ago in the great West, a city which contains to-day half a million of inhabitants? Isn't it half a million, messieurs? You are exclusive proprietor of this flourishing settlement, and are consequently fabulously rich, and you would be richer still if you didn't grant lands and houses free of rent to all new-comers who will pledge themselves never to smoke cigars. At this game, in three years, we are told, you are going to be made president of America.'' (The duchess)

The duchess recited this amazing

``legend'' (The duchess)
with a smooth self-possession which gave the speech to Newman's mind, the air of being a bit of amusing dialogue in a play, delivered by a veteran comic actress. Before she (actress) had ceased speaking he (veteran) had burst into loud, irrepressible laughter.
``Dear duchess, dear duchess,'' (the marquis)
the marquis began to murmur, soothingly. Two or three persons came to the door of the room to see who was laughing at the duchess. But the lady continued with the soft, serene assurance of a person who, as a duchess, was certain of being listened to, and, as a garrulous woman, was independent of the pulse of her (woman) auditors.
``But I know you are very remarkable. You must be, to have endeared yourself to this good marquis and to his (marquis) admirable world. They are very exacting. I myself am not very sure at this hour of really possessing it. Eh, Bellegarde? To please you, I see, one must be an American millionaire. But your real triumph, my dear sir, is pleasing the countess; she (countess) is as difficult as a princess in a fairy tale. Your success is a miracle. What is your secret? I don't ask you to reveal it before all these gentlemen, but come and see me some day and give me a specimen of your talents.'' (unknown)

``The secret is with Madame de Cintré,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You must ask her (countess) for it. It consists in her (countess) having a great deal of charity.'' (unknown)

``Very pretty!'' (the duchess)
said the duchess.
``That's a very nice specimen, to begin with. What, Bellegarde, are you already taking monsieur away?'' (unknown)

``I have a duty to perform, dear friend,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis, pointing to the other groups.

``Ah, for you I know what that means. Well, I have seen monsieur; that is what I wanted. He (friend) can't persuade me that he (friend) isn't very clever. Farewell.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

As Newman passed on with his (Newman) host, he (Newman) asked who the duchess was.

``The greatest lady in France,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis. M. de Bellegarde then presented his (Bellegarde) prospective brother-in-law to some twenty other persons of both sexes, selected apparently for their typically august character. In some cases this character was written in good round hand upon the countenance of the wearer; in others Newman was thankful for such help as his (Newman) companion's impressively brief intimation contributed to the discovery of it. There were large, majestic men, and small demonstrative men; there were ugly ladies in yellow lace and quaint jewels, and pretty ladies with white shoulders from which jewels and everything else were absent. Everyone gave Newman extreme attention, everyone smiled, everyone was charmed to make his (Newman) acquaintance, everyone looked at him (Newman) with that soft hardness of good society which puts out its hand but keeps its fingers closed over the coin. If the marquis was going about as a bear-leader, if the fiction of Beauty and the Beast was supposed to have found its companion-piece, the general impression appeared to be that the bear was a very fair imitation of humanity. Newman found his (Newman) reception among the marquis's friends very
``pleasant;'' (marquis friends)
he (Newman) could not have said more for it. It was pleasant to be treated with so much explicit politeness; it was pleasant to hear neatly turned civilities, with a flavor of wit, uttered from beneath carefully-shaped moustaches; it was pleasant to see clever Frenchwomen--they all seemed clever--turn their backs to their partners to get a good look at the strange American whom Claire de Cintré was to marry, and reward the object of the exhibition with a charming smile. At last, as he (Newman) turned away from a battery of smiles and other amenities, Newman caught the eye of the marquis looking at him (Newman) heavily; and thereupon, for a single instant, he (Newman) checked himself.
``Am I behaving like a d--d fool?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked himself.
``Am I stepping about like a terrier on his (terrier) hind legs?'' (he)
At this moment he (Newman) perceived Mrs. Tristram at the other side of the room, and he (Newman) waved his (Newman) hand in farewell to M. de Bellegarde and made his (Bellegarde) way toward her (Tristram).

``Am I holding my head too high?'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) asked.
``Do I look as if I had the lower end of a pulley fastened to my chin?'' (unknown)

``You look like all happy men, very ridiculous,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.
``It's the usual thing, neither better nor worse. I have been watching you for the last ten minutes, and I have been watching M. de Bellegarde. He (Bellegarde) doesn't like it.'' (unknown)

``The more credit to him (Bellegarde) for putting it through,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
replied Newman.
``But I shall be generous. I shan't trouble him (Bellegarde) any more. But I am very happy. I can't stand still here. Please to take my arm and we will go for a walk.'' (He)

He (Newman) led Mrs. Tristram through all the rooms. There were a great many of them, and, decorated for the occasion and filled with a stately crowd, their somewhat tarnished nobleness recovered its lustre. Mrs. Tristram, looking about her (Tristram), dropped a series of softly-incisive comments upon her (Tristram) fellow-guests. But Newman made vague answers; he (Newman) hardly heard her (Tristram), his (Newman) thoughts were elsewhere. They were lost in a cheerful sense of success, of attainment and victory. His (Newman) momentary care as to whether he (Newman) looked like a fool passed away, leaving him (Newman) simply with a rich contentment. He (Newman) had got what he (Newman) wanted. The savor of success had always been highly agreeable to him (Newman), and it had been his (Newman) fortune to know it often. But it had never before been so sweet, been associated with so much that was brilliant and suggestive and entertaining. The lights, the flowers, the music, the crowd, the splendid women, the jewels, the strangeness even of the universal murmur of a clever foreign tongue were all a vivid symbol and assurance of his (Newman) having grasped his (Newman) purpose and forced along his (Newman) groove. If Newman's smile was larger than usual, it was not tickled vanity that pulled the strings; he (Newman) had no wish to be shown with the finger or to achieve a personal success. If he (Newman) could have looked down at the scene, invisible, from a hole in the roof, he (Newman) would have enjoyed it quite as much. It would have spoken to him (Newman) about his (Newman) own prosperity and deepened that easy feeling about life to which, sooner or later, he (Newman) made all experience contribute. Just now the cup seemed full.

``It is a very pretty party,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram, after they had walked a while.
``I have seen nothing objectionable except my husband leaning against the wall and talking to an individual whom I suppose he (husband) takes for a duke, but whom I more than suspect to be the functionary who attends to the lamps. Do you think you could separate them? Knock over a lamp!'' (I)

I doubt whether Newman, who saw no harm in Tristram's conversing with an ingenious mechanic, would have complied with this request; but at this moment Valentin de Bellegarde drew near. Newman, some weeks previously, had presented Madame de Cintré's youngest brother to Mrs. Tristram, for whose merits Valentin professed a discriminating relish and to whom he (Valentin) had paid several visits.

``Did you ever read Keats's Belle Dame sans Merci?'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
asked Mrs. Tristram. ``You remind me of the hero of the ballad:--

`Oh, what can ail thee, knight-at-arms, Alone and palely loitering?'''

``If I am alone, it is because I have been deprived of your society,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``Besides it is good manners for no man except Newman to look happy. This is all to his (Newman) address. It is not for you and me to go before the curtain.'' (unknown)

``You promised me last spring,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman to Mrs. Tristram,
``that six months from that time I should get into a monstrous rage. It seems to me the time's up, and yet the nearest I can come to doing anything rough now is to offer you a _café glacé_.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``I told you we should do things grandly,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``I don't allude to the _cafés glacés_. But everyone is here, and my sister told me just now that Urbain had been adorable.'' (unknown)

``He (Urbain)'s a good fellow, he (Urbain)'s a good fellow,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I love him (Urbain) as a brother. That reminds me that I ought to go and say something polite to your mother.'' (unknown)

``Let it be something very polite indeed,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``It may be the last time you will feel so much like it!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman walked away, almost disposed to clasp old Madame de Bellegarde round the waist. He (Newman) passed through several rooms and at last found the old marquise in the first saloon, seated on a sofa, with her (Tristram) young kinsman, Lord Deepmere, beside her (Tristram). The young man looked somewhat bored; his (man) hands were thrust into his (man) pockets and his (man) eyes were fixed upon the toes of his (man) shoes, his (man) feet being thrust out in front of him (man). Madame de Bellegarde appeared to have been talking to him (Bellegarde) with some intensity and to be waiting for an answer to what she (Tristram) had said, or for some sign of the effect of her (Tristram) words. Her (Tristram) hands were folded in her (Tristram) lap, and she (Tristram) was looking at his (Bellegarde) lordship's simple physiognomy with an air of politely suppressed irritation.

Lord Deepmere looked up as Newman approached, met his (Newman) eyes, and changed color.

``I am afraid I disturb an interesting interview,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

Madame de Bellegarde rose, and her (Tristram) companion rising at the same time, she (Tristram) put her (Tristram) hand into his (Newman) arm. She (Tristram) answered nothing for an instant, and then, as he (Newman) remained silent, she (Tristram) said with a smile,

``It would be polite for Lord Deepmere to say it was very interesting.'' (she)

``Oh, I'm not polite!'' (lordship)
cried his (Newman) lordship.
``But it _was_ interesting.'' (unknown)

``Madame de Bellegarde was giving you some good advice, eh?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``toning you down a little?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I was giving him (Bellegarde) some excellent advice,'' (the marquise)
said the marquise, fixing her (Tristram) fresh, cold eyes upon our hero.
``It's for him (Bellegarde) to take it.'' (unknown)

``Take it, sir--take it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman exclaimed.
``Any advice the marquise gives you to-night must be good. For to-night, marquise, you must speak from a cheerful, comfortable spirit, and that makes good advice. You see everything going on so brightly and successfully round you. Your party is magnificent; it was a very happy thought. It is much better than that thing of mine would have been.'' (unknown)

``If you are pleased I am satisfied,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``My desire was to please you.'' (unknown)

``Do you want to please me a little more?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Just drop our lordly friend; I am sure he (friend) wants to be off and shake his (friend) heels a little. Then take my arm and walk through the rooms.'' (unknown)

``My desire was to please you,'' (the lady)
the old lady repeated. And she (lady) liberated Lord Deepmere, Newman rather wondering at her (lady) docility.
``If this young man is wise,'' (she)
she (lady) added,
``he (man) will go and find my daughter and ask her (daughter) to dance.'' (she)

``I have been endorsing your advice,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, bending over her (lady) and laughing,
``I suppose I must swallow that!'' (her)

Lord Deepmere wiped his (Deepmere) forehead and departed, and Madame de Bellegarde took Newman's arm.

``Yes, it's a very pleasant, sociable entertainment,'' (unknown)
the latter declared, as they proceeded on their circuit.
``Everyone seems to know everyone and to be glad to see everyone. The marquis has made me acquainted with ever so many people, and I feel quite like one of the family. It's an occasion,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman continued, wanting to say something thoroughly kind and comfortable,
``that I shall always remember, and remember very pleasantly.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I think it is an occasion that we shall none of us forget,'' (the marquise)
said the marquise, with her (lady) pure, neat enunciation.

People made way for her (lady) as she (lady) passed, others turned round and looked at her (lady), and she (lady) received a great many greetings and pressings of the hand, all of which she (lady) accepted with the most delicate dignity. But though she (lady) smiled upon everyone, she (lady) said nothing until she (lady) reached the last of the rooms, where she (lady) found her (lady) elder son. Then,

``This is enough, sir,'' (she)
she (lady) declared with measured softness to Newman, and turned to the marquis. He (Newman) put out both his (Newman) hands and took both hers, drawing her (lady) to a seat with an air of the tenderest veneration. It was a most harmonious family group, and Newman discreetly retired. He (Newman) moved through the rooms for some time longer, circulating freely, overtopping most people by his (Newman) great height, renewing acquaintance with some of the groups to which Urbain de Bellegarde had presented him (Bellegarde), and expending generally the surplus of his (Bellegarde) equanimity. He (Bellegarde) continued to find it all extremely agreeable; but the most agreeable things have an end, and the revelry on this occasion began to deepen to a close. The music was sounding its ultimate strains and people were looking for the marquise, to make their farewells. There seemed to be some difficulty in finding her (groups), and Newman heard a report that she (groups) had left the ball, feeling faint.
``She (everyone) has succumbed to the emotions of the evening,'' (he)
he (Newman) heard a lady say.
``Poor, dear marquise; I can imagine all that they may have been for her (everyone)!'' (he)
But he (Newman) learned immediately afterwards that she (lady) had recovered herself and was seated in an armchair near the doorway, receiving parting compliments from great ladies who insisted upon her (lady) not rising. He (Newman) himself set out in quest of Madame de Cintré. He (Newman) had seen her (lady) move past him (Newman) many times in the rapid circles of a waltz, but in accordance with her (lady) explicit instructions he (Newman) had exchanged no words with her (lady) since the beginning of the evening. The whole house having been thrown open, the apartments of the _rez-de-chaussée_ were also accessible, though a smaller number of persons had gathered there. Newman wandered through them, observing a few scattered couples to whom this comparative seclusion appeared grateful and reached a small conservatory which opened into the garden. The end of the conservatory was formed by a clear sheet of glass, unmasked by plants, and admitting the winter starlight so directly that a person standing there would seem to have passed into the open air. Two persons stood there now, a lady and a gentleman; the lady Newman, from within the room and although she (lady) had turned her (lady) back to it, immediately recognized as Madame de Cintré. He (Newman) hesitated as to whether he (Newman) would advance, but as he (Newman) did so she (lady) looked round, feeling apparently that he (Newman) was there. She (lady) rested her (lady) eyes on him (Newman) a moment and then turned again to her (lady) companion.

``It is almost a pity not to tell Mr. Newman,'' (she)
she (lady) said softly, but in a tone that Newman could hear.

``Tell him (Newman) if you like!'' (the gentleman)
the gentleman answered, in the voice of Lord Deepmere.

``Oh, tell me by all means!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman advancing.

Lord Deepmere, he (Newman) observed, was very red in the face, and he (Newman) had twisted his (Newman) gloves into a tight cord as if he (Newman) had been squeezing them dry. These, presumably, were tokens of violent emotion, and it seemed to Newman that the traces of corresponding agitation were visible in Madame de Cintré's face. The two had been talking with much vivacity.

``What I should tell you is only to my lord's credit,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré, smiling frankly enough.

``He (lord) wouldn't like it any better for that!'' (lord)
said my lord, with his (lord) awkward laugh.

``Come; what's the mystery?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman demanded.
``Clear it up. I don't like mysteries.'' (unknown)

``We must have some things we don't like, and go without some we do,'' (the nobleman)
said the ruddy young nobleman, laughing still.

``It's to Lord Deepmere's credit, but it is not to everyone's,'' (unknown)
said Madam de Cintré.
``So I shall say nothing about it. You may be sure,'' (she)
she (Madame) added; and she (Madame) put out her (Madame) hand to the Englishman, who took it half shyly, half impetuously.
``And now go and dance!'' (she)
she (Madame) said.

``Oh yes, I feel awfully like dancing!'' (he)
he (Englishman) answered.
``I shall go and get tipsy.'' (he)
And he (Englishman) walked away with a gloomy guffaw.

``What has happened between you?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

``I can't tell you--now,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.
``Nothing that need make you unhappy.'' (unknown)

``Has the little Englishman been trying to make love to you?'' (She)

She (Madame) hesitated, and then she (Madame) uttered a grave

``No! he (Englishman)'s a very honest little fellow.'' (she)

``But you are agitated. Something is the matter.'' (unknown)

``Nothing, I repeat, that need make you unhappy. My agitation is over. Some day I will tell you what it was; not now. I can't now!'' (unknown)

``Well, I confess,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
remarked Newman,
``I don't want to hear anything unpleasant. I am satisfied with everything--most of all with you. I have seen all the ladies and talked with a great many of them; but I am satisfied with you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Madame de Cintré covered him (Newman) for a moment with her (Madame) large, soft glance, and then turned her (Madame) eyes away into the starry night. So they stood silent a moment, side by side.
``Say you are satisfied with me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

He (Newman) had to wait a moment for the answer; but it came at last, low yet distinct:

``I am very happy.'' (He)

It was presently followed by a few words from another source, which made them both turn round.

``I am sadly afraid Madame de Cintré will take a chill. I have ventured to bring a shawl.'' (unknown)
Mrs. Bread stood there softly solicitous, holding a white drapery in her (Madame) hand.

``Thank you,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré,
``the sight of those cold stars gives one a sense of frost. I won't take your shawl, but we will go back into the house.'' (Madame de Cintré)

She (Madame) passed back and Newman followed her (Madame), Mrs. Bread standing respectfully aside to make way for them. Newman paused an instant before the old woman, and she (woman) glanced up at him (Newman) with a silent greeting.

``Oh, yes,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``you must come and live with us.'' (he)

``Well then, sir, if you will,'' (she)
she (woman) answered,
``you have not seen the last of me!'' (she)

CHAPTER XVII

Newman was fond of music and went often to the opera. A couple of evenings after Madame de Bellegarde's ball he (Bellegarde) sat listening to

``Don Giovanni,'' (he)
having in honor of this work, which he (Bellegarde) had never yet seen represented, come to occupy his (Bellegarde) orchestra-chair before the rising of the curtain. Frequently he (Bellegarde) took a large box and invited a party of his (Bellegarde) compatriots; this was a mode of recreation to which he (Bellegarde) was much addicted. He (Bellegarde) liked making up parties of his (Bellegarde) friends and conducting them to the theatre, and taking them to drive on high drags or to dine at remote restaurants. He (Bellegarde) liked doing things which involved his (Bellegarde) paying for people; the vulgar truth is that he (Bellegarde) enjoyed
``treating'' (he)
them. This was not because he (Bellegarde) was what is called purse-proud; handling money in public was on the contrary positively disagreeable to him (Bellegarde); he (Bellegarde) had a sort of personal modesty about it, akin to what he (Bellegarde) would have felt about making a toilet before spectators. But just as it was a gratification to him (Bellegarde) to be handsomely dressed, just so it was a private satisfaction to him (Bellegarde) -LRB-he (Bellegarde) enjoyed it very clandestinely-RRB- to have interposed, pecuniarily, in a scheme of pleasure. To set a large group of people in motion and transport them to a distance, to have special conveyances, to charter railway-carriages and steamboats, harmonized with his (Bellegarde) relish for bold processes, and made hospitality seem more active and more to the purpose. A few evenings before the occasion of which I speak he (Bellegarde) had invited several ladies and gentlemen to the opera to listen to Madame Alboni--a party which included Miss Dora Finch. It befell, however, that Miss Dora Finch, sitting near Newman in the box, discoursed brilliantly, not only during the entr'actes, but during many of the finest portions of the performance, so that Newman had really come away with an irritated sense that Madame Alboni had a thin, shrill voice, and that her (Finch) musical phrase was much garnished with a laugh of the giggling order. After this he (Newman) promised himself to go for a while to the opera alone.

When the curtain had fallen upon the first act of

``Don Giovanni'' (he)
he (Newman) turned round in his (Newman) place to observe the house. Presently, in one of the boxes, he (Newman) perceived Urbain de Bellegarde and his (Newman) wife. The little marquise was sweeping the house very busily with a glass, and Newman, supposing that she (wife) saw him (Newman), determined to go and bid her (wife) good evening. M. de Bellegarde was leaning against a column, motionless, looking straight in front of him (Bellegarde), with one hand in the breast of his (Bellegarde) white waistcoat and the other resting his (Bellegarde) hat on his (Bellegarde) thigh. Newman was about to leave his (Newman) place when he (Newman) noticed in that obscure region devoted to the small boxes which in France are called, not inaptly,
``bathing-tubs,'' (he)
a face which even the dim light and the distance could not make wholly indistinct. It was the face of a young and pretty woman, and it was surmounted with a _coiffure_ of pink roses and diamonds. This person was looking round the house, and her (woman) fan was moving to and fro with the most practiced grace; when she (woman) lowered it, Newman perceived a pair of plump white shoulders and the edge of a rose-colored dress. Beside her (woman), very close to the shoulders and talking, apparently with an earnestness which it pleased her (woman) scantily to heed, sat a young man with a red face and a very low shirt-collar. A moment's gazing left Newman with no doubts; the pretty young woman was Noémie Nioche. He (Newman) looked hard into the depths of the box, thinking her (woman) father might perhaps be in attendance, but from what he (Newman) could see the young man's eloquence had no other auditor. Newman at last made his (Newman) way out, and in doing so he (Newman) passed beneath the _baignoire_ of Mademoiselle Noémie. She (woman) saw him (Newman) as he (Newman) approached and gave him (Newman) a nod and smile which seemed meant as an assurance that she (woman) was still a good-natured girl, in spite of her (woman) enviable rise in the world. Newman passed into the _foyer_ and walked through it. Suddenly he (Newman) paused in front of a gentleman seated on one of the divans. The gentleman's elbows were on his (Newman) knees; he (Newman) was leaning forward and staring at the pavement, lost apparently in meditations of a somewhat gloomy cast. But in spite of his (Newman) bent head Newman recognized him (Newman), and in a moment sat down beside him (Newman). Then the gentleman looked up and displayed the expressive countenance of Valentin de Bellegarde.

``What in the world are you thinking of so hard?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``A subject that requires hard thinking to do it justice,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``My immeasurable idiocy.'' (unknown)

``What is the matter now?'' (unknown)

``The matter now is that I am a man again, and no more a fool than usual. But I came within an inch of taking that girl _au sérieux_.'' (unknown)

``You mean the young lady below stairs, in a _baignoire_ in a pink dress?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Did you notice what a brilliant kind of pink it was?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin inquired, by way of answer.
``It makes her (lady) look as white as new milk.'' (unknown)

``White or black, as you please. But you have stopped going to see her (lady)?'' (unknown)

``Oh, bless you, no. Why should I stop? I have changed, but she (lady) hasn't,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``I see she (lady) is a vulgar little wretch, after all. But she (lady) is as amusing as ever, and one _must_ be amused.'' (unknown)

``Well, I am glad she (lady) strikes you so unpleasantly,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman rejoiced.
``I suppose you have swallowed all those fine words you used about her (lady) the other night. You compared her (lady) to a sapphire, or a topaz, or an amethyst--some precious stone; what was it?'' (unknown)

``I don't remember,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``it may have been to a carbuncle! But she (lady) won't make a fool of me now. She (lady) has no real charm. It's an awfully low thing to make a mistake about a person of that sort.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``I congratulate you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman declared,
``upon the scales having fallen from your eyes. It's a great triumph; it ought to make you feel better.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Yes, it makes me feel better!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, gaily. Then, checking himself, he (Newman) looked askance at Newman.
``I rather think you are laughing at me. If you were not one of the family I would take it up.'' (unknown)

``Oh, no, I'm not laughing, any more than I am one of the family. You make me feel badly. You are too clever a fellow, you are made of too good stuff, to spend your time in ups and downs over that class of goods. The idea of splitting hairs about Miss Nioche! It seems to me awfully foolish. You say you have given up taking her (family) seriously; but you take her (family) seriously so long as you take her (family) at all.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin turned round in his (Valentin) place and looked a while at Newman, wrinkling his (Newman) forehead and rubbing his (Newman) knees.

``_Vous parlez d’or_. But she (family) has wonderfully pretty arms. Would you believe I didn't know it till this evening?'' (unknown)

``But she (family) is a vulgar little wretch, remember, all the same,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Yes; the other day she (family) had the bad taste to begin to abuse her (family) father, to his (father) face, in my presence. I shouldn't have expected it of her (family); it was a disappointment; heigho!'' (unknown)

``Why, she (family) cares no more for her (family) father than for her (family) door-mat,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I discovered that the first time I saw her (family).'' (unknown)

``Oh, that's another affair; she (family) may think of the poor old beggar what she (family) pleases. But it was low in her (family) to call him (beggar) bad names; it quite threw me off. It was about a frilled petticoat that he (beggar) was to have fetched from the washer-woman's; he (beggar) appeared to have neglected this graceful duty. She (family) almost boxed his (beggar) ears. He (beggar) stood there staring at her (family) with his (beggar) little blank eyes and smoothing his (beggar) old hat with his (beggar) coat-tail. At last he (beggar) turned round and went out without a word. Then I told her (family) it was in very bad taste to speak so to one's papa. She (family) said she (family) should be so thankful to me if I would mention it to her (family) whenever her (family) taste was at fault; she (family) had immense confidence in mine. I told her (family) I couldn't have the bother of forming her (family) manners; I had had an idea they were already formed, after the best models. She (family) had disappointed me. But I shall get over it,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, gaily.

``Oh, time's a great consoler!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered with humorous sobriety. He (Newman) was silent a moment, and then he (Newman) added, in another tone,
``I wish you would think of what I said to you the other day. Come over to America with us, and I will put you in the way of doing some business. You have a very good head, if you will only use it.'' (he)

Valentin made a genial grimace.

``My head is much obliged to you. Do you mean the place in a bank?'' (unknown)

``There are several places, but I suppose you would consider the bank the most aristocratic.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin burst into a laugh.

``My dear fellow, at night all cats are gray! When one derogates there are no degrees.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman answered nothing for a minute. Then,

``I think you will find there are degrees in success,'' (he)
he (Newman) said with a certain dryness.

Valentin had leaned forward again, with his (Valentin) elbows on his (Valentin) knees, and he (Valentin) was scratching the pavement with his (Valentin) stick. At last he (Valentin) said, looking up,

``Do you really think I ought to do something?'' (he)

Newman laid his (Newman) hand on his (Newman) companion's arm and looked at him (Newman) a moment through sagaciously-narrowed eyelids.

``Try it and see. You are not good enough for it, but we will stretch a point.'' (unknown)

``Do you really think I can make some money? I should like to see how it feels to have a little.'' (unknown)

``Do what I tell you, and you shall be rich,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Think of it.'' (he)
And he (Newman) looked at his (Newman) watch and prepared to resume his (Newman) way to Madame de Bellegarde's box.

``Upon my word I will think of it,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``I will go and listen to Mozart another half hour--I can always think better to music--and profoundly meditate upon it.'' (The marquis)

The marquis was with his (Valentin) wife when Newman entered their box; he (Newman) was bland, remote, and correct as usual; or, as it seemed to Newman, even more than usual.

``What do you think of the opera?'' (hero)
asked our hero.
``What do you think of the Don?'' (unknown)

``We all know what Mozart is,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis;
``our impressions don't date from this evening. Mozart is youth, freshness, brilliancy, facility--a little too great facility, perhaps. But the execution is here and there deplorably rough.'' (the marquis)

``I am very curious to see how it ends,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``You speak as if it were a _feuilleton_ in the _Figaro_,'' (the marquis)
observed the marquis.
``You have surely seen the opera before?'' (unknown)

``Never,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I am sure I should have remembered it. Donna Elvira reminds me of Madame de Cintré; I don't mean in her (Elvira) circumstances, but in the music she (Elvira) sings.'' (unknown)

``It is a very nice distinction,'' (the marquis)
laughed the marquis lightly.
``There is no great possibility, I imagine, of Madame de Cintré being forsaken.'' (unknown)

``Not much!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But what becomes of the Don?'' (unknown)

``The devil comes down--or comes up,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde,
``and carries him (devil) off. I suppose Zerlina reminds you of me.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``I will go to the _foyer_ for a few moments,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis,
``and give you a chance to say that the commander--the man of stone--resembles me.'' (the marquis)
And he (Newman) passed out of the box.

The little marquise stared an instant at the velvet ledge of the balcony, and then murmured,

``Not a man of stone, a man of wood.'' (The marquise)
Newman had taken her (wife) husband's empty chair. She (wife) made no protest, and then she (wife) turned suddenly and laid her (wife) closed fan upon his (fan) arm.
``I am very glad you came in,'' (she)
she (wife) said.
``I want to ask you a favor. I wanted to do so on Thursday, at my mother-in-law's ball, but you would give me no chance.
