You were in such very good spirits that I thought you might grant my little favor then; not that you look particularly doleful now. It is something you must promise me; now is the time to take you; after you are married you will be good for nothing. Come, promise!'' (unknown)

``I never sign a paper without reading it first,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Show me your document.'' (unknown)

``No, you must sign with your eyes shut; I will hold your hand. Come, before you put your head into the noose. You ought to be thankful to me for giving you a chance to do something amusing.'' (unknown)

``If it is so amusing,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``it will be in even better season after I am married.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``In other words,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
cried Madame de Bellegarde,
``you will not do it at all. You will be afraid of your wife.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``Oh, if the thing is intrinsically improper,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I won't go into it. If it is not, I will do it after my marriage.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``You talk like a treatise on logic, and English logic into the bargain!'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
exclaimed Madame de Bellegarde.
``Promise, then, after you are married. After all, I shall enjoy keeping you to it.'' (unknown)

``Well, then, after I am married,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman serenely.

The little marquise hesitated a moment, looking at him (Newman), and he (Newman) wondered what was coming.

``I suppose you know what my life is,'' (she)
she (wife) presently said.
``I have no pleasure, I see nothing, I do nothing. I live in Paris as I might live at Poitiers. My mother-in-law calls me--what is the pretty word?--a gad-about? accuses me of going to unheard-of places, and thinks it ought to be joy enough for me to sit at home and count over my ancestors on my fingers. But why should I bother about my ancestors? I am sure they never bothered about me. I don't propose to live with a green shade on my eyes; I hold that things were made to look at. My husband, you know, has principles, and the first on the list is that the Tuileries are dreadfully vulgar. If the Tuileries are vulgar, his (husband) principles are tiresome. If I chose I might have principles quite as well as he (husband). If they grew on one's family tree I should only have to give mine a shake to bring down a shower of the finest. At any rate, I prefer clever Bonapartes to stupid Bourbons.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I see; you want to go to court,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, vaguely conjecturing that she (wife) might wish him (Newman) to appeal to the United States legation to smooth her (wife) way to the imperial halls.

The marquise gave a little sharp laugh.

``You are a thousand miles away. I will take care of the Tuileries myself; the day I decide to go they will be very glad to have me. Sooner or later I shall dance in an imperial quadrille. I know what you are going to say: `How will you dare?' But I _shall_ dare. I am afraid of my husband; he (husband) is soft, smooth, irreproachable; everything that you know; but I am afraid of him (husband)--horribly afraid of him (husband). And yet I shall arrive at the Tuileries. But that will not be this winter, nor perhaps next, and meantime I must live. For the moment, I want to go somewhere else; it's my dream. I want to go to the Bal Bullier.'' (unknown)

``To the Bal Bullier?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
repeated Newman, for whom the words at first meant nothing.

``The ball in the Latin Quarter, where the students dance with their mistresses. Don't tell me you have not heard of it.'' (unknown)

``Oh yes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``I have heard of it; I remember now. I have even been there. And you want to go there?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``It is silly, it is low, it is anything you please. But I want to go. Some of my friends have been, and they say it is awfully _drôle_. My friends go everywhere; it is only I who sit moping at home.'' (unknown)

``It seems to me you are not at home now,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``and I shouldn't exactly say you were moping.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I am bored to death. I have been to the opera twice a week for the last eight years. Whenever I ask for anything my mouth is stopped with that: Pray, madam, haven't you an opera box? Could a woman of taste want more? In the first place, my opera box was down in my _contrat_; they have to give it to me. To-night, for instance, I should have preferred a thousand times to go to the Palais Royal. But my husband won't go to the Palais Royal because the ladies of the court go there so much. You may imagine, then, whether he (husband) would take me to Bullier's; he (husband) says it is a mere imitation--and a bad one--of what they do at the Princess Kleinfuss's. But as I don't go to the Princess Kleinfuss's, the next best thing is to go to Bullier's. It is my dream, at any rate, it's a fixed idea. All I ask of you is to give me your arm; you are less compromising than anyone else. I don't know why, but you are. I can arrange it. I shall risk something, but that is my own affair. Besides, fortune favors the bold. Don't refuse me; it is my dream!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman gave a loud laugh. It seemed to him (Newman) hardly worth while to be the wife of the Marquis de Bellegarde, a daughter of the crusaders, heiress of six centuries of glories and traditions, to have centred one's aspirations upon the sight of a couple of hundred young ladies kicking off young men's hats. It struck him (Newman) as a theme for the moralist; but he (Newman) had no time to moralize upon it. The curtain rose again; M. de Bellegarde returned, and Newman went back to his (Newman) seat.

He (Newman) observed that Valentin de Bellegarde had taken his (Bellegarde) place in the _baignoire_ of Mademoiselle Nioche, behind this young lady and her (lady) companion, where he (companion) was visible only if one carefully looked for him (companion). In the next act Newman met him (Newman) in the lobby and asked him (Newman) if he (Newman) had reflected upon possible emigration.

``If you really meant to meditate,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``you might have chosen a better place for it.'' (he)

``Oh, the place was not bad,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``I was not thinking of that girl. I listened to the music, and, without thinking of the play or looking at the stage, I turned over your proposal. At first it seemed quite fantastic. And then a certain fiddle in the orchestra--I could distinguish it--began to say as it scraped away, `Why not, why not?' And then, in that rapid movement, all the fiddles took it up and the conductor's stick seemed to beat it in the air: `Why not, why not?' I'm sure I can't say! I don't see why not. I don't see why I shouldn't do something. It appears to me really a very bright idea. This sort of thing is certainly very stale. And then I could come back with a trunk full of dollars. Besides, I might possibly find it amusing. They call me a _raffiné_; who knows but that I might discover an unsuspected charm in shop-keeping? It would really have a certain romantic, picturesque side; it would look well in my biography. It would look as if I were a strong man, a first-rate man, a man who dominated circumstances.'' (unknown)

``Never mind how it would look,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``It always looks well to have half a million of dollars. There is no reason why you shouldn't have them if you will mind what I tell you--I alone--and not talk to other parties.'' (He)
He (Newman) passed his (Newman) arm into that of his (Newman) companion, and the two walked for some time up and down one of the less frequented corridors. Newman's imagination began to glow with the idea of converting his (Newman) bright, impracticable friend into a first-class man of business. He (Newman) felt for the moment a sort of spiritual zeal, the zeal of the propagandist. Its ardor was in part the result of that general discomfort which the sight of all uninvested capital produced in him (Newman); so fine an intelligence as Bellegarde's ought to be dedicated to high uses. The highest uses known to Newman's experience were certain transcendent sagacities in the handling of railway stock. And then his (Newman) zeal was quickened by his (Newman) personal kindness for Valentin; he (Newman) had a sort of pity for him (Newman) which he (Newman) was well aware he (Newman) never could have made the Comte de Bellegarde understand. He (Newman) never lost a sense of its being pitiable that Valentin should think it a large life to revolve in varnished boots between the Rue d’Anjou and the Rue de l’Université, taking the Boulevard des Italiens on the way, when over there in America one's promenade was a continent, and one's Boulevard stretched from New York to San Francisco. It mortified him (Francisco), moreover, to think that Valentin lacked money; there was a painful grotesqueness in it. It affected him (Valentin) as the ignorance of a companion, otherwise without reproach, touching some rudimentary branch of learning would have done. There were things that one knew about as a matter of course, he (companion) would have said in such a case. Just so, if one pretended to be easy in the world, one had money as a matter of course, one had made it! There was something almost ridiculously anomalous to Newman in the sight of lively pretensions unaccompanied by large investments in railroads; though I may add that he (Newman) would not have maintained that such investments were in themselves a proper ground for pretensions.
``I will make you do something,'' (he)
he (Newman) said to Valentin;
``I will put you through. I know half a dozen things in which we can make a place for you. You will see some lively work. It will take you a little while to get used to the life, but you will work in before long, and at the end of six months--after you have done a thing or two on your own account--you will like it. And then it will be very pleasant for you, having your sister over there. It will be pleasant for her (sister) to have you, too. Yes, Valentin,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
continued Newman, pressing his (Newman) friend's arm genially,
``I think I see just the opening for you. Keep quiet and I'll push you right in.'' (friend)

Newman pursued this favoring strain for some time longer. The two men strolled about for a quarter of an hour. Valentin listened and questioned, many of his (Valentin) questions making Newman laugh loud at the _naïveté_ of his (Newman) ignorance of the vulgar processes of money-getting; smiling himself, too, half ironical and half curious. And yet he (Newman) was serious; he (Newman) was fascinated by Newman's plain prose version of the legend of El Dorado. It is true, however, that though to accept an

``opening'' (he)
in an American mercantile house might be a bold, original, and in its consequences extremely agreeable thing to do, he (Newman) did not quite see himself objectively doing it. So that when the bell rang to indicate the close of the entr'acte, there was a certain mock-heroism in his (Newman) saying, with his (Newman) brilliant smile,
``Well, then, put me through; push me in! I make myself over to you. Dip me into the pot and turn me into gold.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

They had passed into the corridor which encircled the row of _baignoires_, and Valentin stopped in front of the dusky little box in which Mademoiselle Nioche had bestowed herself, laying his (Valentin) hand on the doorknob.

``Oh, come, are you going back there?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``_Mon Dieu, oui_,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.

``Haven't you another place?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I have my usual place, in the stalls.'' (unknown)

``You had better go and occupy it, then.'' (unknown)

``I see her (me) very well from there, too,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
added Valentin, serenely,
``and to-night she (me) is worth seeing. But,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
he (Valentin) added in a moment,
``I have a particular reason for going back just now.'' (he)

``Oh, I give you up,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You are infatuated!'' (unknown)

``No, it is only this. There is a young man in the box whom I shall annoy by going in, and I want to annoy him (man).'' (unknown)

``I am sorry to hear it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Can't you leave the poor fellow alone?'' (unknown)

``No, he (fellow) has given me cause. The box is not his (fellow). Noémie came in alone and installed herself. I went and spoke to her (Noémie), and in a few moments she (Noémie) asked me to go and get her (Noémie) fan from the pocket of her (Noémie) cloak, which the _ouvreuse_ had carried off. In my absence this gentleman came in and took the chair beside Noémie in which I had been sitting. My reappearance disgusted him (gentleman), and he (gentleman) had the grossness to show it. He (gentleman) came within an ace of being impertinent. I don't know who he (gentleman) is; he (gentleman) is some vulgar wretch. I can't think where she (Noémie) picks up such acquaintances. He (gentleman) has been drinking, too, but he (gentleman) knows what he (gentleman) is about. Just now, in the second act, he (gentleman) was unmannerly again. I shall put in another appearance for ten minutes--time enough to give him (gentleman) an opportunity to commit himself, if he (gentleman) feels inclined. I really can't let the brute suppose that he (gentleman) is keeping me out of the box.'' (unknown)

``My dear fellow,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, remonstrantly,
``what child's play! You are not going to pick a quarrel about that girl, I hope.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``That girl has nothing to do with it, and I have no intention of picking a quarrel. I am not a bully nor a fire-eater. I simply wish to make a point that a gentleman must.'' (unknown)

``Oh, damn your point!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``That is the trouble with you Frenchmen; you must be always making points. Well,'' (he)
he (Newman) added,
``be short. But if you are going in for this kind of thing, we must ship you off to America in advance.'' (he)

``Very good,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin answered,
``whenever you please. But if I go to America, I must not let this gentleman suppose that it is to run away from him (gentleman).'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

And they separated. At the end of the act Newman observed that Valentin was still in the _baignoire_. He (Newman) strolled into the corridor again, expecting to meet him (Newman), and when he (Newman) was within a few yards of Mademoiselle Nioche's box saw his (Newman) friend pass out, accompanied by the young man who had been seated beside its fair occupant. The two gentlemen walked with some quickness of step to a distant part of the lobby, where Newman perceived them stop and stand talking. The manner of each was perfectly quiet, but the stranger, who looked flushed, had begun to wipe his (stranger) face very emphatically with his (stranger) pocket-handkerchief. By this time Newman was abreast of the _baignoire_; the door had been left ajar, and he (Newman) could see a pink dress inside. He (Newman) immediately went in. Mademoiselle Nioche turned and greeted him (Newman) with a brilliant smile.

``Ah, you have at last decided to come and see me?'' (she)
she (stranger) exclaimed.
``You just save your politeness. You find me in a fine moment. Sit down.'' (unknown)
There was a very becoming little flush in her (stranger) cheek, and her (stranger) eye had a noticeable spark. You would have said that she (stranger) had received some very good news.

``Something has happened here!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, without sitting down.

``You find me in a very fine moment,'' (she)
she (stranger) repeated.
``Two gentlemen--one of them is M. de Bellegarde, the pleasure of whose acquaintance I owe to you--have just had words about your humble servant. Very big words too. They can't come off without crossing swords. A duel--that will give me a push!'' (Mademoiselle Noémie/Noémie/Mademoiselle)
cried Mademoiselle Noémie clapping her (stranger) little hands.
``_C’est ça qui pose une femme!_'' (unknown)

``You don't mean to say that Bellegarde is going to fight about _you!_'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
exclaimed Newman disgustedly.

``Nothing else!'' (she)
and she (stranger) looked at him (Newman) with a hard little smile.
``No, no, you are not _galant!_ And if you prevent this affair I shall owe you a grudge--and pay my debt!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman uttered an imprecation which, though brief--it consisted simply of the interjection

``Oh!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
followed by a geographical, or more correctly, perhaps a theological noun in four letters--had better not be transferred to these pages. He (Newman) turned his (Newman) back without more ceremony upon the pink dress and went out of the box. In the corridor he (Newman) found Valentin and his (Valentin) companion walking towards him (Valentin). The latter was thrusting a card into his (Valentin) waistcoat pocket. Mademoiselle Noémie's jealous votary was a tall, robust young man with a thick nose, a prominent blue eye, a Germanic physiognomy, and a massive watch-chain. When they reached the box, Valentin with an emphasized bow made way for him (Valentin) to pass in first. Newman touched Valentin's arm as a sign that he (Newman) wished to speak with him (Newman), and Bellegarde answered that he (Bellegarde) would be with him (Bellegarde) in an instant. Valentin entered the box after the robust young man, but a couple of minutes afterwards he (Valentin) reappeared, largely smiling.

``She (me) is immensely tickled,'' (he)
he (Valentin) said.
``She (me) says we will make her (me) fortune. I don't want to be fatuous, but I think it is very possible.'' (unknown)

``So you are going to fight?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``My dear fellow, don't look so mortally disgusted. It was not my choice. The thing is all arranged.'' (unknown)

``I told you so!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
groaned Newman.

``I told _him (I)_ so,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, smiling.

``What did he (I) do to you?'' (unknown)

``My good friend, it doesn't matter what. He (friend) used an expression--I took it up.'' (unknown)

``But I insist upon knowing; I can't, as your elder brother, have you rushing into this sort of nonsense.'' (unknown)

``I am very much obliged to you,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``I have nothing to conceal, but I can't go into particulars now and here.'' (unknown)

``We will leave this place, then. You can tell me outside.'' (unknown)

``Oh no, I can't leave this place, why should I hurry away? I will go to my orchestra-stall and sit out the opera.'' (unknown)

``You will not enjoy it; you will be preoccupied.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin looked at him (Valentin) a moment, colored a little, smiled, and patted him (Valentin) on the arm.

``You are delightfully simple! Before an affair a man is quiet. The quietest thing I can do is to go straight to my place.'' (unknown)

``Ah,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``you want her (You) to see you there--you and your quietness. I am not so simple! It is a poor business.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Valentin remained, and the two men, in their respective places, sat out the rest of the performance, which was also enjoyed by Mademoiselle Nioche and her (couple) truculent admirer. At the end Newman joined Valentin again, and they went into the street together. Valentin shook his (Valentin) head at his (Valentin) friend's proposal that he (Valentin) should get into Newman's own vehicle, and stopped on the edge of the pavement.

``I must go off alone,'' (he)
he (Valentin) said;
``I must look up a couple of friends who will take charge of this matter.'' (he)

``I will take charge of it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman declared.
``Put it into my hands.'' (unknown)

``You are very kind, but that is hardly possible. In the first place, you are, as you said just now, almost my brother; you are about to marry my sister. That alone disqualifies you; it casts doubts on your impartiality. And if it didn't, it would be enough for me that I strongly suspect you of disapproving of the affair. You would try to prevent a meeting.'' (unknown)

``Of course I should,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Whoever your friends are, I hope they will do that.'' (unknown)

``Unquestionably they will. They will urge that excuses be made, proper excuses. But you would be too good-natured. You won't do.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman was silent a moment. He (Newman) was keenly annoyed, but he (Newman) saw it was useless to attempt interference.

``When is this precious performance to come off?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.

``The sooner the better,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``The day after to-morrow, I hope.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I have certainly a claim to know the facts. I can't consent to shut my eyes to the matter.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I shall be most happy to tell you the facts,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``They are very simple, and it will be quickly done. But now everything depends on my putting my hands on my friends without delay. I will jump into a cab; you had better drive to my room and wait for me there. I will turn up at the end of an hour.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman assented protestingly, let his (Newman) friend go, and then betook himself to the picturesque little apartment in the Rue d’Anjou. It was more than an hour before Valentin returned, but when he (Valentin) did so he (Valentin) was able to announce that he (Valentin) had found one of his (Valentin) desired friends, and that this gentleman had taken upon himself the care of securing an associate. Newman had been sitting without lights by Valentin's faded fire, upon which he (Newman) had thrown a log; the blaze played over the richly-encumbered little sitting-room and produced fantastic gleams and shadows. He (Newman) listened in silence to Valentin's account of what had passed between him (Valentin) and the gentleman whose card he (Valentin) had in his (Valentin) pocket--M. Stanislas Kapp, of Strasbourg--after his (Kapp) return to Mademoiselle Nioche's box. This hospitable young lady had espied an acquaintance on the other side of the house, and had expressed her (lady) displeasure at his (Kapp) not having the civility to come and pay her (lady) a visit.

``Oh, let him (my) alone!'' (M. Stanislas Kapp/M. Kapp/M. Stanislas)
M. Stanislas Kapp had hereupon exclaimed.
``There are too many people in the box already.'' (he)
And he (Kapp) had fixed his (Kapp) eyes with a demonstrative stare upon M. de Bellegarde. Valentin had promptly retorted that if there were too many people in the box it was easy for M. Kapp to diminish the number.
``I shall be most happy to open the door for _you!_'' (M. Stanislas Kapp/M. Kapp/M. Stanislas)
M. Kapp exclaimed.
``I shall be delighted to fling you into the pit!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin had answered.
``Oh, do make a rumpus and get into the papers!'' (Miss Noémie)
Miss Noémie had gleefully ejaculated.
``M. Kapp, turn him (Kapp) out; or, M. de Bellegarde, pitch him (Kapp) into the pit, into the orchestra--anywhere! I don't care who does which, so long as you make a scene.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin answered that they would make no scene, but that the gentleman would be so good as to step into the corridor with him (Valentin). In the corridor, after a brief further exchange of words, there had been an exchange of cards. M. Stanislas Kapp was very stiff. He (Kapp) evidently meant to force his (Kapp) offence home.

``The man, no doubt, was insolent,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said;
``but if you hadn't gone back into the box the thing wouldn't have happened.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Why, don't you see,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin replied, ``that the event proves the extreme propriety of my going back into the box? M. Kapp wished to provoke me; he (Kapp) was awaiting his (Kapp) chance. In such a case--that is, when he (Kapp) has been, so to speak, notified--a man must be on hand to receive the provocation. My not returning would simply have been tantamount to my saying to M. Stanislas Kapp, `Oh, if you are going to be disagreeable'''--

```You must manage it by yourself; damned if I'll help you!' That would have been a thoroughly sensible thing to say. The only attraction for you seems to have been the prospect of M. Kapp's impertinence,'' Newman went on.

``You told me you were not going back for that girl.'' (unknown)

``Oh, don't mention that girl any more,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
murmured Valentin.
``She (girl)'s a bore.'' (unknown)

``With all my heart. But if that is the way you feel about her (girl), why couldn't you let her (girl) alone?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin shook his (Valentin) head with a fine smile.

``I don't think you quite understand, and I don't believe I can make you. She (girl) understood the situation; she (girl) knew what was in the air; she (girl) was watching us.'' (unknown)

``A cat may look at a king! What difference does that make?'' (unknown)

``Why, a man can't back down before a woman.'' (unknown)

``I don't call her (woman) a woman. You said yourself she (woman) was a stone,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.

``Well,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin rejoined,
``there is no disputing about tastes. It's a matter of feeling; it's measured by one's sense of honor.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``Oh, confound your sense of honor!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.

``It is vain talking,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin;
``words have passed, and the thing is settled.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Newman turned away, taking his (Newman) hat. Then pausing with his (Newman) hand on the door,

``What are you going to use?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.

``That is for M. Stanislas Kapp, as the challenged party, to decide. My own choice would be a short, light sword. I handle it well. I'm an indifferent shot.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman had put on his (Newman) hat; he (Newman) pushed it back, gently scratching his (Newman) forehead, high up.

``I wish it were pistols,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``I could show you how to lodge a bullet!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin broke into a laugh.

``What is it some English poet says about consistency? It's a flower, or a star, or a jewel. Yours has the beauty of all three!'' (he)
But he (Valentin) agreed to see Newman again on the morrow, after the details of his (Newman) meeting with M. Stanislas Kapp should have been arranged.

In the course of the day Newman received three lines from him (Newman), saying that it had been decided that he (Newman) should cross the frontier, with his (Newman) adversary, and that he (Newman) was to take the night express to Geneva. He (Newman) should have time, however, to dine with Newman. In the afternoon Newman called upon Madame de Cintré, but his (Newman) visit was brief. She (it) was as gracious and sympathetic as he (Newman) had ever found her (it), but she (it) was sad, and she (it) confessed, on Newman's charging her (it) with her (it) red eyes, that she (it) had been crying. Valentin had been with her (it) a couple of hours before, and his (Valentin) visit had left her (it) with a painful impression. He (Valentin) had laughed and gossiped, he (Valentin) had brought her (it) no bad news, he (Valentin) had only been, in his (Valentin) manner, rather more affectionate than usual. His (Valentin) fraternal tenderness had touched her (it), and on his (Valentin) departure she (it) had burst into tears. She (it) had felt as if something strange and sad were going to happen; she (it) had tried to reason away the fancy, and the effort had only given her (it) a headache. Newman, of course, was perforce tongue-tied about Valentin's projected duel, and his (Valentin) dramatic talent was not equal to satirizing Madame de Cintré's presentiment as pointedly as perfect security demanded. Before he (Cintré) went away he (Cintré) asked Madame de Cintré whether Valentin had seen his (Valentin) mother.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (mother) said,
``but he (poet) didn't make her (My) cry.'' (she)

It was in Newman's own apartment that Valentin dined, having brought his (Valentin) portmanteau, so that he (Valentin) might adjourn directly to the railway. M. Stanislas Kapp had positively declined to make excuses, and he (Kapp), on his (Kapp) side, obviously, had none to offer. Valentin had found out with whom he (Valentin) was dealing. M. Stanislas Kapp was the son of and heir of a rich brewer of Strasbourg, a youth of a sanguineous--and sanguinary--temperament. He (Kapp) was making ducks and drakes of the paternal brewery, and although he (Kapp) passed in a general way for a good fellow, he (Kapp) had already been observed to be quarrelsome after dinner.

``_Que voulez-vous?_'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``Brought up on beer, he (poet) can't stand champagne.'' (He)
He (Valentin) had chosen pistols. Valentin, at dinner, had an excellent appetite; he (Valentin) made a point, in view of his (Valentin) long journey, of eating more than usual. He (Valentin) took the liberty of suggesting to Newman a slight modification in the composition of a certain fish-sauce; he (Newman) thought it would be worth mentioning to the cook. But Newman had no thoughts for fish-sauce; he (Newman) felt thoroughly discontented. As he (Newman) sat and watched his (Newman) amiable and clever companion going through his (Newman) excellent repast with the delicate deliberation of hereditary epicurism, the folly of so charming a fellow traveling off to expose his (Newman) agreeable young life for the sake of M. Stanislas and Mademoiselle Noémie struck him (Stanislas) with intolerable force. He (Stanislas) had grown fond of Valentin, he (Valentin) felt now how fond; and his (Valentin) sense of helplessness only increased his (Valentin) irritation.

``Well, this sort of thing may be all very well,'' (he)
he (Valentin) cried at last,
``but I declare I don't see it. I can't stop you, perhaps, but at least I can protest. I do protest, violently.'' (he)

``My dear fellow, don't make a scene,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``Scenes in these cases are in very bad taste.'' (unknown)

``Your duel itself is a scene,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``that's all it is! It's a wretched theatrical affair. Why don't you take a band of music with you outright? It's d--d barbarous and it's d--d corrupt, both.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Oh, I can't begin, at this time of day, to defend the theory of dueling,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``It is our custom, and I think it is a good thing. Quite apart from the goodness of the cause in which a duel may be fought, it has a kind of picturesque charm which in this age of vile prose seems to me greatly to recommend it. It's a remnant of a higher-tempered time; one ought to cling to it. Depend upon it, a duel is never amiss.'' (unknown)

``I don't know what you mean by a higher-tempered time,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Because your great-grandfather was an ass, is that any reason why you should be? For my part I think we had better let our temper take care of itself; it generally seems to me quite high enough; I am not afraid of being too meek. If your great-grandfather were to make himself unpleasant to me, I think I could manage him (great-grandfather) yet.'' (unknown)

``My dear friend,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin, smiling,
``you can't invent anything that will take the place of satisfaction for an insult. To demand it and to give it are equally excellent arrangements.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``Do you call this sort of thing satisfaction?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.
``Does it satisfy you to receive a present of the carcass of that coarse fop? does it gratify you to make him (friend) a present of yours? If a man hits you, hit him (man) back; if a man libels you, haul him (man) up.'' (unknown)

``Haul him (man) up, into court? Oh, that is very nasty!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.

``The nastiness is his (man)--not yours. And for that matter, what you are doing is not particularly nice. You are too good for it. I don't say you are the most useful man in the world, or the cleverest, or the most amiable. But you are too good to go and get your throat cut for a prostitute.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin flushed a little, but he (Valentin) laughed.

``I shan't get my throat cut if I can help it. Moreover, one's honor hasn't two different measures. It only knows that it is hurt; it doesn't ask when, or how, or where.'' (unknown)

``The more fool it is!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

Valentin ceased to laugh; he (Valentin) looked grave.

``I beg you not to say any more,'' (he)
he (Valentin) said.
``If you do I shall almost fancy you don't care about--about'' (he)
--and he (Valentin) paused.

``About what?'' (unknown)

``About that matter--about one's honor.'' (unknown)

``Fancy what you please,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Fancy while you are at it that I care about _you_--though you are not worth it. But come back without damage,'' (he)
he (Newman) added in a moment,
``and I will forgive you. And then,'' (he)
he (Newman) continued, as Valentin was going,
``I will ship you straight off to America.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``Well,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
answered Valentin,
``if I am to turn over a new page, this may figure as a tail-piece to the old.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
And then he (Valentin) lit another cigar and departed.

``Blast that girl!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman as the door closed upon Valentin.

CHAPTER XVIII

Newman went the next morning to see Madame de Cintré, timing his (Newman) visit so as to arrive after the noonday breakfast. In the court of the _hôtel_, before the portico, stood Madame de Bellegarde's old square carriage. The servant who opened the door answered Newman's inquiry with a slightly embarrassed and hesitating murmur, and at the same moment Mrs. Bread appeared in the background, dim-visaged as usual, and wearing a large black bonnet and shawl.

``What is the matter?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.
``Is Madame la Comtesse at home, or not?'' (him)

Mrs. Bread advanced, fixing her (Valentin) eyes upon him (Newman): he (Newman) observed that she (Valentin) held a sealed letter, very delicately, in her (Valentin) fingers.

``The countess has left a message for you, sir; she (countess) has left this,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Mrs. Bread, holding out the letter, which Newman took.

``Left it? Is she (countess) out? Is she (countess) gone away?'' (unknown)

``She (countess) is going away, sir; she (countess) is leaving town,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.

``Leaving town!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
exclaimed Newman.
``What has happened?'' (unknown)

``It is not for me to say, sir,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread, with her (Valentin) eyes on the ground.
``But I thought it would come.'' (unknown)

``What would come, pray?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman demanded. He (Newman) had broken the seal of the letter, but he (Newman) still questioned.
``She (countess) is in the house? She (countess) is visible?'' (unknown)

``I don't think she (countess) expected you this morning,'' (the waiting-woman)
the old waiting-woman replied.
``She (countess) was to leave immediately.'' (unknown)

``Where is she (countess) going?'' (unknown)

``To Fleurières.'' (unknown)

``To Fleurières? But surely I can see her (countess)?'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread hesitated a moment, and then clasping together her (Valentin) two hands,

``I will take you!'' (she)
she (Valentin) said. And she (Valentin) led the way upstairs. At the top of the staircase she (Valentin) paused and fixed her (Valentin) dry, sad eyes upon Newman.
``Be very easy with her (countess),'' (she)
she (Valentin) said;
``she (countess) is most unhappy!'' (she)
Then she (Valentin) went on to Madame de Cintré's apartment; Newman, perplexed and alarmed, followed her (Valentin) rapidly. Mrs. Bread threw open the door, and Newman pushed back the curtain at the farther side of its deep embrasure. In the middle of the room stood Madame de Cintré; her (Valentin) face was pale and she (Valentin) was dressed for traveling. Behind her (Valentin), before the fire-place, stood Urbain de Bellegarde, looking at his (Bellegarde) finger-nails; near the marquis sat his (Bellegarde) mother, buried in an armchair, and with her (mother) eyes immediately fixing themselves upon Newman. He (Newman) felt, as soon as he (Newman) entered the room, that he (Newman) was in the presence of something evil; he (Newman) was startled and pained, as he (Newman) would have been by a threatening cry in the stillness of the night. He (Newman) walked straight to Madame de Cintré and seized her (mother) by the hand.

``What is the matter?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked commandingly;
``what is happening?'' (he)

Urbain de Bellegarde stared, then left his (Bellegarde) place and came and leaned upon his (Bellegarde) mother's chair, behind. Newman's sudden irruption had evidently discomposed both mother and son. Madame de Cintré stood silent, with her (mother) eyes resting upon Newman's. She (mother) had often looked at him (Newman) with all her (mother) soul, as it seemed to him (Newman); but in this present gaze there was a sort of bottomless depth. She (mother) was in distress; it was the most touching thing he (Newman) had ever seen. His (Newman) heart rose into his (Newman) throat, and he (Newman) was on the point of turning to her (mother) companions, with an angry challenge; but she (mother) checked him (Newman), pressing the hand that held her (mother) own.

``Something very grave has happened,'' (she)
she (mother) said.
``I cannot marry you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman dropped her (mother) hand and stood staring, first at her (mother) and then at the others.

``Why not?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked, as quietly as possible.

Madame de Cintré almost smiled, but the attempt was strange.

``You must ask my mother, you must ask my brother.'' (unknown)

``Why can't she (mother) marry me?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, looking at them.

Madame de Bellegarde did not move in her (mother) place, but she (mother) was as pale as her (mother) daughter. The marquis looked down at her (mother). She (mother) said nothing for some moments, but she (mother) kept her (mother) keen, clear eyes upon Newman, bravely. The marquis drew himself up and looked at the ceiling.

``It's impossible!'' (he)
he (Newman) said softly.

``It's improper,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.

Newman began to laugh.

``Oh, you are fooling!'' (he)
he (Newman) exclaimed.

``My sister, you have no time; you are losing your train,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis.

``Come, is he (brother) mad?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``No; don't think that,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.
``But I am going away.'' (unknown)

``Where are you going?'' (unknown)

``To the country, to Fleurières; to be alone.'' (unknown)

``To leave me?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, slowly.

``I can't see you, now,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.

``_Now_--why not?'' (unknown)

``I am ashamed,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré, simply.

Newman turned toward the marquis.

``What have you done to her (sister)--what does it mean?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked with the same effort at calmness, the fruit of his (Newman) constant practice in taking things easily. He (Newman) was excited, but excitement with him (Newman) was only an intenser deliberateness; it was the swimmer stripped.

``It means that I have given you up,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.
``It means that.'' (unknown)

Her (marquis) face was too charged with tragic expression not fully to confirm her (marquis) words. Newman was profoundly shocked, but he (Newman) felt as yet no resentment against her (marquis). He (Newman) was amazed, bewildered, and the presence of the old marquise and her (marquis) son seemed to smite his (son) eyes like the glare of a watchman's lantern.

``Can't I see you alone?'' (he)
he (son) asked.

``It would be only more painful. I hoped I should not see you--I should escape. I wrote to you. Good-bye.'' (she)
And she (marquis) put out her (marquis) hand again.

Newman put both his (Newman) own into his (Newman) pockets.

``I will go with you,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

She (marquis) laid her (marquis) two hands on his (Newman) arm.

``Will you grant me a last request?'' (she)
and as she (marquis) looked at him (Newman), urging this, her (marquis) eyes filled with tears.
``Let me go alone--let me go in peace. I can't call it peace--it's death. But let me bury myself. So--good-bye.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman passed his (Newman) hand into his (Newman) hair and stood slowly rubbing his (Newman) head and looking through his (Newman) keenly-narrowed eyes from one to the other of the three persons before him (Newman). His (Newman) lips were compressed, and the two lines which had formed themselves beside his (Newman) mouth might have made it appear at a first glance that he (Newman) was smiling. I have said that his (Newman) excitement was an intenser deliberateness, and now he (Newman) looked grimly deliberate.

``It seems very much as if you had interfered, marquis,'' (he)
he (Newman) said slowly.
``I thought you said you wouldn't interfere. I know you don't like me; but that doesn't make any difference. I thought you promised me you wouldn't interfere. I thought you swore on your honor that you wouldn't interfere. Don't you remember, marquis?'' (The marquis)

The marquis lifted his (marquis) eyebrows; but he (marquis) was apparently determined to be even more urbane than usual. He (marquis) rested his (marquis) two hands upon the back of his (marquis) mother's chair and bent forward, as if he (marquis) were leaning over the edge of a pulpit or a lecture-desk. He (marquis) did not smile, but he (marquis) looked softly grave.

``Excuse me, sir,'' (he)
he (marquis) said,
``I assured you that I would not influence my sister's decision. I adhered, to the letter, to my engagement. Did I not, sister?'' (he)

``Don't appeal, my son,'' (the marquise)
said the marquise,
``your word is sufficient.'' (the marquise)

``Yes--she (sister) accepted me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``That is very true, I can't deny that. At least,'' (he)
he (Newman) added, in a different tone, turning to Madame de Cintré,
``you _did_ accept me?'' (Madame)

Something in the tone seemed to move her (mother) strongly. She (mother) turned away, burying her (mother) face in her (mother) hands.

``But you have interfered now, haven't you?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
inquired Newman of the marquis.

``Neither then nor now have I attempted to influence my sister. I used no persuasion then, I have used no persuasion to-day.'' (unknown)

``And what have you used?'' (unknown)

``We have used authority,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde in a rich, bell-like voice.

``Ah, you have used authority,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman exclaimed.
``They have used authority,'' (he)
he (Newman) went on, turning to Madame de Cintré.
``What is it? how did they use it?'' (unknown)

``My mother commanded,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.

``Commanded you to give me up--I see. And you obey--I see. But why do you obey?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

Madame de Cintré looked across at the old marquise; her (mother) eyes slowly measured her (mother) from head to foot.

``I am afraid of my mother,'' (she)
she (mother) said.

Madame de Bellegarde rose with a certain quickness, crying,

``This is a most indecent scene!'' (unknown)

``I have no wish to prolong it,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré; and turning to the door she (mother) put out her (mother) hand again.
``If you can pity me a little, let me go alone.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman shook her (mother) hand quietly and firmly.

``I'll come down there,'' (he)
he (Newman) said. The _portière_ dropped behind her (mother), and Newman sank with a long breath into the nearest chair. He (Newman) leaned back in it, resting his (Newman) hands on the knobs of the arms and looking at Madame de Bellegarde and Urbain. There was a long silence. They stood side by side, with their heads high and their handsome eyebrows arched.

``So you make a distinction?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said at last.
``You make a distinction between persuading and commanding? It's very neat. But the distinction is in favor of commanding. That rather spoils it.'' (unknown)

``We have not the least objection to defining our position,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde.
``We understand that it should not at first appear to you quite clear. We rather expected, indeed, that you should not do us justice.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I'll do you justice,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Don't be afraid. Please proceed.'' (The marquise)

The marquise laid her (mother) hand on her (mother) son's arm, as if to deprecate the attempt to define their position.

``It is quite useless,'' (she)
she (mother) said,
``to try and arrange this matter so as to make it agreeable to you. It can never be agreeable to you. It is a disappointment, and disappointments are unpleasant. I thought it over carefully and tried to arrange it better; but I only gave myself a headache and lost my sleep. Say what we will, you will think yourself ill-treated, and you will publish your wrongs among your friends. But we are not afraid of that. Besides, your friends are not our friends, and it will not matter. Think of us as you please. I only beg you not to be violent. I have never in my life been present at a violent scene of any kind, and at my age I can't be expected to begin.'' (she)

``Is _that_ all you have got to say?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman, slowly rising out of his (Newman) chair.
``That's a poor show for a clever lady like you, marquise. Come, try again.'' (unknown)

``My mother goes to the point, with her (mother) usual honesty and intrepidity,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis, toying with his (Newman) watch-guard.
``But it is perhaps well to say a little more. We of course quite repudiate the charge of having broken faith with you. We left you entirely at liberty to make yourself agreeable to my sister. We left her (sister) quite at liberty to entertain your proposal. When she (sister) accepted you we said nothing. We therefore quite observed our promise. It was only at a later stage of the affair, and on quite a different basis, as it were, that we determined to speak. It would have been better, perhaps, if we had spoken before. But really, you see, nothing has yet been done.'' (unknown)

``Nothing has yet been done?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman repeated the words, unconscious of their comical effect. He (Newman) had lost the sense of what the marquis was saying; M. de Bellegarde's superior style was a mere humming in his (Bellegarde) ears. All that he (Bellegarde) understood, in his (Bellegarde) deep and simple indignation, was that the matter was not a violent joke, and that the people before him (Bellegarde) were perfectly serious.
``Do you suppose I can take this?'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) asked.
``Do you suppose it can matter to me what you say? Do you suppose I can seriously listen to you? You are simply crazy!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Madame de Bellegarde gave a rap with her (mother) fan in the palm of her (mother) hand.

``If you don't take it you can leave it, sir. It matters very little what you do. My daughter has given you up.'' (unknown)

``She (daughter) doesn't mean it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman declared after a moment.

``I think I can assure you that she (daughter) does,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis.

``Poor woman, what damnable thing have you done to her (woman)?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.

``Gently, gently!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
murmured M. de Bellegarde.

``She (woman) told you,'' (the lady)
said the old lady.
``I commanded her (woman).'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman shook his (Newman) head, heavily.

``This sort of thing can't be, you know,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``A man can't be used in this fashion. You have got no right; you have got no power.'' (unknown)

``My power,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde,
``is in my children's obedience.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``In their fear, your daughter said. There is something very strange in it. Why should your daughter be afraid of you?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
added Newman, after looking a moment at the old lady.
``There is some foul play.'' (The marquise)

The marquise met his (marquise) gaze without flinching, and as if she (lady) did not hear or heed what he (marquise) said.

``I did my best,'' (she)
she (lady) said, quietly.
``I could endure it no longer.'' (unknown)

``It was a bold experiment!'' (the marquis)
said the marquis.

Newman felt disposed to walk to him (Newman), clutch his (Newman) neck with his (Newman) fingers and press his (Newman) windpipe with his (Newman) thumb.

``I needn't tell you how you strike me,'' (he)
he (Newman) said;
``of course you know that. But I should think you would be afraid of your friends--all those people you introduced me to the other night. There were some very nice people among them; you may depend upon it there were some honest men and women.'' (he)

``Our friends approve us,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde,
``there is not a family among them that would have acted otherwise. And however that may be, we take the cue from no one. The Bellegardes have been used to set the example, not to wait for it.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``You would have waited long before anyone would have set you such an example as this,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
exclaimed Newman.
``Have I done anything wrong?'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) demanded.
``Have I given you reason to change your opinion? Have you found out anything against me? I can't imagine.'' (unknown)

``Our opinion,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde,
``is quite the same as at first--exactly. We have no ill-will towards yourself; we are very far from accusing you of misconduct. Since your relations with us began you have been, I frankly confess, less--less peculiar than I expected. It is not your disposition that we object to, it is your antecedents. We really cannot reconcile ourselves to a commercial person. We fancied in an evil hour that we could; it was a great misfortune. We determined to persevere to the end, and to give you every advantage. I was resolved that you should have no reason to accuse me of want of loyalty. We let the thing certainly go very far; we introduced you to our friends. To tell the truth, it was that, I think, that broke me down. I succumbed to the scene that took place on Thursday night in these rooms. You must excuse me if what I say is disagreeable to you, but we cannot release ourselves without an explanation.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``There can be no better proof of our good faith,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis,
``than our committing ourselves to you in the eyes of the world the other evening. We endeavored to bind ourselves--to tie our hands, as it were.'' (the marquis)

``But it was that,'' (mother)
added his (Bellegarde) mother,
``that opened our eyes and broke our bonds. We should have been most uncomfortable! You know,'' (mother)
she (mother) added in a moment,
``that you were forewarned. I told you we were very proud.'' (she)

Newman took up his (Newman) hat and began mechanically to smooth it; the very fierceness of his (Newman) scorn kept him (Newman) from speaking.

``You are not proud enough,'' (he)
he (Newman) observed at last.

``In all this matter,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis, smiling,
``I really see nothing but our humility.'' (the marquis)

``Let us have no more discussion than is necessary,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
resumed Madame de Bellegarde.
``My daughter told you everything when she (daughter) said she (daughter) gave you up.'' (unknown)

``I am not satisfied about your daughter,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``I want to know what you did to her (daughter). It is all very easy talking about authority and saying you commanded her (daughter). She (daughter) didn't accept me blindly, and she (daughter) wouldn't have given me up blindly. Not that I believe yet she (daughter) has really given me up; she (daughter) will talk it over with me. But you have frightened her (daughter), you have bullied her (daughter), you have _hurt_ her (daughter). What was it you did to her (daughter)?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I did very little!'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde, in a tone which gave Newman a chill when he (Newman) afterwards remembered it.

``Let me remind you that we offered you these explanations,'' (the marquis)
the marquis observed,
``with the express understanding that you should abstain from violence of language.'' (the marquis)

``I am not violent,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered,
``it is you who are violent! But I don't know that I have much more to say to you. What you expect of me, apparently, is to go my way, thanking you for favors received, and promising never to trouble you again.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``We expect of you to act like a clever man,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``You have shown yourself that already, and what we have done is altogether based upon your being so. When one must submit, one must. Since my daughter absolutely withdraws, what will be the use of your making a noise?'' (unknown)

``It remains to be seen whether your daughter absolutely withdraws. Your daughter and I are still very good friends; nothing is changed in that. As I say, I will talk it over with her (daughter).'' (unknown)

``That will be of no use,'' (the lady)
said the old lady.
``I know my daughter well enough to know that words spoken as she (daughter) just now spoke to you are final. Besides, she (daughter) has promised me.'' (unknown)

``I have no doubt her (daughter) promise is worth a great deal more than your own,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``nevertheless I don't give her (daughter) up.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Just as you please! But if she (daughter) won't even see you,--and she (daughter) won't,--your constancy must remain purely Platonic.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Poor Newman was feigning a greater confidence than he (Newman) felt. Madame de Cintré's strange intensity had in fact struck a chill to his (Newman) heart; her (lady) face, still impressed upon his (Newman) vision, had been a terribly vivid image of renunciation. He (Newman) felt sick, and suddenly helpless. He (Newman) turned away and stood for a moment with his (Newman) hand on the door; then he (Newman) faced about and after the briefest hesitation broke out with a different accent.

``Come, think of what this must be to me, and let her (daughter) alone! Why should you object to me so--what's the matter with me? I can't hurt you. I wouldn't if I could. I'm the most unobjectionable fellow in the world. What if I am a commercial person? What under the sun do you mean? A commercial person? I will be any sort of a person you want. I never talked to you about business. Let her (daughter) go, and I will ask no questions. I will take her (daughter) away, and you shall never see me or hear of me again. I will stay in America if you like. I'll sign a paper promising never to come back to Europe! All I want is not to lose her (daughter)!'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

Madame de Bellegarde and her (lady) son exchanged a glance of lucid irony, and Urbain said,

``My dear sir, what you propose is hardly an improvement. We have not the slightest objection to seeing you, as an amiable foreigner, and we have every reason for not wishing to be eternally separated from my sister. We object to the marriage; and in that way,'' (Urbain/Urbain de Bellegarde)
and M. de Bellegarde gave a small, thin laugh,
``she (sister) would be more married than ever.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``Well, then,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``where is this place of yours--Fleurières? I know it is near some old city on a hill.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Precisely. Poitiers is on a hill,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``I don't know how old it is. We are not afraid to tell you.'' (unknown)

``It is Poitiers, is it? Very good,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I shall immediately follow Madame de Cintré.'' (unknown)

``The trains after this hour won't serve you,'' (Urbain/Urbain de Bellegarde)
said Urbain.

``I shall hire a special train!'' (unknown)

``That will be a very silly waste of money,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.

``It will be time enough to talk about waste three days hence,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered; and clapping his (Newman) hat on his (Newman) head, he (Newman) departed.

He (Newman) did not immediately start for Fleurières; he (Newman) was too stunned and wounded for consecutive action. He (Newman) simply walked; he (Newman) walked straight before him (Newman), following the river, till he (Newman) got out of the _enceinte_ of Paris. He (Newman) had a burning, tingling sense of personal outrage. He (Newman) had never in his (Newman) life received so absolute a check; he (Newman) had never been pulled up, or, as he (Newman) would have said,

``let down,'' (he)
so short; and he (Newman) found the sensation intolerable; he (Newman) strode along, tapping the trees and lamp-posts fiercely with his (Newman) stick and inwardly raging. To lose Madame de Cintré after he (Newman) had taken such jubilant and triumphant possession of her (Newman) was as great an affront to his (Newman) pride as it was an injury to his (Newman) happiness. And to lose her (Newman) by the interference and the dictation of others, by an impudent old woman and a pretentious fop stepping in with their
``authority'' (a fop)
! It was too preposterous, it was too pitiful. Upon what he (Newman) deemed the unblushing treachery of the Bellegardes Newman wasted little thought; he (Newman) consigned it, once for all, to eternal perdition. But the treachery of Madame de Cintré herself amazed and confounded him (Newman); there was a key to the mystery, of course, but he (Newman) groped for it in vain. Only three days had elapsed since she (Newman) stood beside him (Newman) in the starlight, beautiful and tranquil as the trust with which he (Newman) had inspired her (Newman), and told him (Newman) that she (Newman) was happy in the prospect of their marriage. What was the meaning of the change? of what infernal potion had she (Newman) tasted? Poor Newman had a terrible apprehension that she (Newman) had really changed. His (Newman) very admiration for her (Newman) attached the idea of force and weight to her (Newman) rupture. But he (Newman) did not rail at her (Newman) as false, for he (Newman) was sure she (Newman) was unhappy. In his (Newman) walk he (Newman) had crossed one of the bridges of the Seine, and he (Newman) still followed, unheedingly, the long, unbroken quay. He (Newman) had left Paris behind him (Newman), and he (Newman) was almost in the country; he (Newman) was in the pleasant suburb of Auteuil. He (Newman) stopped at last, looked around him (Newman) without seeing or caring for its pleasantness, and then slowly turned and at a slower pace retraced his (Newman) steps. When he (Newman) came abreast of the fantastic embankment known as the Trocadero, he (Newman) reflected, through his (Newman) throbbing pain, that he (Newman) was near Mrs. Tristram's dwelling, and that Mrs. Tristram, on particular occasions, had much of a woman's kindness in her (Tristram) utterance. He (Newman) felt that he (Newman) needed to pour out his (Newman) ire and he (Newman) took the road to her (Tristram) house. Mrs. Tristram was at home and alone, and as soon as she (Tristram) had looked at him (Newman), on his (Newman) entering the room, she (Tristram) told him (Newman) that she (Tristram) knew what he (Newman) had come for. Newman sat down heavily, in silence, looking at her (Tristram).

``They have backed out!'' (she)
she (Tristram) said.
``Well, you may think it strange, but I felt something the other night in the air.'' (he)
Presently he (Newman) told her (Tristram) his (Newman) story; she (Tristram) listened, with her (Tristram) eyes fixed on him (Newman). When he (Newman) had finished she (Tristram) said quietly,
``They want her (Madame) to marry Lord Deepmere.'' (she)
Newman stared. He (Newman) did not know that she (Tristram) knew anything about Lord Deepmere.
``But I don't think she (Madame) will,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Mrs. Tristram added.

``_She (Madame)_ marry that poor little cub!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``Oh, Lord! And yet, why did she (Madame) refuse me?'' (unknown)

``But that isn't the only thing,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram.
``They really couldn't endure you any longer. They had overrated their courage. I must say, to give the devil his (devil) due, that there is something rather fine in that. It was your commercial quality in the abstract they couldn't swallow. That is really aristocratic. They wanted your money, but they have given you up for an idea.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman frowned most ruefully, and took up his (Newman) hat again.

``I thought you would encourage me!'' (he)
he (Newman) said, with almost childlike sadness.

``Excuse me,'' (she)
she (Tristram) answered very gently.
``I feel none the less sorry for you, especially as I am at the bottom of your troubles. I have not forgotten that I suggested the marriage to you. I don't believe that Madame de Cintré has any intention of marrying Lord Deepmere. It is true he (Deepmere) is not younger than she (I), as he (Deepmere) looks. He (Deepmere) is thirty-three years old; I looked in the Peerage. But no--I can't believe her (I) so horribly, cruelly false.'' (unknown)

``Please say nothing against her (I),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Poor woman, she (woman) _is_ cruel. But of course you will go after her (woman) and you will plead powerfully. Do you know that as you are now,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Mrs. Tristram pursued, with characteristic audacity of comment,
``you are extremely eloquent, even without speaking? To resist you a woman must have a very fixed idea in her (woman) head. I wish I had done you a wrong, that you might come to me in that fine fashion! But go to Madame de Cintré at any rate, and tell her (woman) that she (woman) is a puzzle even to me. I am very curious to see how far family discipline will go.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Newman sat a while longer, leaning his (Newman) elbows on his (Newman) knees and his (Newman) head in his (Newman) hands, and Mrs. Tristram continued to temper charity with philosophy and compassion with criticism. At last she (Tristram) inquired,

``And what does the Count Valentin say to it?'' (she)
Newman started; he (Newman) had not thought of Valentin and his (Newman) errand on the Swiss frontier since the morning. The reflection made him (Newman) restless again, and he (Newman) took his (Newman) leave. He (Newman) went straight to his (Newman) apartment, where, upon the table of the vestibule, he (Newman) found a telegram. It ran -LRB-with the date and place-RRB- as follows:
``I am seriously ill; please to come to me as soon as possible. V. B.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman groaned at this miserable news, and at the necessity of deferring his (Newman) journey to the Château de Fleurières. But he (Newman) wrote to Madame de Cintré these few lines; they were all he (Newman) had time for:--

``I don't give you up, and I don't really believe you give me up. I don't understand it, but we shall clear it up together. I can't follow you to-day, as I am called to see a friend at a distance who is very ill, perhaps dying. But I shall come to you as soon as I can leave my friend. Why shouldn't I say that he (friend) is your brother? C. N.'' (he)

After this he (Newman) had only time to catch the night express to Geneva.

CHAPTER XIX

Newman possessed a remarkable talent for sitting still when it was necessary, and he (Newman) had an opportunity to use it on his (Newman) journey to Switzerland. The successive hours of the night brought him (Newman) no sleep, but he (Newman) sat motionless in his (Newman) corner of the railway-carriage, with his (Newman) eyes closed, and the most observant of his (Newman) fellow-travelers might have envied him (Newman) his (Newman) apparent slumber. Toward morning slumber really came, as an effect of mental rather than of physical fatigue. He (Newman) slept for a couple of hours, and at last, waking, found his (Newman) eyes resting upon one of the snow-powdered peaks of the Jura, behind which the sky was just reddening with the dawn. But he (Newman) saw neither the cold mountain nor the warm sky; his (Newman) consciousness began to throb again, on the very instant, with a sense of his (Newman) wrong. He (Newman) got out of the train half an hour before it reached Geneva, in the cold morning twilight, at the station indicated in Valentin's telegram. A drowsy station-master was on the platform with a lantern, and the hood of his (Valentin) overcoat over his (Valentin) head, and near him (Valentin) stood a gentleman who advanced to meet Newman. This personage was a man of forty, with a tall lean figure, a sallow face, a dark eye, a neat moustache, and a pair of fresh gloves. He (Newman) took off his (Newman) hat, looking very grave, and pronounced Newman's name. Our hero assented and said,

``You are M. de Bellegarde's friend?'' (hero)

``I unite with you in claiming that sad honor,'' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.
``I had placed myself at M. de Bellegarde's service in this melancholy affair, together with M. de Grosjoyaux, who is now at his (Grosjoyaux) bedside. M. de Grosjoyaux, I believe, has had the honor of meeting you in Paris, but as he (Grosjoyaux) is a better nurse than I he (Grosjoyaux) remained with our poor friend. Bellegarde has been eagerly expecting you.'' (unknown)

``And how is Bellegarde?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``He (Bellegarde) was badly hit?'' (unknown)

``The doctor has condemned him (Bellegarde); we brought a surgeon with us. But he (Bellegarde) will die in the best sentiments. I sent last evening for the curé of the nearest French village, who spent an hour with him (Bellegarde). The curé was quite satisfied.'' (unknown)

``Heaven forgive us!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
groaned Newman.
``I would rather the doctor were satisfied! And can he (doctor) see me--shall he (doctor) know me?'' (unknown)

``When I left him (doctor), half an hour ago, he (doctor) had fallen asleep after a feverish, wakeful night. But we shall see.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And Newman's companion proceeded to lead the way out of the station to the village, explaining as he (Newman) went that the little party was lodged in the humblest of Swiss inns, where, however, they had succeeded in making M. de Bellegarde much more comfortable than could at first have been expected.
``We are old companions in arms,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin's second;
``it is not the first time that one of us has helped the other to lie easily. It is a very nasty wound, and the nastiest thing about it is that Bellegarde's adversary was not shot. He (Bellegarde) put his (Bellegarde) bullet where he (Bellegarde) could. It took it into its head to walk straight into Bellegarde's left side, just below the heart.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

As they picked their way in the gray, deceptive dawn, between the manure-heaps of the village street, Newman's new acquaintance narrated the particulars of the duel. The conditions of the meeting had been that if the first exchange of shots should fail to satisfy one of the two gentlemen, a second should take place. Valentin's first bullet had done exactly what Newman's companion was convinced he (Newman) had intended it to do; it had grazed the arm of M. Stanislas Kapp, just scratching the flesh. M. Kapp's own projectile, meanwhile, had passed at ten good inches from the person of Valentin. The representatives of M. Stanislas had demanded another shot, which was granted. Valentin had then fired aside and the young Alsatian had done effective execution.

``I saw, when we met him (Bellegarde) on the ground,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman's informant,
``that he (Bellegarde) was not going to be _commode_. It is a kind of bovine temperament.'' (Newman informant)
Valentin had immediately been installed at the inn, and M. Stanislas and his (Stanislas) friends had withdrawn to regions unknown. The police authorities of the canton had waited upon the party at the inn, had been extremely majestic, and had drawn up a long _procès-verbal_; but it was probable that they would wink at so very gentlemanly a bit of bloodshed. Newman asked whether a message had not been sent to Valentin's family, and learned that up to a late hour on the preceding evening Valentin had opposed it. He (Valentin) had refused to believe his (Valentin) wound was dangerous. But after his (Valentin) interview with the curé he (Valentin) had consented, and a telegram had been dispatched to his (Valentin) mother.
``But the marquise had better hurry!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman's conductor.

``Well, it's an abominable affair!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``That's all I have to say!'' (unknown)
To say this, at least, in a tone of infinite disgust was an irresistible need.

``Ah, you don't approve?'' (conductor)
questioned his (Newman) conductor, with curious urbanity.

``Approve?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``I wish that when I had him (marquise) there, night before last, I had locked him (marquise) up in my _cabinet de toilette!_'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin's late second opened his (Valentin) eyes, and shook his (Valentin) head up and down two or three times, gravely, with a little flute-like whistle. But they had reached the inn, and a stout maid-servant in a night-cap was at the door with a lantern, to take Newman's traveling-bag from the porter who trudged behind him (Newman). Valentin was lodged on the ground-floor at the back of the house, and Newman's companion went along a stone-faced passage and softly opened a door. Then he (Newman) beckoned to Newman, who advanced and looked into the room, which was lighted by a single shaded candle. Beside the fire sat M. de Grosjoyaux asleep in his (Grosjoyaux) dressing-gown--a little plump, fair man whom Newman had seen several times in Valentin's company. On the bed lay Valentin, pale and still, with his (Valentin) eyes closed--a figure very shocking to Newman, who had seen it hitherto awake to its fingertips. M. de Grosjoyaux's colleague pointed to an open door beyond, and whispered that the doctor was within, keeping guard. So long as Valentin slept, or seemed to sleep, of course Newman could not approach him (Newman); so our hero withdrew for the present, committing himself to the care of the half-waked _bonne_. She (Valentin) took him (Newman) to a room above-stairs, and introduced him (Newman) to a bed on which a magnified bolster, in yellow calico, figured as a counterpane. Newman lay down, and, in spite of his (Newman) counterpane, slept for three or four hours. When he (Newman) awoke, the morning was advanced and the sun was filling his (Newman) window, and he (Newman) heard, outside of it, the clucking of hens. While he (Newman) was dressing there came to his (Newman) door a messenger from M. de Grosjoyaux and his (Grosjoyaux) companion proposing that he (Grosjoyaux) should breakfast with them. Presently he (Grosjoyaux) went downstairs to the little stone-paved dining-room, where the maid-servant, who had taken off her (Newman) night-cap, was serving the repast. M. de Grosjoyaux was there, surprisingly fresh for a gentleman who had been playing sick-nurse half the night, rubbing his (Grosjoyaux) hands and watching the breakfast table attentively. Newman renewed acquaintance with him (Newman), and learned that Valentin was still sleeping; the surgeon, who had had a fairly tranquil night, was at present sitting with him (Valentin). Before M. de Grosjoyaux's associate reappeared, Newman learned that his (Newman) name was M. Ledoux, and that Bellegarde's acquaintance with him (Newman) dated from the days when they served together in the Pontifical Zouaves. M. Ledoux was the nephew of a distinguished Ultramontane bishop. At last the bishop's nephew came in with a toilet in which an ingenious attempt at harmony with the peculiar situation was visible, and with a gravity tempered by a decent deference to the best breakfast that the Croix Helvétique had ever set forth. Valentin's servant, who was allowed only in scanty measure the honor of watching with his (Valentin) master, had been lending a light Parisian hand in the kitchen. The two Frenchmen did their best to prove that if circumstances might overshadow, they could not really obscure, the national talent for conversation, and M. Ledoux delivered a neat little eulogy on poor Bellegarde, whom he (Bellegarde) pronounced the most charming Englishman he (Bellegarde) had ever known.

``Do you call him (marquise) an Englishman?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

M. Ledoux smiled a moment and then made an epigram. _

``C’est plus qu’un Anglais--c’est un Anglomane!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
_ Newman said soberly that he (Newman) had never noticed it; and M. de Grosjoyaux remarked that it was really too soon to deliver a funeral oration upon poor Bellegarde.
``Evidently,'' (M. Ledoux/Ledoux)
said M. Ledoux.
``But I couldn't help observing this morning to Mr. Newman that when a man has taken such excellent measures for his (Newman) salvation as our dear friend did last evening, it seems almost a pity he (Newman) should put it in peril again by returning to the world.'' (M. Ledoux/Ledoux)
M. Ledoux was a great Catholic, and Newman thought him (Newman) a queer mixture. His (Newman) countenance, by daylight, had a sort of amiably saturnine cast; he (Newman) had a very large thin nose, and looked like a Spanish picture. He (Newman) appeared to think dueling a very perfect arrangement, provided, if one should get hit, one could promptly see the priest. He (priest) seemed to take a great satisfaction in Valentin's interview with the curé, and yet his (Valentin) conversation did not at all indicate a sanctimonious habit of mind. M. Ledoux had evidently a high sense of the becoming, and was prepared to be urbane and tasteful on all points. He (Ledoux) was always furnished with a smile -LRB-which pushed his (Ledoux) moustache up under his (Ledoux) nose-RRB- and an explanation. _Savoir-vivre_--knowing how to live--was his (Ledoux) specialty, in which he (Ledoux) included knowing how to die; but, as Newman reflected, with a good deal of dumb irritation, he (Newman) seemed disposed to delegate to others the application of his (Newman) learning on this latter point. M. de Grosjoyaux was of quite another complexion, and appeared to regard his (Grosjoyaux) friend's theological unction as the sign of an inaccessibly superior mind. He (Grosjoyaux) was evidently doing his (Grosjoyaux) utmost, with a kind of jovial tenderness, to make life agreeable to Valentin to the last, and help him (Valentin) as little as possible to miss the Boulevard des Italiens; but what chiefly occupied his (Valentin) mind was the mystery of a bungling brewer's son making so neat a shot. He (Valentin) himself could snuff a candle, etc., and yet he (Valentin) confessed that he (Valentin) could not have done better than this. He (Valentin) hastened to add that on the present occasion he (Valentin) would have made a point of not doing so well. It was not an occasion for that sort of murderous work, _que diable!_ He (Valentin) would have picked out some quiet fleshy spot and just tapped it with a harmless ball. M. Stanislas Kapp had been deplorably heavy-handed; but really, when the world had come to that pass that one granted a meeting to a brewer's son!... This was M. de Grosjoyaux's nearest approach to a generalization. He (Grosjoyaux) kept looking through the window, over the shoulder of M. Ledoux, at a slender tree which stood at the end of a lane, opposite to the inn, and seemed to be measuring its distance from his (Ledoux) extended arm and secretly wishing that, since the subject had been introduced, propriety did not forbid a little speculative pistol-practice.

Newman was in no humor to enjoy good company. He (Newman) could neither eat nor talk; his (Newman) soul was sore with grief and anger, and the weight of his (Newman) double sorrow was intolerable. He (Newman) sat with his (Newman) eyes fixed upon his (Newman) plate, counting the minutes, wishing at one moment that Valentin would see him (Valentin) and leave him (Valentin) free to go in quest of Madame de Cintré and his (Valentin) lost happiness, and mentally calling himself a vile brute the next, for the impatient egotism of the wish.
