He (Valentin) was very poor company, himself, and even his (Valentin) acute preoccupation and his (Valentin) general lack of the habit of pondering the impression he (Valentin) produced did not prevent him (Valentin) from reflecting that his (Valentin) companions must be puzzled to see how poor Bellegarde came to take such a fancy to this taciturn Yankee that he (Bellegarde) must needs have him (Bellegarde) at his (Bellegarde) death-bed. After breakfast he (Bellegarde) strolled forth alone into the village and looked at the fountain, the geese, the open barn doors, the brown, bent old women, showing their hugely darned stocking-heels at the ends of their slowly-clicking sabots, and the beautiful view of snowy Alps and purple Jura at either end of the little street. The day was brilliant; early spring was in the air and in the sunshine, and the winter's damp was trickling out of the cottage eaves. It was birth and brightness for all nature, even for chirping chickens and waddling goslings, and it was to be death and burial for poor, foolish, generous, delightful Bellegarde. Newman walked as far as the village church, and went into the small graveyard beside it, where he (Newman) sat down and looked at the awkward tablets which were planted around. They were all sordid and hideous, and Newman could feel nothing but the hardness and coldness of death. He (Newman) got up and came back to the inn, where he (Newman) found M. Ledoux having coffee and a cigarette at a little green table which he (Ledoux) had caused to be carried into the small garden. Newman, learning that the doctor was still sitting with Valentin, asked M. Ledoux if he (Ledoux) might not be allowed to relieve him (Ledoux); he (Ledoux) had a great desire to be useful to his (Ledoux) poor friend. This was easily arranged; the doctor was very glad to go to bed. He (doctor) was a youthful and rather jaunty practitioner, but he (doctor) had a clever face, and the ribbon of the Legion of Honor in his (doctor) buttonhole; Newman listened attentively to the instructions he (Newman) gave him (Newman) before retiring, and took mechanically from his (Newman) hand a small volume which the surgeon recommended as a help to wakefulness, and which turned out to be an old copy of

``Les Liaisons Dangereuses.'' (the surgeon)

Valentin was still lying with his (Valentin) eyes closed, and there was no visible change in his (Valentin) condition. Newman sat down near him (Newman), and for a long time narrowly watched him (Newman). Then his (Newman) eyes wandered away with his (Newman) thoughts upon his (Newman) own situation, and rested upon the chain of the Alps, disclosed by the drawing of the scant white cotton curtain of the window, through which the sunshine passed and lay in squares upon the red-tiled floor. He (Newman) tried to interweave his (Newman) reflections with hope, but he (Newman) only half succeeded. What had happened to him (Newman) seemed to have, in its violence and audacity, the force of a real calamity--the strength and insolence of Destiny herself. It was unnatural and monstrous, and he (Newman) had no arms against it. At last a sound struck upon the stillness, and he (Newman) heard Valentin's voice.

``It can't be about _me_ you are pulling that long face!'' (He)
He (Newman) found, when he (Newman) turned, that Valentin was lying in the same position; but his (Valentin) eyes were open, and he (Valentin) was even trying to smile. It was with a very slender strength that he (Valentin) returned the pressure of Newman's hand.
``I have been watching you for a quarter of an hour,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin went on;
``you have been looking as black as thunder. You are greatly disgusted with me, I see. Well, of course! So am I!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

``Oh, I shall not scold you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I feel too badly. And how are you getting on?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I'm getting off! They have quite settled that; haven't they?'' (unknown)

``That's for you to settle; you can get well if you try,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with resolute cheerfulness.

``My dear fellow, how can I try? Trying is violent exercise, and that sort of thing isn't in order for a man with a hole in his (man) side as big as your hat, that begins to bleed if he (man) moves a hair's-breadth. I knew you would come,'' (he)
he (Newman) continued;
``I knew I should wake up and find you here; so I'm not surprised. But last night I was very impatient. I didn't see how I could keep still until you came. It was a matter of keeping still, just like this; as still as a mummy in his (man) case. You talk about trying; I tried that! Well, here I am yet--these twenty hours. It seems like twenty days.'' (he)
Bellegarde talked slowly and feebly, but distinctly enough. It was visible, however, that he (Bellegarde) was in extreme pain, and at last he (Bellegarde) closed his (Bellegarde) eyes. Newman begged him (Newman) to remain silent and spare himself; the doctor had left urgent orders.
``Oh,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin,
``let us eat and drink, for to-morrow--to-morrow'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
--and he (Valentin) paused again.
``No, not to-morrow, perhaps, but to-day. I can't eat and drink, but I can talk. What's to be gained, at this pass, by renun--renunciation? I mustn't use such big words. I was always a chatterer; Lord, how I have talked in my day!'' (unknown)

``That's a reason for keeping quiet now,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``We know how well you talk, you know.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

But Valentin, without heeding him (Valentin), went on in the same weak, dying drawl.

``I wanted to see you because you have seen my sister. Does she (sister) know--will she (sister) come?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman was embarrassed.

``Yes, by this time she (sister) must know.'' (unknown)

``Didn't you tell her (sister)?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin asked. And then, in a moment,
``Didn't you bring me any message from her (sister)?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
His (Newman) eyes rested upon Newman's with a certain soft keenness.

``I didn't see her (sister) after I got your telegram,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I wrote to her (sister).'' (unknown)

``And she (sister) sent you no answer?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman was obliged to reply that Madame de Cintré had left Paris.

``She (sister) went yesterday to Fleurières.'' (unknown)

``Yesterday--to Fleurières? Why did she (sister) go to Fleurières? What day is this? What day was yesterday? Ah, then I shan't see her (sister),'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin sadly.
``Fleurières is too far!'' (he)
And then he (Valentin) closed his (Valentin) eyes again. Newman sat silent, summoning pious invention to his (Newman) aid, but he (Newman) was relieved at finding that Valentin was apparently too weak to reason or to be curious. Bellegarde, however, presently went on.
``And my mother--and my brother--will they come? Are they at Fleurières?'' (unknown)

``They were in Paris, but I didn't see them, either,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered.
``If they received your telegram in time, they will have started this morning. Otherwise they will be obliged to wait for the night-express, and they will arrive at the same hour as I did.'' (unknown)

``They won't thank me--they won't thank me,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin murmured.
``They will pass an atrocious night, and Urbain doesn't like the early morning air. I don't remember ever in my life to have seen him (Urbain) before noon--before breakfast. No one ever saw him (Urbain). We don't know how he (Urbain) is then. Perhaps he (Urbain)'s different. Who knows? Posterity, perhaps, will know. That's the time he (Urbain) works, in his (Urbain) _cabinet_, at the history of the Princesses. But I had to send for them--hadn't I? And then I want to see my mother sit there where you sit, and say good-bye to her (mother). Perhaps, after all, I don't know her (mother), and she (mother) will have some surprise for me. Don't think you know her (mother) yet, yourself; perhaps she (mother) may surprise _you_. But if I can't see Claire, I don't care for anything. I have been thinking of it--and in my dreams, too. Why did she (Claire) go to Fleurières to-day? She (Claire) never told me. What has happened? Ah, she (Claire) ought to have guessed I was here--this way. It is the first time in her (Claire) life she (Claire) ever disappointed me. Poor Claire!'' (unknown)

``You know we are not man and wife quite yet,--your sister and I,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``She (sister) doesn't yet account to me for all her (sister) actions.'' (he)
And, after a fashion, he (Newman) smiled.

Valentin looked at him (Valentin) a moment.

``Have you quarreled?'' (unknown)

``Never, never, never!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman exclaimed.

``How happily you say that!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``You are going to be happy--_va!_'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
In answer to this stroke of irony, none the less powerful for being so unconscious, all poor Newman could do was to give a helpless and transparent stare. Valentin continued to fix him (Valentin) with his (Valentin) own rather over-bright gaze, and presently he (Valentin) said,
``But something _is_ the matter with you. I watched you just now; you haven't a bridegroom's face.'' (he)

``My dear fellow,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``how can I show _you_ a bridegroom's face? If you think I enjoy seeing you lie there and not being able to help you'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
--

``Why, you are just the man to be cheerful; don't forfeit your rights! I'm a proof of your wisdom. When was a man ever gloomy when he (man) could say, `I told you so?' You told me so, you know. You did what you could about it. You said some very good things; I have thought them over. But, my dear friend, I was right, all the same. This is the regular way.'' (unknown)

``I didn't do what I ought,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I ought to have done something else.'' (unknown)

``For instance?'' (unknown)

``Oh, something or other. I ought to have treated you as a small boy.'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm a very small boy, now,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin.
``I'm rather less than an infant. An infant is helpless, but it's generally voted promising. I'm not promising, eh? Society can't lose a less valuable member.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman was strongly moved. He (Newman) got up and turned his (Newman) back upon his (Newman) friend and walked away to the window, where he (Newman) stood looking out, but only vaguely seeing.

``No, I don't like the look of your back,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin continued.
``I have always been an observer of backs; yours is quite out of sorts.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman returned to his (Newman) bedside and begged him (Newman) to be quiet.

``Be quiet and get well,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``That's what you must do. Get well and help me.'' (unknown)

``I told you you were in trouble! How can I help you?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin asked.

``I'll let you know when you are better. You were always curious; there is something to get well for!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered, with resolute animation.

Valentin closed his (Valentin) eyes and lay a long time without speaking. He (Valentin) seemed even to have fallen asleep. But at the end of half an hour he (Valentin) began to talk again.

``I am rather sorry about that place in the bank. Who knows but that I might have become another Rothschild? But I wasn't meant for a banker; bankers are not so easy to kill. Don't you think I have been very easy to kill? It's not like a serious man. It's really very mortifying. It's like telling your hostess you must go, when you count upon her (hostess) begging you to stay, and then finding she (hostess) does no such thing. `Really--so soon? You've only just come!' Life doesn't make me any such polite little speech.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman for some time said nothing, but at last he (Newman) broke out.

``It's a bad case--it's a bad case--it's the worst case I ever met. I don't want to say anything unpleasant, but I can't help it. I've seen men dying before--and I've seen men shot. But it always seemed more natural; they were not so clever as you. Damnation--damnation! You might have done something better than this. It's about the meanest winding-up of a man's affairs that I can imagine!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin feebly waved his (Valentin) hand to and fro.

``Don't insist--don't insist! It is mean--decidedly mean. For you see at the bottom--down at the bottom, in a little place as small as the end of a wine funnel--I agree with you!'' (the doctor)

A few moments after this the doctor put his (doctor) head through the half-opened door and, perceiving that Valentin was awake, came in and felt his (Valentin) pulse. He (Valentin) shook his (Valentin) head and declared that he (Valentin) had talked too much--ten times too much.

``Nonsense!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin;
``a man sentenced to death can never talk too much. Have you never read an account of an execution in a newspaper? Don't they always set a lot of people at the prisoner--lawyers, reporters, priests--to make him (prisoner) talk? But it's not Mr. Newman's fault; he (Newman) sits there as mum as a death's-head.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

The doctor observed that it was time his (Valentin) patient's wound should be dressed again; MM. de Grosjoyaux and Ledoux, who had already witnessed this delicate operation, taking Newman's place as assistants. Newman withdrew and learned from his (Newman) fellow-watchers that they had received a telegram from Urbain de Bellegarde to the effect that their message had been delivered in the Rue de l’Université too late to allow him (Newman) to take the morning train, but that he (Newman) would start with his (Newman) mother in the evening. Newman wandered away into the village again, and walked about restlessly for two or three hours. The day seemed terribly long. At dusk he (Newman) came back and dined with the doctor and M. Ledoux. The dressing of Valentin's wound had been a very critical operation; the doctor didn't really see how he (doctor) was to endure a repetition of it. He (doctor) then declared that he (doctor) must beg of Mr. Newman to deny himself for the present the satisfaction of sitting with M. de Bellegarde; more than anyone else, apparently, he (Bellegarde) had the flattering but inconvenient privilege of exciting him (Bellegarde). M. Ledoux, at this, swallowed a glass of wine in silence; he (Ledoux) must have been wondering what the deuce Bellegarde found so exciting in the American.

Newman, after dinner, went up to his (Newman) room, where he (Newman) sat for a long time staring at his (Newman) lighted candle, and thinking that Valentin was dying downstairs. Late, when the candle had burnt low, there came a soft rap at his (Valentin) door. The doctor stood there with a candlestick and a shrug.

``He (Newman) must amuse himself still!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
said Valentin's medical adviser.
``He (Newman) insists upon seeing you, and I am afraid you must come. I think at this rate, that he (Newman) will hardly outlast the night.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman went back to Valentin's room, which he (Newman) found lighted by a taper on the hearth. Valentin begged him (Valentin) to light a candle.

``I want to see your face,'' (he)
he (Valentin) said.
``They say you excite me,'' (he)
he (Valentin) went on, as Newman complied with this request,
``and I confess I do feel excited. But it isn't you--it's my own thoughts. I have been thinking--thinking. Sit down there and let me look at you again.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman seated himself, folded his (Newman) arms, and bent a heavy gaze upon his (Newman) friend. He (Newman) seemed to be playing a part, mechanically, in a lugubrious comedy. Valentin looked at him (Valentin) for some time.
``Yes, this morning I was right; you have something on your mind heavier than Valentin de Bellegarde. Come, I'm a dying man and it's indecent to deceive me. Something happened after I left Paris. It was not for nothing that my sister started off at this season of the year for Fleurières. Why was it? It sticks in my crop. I have been thinking it over, and if you don't tell me I shall guess.'' (unknown)

``I had better not tell you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``It won't do you any good.'' (unknown)

``If you think it will do me any good not to tell me, you are very much mistaken. There is trouble about your marriage.'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``There is trouble about my marriage.'' (unknown)

``Good!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
And Valentin was silent again.
``They have stopped it.'' (unknown)

``They have stopped it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman. Now that he (Newman) had spoken out, he (Newman) found a satisfaction in it which deepened as he (Newman) went on.
``Your mother and brother have broken faith. They have decided that it can't take place. They have decided that I am not good enough, after all. They have taken back their word. Since you insist, there it is!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin gave a sort of groan, lifted his (Valentin) hands a moment, and then let them drop.

``I am sorry not to have anything better to tell you about them,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman pursued.
``But it's not my fault. I was, indeed, very unhappy when your telegram reached me; I was quite upside down. You may imagine whether I feel any better now.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin moaned gaspingly, as if his (Valentin) wound were throbbing.

``Broken faith, broken faith!'' (he)
he (Valentin) murmured.
``And my sister--my sister?'' (unknown)

``Your sister is very unhappy; she (sister) has consented to give me up. I don't know why. I don't know what they have done to her (sister); it must be something pretty bad. In justice to her (sister) you ought to know it. They have made her (sister) suffer. I haven't seen her (sister) alone, but only before them! We had an interview yesterday morning. They came out flat, in so many words. They told me to go about my business. It seems to me a very bad case. I'm angry, I'm sore, I'm sick.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin lay there staring, with his (Valentin) eyes more brilliantly lighted, his (Valentin) lips soundlessly parted, and a flush of color in his (Valentin) pale face. Newman had never before uttered so many words in the plaintive key, but now, in speaking to Valentin in the poor fellow's extremity, he (Valentin) had a feeling that he (Valentin) was making his (Valentin) complaint somewhere within the presence of the power that men pray to in trouble; he (Valentin) felt his (Valentin) outgush of resentment as a sort of spiritual privilege.

``And Claire,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
--said Bellegarde,--
``Claire? She (Claire) has given you up?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``I don't really believe it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``No. Don't believe it, don't believe it. She (Claire) is gaining time; excuse her (Claire).'' (unknown)

``I pity her (Claire)!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Poor Claire!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
murmured Valentin.
``But they--but they'' (he)
--and he (Newman) paused again.
``You saw them; they dismissed you, face to face?'' (unknown)

``Face to face. They were very explicit.'' (unknown)

``What did they say?'' (unknown)

``They said they couldn't stand a commercial person.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin put out his (Valentin) hand and laid it upon Newman's arm.

``And about their promise--their engagement with you?'' (unknown)

``They made a distinction. They said it was to hold good only until Madame de Cintré accepted me.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

Valentin lay staring a while, and his (Valentin) flush died away.

``Don't tell me any more,'' (he)
he (Valentin) said at last.
``I'm ashamed.'' (unknown)

``You? You are the soul of honor,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman simply.

Valentin groaned and turned away his (Valentin) head. For some time nothing more was said. Then Valentin turned back again and found a certain force to press Newman's arm.

``It's very bad--very bad. When my people--when my race--come to that, it is time for me to withdraw. I believe in my sister; she (sister) will explain. Excuse her (sister). If she (sister) can't--if she (sister) can't, forgive her (sister). She (sister) has suffered. But for the others it is very bad--very bad. You take it very hard? No, it's a shame to make you say so.'' (He)
He (Newman) closed his (Newman) eyes and again there was a silence. Newman felt almost awed; he (Newman) had evoked a more solemn spirit than he (Newman) expected. Presently Valentin looked at him (Valentin) again, removing his (Valentin) hand from his (Valentin) arm.
``I apologize,'' (he)
he (Valentin) said.
``Do you understand? Here on my death-bed. I apologize for my family. For my mother. For my brother. For the ancient house of Bellegarde. _Voilà!_'' (he)
he (Valentin) added softly.

Newman for an answer took his (Newman) hand and pressed it with a world of kindness. Valentin remained quiet, and at the end of half an hour the doctor softly came in. Behind him (Valentin), through the half-open door, Newman saw the two questioning faces of MM. de Grosjoyaux and Ledoux. The doctor laid his (Newman) hand on Valentin's wrist and sat looking at him (Valentin). He (Valentin) gave no sign and the two gentlemen came in, M. Ledoux having first beckoned to someone outside. This was M. le Curé, who carried in his (Curé) hand an object unknown to Newman, and covered with a white napkin. M. le Curé was short, round, and red: he (Curé) advanced, pulling off his (Curé) little black cap to Newman, and deposited his (Newman) burden on the table; and then he (Newman) sat down in the best armchair, with his (Newman) hands folded across his (Newman) person. The other gentlemen had exchanged glances which expressed unanimity as to the timeliness of their presence. But for a long time Valentin neither spoke nor moved. It was Newman's belief, afterwards, that M. le Curé went to sleep. At last abruptly, Valentin pronounced Newman's name. His (Valentin) friend went to him (Valentin), and he (Valentin) said in French,

``You are not alone. I want to speak to you alone.'' (French)
Newman looked at the doctor, and the doctor looked at the curé, who looked back at him (Newman); and then the doctor and the curé, together, gave a shrug.
``Alone--for five minutes,'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
Valentin repeated.
``Please leave us.'' (The curé)

The curé took up his (Valentin) burden again and led the way out, followed by his (Valentin) companions. Newman closed the door behind them and came back to Valentin's bedside. Bellegarde had watched all this intently.

``It's very bad, it's very bad,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said, after Newman had seated himself close to him (Newman).
``The more I think of it the worse it is.'' (unknown)

``Oh, don't think of it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

But Valentin went on, without heeding him (Newman).

``Even if they should come round again, the shame--the baseness--is there.'' (unknown)

``Oh, they won't come round!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Well, you can make them.'' (unknown)

``Make them?'' (unknown)

``I can tell you something--a great secret--an immense secret. You can use it against them--frighten them, force them.'' (unknown)

``A secret!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman repeated. The idea of letting Valentin, on his (Valentin) death-bed, confide him (Valentin) an
``immense secret'' (him)
shocked him (Valentin), for the moment, and made him (Valentin) draw back. It seemed an illicit way of arriving at information, and even had a vague analogy with listening at a keyhole. Then, suddenly, the thought of
``forcing'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
Madame de Bellegarde and her (Valentin) son became attractive, and Newman bent his (Newman) head closer to Valentin's lips. For some time, however, the dying man said nothing more. He (Newman) only lay and looked at his (Newman) friend with his (Newman) kindled, expanded, troubled eye, and Newman began to believe that he (Newman) had spoken in delirium. But at last he (Newman) said,--

``There was something done--something done at Fleurières. It was foul play. My father--something happened to him (father). I don't know; I have been ashamed--afraid to know. But I know there is something. My mother knows--Urbain knows.'' (he)

``Something happened to your father?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, urgently.

Valentin looked at him (Valentin), still more wide-eyed.

``He (Urbain) didn't get well.'' (unknown)

``Get well of what?'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

But the immense effort which Valentin had made, first to decide to utter these words and then to bring them out, appeared to have taken his (Valentin) last strength. He (Valentin) lapsed again into silence, and Newman sat watching him (Newman).

``Do you understand?'' (he)
he (Newman) began again, presently.
``At Fleurières. You can find out. Mrs. Bread knows. Tell her (mother) I begged you to ask her (mother). Then tell them that, and see. It may help you. If not, tell everyone. It will--it will'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
--here Valentin's voice sank to the feeblest murmur--
``it will avenge you!'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)

The words died away in a long, soft groan. Newman stood up, deeply impressed, not knowing what to say; his (Newman) heart was beating violently.

``Thank you,'' (he)
he (Newman) said at last.
``I am much obliged.'' (Valentin/Mr. Valentin)
But Valentin seemed not to hear him (Valentin), he (Valentin) remained silent, and his (Valentin) silence continued. At last Newman went and opened the door. M. le Curé re-entered, bearing his (Newman) sacred vessel and followed by the three gentlemen and by Valentin's servant. It was almost processional.

CHAPTER XX

Valentin de Bellegarde died tranquilly, just as the cold faint March dawn began to illumine the faces of the little knot of friends gathered about his (Bellegarde) bedside. An hour afterwards Newman left the inn and drove to Geneva; he (Newman) was naturally unwilling to be present at the arrival of Madame de Bellegarde and her (servant) first-born. At Geneva, for the moment, he (Bellegarde) remained. He (Bellegarde) was like a man who has had a fall and wants to sit still and count his (Bellegarde) bruises. He (Bellegarde) instantly wrote to Madame de Cintré, relating to her (servant) the circumstances of her (servant) brother's death--with certain exceptions--and asking her (servant) what was the earliest moment at which he (Bellegarde) might hope that she (servant) would consent to see him (Bellegarde). M. Ledoux had told him (Ledoux) that he (Ledoux) had reason to know that Valentin's will--Bellegarde had a great deal of elegant personal property to dispose of--contained a request that he (Bellegarde) should be buried near his (Bellegarde) father in the churchyard of Fleurières, and Newman intended that the state of his (Newman) own relations with the family should not deprive him (Newman) of the satisfaction of helping to pay the last earthly honors to the best fellow in the world. He (fellow) reflected that Valentin's friendship was older than Urbain's enmity, and that at a funeral it was easy to escape notice. Madame de Cintré's answer to his (Cintré) letter enabled him (Cintré) to time his (Cintré) arrival at Fleurières. This answer was very brief; it ran as follows:--

``I thank you for your letter, and for your being with Valentin. It is a most inexpressible sorrow to me that I was not. To see you will be nothing but a distress to me; there is no need, therefore, to wait for what you call brighter days. It is all one now, and I shall have no brighter days. Come when you please; only notify me first. My brother is to be buried here on Friday, and my family is to remain here. C. de C.'' (he)

As soon as he (Cintré) received this letter Newman went straight to Paris and to Poitiers. The journey took him (Newman) far southward, through green Touraine and across the far-shining Loire, into a country where the early spring deepened about him (Newman) as he (Newman) went. But he (Newman) had never made a journey during which he (Newman) heeded less what he (Newman) would have called the lay of the land. He (Newman) obtained lodging at the inn at Poitiers, and the next morning drove in a couple of hours to the village of Fleurières. But here, preoccupied though he (Newman) was, he (Newman) could not fail to notice the picturesqueness of the place. It was what the French call a _petit bourg_; it lay at the base of a sort of huge mound on the summit of which stood the crumbling ruins of a feudal castle, much of whose sturdy material, as well as that of the wall which dropped along the hill to enclose the clustered houses defensively, had been absorbed into the very substance of the village. The church was simply the former chapel of the castle, fronting upon its grass-grown court, which, however, was of generous enough width to have given up its quaintest corner to a little graveyard. Here the very headstones themselves seemed to sleep, as they slanted into the grass; the patient elbow of the rampart held them together on one side, and in front, far beneath their mossy lids, the green plains and blue distances stretched away. The way to church, up the hill, was impracticable to vehicles. It was lined with peasants, two or three rows deep, who stood watching old Madame de Bellegarde slowly ascend it, on the arm of her (patient) elder son, behind the pall-bearers of the other. Newman chose to lurk among the common mourners who murmured

``Madame la Comtesse'' (the mourners)
as a tall figure veiled in black passed before them. He (Newman) stood in the dusky little church while the service was going forward, but at the dismal tomb-side he (Newman) turned away and walked down the hill. He (Newman) went back to Poitiers, and spent two days in which patience and impatience were singularly commingled. On the third day he (Newman) sent Madame de Cintré a note, saying that he (Newman) would call upon her (patient) in the afternoon, and in accordance with this he (Newman) again took his (Newman) way to Fleurières. He (Newman) left his (Newman) vehicle at the tavern in the village street, and obeyed the simple instructions which were given him (Newman) for finding the château.

``It is just beyond there,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said the landlord, and pointed to the tree-tops of the park, above the opposite houses. Newman followed the first cross-road to the right--it was bordered with mouldy cottages--and in a few moments saw before him (Newman) the peaked roofs of the towers. Advancing farther, he (Newman) found himself before a vast iron gate, rusty and closed; here he (Newman) paused a moment, looking through the bars. The château was near the road; this was at once its merit and its defect; but its aspect was extremely impressive. Newman learned afterwards, from a guide-book of the province, that it dated from the time of Henry IV. It presented to the wide, paved area which preceded it and which was edged with shabby farm-buildings an immense façade of dark time-stained brick, flanked by two low wings, each of which terminated in a little Dutch-looking pavilion capped with a fantastic roof. Two towers rose behind, and behind the towers was a mass of elms and beeches, now just faintly green.

But the great feature was a wide, green river which washed the foundations of the château. The building rose from an island in the circling stream, so that this formed a perfect moat spanned by a two-arched bridge without a parapet. The dull brick walls, which here and there made a grand, straight sweep; the ugly little cupolas of the wings, the deep-set windows, the long, steep pinnacles of mossy slate, all mirrored themselves in the tranquil river. Newman rang at the gate, and was almost frightened at the tone with which a big rusty bell above his (Newman) head replied to him (Newman). An old woman came out from the gate-house and opened the creaking portal just wide enough for him (Newman) to pass, and he (Newman) went in, across the dry, bare court and the little cracked white slabs of the causeway on the moat. At the door of the château he (Newman) waited for some moments, and this gave him (Newman) a chance to observe that Fleurières was not

``kept up,'' (Fleurières)
and to reflect that it was a melancholy place of residence.
``It looks,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman to himself--and I give the comparison for what it is worth--
``like a Chinese penitentiary.'' (I)
At last the door was opened by a servant whom he (servant) remembered to have seen in the Rue de l’Université. The man's dull face brightened as he (servant) perceived our hero, for Newman, for indefinable reasons, enjoyed the confidence of the liveried gentry. The footman led the way across a great central vestibule, with a pyramid of plants in tubs in the middle of glass doors all around, to what appeared to be the principal drawing-room of the château. Newman crossed the threshold of a room of superb proportions, which made him (Newman) feel at first like a tourist with a guide-book and a cicerone awaiting a fee. But when his (Newman) guide had left him (Newman) alone, with the observation that he (Newman) would call Madame la Comtesse, Newman perceived that the salon contained little that was remarkable save a dark ceiling with curiously carved rafters, some curtains of elaborate, antiquated tapestry, and a dark oaken floor, polished like a mirror. He (Newman) waited some minutes, walking up and down; but at length, as he (Newman) turned at the end of the room, he (Newman) saw that Madame de Cintré had come in by a distant door. She (Comtesse) wore a black dress, and she (Comtesse) stood looking at him (Newman). As the length of the immense room lay between them he (Newman) had time to look at her (Comtesse) before they met in the middle of it.

He (Newman) was dismayed at the change in her (Comtesse) appearance. Pale, heavy-browed, almost haggard with a sort of monastic rigidity in her (Comtesse) dress, she (Comtesse) had little but her (Comtesse) pure features in common with the woman whose radiant good grace he (Newman) had hitherto admired. She (Comtesse) let her (Comtesse) eyes rest on his (Newman) own, and she (Comtesse) let him (Newman) take her (Comtesse) hand; but her (Comtesse) eyes looked like two rainy autumn moons, and her (Comtesse) touch was portentously lifeless.

``I was at your brother's funeral,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said.
``Then I waited three days. But I could wait no longer.'' (unknown)

``Nothing can be lost or gained by waiting,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.
``But it was very considerate of you to wait, wronged as you have been.'' (unknown)

``I'm glad you think I have been wronged,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with that oddly humorous accent with which he (Newman) often uttered words of the gravest meaning.

``Do I need to say so?'' (she)
she (Comtesse) asked.
``I don't think I have wronged, seriously, many persons; certainly not consciously. To you, to whom I have done this hard and cruel thing, the only reparation I can make is to say, `I know it, I feel it!' The reparation is pitifully small!'' (unknown)

``Oh, it's a great step forward!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with a gracious smile of encouragement. He (Newman) pushed a chair towards her (Comtesse) and held it, looking at her (Comtesse) urgently. She (Comtesse) sat down, mechanically, and he (Newman) seated himself near her (Comtesse); but in a moment he (Newman) got up, restlessly, and stood before her (Comtesse). She (Comtesse) remained seated, like a troubled creature who had passed through the stage of restlessness.

``I say nothing is to be gained by my seeing you,'' (she)
she (Comtesse) went on,
``and yet I am very glad you came. Now I can tell you what I feel. It is a selfish pleasure, but it is one of the last I shall have.'' (she)
And she (Comtesse) paused, with her (Comtesse) great misty eyes fixed upon him (Newman).
``I know how I have deceived and injured you; I know how cruel and cowardly I have been. I see it as vividly as you do--I feel it to the ends of my fingers.'' (she)
And she (Comtesse) unclasped her (Comtesse) hands, which were locked together in her (Comtesse) lap, lifted them, and dropped them at her (Comtesse) side.
``Anything that you may have said of me in your angriest passion is nothing to what I have said to myself.'' (unknown)

``In my angriest passion,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I have said nothing hard of you. The very worst thing I have said of you yet is that you are the loveliest of women.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) seated himself before her (Comtesse) again abruptly.

She (Comtesse) flushed a little, but even her (Comtesse) flush was pale.

``That is because you think I will come back. But I will not come back. It is in that hope you have come here, I know; I am very sorry for you. I would do almost anything for you. To say that, after what I have done, seems simply impudent; but what can I say that will not seem impudent? To wrong you and apologize--that is easy enough. I should not have wronged you.'' (She)
She (Comtesse) stopped a moment, looking at him (Newman), and motioned him (Newman) to let her (Comtesse) go on.
``I ought never to have listened to you at first; that was the wrong. No good could come of it. I felt it, and yet I listened; that was your fault. I liked you too much; I believed in you.'' (unknown)

``And don't you believe in me now?'' (unknown)

``More than ever. But now it doesn't matter. I have given you up.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman gave a powerful thump with his (Newman) clenched fist upon his (Newman) knee.

``Why, why, why?'' (he)
he (Newman) cried.
``Give me a reason--a decent reason. You are not a child--you are not a minor, nor an idiot. You are not obliged to drop me because your mother told you to. Such a reason isn't worthy of you.'' (unknown)

``I know that; it's not worthy of me. But it's the only one I have to give. After all,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré, throwing out her (Comtesse) hands,
``think me an idiot and forget me! That will be the simplest way.'' (Madame de Cintré)

Newman got up and walked away with a crushing sense that his (Newman) cause was lost, and yet with an equal inability to give up fighting. He (Newman) went to one of the great windows, and looked out at the stiffly embanked river and the formal gardens which lay beyond it. When he (Newman) turned round, Madame de Cintré had risen; she (Comtesse) stood there silent and passive.

``You are not frank,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``you are not honest. Instead of saying that you are imbecile, you should say that other people are wicked. Your mother and your brother have been false and cruel; they have been so to me, and I am sure they have been so to you. Why do you try to shield them? Why do you sacrifice me to them? I'm not false; I'm not cruel. You don't know what you give up; I can tell you that--you don't. They bully you and plot about you; and I--I'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
--And he (Newman) paused, holding out his (Newman) hands. She (Comtesse) turned away and began to leave him (Newman).
``You told me the other day that you were afraid of your mother,'' (he)
he (Newman) said, following her (Comtesse).
``What did you mean?'' (unknown)

Madame de Cintré shook her (Comtesse) head.

``I remember; I was sorry afterwards.'' (unknown)

``You were sorry when she (mother) came down and put on the thumbscrews. In God's name what _is_ it she (mother) does to you?'' (unknown)

``Nothing. Nothing that you can understand. And now that I have given you up, I must not complain of her (mother) to you.'' (unknown)

``That's no reasoning!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``Complain of her (mother), on the contrary. Tell me all about it, frankly and trustfully, as you ought, and we will talk it over so satisfactorily that you won't give me up.'' (unknown)

Madame de Cintré looked down some moments, fixedly; and then, raising her (Comtesse) eyes, she (Comtesse) said,

``One good at least has come of this: I have made you judge me more fairly. You thought of me in a way that did me great honor; I don't know why you had taken it into your head. But it left me no loophole for escape--no chance to be the common, weak creature I am. It was not my fault; I warned you from the first. But I ought to have warned you more. I ought to have convinced you that I was doomed to disappoint you. But I _was_, in a way, too proud. You see what my superiority amounts to, I hope!'' (she)
she (Comtesse) went on, raising her (Comtesse) voice with a tremor which even then and there Newman thought beautiful.
``I am too proud to be honest, I am not too proud to be faithless. I am timid and cold and selfish. I am afraid of being uncomfortable.'' (unknown)

``And you call marrying me uncomfortable!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman staring.

Madame de Cintré blushed a little and seemed to say that if begging his (Newman) pardon in words was impudent, she (Comtesse) might at least thus mutely express her (Comtesse) perfect comprehension of his (Newman) finding her (Comtesse) conduct odious.

``It is not marrying you; it is doing all that would go with it. It's the rupture, the defiance, the insisting upon being happy in my own way. What right have I to be happy when--when'' (she)
--And she (Comtesse) paused.

``When what?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``When others have been most unhappy!'' (unknown)

``What others?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.
``What have you to do with any others but me? Besides you said just now that you wanted happiness, and that you should find it by obeying your mother. You contradict yourself.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I contradict myself; that shows you that I am not even intelligent.'' (unknown)

``You are laughing at me!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``You are mocking me!'' (She)

She (Comtesse) looked at him (Newman) intently, and an observer might have said that she (Comtesse) was asking herself whether she (Comtesse) might not most quickly end their common pain by confessing that she (Comtesse) was mocking him (Newman).

``No; I am not,'' (she)
she (Comtesse) presently said.

``Granting that you are not intelligent,'' (he)
he (Newman) went on,
``that you are weak, that you are common, that you are nothing that I have believed you were--what I ask of you is not heroic effort, it is a very common effort. There is a great deal on my side to make it easy. The simple truth is that you don't care enough about me to make it.'' (he)

``I am cold,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré,
``I am as cold as that flowing river.'' (Madame de Cintré)

Newman gave a great rap on the floor with his (Newman) stick, and a long, grim laugh.

``Good, good!'' (he)
he (Newman) cried.
``You go altogether too far--you overshoot the mark. There isn't a woman in the world as bad as you would make yourself out. I see your game; it's what I said. You are blackening yourself to whiten others. You don't want to give me up, at all; you like me--you like me. I know you do; you have shown it, and I have felt it. After that, you may be as cold as you please! They have bullied you, I say; they have tortured you. It's an outrage, and I insist upon saving you from the extravagance of your own generosity. Would you chop off your hand if your mother requested it?'' (unknown)

Madame de Cintré looked a little frightened.

``I spoke of my mother too blindly, the other day. I am my own mistress, by law and by her (mistress) approval. She (mistress) can do nothing to me; she (mistress) has done nothing. She (mistress) has never alluded to those hard words I used about her (mistress).'' (unknown)

``She (mistress) has made you feel them, I'll promise you!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``It's my conscience that makes me feel them.'' (unknown)

``Your conscience seems to me to be rather mixed!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
exclaimed Newman, passionately.

``It has been in great trouble, but now it is very clear,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.
``I don't give you up for any worldly advantage or for any worldly happiness.'' (unknown)

``Oh, you don't give me up for Lord Deepmere, I know,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I won't pretend, even to provoke you, that I think that. But that's what your mother and your brother wanted, and your mother, at that villainous ball of hers--I liked it at the time, but the very thought of it now makes me rabid--tried to push him (brother) on to make up to you.'' (unknown)

``Who told you this?'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré softly.

``Not Valentin. I observed it. I guessed it. I didn't know at the time that I was observing it, but it stuck in my memory. And afterwards, you recollect, I saw Lord Deepmere with you in the conservatory. You said then that you would tell me at another time what he (Deepmere) had said to you.'' (unknown)

``That was before--before _this_,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré.

``It doesn't matter,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``and, besides, I think I know. He (Deepmere)'s an honest little Englishman. He (Deepmere) came and told you what your mother was up to--that she (mother) wanted him (Deepmere) to supplant me; not being a commercial person. If he (Deepmere) would make you an offer she (mother) would undertake to bring you over and give me the slip. Lord Deepmere isn't very intellectual, so she (mother) had to spell it out to him (Deepmere). He (Deepmere) said he (Deepmere) admired you `no end,' and that he (Deepmere) wanted you to know it; but he (Deepmere) didn't like being mixed up with that sort of underhand work, and he (Deepmere) came to you and told tales. That was about the amount of it, wasn't it? And then you said you were perfectly happy.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I don't see why we should talk of Lord Deepmere,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.
``It was not for that you came here. And about my mother, it doesn't matter what you suspect and what you know. When once my mind has been made up, as it is now, I should not discuss these things. Discussing anything, now, is very idle. We must try and live each as we can. I believe you will be happy again; even, sometimes, when you think of me. When you do so, think this--that it was not easy, and that I did the best I could. I have things to reckon with that you don't know. I mean I have feelings. I must do as they force me--I must, I must. They would haunt me otherwise,'' (she)
she (Comtesse) cried, with vehemence;
``they would kill me!'' (she)

``I know what your feelings are: they are superstitions! They are the feeling that, after all, though I _am_ a good fellow, I have been in business; the feeling that your mother's looks are law and your brother's words are gospel; that you all hang together, and that it's a part of the everlasting proprieties that they should have a hand in everything you do. It makes my blood boil. That _is_ cold; you are right. And what I feel here,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
and Newman struck his (Newman) heart and became more poetical than he (Newman) knew,
``is a glowing fire!'' (he)

A spectator less preoccupied than Madame de Cintré's distracted wooer would have felt sure from the first that her (Comtesse) appealing calm of manner was the result of violent effort, in spite of which the tide of agitation was rapidly rising. On these last words of Newman's it overflowed, though at first she (Comtesse) spoke low, for fear of her (Comtesse) voice betraying her (Comtesse).

``No. I was not right--I am not cold! I believe that if I am doing what seems so bad, it is not mere weakness and falseness. Mr. Newman, it's like a religion. I can't tell you--I can't! It's cruel of you to insist. I don't see why I shouldn't ask you to believe me--and pity me. It's like a religion. There's a curse upon the house; I don't know what--I don't know why--don't ask me. We must all bear it. I have been too selfish; I wanted to escape from it. You offered me a great chance--besides my liking you. It seemed good to change completely, to break, to go away. And then I admired you. But I can't--it has overtaken and come back to me.'' (her)
Her (Comtesse) self-control had now completely abandoned her (Comtesse), and her (Comtesse) words were broken with long sobs.
``Why do such dreadful things happen to us--why is my brother Valentin killed, like a beast in the midst of his (Valentin) youth and his (Valentin) gaiety and his (Valentin) brightness and all that we loved him (Valentin) for? Why are there things I can't ask about--that I am afraid to know? Why are there places I can't look at, sounds I can't hear? Why is it given to me to choose, to decide, in a case so hard and so terrible as this? I am not meant for that--I am not made for boldness and defiance. I was made to be happy in a quiet, natural way.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
At this Newman gave a most expressive groan, but Madame de Cintré went on.
``I was made to do gladly and gratefully what is expected of me. My mother has always been very good to me; that's all I can say. I must not judge her (mother); I must not criticize her (mother). If I did, it would come back to me. I can't change!'' (unknown)

``No,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, bitterly;
``_I_ must change--if I break in two in the effort!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``You are different. You are a man; you will get over it. You have all kinds of consolation. You were born--you were trained, to changes. Besides--besides, I shall always think of you.'' (unknown)

``I don't care for that!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``You are cruel--you are terribly cruel. God forgive you! You may have the best reasons and the finest feelings in the world; that makes no difference. You are a mystery to me; I don't see how such hardness can go with such loveliness.'' (him)

Madame de Cintré fixed him (Newman) a moment with her (Comtesse) swimming eyes.

``You believe I am hard, then?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman answered her (Comtesse) look, and then broke out,

``You are a perfect, faultless creature! Stay by me!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Of course I am hard,'' (she)
she (Comtesse) went on.
``Whenever we give pain we are hard. And we _must_ give pain; that's the world,--the hateful, miserable world! Ah!'' (she)
and she (Comtesse) gave a long, deep sigh,
``I can't even say I am glad to have known you--though I am. That too is to wrong you. I can say nothing that is not cruel. Therefore let us part, without more of this. Good-bye!'' (she)
And she (Comtesse) put out her (Comtesse) hand.

Newman stood and looked at it without taking it, and raised his (Newman) eyes to her (Comtesse) face. He (Newman) felt, himself, like shedding tears of rage.

``What are you going to do?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.
``Where are you going?'' (unknown)

``Where I shall give no more pain and suspect no more evil. I am going out of the world.'' (unknown)

``Out of the world?'' (unknown)

``I am going into a convent.'' (unknown)

``Into a convent!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman repeated the words with the deepest dismay; it was as if she (Comtesse) had said she (Comtesse) was going into an hospital.
``Into a convent--_you!_'' (unknown)

``I told you that it was not for my worldly advantage or pleasure I was leaving you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

But still Newman hardly understood.

``You are going to be a nun,'' (he)
he (Newman) went on,
``in a cell--for life--with a gown and white veil?'' (he)

``A nun--a Carmelite nun,'' (Madame)
said Madame de Cintré.
``For life, with God's leave.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

The idea struck Newman as too dark and horrible for belief, and made him (Newman) feel as he (Newman) would have done if she (Comtesse) had told him (Newman) that she (Comtesse) was going to mutilate her (Comtesse) beautiful face, or drink some potion that would make her (Comtesse) mad. He (Newman) clasped his (Newman) hands and began to tremble, visibly.

``Madame de Cintré, don't, don't!'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``I beseech you! On my knees, if you like, I'll beseech you.'' (She)

She (Comtesse) laid her (Comtesse) hand upon his (Newman) arm, with a tender, pitying, almost reassuring gesture.

``You don't understand,'' (she)
she (Comtesse) said.
``You have wrong ideas. It's nothing horrible. It is only peace and safety. It is to be out of the world, where such troubles as this come to the innocent, to the best. And for life--that's the blessing of it! They can't begin again.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman dropped into a chair and sat looking at her (Comtesse) with a long, inarticulate murmur. That this superb woman, in whom he (Newman) had seen all human grace and household force, should turn from him (Newman) and all the brightness that he (Newman) offered her (Comtesse)--him (Newman) and his (Newman) future and his (Newman) fortune and his (Newman) fidelity--to muffle herself in ascetic rags and entomb herself in a cell was a confounding combination of the inexorable and the grotesque. As the image deepened before him (Newman) the grotesque seemed to expand and overspread it; it was a reduction to the absurd of the trial to which he (Newman) was subjected.

``You--you a nun!'' (he)
he (Newman) exclaimed;
``you with your beauty defaced--you behind locks and bars! Never, never, if I can prevent it!'' (he)
And he (Newman) sprang to his (Newman) feet with a violent laugh.

``You can't prevent it,'' (Madame de Cintré)
said Madame de Cintré,
``and it ought--a little--to satisfy you. Do you suppose I will go on living in the world, still beside you, and yet not with you? It is all arranged. Good-bye, good-bye.'' (Madame de Cintré)

This time he (Cintré) took her (Comtesse) hand, took it in both his (Cintré) own.

``Forever?'' (he)
he (Cintré) said. Her (Comtesse) lips made an inaudible movement and his (Cintré) own uttered a deep imprecation. She (Comtesse) closed her (Comtesse) eyes, as if with the pain of hearing it; then he (Cintré) drew her (Comtesse) towards him (Cintré) and clasped her (Comtesse) to his (Cintré) breast. He (Cintré) kissed her (Comtesse) white face; for an instant she (Comtesse) resisted and for a moment she (Comtesse) submitted; then, with force, she (Comtesse) disengaged herself and hurried away over the long shining floor. The next moment the door closed behind her (Comtesse).

Newman made his (Newman) way out as he (Newman) could.

CHAPTER XXI

There is a pretty public walk at Poitiers, laid out upon the crest of the high hill around which the little city clusters, planted with thick trees and looking down upon the fertile fields in which the old English princes fought for their right and held it. Newman paced up and down this quiet promenade for the greater part of the next day and let his (Newman) eyes wander over the historic prospect; but he (Newman) would have been sadly at a loss to tell you afterwards whether the latter was made up of coal-fields or of vineyards. He (Newman) was wholly given up to his (Newman) grievance, of which reflection by no means diminished the weight. He (Newman) feared that Madame de Cintré was irretrievably lost; and yet, as he (Cintré) would have said himself, he (Cintré) didn't see his (Cintré) way clear to giving her (Newman) up. He (Cintré) found it impossible to turn his (Cintré) back upon Fleurières and its inhabitants; it seemed to him (Cintré) that some germ of hope or reparation must lurk there somewhere, if he (Cintré) could only stretch his (Cintré) arm out far enough to pluck it. It was as if he (Cintré) had his (Cintré) hand on a door-knob and were closing his (Cintré) clenched fist upon it: he (Cintré) had thumped, he (Cintré) had called, he (Cintré) had pressed the door with his (Cintré) powerful knee and shaken it with all his (Cintré) strength, and dead, damning silence had answered him (Cintré). And yet something held him (Cintré) there--something hardened the grasp of his (Cintré) fingers. Newman's satisfaction had been too intense, his (Cintré) whole plan too deliberate and mature, his (Cintré) prospect of happiness too rich and comprehensive for this fine moral fabric to crumble at a stroke. The very foundation seemed fatally injured, and yet he (Cintré) felt a stubborn desire still to try to save the edifice. He (Cintré) was filled with a sorer sense of wrong than he (Cintré) had ever known, or than he (Cintré) had supposed it possible he (Cintré) should know. To accept his (Cintré) injury and walk away without looking behind him (Cintré) was a stretch of good-nature of which he (Cintré) found himself incapable. He (Cintré) looked behind him (Cintré) intently and continually, and what he (Cintré) saw there did not assuage his (Cintré) resentment. He (Cintré) saw himself trustful, generous, liberal, patient, easy, pocketing frequent irritation and furnishing unlimited modesty. To have eaten humble pie, to have been snubbed and patronized and satirized and have consented to take it as one of the conditions of the bargain--to have done this, and done it all for nothing, surely gave one a right to protest. And to be turned off because one was a commercial person! As if he (Cintré) had ever talked or dreamt of the commercial since his (Cintré) connection with the Bellegardes began--as if he (Cintré) had made the least circumstance of the commercial--as if he (Cintré) would not have consented to confound the commercial fifty times a day, if it might have increased by a hair's breadth the chance of the Bellegardes' not playing him (Cintré) a trick! Granted that being commercial was fair ground for having a trick played upon one, how little they knew about the class so designed and its enterprising way of not standing upon trifles! It was in the light of his (Cintré) injury that the weight of Newman's past endurance seemed so heavy; his (Cintré) actual irritation had not been so great, merged as it was in his (Cintré) vision of the cloudless blue that overarched his (Cintré) immediate wooing. But now his (Cintré) sense of outrage was deep, rancorous, and ever present; he (Cintré) felt that he (Cintré) was a good fellow wronged. As for Madame de Cintré's conduct, it struck him (Cintré) with a kind of awe, and the fact that he (Cintré) was powerless to understand it or feel the reality of its motives only deepened the force with which he (Cintré) had attached himself to her (Cintré). He (Cintré) had never let the fact of her (Cintré) Catholicism trouble him (Cintré); Catholicism to him (Cintré) was nothing but a name, and to express a mistrust of the form in which her (Cintré) religious feelings had moulded themselves would have seemed to him (Cintré) on his (Cintré) own part a rather pretentious affectation of Protestant zeal. If such superb white flowers as that could bloom in Catholic soil, the soil was not insalubrious. But it was one thing to be a Catholic, and another to turn nun--on your hand! There was something lugubriously comical in the way Newman's thoroughly contemporaneous optimism was confronted with this dusky old-world expedient. To see a woman made for him (Newman) and for motherhood to his (Newman) children juggled away in this tragic travesty--it was a thing to rub one's eyes over, a nightmare, an illusion, a hoax. But the hours passed away without disproving the thing, and leaving him (Newman) only the after-sense of the vehemence with which he (Newman) had embraced Madame de Cintré. He (Newman) remembered her (woman) words and her (woman) looks; he (Newman) turned them over and tried to shake the mystery out of them and to infuse them with an endurable meaning. What had she (woman) meant by her (woman) feeling being a kind of religion? It was the religion simply of the family laws, the religion of which her (woman) implacable little mother was the high priestess. Twist the thing about as her (woman) generosity would, the one certain fact was that they had used force against her (woman). Her (woman) generosity had tried to screen them, but Newman's heart rose into his (Newman) throat at the thought that they should go scot-free.

The twenty-four hours wore themselves away, and the next morning Newman sprang to his (Newman) feet with the resolution to return to Fleurières and demand another interview with Madame de Bellegarde and her (woman) son. He (Bellegarde) lost no time in putting it into practice. As he (Bellegarde) rolled swiftly over the excellent road in the little calèche furnished him (Bellegarde) at the inn at Poitiers, he (Bellegarde) drew forth, as it were, from the very safe place in his (Bellegarde) mind to which he (Bellegarde) had consigned it, the last information given him (Bellegarde) by poor Valentin. Valentin had told him (Valentin) he (Valentin) could do something with it, and Newman thought it would be well to have it at hand. This was of course not the first time, lately, that Newman had given it his (Newman) attention. It was information in the rough,--it was dark and puzzling; but Newman was neither helpless nor afraid. Valentin had evidently meant to put him (Valentin) in possession of a powerful instrument, though he (Valentin) could not be said to have placed the handle very securely within his (Valentin) grasp. But if he (Valentin) had not really told him (Valentin) the secret, he (Valentin) had at least given him (Valentin) the clew to it--a clew of which that queer old Mrs. Bread held the other end. Mrs. Bread had always looked to Newman as if she (Newman) knew secrets; and as he (Newman) apparently enjoyed her (Newman) esteem, he (Newman) suspected she (Newman) might be induced to share her (Newman) knowledge with him (Newman). So long as there was only Mrs. Bread to deal with, he (Newman) felt easy. As to what there was to find out, he (Newman) had only one fear--that it might not be bad enough. Then, when the image of the marquise and her (Newman) son rose before him (son) again, standing side by side, the old woman's hand in Urbain's arm, and the same cold, unsociable fixedness in the eyes of each, he (Urbain) cried out to himself that the fear was groundless. There was blood in the secret at the very least! He (Urbain) arrived at Fleurières almost in a state of elation; he (Urbain) had satisfied himself, logically, that in the presence of his (Urbain) threat of exposure they would, as he (Urbain) mentally phrased it, rattle down like unwound buckets. He (Urbain) remembered indeed that he (Urbain) must first catch his (Urbain) hare--first ascertain what there was to expose; but after that, why shouldn't his (Urbain) happiness be as good as new again? Mother and son would drop their lovely victim in terror and take to hiding, and Madame de Cintré, left to herself, would surely come back to him (Cintré). Give her (Mother) a chance and she (Mother) would rise to the surface, return to the light. How could she (Mother) fail to perceive that his (Cintré) house would be much the most comfortable sort of convent?

Newman, as he (Newman) had done before, left his (Newman) conveyance at the inn and walked the short remaining distance to the château. When he (Newman) reached the gate, however, a singular feeling took possession of him (Newman)--a feeling which, strange as it may seem, had its source in its unfathomable good nature. He (Newman) stood there a while, looking through the bars at the large, time-stained face of the edifice, and wondering to what crime it was that the dark old house, with its flowery name, had given convenient occasion. It had given occasion, first and last, to tyrannies and sufferings enough, Newman said to himself; it was an evil-looking place to live in. Then, suddenly, came the reflection--What a horrible rubbish-heap of iniquity to fumble in! The attitude of inquisitor turned its ignobler face, and with the same movement Newman declared that the Bellegardes should have another chance. He (Newman) would appeal once more directly to their sense of fairness, and not to their fear, and if they should be accessible to reason, he (Newman) need know nothing worse about them than what he (Newman) already knew. That was bad enough.

The gate-keeper let him (Newman) in through the same stiff crevice as before, and he (Newman) passed through the court and over the little rustic bridge on the moat. The door was opened before he (Newman) had reached it, and, as if to put his (Newman) clemency to rout with the suggestion of a richer opportunity, Mrs. Bread stood there awaiting him (Newman). Her (Newman) face, as usual, looked as hopelessly blank as the tide-smoothed sea-sand, and her (Newman) black garments seemed of an intenser sable. Newman had already learned that her (Newman) strange inexpressiveness could be a vehicle for emotion, and he (Newman) was not surprised at the muffled vivacity with which she (Newman) whispered,

``I thought you would try again, sir. I was looking out for you.'' (she)

``I am glad to see you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``I think you are my friend.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Mrs. Bread looked at him (Newman) opaquely.

``I wish you well sir; but it's vain wishing now.'' (unknown)

``You know, then, how they have treated me?'' (unknown)

``Oh, sir,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Mrs. Bread, dryly,
``I know everything.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman hesitated a moment.

``Everything?'' (Mrs. Bread)

Mrs. Bread gave him (Newman) a glance somewhat more lucent.

``I know at least too much, sir.'' (unknown)

``One can never know too much. I congratulate you. I have come to see Madame de Bellegarde and her (I) son,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman added.
``Are they at home? If they are not, I will wait.'' (unknown)

``My lady is always at home,'' (unknown)
Mrs. Bread replied,
``and the marquis is mostly with her (lady).'' (unknown)

``Please then tell them--one or the other, or both--that I am here and that I desire to see them.'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread hesitated.

``May I take a great liberty, sir?'' (unknown)

``You have never taken a liberty but you have justified it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with diplomatic urbanity.

Mrs. Bread dropped her (Bread) wrinkled eyelids as if she (Bread) were curtseying; but the curtsey stopped there; the occasion was too grave.

``You have come to plead with them again, sir? Perhaps you don't know this--that Madame de Cintré returned this morning to Paris.'' (unknown)

``Ah, she (lady)'s gone!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And Newman, groaning, smote the pavement with his (Newman) stick.

``She (lady) has gone straight to the convent--the Carmelites they call it. I see you know, sir. My lady and the marquis take it very ill. It was only last night she (lady) told them.'' (unknown)

``Ah, she (lady) had kept it back, then?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``Good, good! And they are very fierce?'' (unknown)

``They are not pleased,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.
``But they may well dislike it. They tell me it's most dreadful, sir; of all the nuns in Christendom the Carmelites are the worst. You may say they are really not human, sir; they make you give up everything--forever. And to think of _her (lady)_ there! If I was one that cried, sir, I could cry.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman looked at her (Bread) an instant.

``We mustn't cry, Mrs. Bread; we must act. Go and call them!'' (he)
And he (Newman) made a movement to enter farther.

But Mrs. Bread gently checked him (Newman).

``May I take another liberty? I am told you were with my dearest Mr. Valentin, in his (Valentin) last hours. If you would tell me a word about him (Valentin)! The poor count was my own boy, sir; for the first year of his (boy) life he (boy) was hardly out of my arms; I taught him (boy) to speak. And the count spoke so well, sir! He (boy) always spoke well to his (boy) poor old Bread. When he (boy) grew up and took his (boy) pleasure he (boy) always had a kind word for me. And to die in that wild way! They have a story that he (boy) fought with a wine-merchant. I can't believe that, sir! And was he (boy) in great pain?'' (unknown)

``You are a wise, kind old woman, Mrs. Bread,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I hoped I might see you with my own children in your arms. Perhaps I shall, yet.'' (he)
And he (Newman) put out his (Newman) hand. Mrs. Bread looked for a moment at his (Newman) open palm, and then, as if fascinated by the novelty of the gesture, extended her (Bread) own ladylike fingers. Newman held her (Bread) hand firmly and deliberately, fixing his (Newman) eyes upon her (Bread).
``You want to know all about Mr. Valentin?'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

``It would be a sad pleasure, sir.'' (unknown)

``I can tell you everything. Can you sometimes leave this place?'' (unknown)

``The château, sir? I really don't know. I never tried.'' (unknown)

``Try, then; try hard. Try this evening, at dusk. Come to me in the old ruin there on the hill, in the court before the church. I will wait for you there; I have something very important to tell you. An old woman like you can do as she (woman) pleases.'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread stared, wondering, with parted lips.

``Is it from the count, sir?'' (she)
she (Bread) asked.

``From the count--from his (I) death-bed,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I will come, then. I will be bold, for once, for _him (I)_.'' (She)

She (Bread) led Newman into the great drawing-room with which he (Newman) had already made acquaintance, and retired to execute his (Newman) commands. Newman waited a long time; at last he (Newman) was on the point of ringing and repeating his (Newman) request. He (Newman) was looking round him (Newman) for a bell when the marquis came in with his (marquis) mother on his (marquis) arm. It will be seen that Newman had a logical mind when I say that he (Newman) declared to himself, in perfect good faith, as a result of Valentin's dark hints, that his (Valentin) adversaries looked grossly wicked.

``There is no mistake about it now,'' (he)
he (Valentin) said to himself as they advanced.
``They're a bad lot; they have pulled off the mask.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
Madame de Bellegarde and her (mother) son certainly bore in their faces the signs of extreme perturbation; they looked like people who had passed a sleepless night. Confronted, moreover, with an annoyance which they hoped they had disposed of, it was not natural that they should have any very tender glances to bestow upon Newman. He (Newman) stood before them, and such eye-beams as they found available they leveled at him (Newman); Newman feeling as if the door of a sepulchre had suddenly been opened, and the damp darkness were being exhaled.

``You see I have come back,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``I have come to try again.'' (unknown)

``It would be ridiculous,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde,
``to pretend that we are glad to see you or that we don't question the taste of your visit.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

``Oh, don't talk about taste,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with a laugh,
``or that will bring us round to yours! If I consulted my taste I certainly shouldn't come to see you. Besides, I will make as short work as you please. Promise me to raise the blockade--to set Madame de Cintré at liberty--and I will retire instantly.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``We hesitated as to whether we would see you,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde;
``and we were on the point of declining the honor. But it seemed to me that we should act with civility, as we have always done, and I wished to have the satisfaction of informing you that there are certain weaknesses that people of our way of feeling can be guilty of but once.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``You may be weak but once, but you will be audacious many times, madam,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered.
``I didn't come however, for conversational purposes. I came to say this, simply: that if you will write immediately to your daughter that you withdraw your opposition to her (daughter) marriage, I will take care of the rest. You don't want her (daughter) to turn nun--you know more about the horrors of it than I do. Marrying a commercial person is better than that. Give me a letter to her (daughter), signed and sealed, saying you retract and that she (daughter) may marry me with your blessing, and I will take it to her (daughter) at the convent and bring her (daughter) out. There's your chance--I call those easy terms.'' (unknown)

``We look at the matter otherwise, you know. We call them very hard terms,'' (Urbain/Urbain de Bellegarde)
said Urbain de Bellegarde. They had all remained standing rigidly in the middle of the room.
``I think my mother will tell you that she (mother) would rather her (mother) daughter should become Sœur Catherine than Mrs. Newman.'' (the lady)

But the old lady, with the serenity of supreme power, let her (lady) son make her (lady) epigrams for her (lady). She (lady) only smiled, almost sweetly, shaking her (lady) head and repeating,

``But once, Mr. Newman; but once!'' (She)

Nothing that Newman had ever seen or heard gave him (Newman) such a sense of marble hardness as this movement and the tone that accompanied it.

``Could anything compel you?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.
``Do you know of anything that would force you?'' (unknown)

``This language, sir,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis,
``addressed to people in bereavement and grief is beyond all qualification.'' (the marquis)

``In most cases,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered,
``your objection would have some weight, even admitting that Madame de Cintré's present intentions make time precious. But I have thought of what you speak of, and I have come here to-day without scruple simply because I consider your brother and you two very different parties. I see no connection between you. Your brother was ashamed of you. Lying there wounded and dying, the poor fellow apologized to me for your conduct. He (fellow) apologized to me for that of his (fellow) mother.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

For a moment the effect of these words was as if Newman had struck a physical blow. A quick flush leaped into the faces of Madame de Bellegarde and her (lady) son, and they exchanged a glance like a twinkle of steel. Urbain uttered two words which Newman but half heard, but of which the sense came to him (Newman) as it were in the reverberation of the sound,

``_Le misérable!_'' (him)

``You show little respect for the living,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde,
``but at least respect the dead. Don't profane--don't insult--the memory of my innocent son.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

``I speak the simple truth,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman declared,
``and I speak it for a purpose. I repeat it--distinctly. Your son was utterly disgusted--your son apologized.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Urbain de Bellegarde was frowning portentously, and Newman supposed he (Newman) was frowning at poor Valentin's invidious image. Taken by surprise, his (Newman) scant affection for his (Newman) brother had made a momentary concession to dishonor. But not for an appreciable instant did his (Newman) mother lower her (mother) flag.

``You are immensely mistaken, sir,'' (she)
she (mother) said.
``My son was sometimes light, but he (son) was never indecent. He (son) died faithful to his (son) name.'' (unknown)

``You simply misunderstood him (son),'' (the marquis)
said the marquis, beginning to rally.
``You affirm the impossible!'' (unknown)

``Oh, I don't care for poor Valentin's apology,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``It was far more painful than pleasant to me. This atrocious thing was not his (Valentin) fault; he (Valentin) never hurt me, or anyone else; he (Valentin) was the soul of honor. But it shows how he (Valentin) took it.'' (unknown)

``If you wish to prove that my poor brother, in his (brother) last moments, was out of his (brother) head, we can only say that under the melancholy circumstances nothing was more possible. But confine yourself to that.'' (unknown)

``He (brother) was quite in his (brother) right mind,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with gentle but dangerous doggedness;
``I have never seen him (brother) so bright and clever. It was terrible to see that witty, capable fellow dying such a death. You know I was very fond of your brother. And I have further proof of his (brother) sanity,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman concluded.

The marquise gathered herself together majestically.

``This is too gross!'' (she)
she (mother) cried.
``We decline to accept your story, sir--we repudiate it. Urbain, open the door.'' (She)
She (mother) turned away, with an imperious motion to her (mother) son, and passed rapidly down the length of the room. The marquis went with her (mother) and held the door open. Newman was left standing.

He (Newman) lifted his (Newman) finger, as a sign to M. de Bellegarde, who closed the door behind his (Bellegarde) mother and stood waiting. Newman slowly advanced, more silent, for the moment, than life. The two men stood face to face. Then Newman had a singular sensation; he (Newman) felt his (Newman) sense of injury almost brimming over into jocularity.

``Come,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``you don't treat me well; at least admit that.'' (he)

M. de Bellegarde looked at him (Bellegarde) from head to foot, and then, in the most delicate, best-bred voice,

``I detest you personally,'' (him)
he (Bellegarde) said.

``That's the way I feel to you, but for politeness sake I don't say it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``It's singular I should want so much to be your brother-in-law, but I can't give it up. Let me try once more.'' (he)
And he (Newman) paused a moment.
``You have a secret--you have a skeleton in the closet.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
