M. de Bellegarde continued to look at him (Bellegarde) hard, but Newman could not see whether his (Newman) eyes betrayed anything; the look of his (Newman) eyes was always so strange. Newman paused again, and then went on.
``You and your mother have committed a crime.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
At this M. de Bellegarde's eyes certainly did change; they seemed to flicker, like blown candles. Newman could see that he (Newman) was profoundly startled; but there was something admirable in his (Newman) self-control.

``Continue,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
said M. de Bellegarde.

Newman lifted a finger and made it waver a little in the air.

``Need I continue? You are trembling.'' (unknown)

``Pray where did you obtain this interesting information?'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
M. de Bellegarde asked, very softly.

``I shall be strictly accurate,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I won't pretend to know more than I do. At present that is all I know. You have done something that you must hide, something that would damn you if it were known, something that would disgrace the name you are so proud of. I don't know what it is, but I can find out. Persist in your present course and I _will_ find out. Change it, let your sister go in peace, and I will leave you alone. It's a bargain?'' (The marquis)

The marquis almost succeeded in looking untroubled; the breaking up of the ice in his (Newman) handsome countenance was an operation that was necessarily gradual. But Newman's mildly-syllabled argumentation seemed to press, and press, and presently he (Newman) averted his (Newman) eyes. He (Newman) stood some moments, reflecting.

``My brother told you this,'' (he)
he (Newman) said, looking up.

Newman hesitated a moment.

``Yes, your brother told me.'' (The marquis)

The marquis smiled, handsomely.

``Didn't I say that he (brother) was out of his (brother) mind?'' (unknown)

``He (brother) was out of his (brother) mind if I don't find out. He (brother) was very much in it if I do.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

M. de Bellegarde gave a shrug.

``Eh, sir, find out or not, as you please.'' (unknown)

``I don't frighten you?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
demanded Newman.

``That's for you to judge.'' (unknown)

``No, it's for you to judge, at your leisure. Think it over, feel yourself all round. I will give you an hour or two. I can't give you more, for how do we know how fast they may be making Madame de Cintré a nun? Talk it over with your mother; let her (mother) judge whether she (mother) is frightened. I don't believe she (mother) is as easily frightened, in general, as you; but you will see. I will go and wait in the village, at the inn, and I beg you to let me know as soon as possible. Say by three o’clock. A simple _yes_ or _no_ on paper will do. Only, you know, in case of a _yes_ I shall expect you, this time, to stick to your bargain.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And with this Newman opened the door and let himself out. The marquis did not move, and Newman, retiring, gave him (Newman) another look.
``At the inn, in the village,'' (he)
he (Newman) repeated. Then he (Newman) turned away altogether and passed out of the house.

He (Newman) was extremely excited by what he (Newman) had been doing, for it was inevitable that there should be a certain emotion in calling up the spectre of dishonor before a family a thousand years old. But he (Newman) went back to the inn and contrived to wait there, deliberately, for the next two hours. He (Newman) thought it more than probable that Urbain de Bellegarde would give no sign; for an answer to his (Bellegarde) challenge, in either sense, would be a confession of guilt. What he (Bellegarde) most expected was silence--in other words defiance. But he (Bellegarde) prayed that, as he (Bellegarde) imagined it, his (Bellegarde) shot might bring them down. It did bring, by three o’clock, a note, delivered by a footman; a note addressed in Urbain de Bellegarde's handsome English hand. It ran as follows:--

``I cannot deny myself the satisfaction of letting you know that I return to Paris, to-morrow, with my mother, in order that we may see my sister and confirm her (sister) in the resolution which is the most effectual reply to your audacious pertinacity.

``HENRI-URBAIN DE BELLEGARDE.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman put the letter into his (Newman) pocket, and continued his (Newman) walk up and down the inn-parlor. He (Newman) had spent most of his (Newman) time, for the past week, in walking up and down. He (Newman) continued to measure the length of the little _salle_ of the Armes de France until the day began to wane, when he (Newman) went out to keep his (Newman) rendezvous with Mrs. Bread. The path which led up the hill to the ruin was easy to find, and Newman in a short time had followed it to the top. He (Newman) passed beneath the rugged arch of the castle wall, and looked about him (Newman) in the early dusk for an old woman in black. The castle yard was empty, but the door of the church was open. Newman went into the little nave and of course found a deeper dusk than without. A couple of tapers, however, twinkled on the altar and just enabled him (Newman) to perceive a figure seated by one of the pillars. Closer inspection helped him (Newman) to recognize Mrs. Bread, in spite of the fact that she (woman) was dressed with unwonted splendor. She (woman) wore a large black silk bonnet, with imposing bows of crape, and an old black satin dress disposed itself in vaguely lustrous folds about her (woman) person. She (woman) had judged it proper to the occasion to appear in her (woman) stateliest apparel. She (woman) had been sitting with her (woman) eyes fixed upon the ground, but when Newman passed before her (woman) she (woman) looked up at him (Newman), and then she (woman) rose.

``Are you a Catholic, Mrs. Bread?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.

``No, sir; I'm a good Church-of-England woman, very Low,'' (she)
she (woman) answered.
``But I thought I should be safer in here than outside. I was never out in the evening before, sir.'' (unknown)

``We shall be safer,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``where no one can hear us.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) led the way back into the castle court and then followed a path beside the church, which he (Newman) was sure must lead into another part of the ruin. He (Newman) was not deceived. It wandered along the crest of the hill and terminated before a fragment of wall pierced by a rough aperture which had once been a door. Through this aperture Newman passed and found himself in a nook peculiarly favorable to quiet conversation, as probably many an earnest couple, otherwise assorted than our friends, had assured themselves. The hill sloped abruptly away, and on the remnant of its crest were scattered two or three fragments of stone. Beneath, over the plain, lay the gathered twilight, through which, in the near distance, gleamed two or three lights from the château. Mrs. Bread rustled slowly after her (himself) guide, and Newman, satisfying himself that one of the fallen stones was steady, proposed to her (himself) to sit upon it. She (himself) cautiously complied, and he (Newman) placed himself upon another, near her (himself).

CHAPTER XXII

``I am very much obliged to you for coming,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said.
``I hope it won't get you into trouble.'' (unknown)

``I don't think I shall be missed. My lady, in these days, is not fond of having me about her (lady).'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
This was said with a certain fluttered eagerness which increased Newman's sense of having inspired the old woman with confidence.

``From the first, you know,'' (he)
he (Newman) answered,
``you took an interest in my prospects. You were on my side. That gratified me, I assure you. And now that you know what they have done to me, I am sure you are with me all the more.'' (he)

``They have not done well--I must say it,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.
``But you mustn't blame the poor countess; they pressed her (countess) hard.'' (unknown)

``I would give a million of dollars to know what they did to her (countess)!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.

Mrs. Bread sat with a dull, oblique gaze fixed upon the lights of the château.

``They worked on her (countess) feelings; they knew that was the way. She (countess) is a delicate creature. They made her (countess) feel wicked. She (countess) is only too good.'' (unknown)

``Ah, they made her (countess) feel wicked,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, slowly; and then he (Newman) repeated it.
``They made her (countess) feel wicked,--they made her (countess) feel wicked.'' (him)
The words seemed to him (Newman) for the moment a vivid description of infernal ingenuity.

``It was because she (countess) was so good that she (countess) gave up--poor sweet lady!'' (unknown)
added Mrs. Bread.

``But she (countess) was better to them than to me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``She (countess) was afraid,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread, very confidently;
``she (countess) has always been afraid, or at least for a long time. That was the real trouble, sir. She (countess) was like a fair peach, I may say, with just one little speck. She (countess) had one little sad spot. You pushed her (countess) into the sunshine, sir, and it almost disappeared. Then they pulled her (countess) back into the shade and in a moment it began to spread. Before we knew it she (countess) was gone. She (countess) was a delicate creature.'' (Madame de Cintré)

This singular attestation of Madame de Cintré's delicacy, for all its singularity, set Newman's wound aching afresh.

``I see,'' (he)
he (Newman) presently said;
``she (countess) knew something bad about her (countess) mother.'' (he)

``No, sir, she (countess) knew nothing,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread, holding her (woman) head very stiff and keeping her (woman) eyes fixed upon the glimmering windows of the château.

``She (countess) guessed something, then, or suspected it.'' (unknown)

``She (countess) was afraid to know,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.

``But _you_ know, at any rate,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

She (woman) slowly turned her (woman) vague eyes upon Newman, squeezing her (woman) hands together in her (woman) lap.

``You are not quite faithful, sir. I thought it was to tell me about Mr. Valentin you asked me to come here.'' (unknown)

``Oh, the more we talk of Mr. Valentin the better,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``That's exactly what I want. I was with him (Valentin), as I told you, in his (Valentin) last hour. He (Valentin) was in a great deal of pain, but he (Valentin) was quite himself. You know what that means; he (Valentin) was bright and lively and clever.'' (unknown)

``Oh, he (Valentin) would always be clever, sir,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.
``And did he (Valentin) know of your trouble?'' (unknown)

``Yes, he (Valentin) guessed it of himself.'' (unknown)

``And what did he (Valentin) say to it?'' (unknown)

``He (Valentin) said it was a disgrace to his (Valentin) name--but it was not the first.'' (unknown)

``Lord, Lord!'' (unknown)
murmured Mrs. Bread.

``He (Lord) said that his (Lord) mother and his (Lord) brother had once put their heads together and invented something even worse.'' (unknown)

``You shouldn't have listened to that, sir.'' (unknown)

``Perhaps not. But I _did_ listen, and I don't forget it. Now I want to know what it is they did.'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread gave a soft moan.

``And you have enticed me up into this strange place to tell you?'' (unknown)

``Don't be alarmed,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I won't say a word that shall be disagreeable to you. Tell me as it suits you, and when it suits you. Only remember that it was Mr. Valentin's last wish that you should.'' (unknown)

``Did he (Valentin) say that?'' (unknown)

``He (Valentin) said it with his (Valentin) last breath--`Tell Mrs. Bread I told you to ask her (Valentin).'''

``Why didn't he (Valentin) tell you himself?'' (unknown)

``It was too long a story for a dying man; he (man) had no breath left in his (man) body. He (man) could only say that he (man) wanted me to know--that, wronged as I was, it was my right to know.'' (unknown)

``But how will it help you, sir?'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.

``That's for me to decide. Mr. Valentin believed it would, and that's why he (Valentin) told me. Your name was almost the last word he (Valentin) spoke.'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread was evidently awe-struck by this statement; she (woman) shook her (woman) clasped hands slowly up and down.

``Excuse me, sir,'' (she)
she (woman) said,
``if I take a great liberty. Is it the solemn truth you are speaking? I _must_ ask you that; must I not, sir?'' (she)

``There's no offense. It _is_ the solemn truth; I solemnly swear it. Mr. Valentin himself would certainly have told me more if he (Valentin) had been able.'' (unknown)

``Oh, sir, if he (Valentin) knew more!'' (unknown)

``Don't you suppose he (Valentin) did?'' (unknown)

``There's no saying what he (Valentin) knew about anything,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread, with a mild head-shake.
``He (Valentin) was so mightily clever. He (Valentin) could make you believe he (Valentin) knew things that he (Valentin) didn't, and that he (Valentin) didn't know others that he (Valentin) had better not have known.'' (unknown)

``I suspect he (Valentin) knew something about his (Valentin) brother that kept the marquis civil to him (Valentin),'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman propounded;
``he (Valentin) made the marquis feel him (Valentin). What he (Valentin) wanted now was to put me in his (Valentin) place; he (Valentin) wanted to give me a chance to make the marquis feel _me_.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Mercy on us!'' (the waiting-woman)
cried the old waiting-woman,
``how wicked we all are!'' (the waiting-woman)

``I don't know,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``some of us are wicked, certainly. I am very angry, I am very sore, and I am very bitter, but I don't know that I am wicked. I have been cruelly injured. They have hurt me, and I want to hurt them. I don't deny that; on the contrary, I tell you plainly that it is the use I want to make of your secret.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Mrs. Bread seemed to hold her (woman) breath.

``You want to publish them--you want to shame them?'' (unknown)

``I want to bring them down,--down, down, down! I want to turn the tables upon them--I want to mortify them as they mortified me. They took me up into a high place and made me stand there for all the world to see me, and then they stole behind me and pushed me into this bottomless pit, where I lie howling and gnashing my teeth! I made a fool of myself before all their friends; but I shall make something worse of them.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

This passionate sally, which Newman uttered with the greater fervor that it was the first time he (Newman) had had a chance to say all this aloud, kindled two small sparks in Mrs. Bread's fixed eyes.

``I suppose you have a right to your anger, sir; but think of the dishonor you will draw down on Madame de Cintré.'' (unknown)

``Madame de Cintré is buried alive,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``What are honor or dishonor to her (friends)? The door of the tomb is at this moment closing behind her (friends).'' (unknown)

``Yes, it's most awful,'' (unknown)
moaned Mrs. Bread.

``She (friends) has moved off, like her (friends) brother Valentin, to give me room to work. It's as if it were done on purpose.'' (unknown)

``Surely,'' (She)
said Mrs. Bread, apparently impressed by the ingenuity of this reflection. She (woman) was silent for some moments; then she (woman) added,
``And would you bring my lady before the courts?'' (she)

``The courts care nothing for my lady,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman replied.
``If she (lady) has committed a crime, she (lady) will be nothing for the courts but a wicked old woman.'' (unknown)

``And will they hang her (lady), sir?'' (unknown)

``That depends upon what she (lady) has done.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And Newman eyed Mrs. Bread intently.

``It would break up the family most terribly, sir!'' (unknown)

``It's time such a family should be broken up!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, with a laugh.

``And me at my age out of place, sir!'' (unknown)
sighed Mrs. Bread.

``Oh, I will take care of you! You shall come and live with me. You shall be my housekeeper, or anything you like. I will pension you for life.'' (unknown)

``Dear, dear, sir, you think of everything.'' (she)
And she (woman) seemed to fall a-brooding.

Newman watched her (woman) a while, and then he (Newman) said suddenly.

``Ah, Mrs. Bread, you are too fond of my lady!'' (She)

She (woman) looked at him (Newman) as quickly.

``I wouldn't have you say that, sir. I don't think it any part of my duty to be fond of my lady. I have served her (lady) faithfully this many a year; but if she (lady) were to die to-morrow, I believe, before Heaven I shouldn't shed a tear for her (lady).'' (unknown)
Then, after a pause,
``I have no reason to love her (lady)!'' (unknown)
Mrs. Bread added.
``The most she (lady) has done for me has been not to turn me out of the house.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman felt that decidedly his (Newman) companion was more and more confidential--that if luxury is corrupting, Mrs. Bread's conservative habits were already relaxed by the spiritual comfort of this preconcerted interview, in a remarkable locality, with a free-spoken millionaire. All his (millionaire) native shrewdness admonished him (millionaire) that his (millionaire) part was simply to let her (woman) take her (woman) time--let the charm of the occasion work. So he (millionaire) said nothing; he (millionaire) only looked at her (woman) kindly. Mrs. Bread sat nursing her (woman) lean elbows.
``My lady once did me a great wrong,'' (she)
she (woman) went on at last.
``She (lady) has a terrible tongue when she (lady) is vexed. It was many a year ago, but I have never forgotten it. I have never mentioned it to a human creature; I have kept my grudge to myself. I dare say I have been wicked, but my grudge has grown old with me. It has grown good for nothing, too, I dare say; but it has lived along, as I have lived. It will die when I die,--not before!'' (unknown)

``And what _is_ your grudge?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

Mrs. Bread dropped her (woman) eyes and hesitated.

``If I were a foreigner, sir, I should make less of telling you; it comes harder to a decent Englishwoman. But I sometimes think I have picked up too many foreign ways. What I was telling you belongs to a time when I was much younger and very different looking to what I am now. I had a very high color, sir, if you can believe it, indeed I was a very smart lass. My lady was younger, too, and the late marquis was youngest of all--I mean in the way he (marquis) went on, sir; he (marquis) had a very high spirit; he (marquis) was a magnificent man. He (marquis) was fond of his (marquis) pleasure, like most foreigners, and it must be owned that he (marquis) sometimes went rather below him (marquis) to take it. My lady was often jealous, and, if you'll believe it, sir, she (lady) did me the honor to be jealous of me. One day I had a red ribbon in my cap, and my lady flew out at me and ordered me to take it off. She (lady) accused me of putting it on to make the marquis look at me. I don't know that I was impertinent, but I spoke up like an honest girl and didn't count my words. A red ribbon indeed! As if it was my ribbons the marquis looked at! My lady knew afterwards that I was perfectly respectable, but she (lady) never said a word to show that she (lady) believed it. But the marquis did!'' (unknown)
Mrs. Bread presently added,
``I took off my red ribbon and put it away in a drawer, where I have kept it to this day. It's faded now, it's a very pale pink; but there it lies. My grudge has faded, too; the red has all gone out of it; but it lies here yet.'' (unknown)
And Mrs. Bread stroked her (woman) black satin bodice.

Newman listened with interest to this decent narrative, which seemed to have opened up the deeps of memory to his (Newman) companion. Then, as she (woman) remained silent, and seemed to be losing herself in retrospective meditation upon her (woman) perfect respectability, he (Newman) ventured upon a short cut to his (Newman) goal.

``So Madame de Bellegarde was jealous; I see. And M. de Bellegarde admired pretty women, without distinction of class. I suppose one mustn't be hard upon him (Bellegarde), for they probably didn't all behave so properly as you. But years afterwards it could hardly have been jealousy that turned Madame de Bellegarde into a criminal.'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread gave a weary sigh.

``We are using dreadful words, sir, but I don't care now. I see you have your idea, and I have no will of my own. My will was the will of my children, as I called them; but I have lost my children now. They are dead--I may say it of both of them; and what should I care for the living? What is anyone in the house to me now--what am I to them? My lady objects to me--she (lady) has objected to me these thirty years. I should have been glad to be something to young Madame de Bellegarde, though I never was nurse to the present marquis. When he (Bellegarde) was a baby I was too young; they wouldn't trust me with him (Bellegarde). But his (Bellegarde) wife told her (wife) own maid, Mamselle Clarisse, the opinion she (wife) had of me. Perhaps you would like to hear it, sir.'' (unknown)

``Oh, immensely,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``She (wife) said that if I would sit in her (wife) children's schoolroom I should do very well for a penwiper! When things have come to that I don't think I need stand upon ceremony.'' (unknown)

``Decidedly not,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Go on, Mrs. Bread.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Mrs. Bread, however, relapsed again into troubled dumbness, and all Newman could do was to fold his (Newman) arms and wait. But at last she (woman) appeared to have set her (woman) memories in order.

``It was when the late marquis was an old man and his (marquis) eldest son had been two years married. It was when the time came on for marrying Mademoiselle Claire; that's the way they talk of it here, you know, sir. The marquis's health was bad; he (marquis) was very much broken down. My lady had picked out M. de Cintré, for no good reason that I could see. But there are reasons, I very well know, that are beyond me, and you must be high in the world to understand them. Old M. de Cintré was very high, and my lady thought him (Cintré) almost as good as herself; that's saying a good deal. Mr. Urbain took sides with his (Urbain) mother, as he (Urbain) always did. The trouble, I believe, was that my lady would give very little money, and all the other gentlemen asked more. It was only M. de Cintré that was satisfied. The Lord willed it he (Lord) should have that one soft spot; it was the only one he (Lord) had. He (Lord) may have been very grand in his (Lord) birth, and he (Lord) certainly was very grand in his (Lord) bows and speeches; but that was all the grandeur he (Lord) had. I think he (Lord) was like what I have heard of comedians; not that I have ever seen one. But I know he (Lord) painted his (Lord) face. He (Lord) might paint it all he (Lord) would; he (Lord) could never make me like it! The marquis couldn't abide him (marquis), and declared that sooner than take such a husband as that Mademoiselle Claire should take none at all. He (husband) and my lady had a great scene; it came even to our ears in the servants' hall. It was not their first quarrel, if the truth must be told. They were not a loving couple, but they didn't often come to words, because, I think, neither of them thought the other's doings worth the trouble. My lady had long ago got over her (lady) jealousy, and she (lady) had taken to indifference. In this, I must say, they were well matched. The marquis was very easy-going; he (marquis) had a most gentlemanly temper. He (marquis) got angry only once a year, but then it was very bad. He (marquis) always took to bed directly afterwards. This time I speak of he (marquis) took to bed as usual, but he (marquis) never got up again. I'm afraid the poor gentleman was paying for his (gentleman) dissipation; isn't it true they mostly do, sir, when they get old? My lady and Mr. Urbain kept quiet, but I know my lady wrote letters to M. de Cintré. The marquis got worse and the doctors gave him (marquis) up. My lady, she (lady) gave him (marquis) up too, and if the truth must be told, she (lady) gave him (marquis) up gladly. When once he (marquis) was out of the way she (lady) could do what she (lady) pleased with her (lady) daughter, and it was all arranged that my poor innocent child should be handed over to M. de Cintré. You don't know what Mademoiselle was in those days, sir; she (lady) was the sweetest young creature in France, and knew as little of what was going on around her (lady) as the lamb does of the butcher. I used to nurse the marquis, and I was always in his (butcher) room. It was here at Fleurières, in the autumn. We had a doctor from Paris, who came and stayed two or three weeks in the house. Then there came two others, and there was a consultation, and these two others, as I said, declared that the marquis couldn't be saved. After this they went off, pocketing their fees, but the other one stayed and did what he (marquis) could. The marquis himself kept crying out that he (marquis) wouldn't die, that he (marquis) didn't want to die, that he (marquis) would live and look after his (marquis) daughter. Mademoiselle Claire and the viscount--that was Mr. Valentin, you know--were both in the house. The doctor was a clever man,--that I could see myself,--and I think he (doctor) believed that the marquis might get well. We took good care of him (doctor), he (doctor) and I, between us, and one day, when my lady had almost ordered her (lady) mourning, my patient suddenly began to mend. He (patient) got better and better, till the doctor said he (patient) was out of danger. What was killing him (patient) was the dreadful fits of pain in his (patient) stomach. But little by little they stopped, and the poor marquis began to make his (marquis) jokes again. The doctor found something that gave him (doctor) great comfort--some white stuff that we kept in a great bottle on the chimney-piece. I used to give it to the marquis through a glass tube; it always made him (marquis) easier. Then the doctor went away, after telling me to keep on giving him (doctor) the mixture whenever he (doctor) was bad. After that there was a little doctor from Poitiers, who came every day. So we were alone in the house--my lady and her (lady) poor husband and their three children. Young Madame de Bellegarde had gone away, with her (lady) little girl, to her (lady) mothers. You know she (lady) is very lively, and her (lady) maid told me that she (lady) didn't like to be where people were dying.'' (she)
Mrs. Bread paused a moment, and then she (woman) went on with the same quiet consistency.
``I think you have guessed, sir, that when the marquis began to turn my lady was disappointed.'' (she)
And she (woman) paused again, bending upon Newman a face which seemed to grow whiter as the darkness settled down upon them.

Newman had listened eagerly--with an eagerness greater even than that with which he (Newman) had bent his (Newman) ear to Valentin de Bellegarde's last words. Every now and then, as his (Newman) companion looked up at him (Newman), she (woman) reminded him (Newman) of an ancient tabby cat, protracting the enjoyment of a dish of milk. Even her (woman) triumph was measured and decorous; the faculty of exultation had been chilled by disuse. She (woman) presently continued.

``Late one night I was sitting by the marquis in his (marquis) room, the great red room in the west tower. He (marquis) had been complaining a little, and I gave him (marquis) a spoonful of the doctor's dose. My lady had been there in the early part of the evening; she (lady) sat far more than an hour by his (doctor) bed. Then she (lady) went away and left me alone. After midnight she (lady) came back, and her (lady) eldest son was with her (lady). They went to the bed and looked at the marquis, and my lady took hold of his (son) hand. Then she (lady) turned to me and said he (son) was not so well; I remember how the marquis, without saying anything, lay staring at her (lady). I can see his (son) white face, at this moment, in the great black square between the bed-curtains. I said I didn't think he (son) was very bad; and she (lady) told me to go to bed--she (lady) would sit a while with him (son). When the marquis saw me going he (marquis) gave a sort of groan, and called out to me not to leave him (marquis); but Mr. Urbain opened the door for me and pointed the way out. The present marquis--perhaps you have noticed, sir--has a very proud way of giving orders, and I was there to take orders. I went to my room, but I wasn't easy; I couldn't tell you why. I didn't undress; I sat there waiting and listening. For what, would you have said, sir? I couldn't have told you; for surely a poor gentleman might be comfortable with his (gentleman) wife and his (gentleman) son. It was as if I expected to hear the marquis moaning after me again. I listened, but I heard nothing. It was a very still night; I never knew a night so still. At last the very stillness itself seemed to frighten me, and I came out of my room and went very softly downstairs. In the anteroom, outside of the marquis's chamber, I found Mr. Urbain walking up and down. He (Urbain) asked me what I wanted, and I said I came back to relieve my lady. He (Urbain) said _he (Urbain)_ would relieve my lady, and ordered me back to bed; but as I stood there, unwilling to turn away, the door of the room opened and my lady came out. I noticed she (lady) was very pale; she (lady) was very strange. She (lady) looked a moment at the count and at me, and then she (lady) held out her (lady) arms to the count. He (Urbain) went to her (lady), and she (lady) fell upon him (Urbain) and hid her (lady) face. I went quickly past her (lady) into the room and to the marquis's bed. He (marquis) was lying there, very white, with his (marquis) eyes shut, like a corpse. I took hold of his (marquis) hand and spoke to him (marquis), and he (marquis) felt to me like a dead man. Then I turned round; my lady and Mr. Urbain were there. `My poor Bread,' said my lady, `M. le Marquis is gone.' Mr. Urbain knelt down by the bed and said softly, `_Mon père, mon père_.' I thought it wonderful strange, and asked my lady what in the world had happened, and why she (lady) hadn't called me. She (lady) said nothing had happened; that she (lady) had only been sitting there with the marquis, very quiet. She (lady) had closed her (lady) eyes, thinking she (lady) might sleep, and she (lady) had slept, she (lady) didn't know how long. When she (lady) woke up he (marquis) was dead. `It's death, my son, it's death,' she (lady) said to the count. Mr. Urbain said they must have the doctor, immediately, from Poitiers, and that he (Urbain) would ride off and fetch him (Urbain). He (Urbain) kissed his (Urbain) father's face, and then he (Urbain) kissed his (Urbain) mother and went away. My lady and I stood there at the bedside. As I looked at the poor marquis it came into my head that he (Urbain) was not dead, that he (Urbain) was in a kind of swoon. And then my lady repeated, `My poor Bread, it's death, it's death;' and I said, `Yes, my lady, it's certainly death.' I said just the opposite to what I believed; it was my notion. Then my lady said we must wait for the doctor, and we sat there and waited. It was a long time; the poor marquis neither stirred nor changed. `I have seen death before,' said my lady, `and it's terribly like this.' `Yes, please, my lady,' said I; and I kept thinking. The night wore away without the count's coming back, and my lady began to be frightened. She (lady) was afraid he (marquis) had had an accident in the dark, or met with some wild people. At last she (lady) got so restless that she (lady) went below to watch in the court for her (lady) son's return. I sat there alone and the marquis never stirred.'' (unknown)

Here Mrs. Bread paused again, and the most artistic of romancers could not have been more effective. Newman made a movement as if he (Newman) were turning over the page of a novel.

``So he (marquis) _was_ dead!'' (he)
he (Newman) exclaimed.

``Three days afterwards he (marquis) was in his (marquis) grave,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread, sententiously.
``In a little while I went away to the front of the house and looked out into the court, and there, before long, I saw Mr. Urbain ride in alone. I waited a bit, to hear him (Urbain) come upstairs with his (Urbain) mother, but they stayed below, and I went back to the marquis's room. I went to the bed and held up the light to him (marquis), but I don't know why I didn't let the candlestick fall. The marquis's eyes were open--open wide! they were staring at me. I knelt down beside him (marquis) and took his (marquis) hands, and begged him (marquis) to tell me, in the name of wonder, whether he (marquis) was alive or dead. Still he (marquis) looked at me a long time, and then he (marquis) made me a sign to put my ear close to him (marquis): `I am dead,' he (marquis) said, `I am dead. The marquise has killed me.' I was all in a tremble; I didn't understand him (marquise). He (marquise) seemed both a man and a corpse, if you can fancy, sir. `But you'll get well now, sir,' I said. And then he (marquise) whispered again, ever so weak; `I wouldn't get well for a kingdom. I wouldn't be that woman's husband again.' And then he (husband) said more; he (husband) said she (woman) had murdered him (husband). I asked him (husband) what she (woman) had done to him (husband), but he (husband) only replied, `Murder, murder. And she (woman)'ll kill my daughter,' he (husband) said; `my poor unhappy child.' And he (husband) begged me to prevent that, and then he (husband) said that he (husband) was dying, that he (husband) was dead. I was afraid to move or to leave him (husband); I was almost dead myself. All of a sudden he (husband) asked me to get a pencil and write for him (husband); and then I had to tell him (husband) that I couldn't manage a pencil. He (husband) asked me to hold him (husband) up in bed while he (husband) wrote himself, and I said he (husband) could never, never do such a thing. But he (husband) seemed to have a kind of terror that gave him (husband) strength. I found a pencil in the room and a piece of paper and a book, and I put the paper on the book and the pencil into his (husband) hand, and moved the candle near him (husband). You will think all this very strange, sir; and very strange it was. The strangest part of it was that I believed he (husband) was dying, and that I was eager to help him (husband) to write. I sat on the bed and put my arm round him (husband), and held him (husband) up. I felt very strong; I believe I could have lifted him (husband) and carried him (husband). It was a wonder how he (husband) wrote, but he (husband) did write, in a big scratching hand; he (husband) almost covered one side of the paper. It seemed a long time; I suppose it was three or four minutes. He (husband) was groaning, terribly, all the while. Then he (husband) said it was ended, and I let him (husband) down upon his (husband) pillows and he (husband) gave me the paper and told me to fold it, and hide it, and give it to those who would act upon it. `Whom do you mean?' I said. `Who are those who will act upon it?' But he (husband) only groaned, for an answer; he (husband) couldn't speak, for weakness. In a few minutes he (husband) told me to go and look at the bottle on the chimney-piece. I knew the bottle he (husband) meant; the white stuff that was good for his (husband) stomach. I went and looked at it, but it was empty. When I came back his (husband) eyes were open and he (husband) was staring at me; but soon he (husband) closed them and he (husband) said no more. I hid the paper in my dress; I didn't look at what was written upon it, though I can read very well, sir, if I haven't any handwriting. I sat down near the bed, but it was nearly half an hour before my lady and the count came in. The marquis looked as he (marquis) did when they left him (marquis), and I never said a word about his (marquis) having been otherwise. Mr. Urbain said that the doctor had been called to a person in childbirth, but that he (Urbain) promised to set out for Fleurières immediately. In another half hour he (Urbain) arrived, and as soon as he (Urbain) had examined the marquis he (Urbain) said that we had had a false alarm. The poor gentleman was very low, but he (gentleman) was still living. I watched my lady and her (lady) son when he (gentleman) said this, to see if they looked at each other, and I am obliged to admit that they didn't. The doctor said there was no reason he (doctor) should die; he (doctor) had been going on so well. And then he (doctor) wanted to know how he (doctor) had suddenly fallen off; he (doctor) had left him (doctor) so very hearty. My lady told her (lady) little story again--what she (lady) had told Mr. Urbain and me--and the doctor looked at her (lady) and said nothing. He (doctor) stayed all the next day at the château, and hardly left the marquis. I was always there. Mademoiselle and Mr. Valentin came and looked at their father, but he (Valentin) never stirred. It was a strange, deathly stupor. My lady was always about; her (lady) face was as white as her (lady) husband's, and she (lady) looked very proud, as I had seen her (lady) look when her (lady) orders or her (lady) wishes had been disobeyed. It was as if the poor marquis had defied her (lady); and the way she (lady) took it made me afraid of her (lady). The apothecary from Poitiers kept the marquis along through the day, and we waited for the other doctor from Paris, who, as I told you, had been staying at Fleurières. They had telegraphed for him (doctor) early in the morning, and in the evening he (doctor) arrived. He (doctor) talked a bit outside with the doctor from Poitiers, and then they came in to see the marquis together. I was with him (marquis), and so was Mr. Urbain. My lady had been to receive the doctor from Paris, and she (lady) didn't come back with him (Urbain) into the room. He (Urbain) sat down by the marquis; I can see him (marquis) there now, with his (marquis) hand on the marquis's wrist, and Mr. Urbain watching him (Urbain) with a little looking-glass in his (Urbain) hand. `I'm sure he (Urbain)'s better,' said the little doctor from Poitiers; `I'm sure he (doctor)'ll come back.' A few moments after he (doctor) had said this the marquis opened his (doctor) eyes, as if he (doctor) were waking up, and looked at us, from one to the other. I saw him (doctor) look at me very softly, as you'd say. At the same moment my lady came in on tiptoe; she (lady) came up to the bed and put in her (lady) head between me and the count. The marquis saw her (lady) and gave a long, most wonderful moan. He (marquis) said something we couldn't understand, and he (marquis) seemed to have a kind of spasm. He (marquis) shook all over and then closed his (marquis) eyes, and the doctor jumped up and took hold of my lady. He (doctor) held her (lady) for a moment a bit roughly. The marquis was stone dead! This time there were those there that knew.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman felt as if he (Newman) had been reading by starlight the report of highly important evidence in a great murder case.

``And the paper--the paper!'' (he)
he (Newman) said, excitedly.
``What was written upon it?'' (unknown)

``I can't tell you, sir,'' (unknown)
answered Mrs. Bread.
``I couldn't read it; it was in French.'' (unknown)

``But could no one else read it?'' (unknown)

``I never asked a human creature.'' (unknown)

``No one has ever seen it?'' (unknown)

``If you see it you'll be the first.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman seized the old woman's hand in both his (Newman) own and pressed it vigorously.

``I thank you ever so much for that,'' (he)
he (Newman) cried.
``I want to be the first, I want it to be my property and no one else's! You're the wisest old woman in Europe. And what did you do with the paper?'' (him)
This information had made him (Newman) feel extraordinarily strong.
``Give it to me quick!'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread got up with a certain majesty.

``It is not so easy as that, sir. If you want the paper, you must wait.'' (unknown)

``But waiting is horrible, you know,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
urged Newman.

``I am sure _I_ have waited; I have waited these many years,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.

``That is very true. You have waited for me. I won't forget it. And yet, how comes it you didn't do as M. de Bellegarde said, show the paper to someone?'' (unknown)

``To whom should I show it?'' (unknown)
answered Mrs. Bread, mournfully.
``It was not easy to know, and many's the night I have lain awake thinking of it. Six months afterwards, when they married Mademoiselle to her (you) vicious old husband, I was very near bringing it out. I thought it was my duty to do something with it, and yet I was mightily afraid. I didn't know what was written on the paper or how bad it might be, and there was no one I could trust enough to ask. And it seemed to me a cruel kindness to do that sweet young creature, letting her (you) know that her (you) father had written her (you) mother down so shamefully; for that's what he (father) did, I suppose. I thought she (you) would rather be unhappy with her (you) husband than be unhappy that way. It was for her (you) and for my dear Mr. Valentin I kept quiet. Quiet I call it, but for me it was a weary quietness. It worried me terribly, and it changed me altogether. But for others I held my tongue, and no one, to this hour, knows what passed between the poor marquis and me.'' (unknown)

``But evidently there were suspicions,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Where did Mr. Valentin get his (Valentin) ideas?'' (unknown)

``It was the little doctor from Poitiers. He (Valentin) was very ill-satisfied, and he (Valentin) made a great talk. He (Valentin) was a sharp Frenchman, and coming to the house, as he (Valentin) did day after day, I suppose he (Valentin) saw more than he (Valentin) seemed to see. And indeed the way the poor marquis went off as soon as his (marquis) eyes fell on my lady was a most shocking sight for anyone. The medical gentleman from Paris was much more accommodating, and he (gentleman) hushed up the other. But for all he (gentleman) could do Mr. Valentin and Mademoiselle heard something; they knew their father's death was somehow against nature. Of course they couldn't accuse their mother, and, as I tell you, I was as dumb as that stone. Mr. Valentin used to look at me sometimes, and his (Valentin) eyes seemed to shine, as if he (Valentin) were thinking of asking me something. I was dreadfully afraid he (Valentin) would speak, and I always looked away and went about my business. If I were to tell him (Valentin), I was sure he (Valentin) would hate me afterwards, and that I could never have borne. Once I went up to him (Valentin) and took a great liberty; I kissed him (Valentin), as I had kissed him (Valentin) when he (Valentin) was a child. `You oughtn't to look so sad, sir,' I said; `believe your poor old Bread. Such a gallant, handsome young man can have nothing to be sad about.' And I think he (man) understood me; he (man) understood that I was begging off, and he (man) made up his (man) mind in his (man) own way. He (man) went about with his (man) unasked question in his (man) mind, as I did with my untold tale; we were both afraid of bringing dishonor on a great house. And it was the same with Mademoiselle. She (we) didn't know what happened; she (we) wouldn't know. My lady and Mr. Urbain asked me no questions because they had no reason. I was as still as a mouse. When I was younger my lady thought me a hussy, and now she (lady) thought me a fool. How should I have any ideas?'' (unknown)

``But you say the little doctor from Poitiers made a talk,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Did no one take it up?'' (unknown)

``I heard nothing of it, sir. They are always talking scandal in these foreign countries you may have noticed--and I suppose they shook their heads over Madame de Bellegarde. But after all, what could they say? The marquis had been ill, and the marquis had died; he (marquis) had as good a right to die as anyone. The doctor couldn't say he (doctor) had not come honestly by his (doctor) cramps. The next year the little doctor left the place and bought a practice in Bordeaux, and if there has been any gossip it died out. And I don't think there could have been much gossip about my lady that anyone would listen to. My lady is so very respectable.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman, at this last affirmation, broke into an immense, resounding laugh. Mrs. Bread had begun to move away from the spot where they were sitting, and he (Newman) helped her (woman) through the aperture in the wall and along the homeward path.

``Yes,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``my lady's respectability is delicious; it will be a great crash!'' (he)
They reached the empty space in front of the church, where they stopped a moment, looking at each other with something of an air of closer fellowship--like two sociable conspirators.
``But what was it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``what was it she (lady) did to her (lady) husband? She (lady) didn't stab him (husband) or poison him (husband).'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I don't know, sir; no one saw it.'' (unknown)

``Unless it was Mr. Urbain. You say he (Urbain) was walking up and down, outside the room. Perhaps he (Urbain) looked through the keyhole. But no; I think that with his (Urbain) mother he (Urbain) would take it on trust.'' (unknown)

``You may be sure I have often thought of it,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.
``I am sure she (mother) didn't touch him (Urbain) with her (mother) hands. I saw nothing on him (Urbain), anywhere. I believe it was in this way. He (Urbain) had a fit of his (Urbain) great pain, and he (Urbain) asked her (mother) for his (Urbain) medicine. Instead of giving it to him (Urbain) she (mother) went and poured it away, before his (Urbain) eyes. Then he (Urbain) saw what she (mother) meant, and, weak and helpless as he (Urbain) was, he (Urbain) was frightened, he (Urbain) was terrified. `You want to kill me,' he (Urbain) said. `Yes, M. le Marquis, I want to kill you,' says my lady, and sits down and fixes her (lady) eyes upon him (Urbain). You know my lady's eyes, I think, sir; it was with them she (lady) killed him (Urbain); it was with the terrible strong will she (lady) put into them. It was like a frost on flowers.'' (unknown)

``Well, you are a very intelligent woman; you have shown great discretion,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I shall value your services as housekeeper extremely.'' (Mrs. Bread)

They had begun to descend the hill, and Mrs. Bread said nothing until they reached the foot. Newman strolled lightly beside her (Bread); his (Newman) head was thrown back and he (Newman) was gazing at all the stars; he (Newman) seemed to himself to be riding his (Newman) vengeance along the Milky Way.

``So you are serious, sir, about that?'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread, softly.

``About your living with me? Why of course I will take care of you to the end of your days. You can't live with those people any longer. And you oughtn't to, you know, after this. You give me the paper, and you move away.'' (unknown)

``It seems very flighty in me to be taking a new place at this time of life,'' (unknown)
observed Mrs. Bread, lugubriously.
``But if you are going to turn the house upside down, I would rather be out of it.'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, in the cheerful tone of a man who feels rich in alternatives.
``I don't think I shall bring in the constables, if that's what you mean. Whatever Madame de Bellegarde did, I am afraid the law can't take hold of it. But I am glad of that; it leaves it altogether to me!'' (unknown)

``You are a mighty bold gentleman, sir,'' (him)
murmured Mrs. Bread, looking at him (Newman) round the edge of her (Bread) great bonnet.

He (Newman) walked with her (Bread) back to the château; the curfew had tolled for the laborious villagers of Fleurières, and the street was unlighted and empty. She (Bread) promised him (Newman) that he (Newman) should have the marquis's manuscript in half an hour. Mrs. Bread choosing not to go in by the great gate, they passed round by a winding lane to a door in the wall of the park, of which she (Bread) had the key, and which would enable her (Bread) to enter the château from behind. Newman arranged with her (Bread) that he (Newman) should await outside the wall her (Bread) return with the coveted document.

She (Bread) went in, and his (Newman) half hour in the dusky lane seemed very long. But he (Newman) had plenty to think about. At last the door in the wall opened and Mrs. Bread stood there, with one hand on the latch and the other holding out a scrap of white paper, folded small. In a moment he (Newman) was master of it, and it had passed into his (Newman) waistcoat pocket.

``Come and see me in Paris,'' (he)
he (Newman) said;
``we are to settle your future, you know; and I will translate poor M. de Bellegarde's French to you.'' (he)
Never had he (Newman) felt so grateful as at this moment for M. Nioche's instructions.

Mrs. Bread's dull eyes had followed the disappearance of the paper, and she (Newman) gave a heavy sigh.

``Well, you have done what you would with me, sir, and I suppose you will do it again. You _must_ take care of me now. You are a terribly positive gentleman.'' (unknown)

``Just now,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I'm a terribly impatient gentleman!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) bade her (Newman) good-night and walked rapidly back to the inn. He (Newman) ordered his (Newman) vehicle to be prepared for his (Newman) return to Poitiers, and then he (Newman) shut the door of the common salle and strode toward the solitary lamp on the chimney-piece. He (Newman) pulled out the paper and quickly unfolded it. It was covered with pencil-marks, which at first, in the feeble light, seemed indistinct. But Newman's fierce curiosity forced a meaning from the tremulous signs. The English of them was as follows:--

``My wife has tried to kill me, and she (wife) has done it; I am dying, dying horribly. It is to marry my dear daughter to M. de Cintré. With all my soul I protest,--I forbid it. I am not insane,--ask the doctors, ask Mrs. B--. It was alone with me here, to-night; she (daughter) attacked me and put me to death. It is murder, if murder ever was. Ask the doctors.

``HENRI-URBAIN DE BELLEGARDE'' (BELLEGARDE CHAPTER XXIII Newman)

CHAPTER XXIII

Newman returned to Paris the second day after his (Newman) interview with Mrs. Bread. The morrow he (Newman) had spent at Poitiers, reading over and over again the little document which he (Newman) had lodged in his (Newman) pocket-book, and thinking what he (Newman) would do in the circumstances and how he (Newman) would do it. He (Newman) would not have said that Poitiers was an amusing place; yet the day seemed very short. Domiciled once more in the Boulevard Haussmann, he (Newman) walked over to the Rue de l’Université and inquired of Madame de Bellegarde's portress whether the marquise had come back. The portress told him (marquise) that she (Newman) had arrived, with M. le Marquis, on the preceding day, and further informed him (marquise) that if he (marquise) desired to enter, Madame de Bellegarde and her (Newman) son were both at home. As she (Newman) said these words the little white-faced old woman who peered out of the dusky gate-house of the Hôtel de Bellegarde gave a small wicked smile--a smile which seemed to Newman to mean,

``Go in if you dare!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
She (woman) was evidently versed in the current domestic history; she (woman) was placed where she (woman) could feel the pulse of the house. Newman stood a moment, twisting his (Newman) moustache and looking at her (woman); then he (Newman) abruptly turned away. But this was not because he (Newman) was afraid to go in--though he (Newman) doubted whether, if he (Newman) did so, he (Newman) should be able to make his (Newman) way, unchallenged, into the presence of Madame de Cintré's relatives. Confidence--excessive confidence, perhaps--quite as much as timidity prompted his (Newman) retreat. He (Newman) was nursing his (Newman) thunderbolt; he (Newman) loved it; he (Newman) was unwilling to part with it. He (Newman) seemed to be holding it aloft in the rumbling, vaguely-flashing air, directly over the heads of his (Newman) victims, and he (Newman) fancied he (Newman) could see their pale, upturned faces. Few specimens of the human countenance had ever given him (Newman) such pleasure as these, lighted in the lurid fashion I have hinted at, and he (Newman) was disposed to sip the cup of contemplative revenge in a leisurely fashion. It must be added, too, that he (Newman) was at a loss to see exactly how he (Newman) could arrange to witness the operation of his (Newman) thunder. To send in his (Newman) card to Madame de Bellegarde would be a waste of ceremony; she (I) would certainly decline to receive him (Bellegarde). On the other hand he (Bellegarde) could not force his (Bellegarde) way into her (I) presence. It annoyed him (Bellegarde) keenly to think that he (Bellegarde) might be reduced to the blind satisfaction of writing her (I) a letter; but he (Bellegarde) consoled himself in a measure with the reflection that a letter might lead to an interview. He (Bellegarde) went home, and feeling rather tired--nursing a vengeance was, it must be confessed, a rather fatiguing process; it took a good deal out of one--flung himself into one of his (Bellegarde) brocaded fauteuils, stretched his (Bellegarde) legs, thrust his (Bellegarde) hands into his (Bellegarde) pockets, and, while he (Bellegarde) watched the reflected sunset fading from the ornate house-tops on the opposite side of the Boulevard, began mentally to compose a cool epistle to Madame de Bellegarde. While he (Bellegarde) was so occupied his (Bellegarde) servant threw open the door and announced ceremoniously,
``Madame Brett!'' (he)

Newman roused himself, expectantly, and in a few moments perceived upon his (Newman) threshold the worthy woman with whom he (Newman) had conversed to such good purpose on the starlit hill-top of Fleurières. Mrs. Bread had made for this visit the same toilet as for her (woman) former expedition. Newman was struck with her (woman) distinguished appearance. His (Newman) lamp was not lit, and as her (woman) large, grave face gazed at him (Newman) through the light dusk from under the shadow of her (woman) ample bonnet, he (Newman) felt the incongruity of such a person presenting herself as a servant. He (Newman) greeted her (woman) with high geniality and bade her (woman) come in and sit down and make herself comfortable. There was something which might have touched the springs both of mirth and of melancholy in the ancient maidenliness with which Mrs. Bread endeavored to comply with these directions. She (woman) was not playing at being fluttered, which would have been simply ridiculous; she (woman) was doing her (woman) best to carry herself as a person so humble that, for her (woman), even embarrassment would have been pretentious; but evidently she (woman) had never dreamed of its being in her (woman) horoscope to pay a visit, at night-fall, to a friendly single gentleman who lived in theatrical-looking rooms on one of the new Boulevards.

``I truly hope I am not forgetting my place, sir,'' (she)
she (woman) murmured.

``Forgetting your place?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``Why, you are remembering it. This is your place, you know. You are already in my service; your wages, as housekeeper, began a fortnight ago. I can tell you my house wants keeping! Why don't you take off your bonnet and stay?'' (unknown)

``Take off my bonnet?'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread, with timid literalness.
``Oh, sir, I haven't my cap. And with your leave, sir, I couldn't keep house in my best gown.'' (unknown)

``Never mind your gown,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, cheerfully.
``You shall have a better gown than that.'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread stared solemnly and then stretched her (woman) hands over her (woman) lustreless satin skirt, as if the perilous side of her (woman) situation were defining itself.

``Oh, sir, I am fond of my own clothes,'' (she)
she (woman) murmured.

``I hope you have left those wicked people, at any rate,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Well, sir, here I am!'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.
``That's all I can tell you. Here I sit, poor Catherine Bread. It's a strange place for me to be. I don't know myself; I never supposed I was so bold. But indeed, sir, I have gone as far as my own strength will bear me.'' (unknown)

``Oh, come, Mrs. Bread,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, almost caressingly,
``don't make yourself uncomfortable. Now's the time to feel lively, you know.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

She (woman) began to speak again with a trembling voice.

``I think it would be more respectable if I could--if I could'' (unknown)
--and her (woman) voice trembled to a pause.

``If you could give up this sort of thing altogether?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman kindly, trying to anticipate her (woman) meaning, which he (Newman) supposed might be a wish to retire from service.

``If I could give up everything, sir! All I should ask is a decent Protestant burial.'' (unknown)

``Burial!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman, with a burst of laughter.
``Why, to bury you now would be a sad piece of extravagance. It's only rascals who have to be buried to get respectable. Honest folks like you and me can live our time out--and live together. Come! Did you bring your baggage?'' (unknown)

``My box is locked and corded; but I haven't yet spoken to my lady.'' (unknown)

``Speak to her (lady), then, and have done with it. I should like to have your chance!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.

``I would gladly give it you, sir. I have passed some weary hours in my lady's dressing-room; but this will be one of the longest. She (lady) will tax me with ingratitude.'' (unknown)

``Well,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``so long as you can tax her (lady) with murder--'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Oh, sir, I can't; not I,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
sighed Mrs. Bread.

``You don't mean to say anything about it? So much the better. Leave that to me.'' (unknown)

``If she (lady) calls me a thankless old woman,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread,
``I shall have nothing to say. But it is better so,'' (she)
she (woman) softly added.
``She (lady) shall be my lady to the last. That will be more respectable.'' (unknown)

``And then you will come to me and I shall be your gentleman,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``that will be more respectable still!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Mrs. Bread rose, with lowered eyes, and stood a moment; then, looking up, she (woman) rested her (woman) eyes upon Newman's face. The disordered proprieties were somehow settling to rest. She (woman) looked at Newman so long and so fixedly, with such a dull, intense devotedness, that he (Newman) himself might have had a pretext for embarrassment. At last she (woman) said gently,

``You are not looking well, sir.'' (she)

``That's natural enough,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I have nothing to feel well about. To be very indifferent and very fierce, very dull and very jovial, very sick and very lively, all at once,--why, it rather mixes one up.'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread gave a noiseless sigh.

``I can tell you something that will make you feel duller still, if you want to feel all one way. About Madame de Cintré.'' (unknown)

``What can you tell me?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman demanded.
``Not that you have seen her (I)?'' (She)

She (woman) shook her (woman) head.

``No, indeed, sir, nor ever shall. That's the dullness of it. Nor my lady. Nor M. de Bellegarde.'' (unknown)

``You mean that she (lady) is kept so close.'' (unknown)

``Close, close,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread, very softly.

These words, for an instant, seemed to check the beating of Newman's heart. He (Newman) leaned back in his (Newman) chair, staring up at the old woman.

``They have tried to see her (lady), and she (lady) wouldn't--she (lady) couldn't?'' (unknown)

``She (lady) refused--forever! I had it from my lady's own maid,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread,
``who had it from my lady. To speak of it to such a person my lady must have felt the shock. Madame de Cintré won't see them now, and now is her (lady) only chance. A while hence she (lady) will have no chance.'' (unknown)

``You mean the other women--the mothers, the daughters, the sisters; what is it they call them?--won't let her (lady)?'' (unknown)

``It is what they call the rule of the house,--or of the order, I believe,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.
``There is no rule so strict as that of the Carmelites. The bad women in the reformatories are fine ladies to them. They wear old brown cloaks--so the _femme de chambre_ told me--that you wouldn't use for a horse blanket. And the poor countess was so fond of soft-feeling dresses; she (countess) would never have anything stiff! They sleep on the ground,'' (she)
Mrs. Bread went on;
``they are no better, no better,'' (she)
--and she (woman) hesitated for a comparison,--
``they are no better than tinkers' wives. They give up everything, down to the very name their poor old nurses called them by. They give up father and mother, brother and sister,--to say nothing of other persons,'' (she)
Mrs. Bread delicately added.
``They wear a shroud under their brown cloaks and a rope round their waists, and they get up on winter nights and go off into cold places to pray to the Virgin Mary. The Virgin Mary is a hard mistress!'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread, dwelling on these terrible facts, sat dry-eyed and pale, with her (woman) hands clasped in her (woman) satin lap. Newman gave a melancholy groan and fell forward, leaning his (Newman) head on his (Newman) hands. There was a long silence, broken only by the ticking of the great gilded clock on the chimney-piece.

``Where is this place--where is the convent?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked at last, looking up.

``There are two houses,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.
``I found out; I thought you would like to know--though it's poor comfort, I think. One is in the Avenue de Messine; they have learned that Madame de Cintré is there. The other is in the Rue d’Enfer. That's a terrible name; I suppose you know what it means.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman got up and walked away to the end of his (Newman) long room. When he (Newman) came back Mrs. Bread had got up, and stood by the fire with folded hands.

``Tell me this,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``Can I get near her (Mary)--even if I don't see her (Mary)? Can I look through a grating, or some such thing, at the place where she (Mary) is?'' (all women)

It is said that all women love a lover, and Mrs. Bread's sense of the pre-established harmony which kept servants in their

``place,'' (servants)
even as planets in their orbits -LRB-not that Mrs. Bread had ever consciously likened herself to a planet-RRB-, barely availed to temper the maternal melancholy with which she (Newman) leaned her (Newman) head on one side and gazed at her (Newman) new employer. She (Newman) probably felt for the moment as if, forty years before, she (Newman) had held him (Newman) also in her (Newman) arms.
``That wouldn't help you, sir. It would only make her (Mary) seem farther away.'' (unknown)

``I want to go there, at all events,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Avenue de Messine, you say? And what is it they call themselves?'' (unknown)

``Carmelites,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.

``I shall remember that.'' (unknown)

Mrs. Bread hesitated a moment, and then,

``It's my duty to tell you this, sir,'' (she)
she (Newman) went on.
``The convent has a chapel, and some people are admitted on Sunday to the mass. You don't see the poor creatures that are shut up there, but I am told you can hear them sing. It's a wonder they have any heart for singing! Some Sunday I shall make bold to go. It seems to me I should know _her (I)_ voice in fifty.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman looked at his (Newman) visitor very gratefully; then he (Newman) held out his (Newman) hand and shook hers.

``Thank you,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``If anyone can get in, I will.'' (he)
A moment later Mrs. Bread proposed, deferentially, to retire, but he (Newman) checked her (Newman) and put a lighted candle into her (Newman) hand.
``There are half a dozen rooms there I don't use,'' (he)
he (Newman) said, pointing through an open door.
``Go and look at them and take your choice. You can live in the one you like best.'' (unknown)
From this bewildering opportunity Mrs. Bread at first recoiled; but finally, yielding to Newman's gentle, reassuring push, she (Newman) wandered off into the dusk with her (Newman) tremulous taper. She (Newman) remained absent a quarter of an hour, during which Newman paced up and down, stopped occasionally to look out of the window at the lights on the Boulevard, and then resumed his (Newman) walk. Mrs. Bread's relish for her (Newman) investigation apparently increased as she (Newman) proceeded; but at last she (Newman) reappeared and deposited her (Newman) candlestick on the chimney-piece.

``Well, have you picked one out?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
asked Newman.

``A room, sir? They are all too fine for a dingy old body like me. There isn't one that hasn't a bit of gilding.'' (unknown)

``It's only tinsel, Mrs. Bread,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``If you stay there a while it will all peel off of itself.'' (he)
And he (Newman) gave a dismal smile.

``Oh, sir, there are things enough peeling off already!'' (unknown)
rejoined Mrs. Bread, with a head-shake.
``Since I was there I thought I would look about me. I don't believe you know, sir. The corners are most dreadful. You do want a housekeeper, that you do; you want a tidy Englishwoman that isn't above taking hold of a broom.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman assured her (Newman) that he (Newman) suspected, if he (Newman) had not measured, his (Newman) domestic abuses, and that to reform them was a mission worthy of her (Newman) powers. She (Newman) held her (Newman) candlestick aloft again and looked around the salon with compassionate glances; then she (Newman) intimated that she (Newman) accepted the mission, and that its sacred character would sustain her (Newman) in her (Newman) rupture with Madame de Bellegarde. With this she (Newman) curtsied herself away.

She (Newman) came back the next day with her (Newman) worldly goods, and Newman, going into his (Newman) drawing-room, found her (Newman) upon her (Newman) aged knees before a divan, sewing up some detached fringe. He (Newman) questioned her (Newman) as to her (Newman) leave-taking with her (Newman) late mistress, and she (Newman) said it had proved easier than she (Newman) feared.

``I was perfectly civil, sir, but the Lord helped me to remember that a good woman has no call to tremble before a bad one.'' (unknown)

``I should think so!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman.
``And does she (woman) know you have come to me?'' (unknown)

``She (woman) asked me where I was going, and I mentioned your name,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread.

``What did she (woman) say to that?'' (unknown)

``She (woman) looked at me very hard, and she (woman) turned very red. Then she (woman) bade me leave her (woman). I was all ready to go, and I had got the coachman, who is an Englishman, to bring down my poor box and to fetch me a cab. But when I went down myself to the gate I found it closed. My lady had sent orders to the porter not to let me pass, and by the same orders the porter's wife--she (wife) is a dreadful sly old body--had gone out in a cab to fetch home M. de Bellegarde from his (Bellegarde) club.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman slapped his (Newman) knee.

``She (wife) _is_ scared! she (wife) _is_ scared!'' (he)
he (Newman) cried, exultantly.

``I was frightened too, sir,'' (unknown)
said Mrs. Bread,
``but I was also mightily vexed. I took it very high with the porter and asked him (porter) by what right he (porter) used violence to an honorable Englishwoman who had lived in the house for thirty years before he (porter) was heard of. Oh, sir, I was very grand, and I brought the man down. He (man) drew his (man) bolts and let me out, and I promised the cabman something handsome if he (man) would drive fast. But he (man) was terribly slow; it seemed as if we should never reach your blessed door. I am all of a tremble still; it took me five minutes, just now, to thread my needle.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman told her (Newman), with a gleeful laugh, that if she (Newman) chose she (Newman) might have a little maid on purpose to thread her (Newman) needles; and he (Newman) went away murmuring to himself again that the old woman _was_ scared--she (woman) _was_ scared!

He (Newman) had not shown Mrs. Tristram the little paper that he (Newman) carried in his (Newman) pocket-book, but since his (Newman) return to Paris he (Newman) had seen her (Tristram) several times, and she (Tristram) had told him (Newman) that he (Newman) seemed to her (Tristram) to be in a strange way--an even stranger way than his (stranger) sad situation made natural. Had his (stranger) disappointment gone to his (stranger) head? He (stranger) looked like a man who was going to be ill, and yet she (Tristram) had never seen him (stranger) more restless and active. One day he (stranger) would sit hanging his (stranger) head and looking as if he (stranger) were firmly resolved never to smile again; another he (stranger) would indulge in laughter that was almost unseemly and make jokes that were bad even for him (stranger). If he (stranger) was trying to carry off his (stranger) sorrow, he (stranger) at such times really went too far. She (Tristram) begged him (stranger) of all things not to be

``strange.'' (him)
Feeling in a measure responsible as she (Tristram) did for the affair which had turned out so ill for him (stranger), she (Tristram) could endure anything but his (stranger) strangeness. He (stranger) might be melancholy if he (stranger) would, or he (stranger) might be stoical; he (stranger) might be cross and cantankerous with her (Tristram) and ask her (Tristram) why she (Tristram) had ever dared to meddle with his (stranger) destiny: to this she (Tristram) would submit; for this she (Tristram) would make allowances. Only, for Heaven's sake, let him (stranger) not be incoherent. That would be extremely unpleasant. It was like people talking in their sleep; they always frightened her (Tristram). And Mrs. Tristram intimated that, taking very high ground as regards the moral obligation which events had laid upon her (Tristram), she (Tristram) proposed not to rest quiet until she (Tristram) should have confronted him (stranger) with the least inadequate substitute for Madame de Cintré that the two hemispheres contained.

``Oh,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``we are even now, and we had better not open a new account! You may bury me some day, but you shall never marry me. It's too rough. I hope, at any rate,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
he (Newman) added,
``that there is nothing incoherent in this--that I want to go next Sunday to the Carmelite chapel in the Avenue de Messine. You know one of the Catholic ministers--an abbé, is that it?--I have seen him (it) here, you know; that motherly old gentleman with the big waistband. Please ask him (gentleman) if I need a special leave to go in, and if I do, beg him (gentleman) to obtain it for me.'' (he)

Mrs. Tristram gave expression to the liveliest joy.

``I am so glad you have asked me to do something!'' (she)
she (Tristram) cried.
``You shall get into the chapel if the abbé is disfrocked for his (gentleman) share in it.'' (she)
And two days afterwards she (Tristram) told him (Newman) that it was all arranged; the abbé was enchanted to serve him (Newman), and if he (Newman) would present himself civilly at the convent gate there would be no difficulty.

CHAPTER XXIV

Sunday was as yet two days off; but meanwhile, to beguile his (Newman) impatience, Newman took his (Newman) way to the Avenue de Messine and got what comfort he (Newman) could in staring at the blank outer wall of Madame de Cintré's present residence. The street in question, as some travelers will remember, adjoins the Parc Monceau, which is one of the prettiest corners of Paris. The quarter has an air of modern opulence and convenience which seems at variance with the ascetic institution, and the impression made upon Newman's gloomily-irritated gaze by the fresh-looking, windowless expanse behind which the woman he (Newman) loved was perhaps even then pledging herself to pass the rest of her (woman) days was less exasperating than he (Newman) had feared. The place suggested a convent with the modern improvements--an asylum in which privacy, though unbroken, might be not quite identical with privation, and meditation, though monotonous, might be of a cheerful cast. And yet he (Newman) knew the case was otherwise; only at present it was not a reality to him (Newman). It was too strange and too mocking to be real; it was like a page torn out of a romance, with no context in his (Newman) own experience.

On Sunday morning, at the hour which Mrs. Tristram had indicated, he (Newman) rang at the gate in the blank wall. It instantly opened and admitted him (Newman) into a clean, cold-looking court, from beyond which a dull, plain edifice looked down upon him (Newman). A robust lay sister with a cheerful complexion emerged from a porter's lodge, and, on his (porter) stating his (porter) errand, pointed to the open door of the chapel, an edifice which occupied the right side of the court and was preceded by the high flight of steps. Newman ascended the steps and immediately entered the open door. Service had not yet begun; the place was dimly lighted, and it was some moments before he (Newman) could distinguish its features. Then he (Newman) saw it was divided by a large close iron screen into two unequal portions. The altar was on the hither side of the screen, and between it and the entrance were disposed several benches and chairs. Three or four of these were occupied by vague, motionless figures--figures that he (Newman) presently perceived to be women, deeply absorbed in their devotion. The place seemed to Newman very cold; the smell of the incense itself was cold. Besides this there was a twinkle of tapers and here and there a glow of colored glass. Newman seated himself; the praying women kept still, with their backs turned. He (Newman) saw they were visitors like himself and he (Newman) would have liked to see their faces; for he (Newman) believed that they were the mourning mothers and sisters of other women who had had the same pitiless courage as Madame de Cintré. But they were better off than he (Newman), for they at least shared the faith to which the others had sacrificed themselves. Three or four persons came in; two of them were elderly gentlemen. Everyone was very quiet. Newman fastened his (Newman) eyes upon the screen behind the altar. That was the convent, the real convent, the place where she (they) was. But he (Newman) could see nothing; no light came through the crevices. He (Newman) got up and approached the partition very gently, trying to look through. But behind it there was darkness, with nothing stirring. He (Newman) went back to his (Newman) place, and after that a priest and two altar boys came in and began to say mass.

Newman watched their genuflections and gyrations with a grim, still enmity; they seemed aids and abettors of Madame de Cintré's desertion; they were mouthing and droning out their triumph. The priest's long, dismal intonings acted upon his (priest) nerves and deepened his (priest) wrath; there was something defiant in his (priest) unintelligible drawl; it seemed meant for Newman himself. Suddenly there arose from the depths of the chapel, from behind the inexorable grating, a sound which drew his (Newman) attention from the altar--the sound of a strange, lugubrious chant, uttered by women's voices. It began softly, but it presently grew louder, and as it increased it became more of a wail and a dirge. It was the chant of the Carmelite nuns, their only human utterance. It was their dirge over their buried affections and over the vanity of earthly desires. At first Newman was bewildered--almost stunned--by the strangeness of the sound; then, as he (Newman) comprehended its meaning, he (Newman) listened intently and his (Newman) heart began to throb. He (Newman) listened for Madame de Cintré's voice, and in the very heart of the tuneless harmony he (Newman) imagined he (Newman) made it out. -LRB-We are obliged to believe that he (Newman) was wrong, inasmuch as she (Newman) had obviously not yet had time to become a member of the invisible sisterhood.-RRB- The chant kept on, mechanical and monotonous, with dismal repetitions and despairing cadences. It was hideous, it was horrible; as it continued, Newman felt that he (Newman) needed all his (Newman) self-control. He (Newman) was growing more agitated; he (Newman) felt tears in his (Newman) eyes. At last, as in its full force the thought came over him (Newman) that this confused, impersonal wail was all that either he (Newman) or the world she (Newman) had deserted should ever hear of the voice he (Newman) had found so sweet, he (Newman) felt that he (Newman) could bear it no longer. He (Newman) rose abruptly and made his (Newman) way out. On the threshold he (Newman) paused, listened again to the dreary strain, and then hastily descended into the court.
