As he (Newman) did so he (Newman) saw the good sister with the high-colored cheeks and the fanlike frill to her (sister) coiffure, who had admitted him (Newman), was in conference at the gate with two persons who had just come in. A second glance informed him (Newman) that these persons were Madame de Bellegarde and her (sister) son, and that they were about to avail themselves of that method of approach to Madame de Cintré which Newman had found but a mockery of consolation. As he (Newman) crossed the court M. de Bellegarde recognized him (Bellegarde); the marquis was coming to the steps, leading his (Bellegarde) mother. The old lady also gave Newman a look, and it resembled that of her (lady) son. Both faces expressed a franker perturbation, something more akin to the humbleness of dismay, than Newman had yet seen in them. Evidently he (Newman) startled the Bellegardes, and they had not their grand behavior immediately in hand. Newman hurried past them, guided only by the desire to get out of the convent walls and into the street. The gate opened itself at his (Newman) approach; he (Newman) strode over the threshold and it closed behind him (Newman). A carriage which appeared to have been standing there, was just turning away from the sidewalk. Newman looked at it for a moment, blankly; then he (Newman) became conscious, through the dusky mist that swam before his (Newman) eyes, that a lady seated in it was bowing to him (Newman). The vehicle had turned away before he (Newman) recognized her (lady); it was an ancient landau with one half the cover lowered. The lady's bow was very positive and accompanied with a smile; a little girl was seated beside her (girl). He (Newman) raised his (Newman) hat, and then the lady bade the coachman stop. The carriage halted again beside the pavement, and she (lady) sat there and beckoned to Newman--beckoned with the demonstrative grace of Madame Urbain de Bellegarde. Newman hesitated a moment before he (Newman) obeyed her (lady) summons, during this moment he (Newman) had time to curse his (Newman) stupidity for letting the others escape him (Newman). He (Newman) had been wondering how he (Newman) could get at them; fool that he (Newman) was for not stopping them then and there! What better place than beneath the very prison walls to which they had consigned the promise of his (Newman) joy? He (Newman) had been too bewildered to stop them, but now he (Newman) felt ready to wait for them at the gate. Madame Urbain, with a certain attractive petulance, beckoned to him (Newman) again, and this time he (Newman) went over to the carriage. She (fool) leaned out and gave him (Newman) her (fool) hand, looking at him (Newman) kindly, and smiling.

``Ah, monsieur,'' (she)
she (fool) said,
``you don't include me in your wrath? I had nothing to do with it.'' (she)

``Oh, I don't suppose _you_ could have prevented it!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered in a tone which was not that of studied gallantry.

``What you say is too true for me to resent the small account it makes of my influence. I forgive you, at any rate, because you look as if you had seen a ghost.'' (unknown)

``I have!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I am glad, then, I didn't go in with Madame de Bellegarde and my husband. You must have seen them, eh? Was the meeting affectionate? Did you hear the chanting? They say it's like the lamentations of the damned. I wouldn't go in: one is certain to hear that soon enough. Poor Claire--in a white shroud and a big brown cloak! That's the _toilette_ of the Carmelites, you know. Well, she (Claire) was always fond of long, loose things. But I must not speak of her (Claire) to you; only I must say that I am very sorry for you, that if I could have helped you I would, and that I think everyone has been very shabby. I was afraid of it, you know; I felt it in the air for a fortnight before it came. When I saw you at my mother-in-law's ball, taking it all so easily, I felt as if you were dancing on your grave. But what could I do? I wish you all the good I can think of. You will say that isn't much! Yes; they have been very shabby; I am not a bit afraid to say it; I assure you everyone thinks so. We are not all like that. I am sorry I am not going to see you again; you know I think you very good company. I would prove it by asking you to get into the carriage and drive with me for a quarter of an hour, while I wait for my mother-in-law. Only if we were seen--considering what has passed, and everyone knows you have been turned away--it might be thought I was going a little too far, even for me. But I shall see you sometimes--somewhere, eh? You know'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
--this was said in English--
``we have a plan for a little amusement.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman stood there with his (Newman) hand on the carriage-door listening to this consolatory murmur with an unlighted eye. He (Newman) hardly knew what Madame de Bellegarde was saying; he (Bellegarde) was only conscious that she (fool) was chattering ineffectively. But suddenly it occurred to him (Bellegarde) that, with her (fool) pretty professions, there was a way of making her (fool) effective; she (fool) might help him (Bellegarde) to get at the old woman and the marquis.

``They are coming back soon--your companions?'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.
``You are waiting for them?'' (unknown)

``They will hear the mass out; there is nothing to keep them longer. Claire has refused to see them.'' (unknown)

``I want to speak to them,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``and you can help me, you can do me a favor. Delay your return for five minutes and give me a chance at them. I will wait for them here.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Madame de Bellegarde clasped her (fool) hands with a tender grimace.

``My poor friend, what do you want to do to them? To beg them to come back to you? It will be wasted words. They will never come back!'' (unknown)

``I want to speak to them, all the same. Pray do what I ask you. Stay away and leave them to me for five minutes; you needn't be afraid; I shall not be violent; I am very quiet.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you look very quiet! If they had _le cœur tendre_ you would move them. But they haven't! However, I will do better for you than what you propose. The understanding is not that I shall come back for them. I am going into the Parc Monceau with my little girl to give her (girl) a walk, and my mother-in-law, who comes so rarely into this quarter, is to profit by the same opportunity to take the air. We are to wait for her (mother-in-law) in the park, where my husband is to bring her (mother-in-law) to us. Follow me now; just within the gates I shall get out of my carriage. Sit down on a chair in some quiet corner and I will bring them near you. There's devotion for you! _Le reste vous regarde_.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

This proposal seemed to Newman extremely felicitous; it revived his (Newman) drooping spirit, and he (Newman) reflected that Madame Urbain was not such a goose as she (fool) seemed. He (Newman) promised immediately to overtake her (fool), and the carriage drove away.

The Parc Monceau is a very pretty piece of landscape-gardening, but Newman, passing into it, bestowed little attention upon its elegant vegetation, which was full of the freshness of spring. He (Newman) found Madame de Bellegarde promptly, seated in one of the quiet corners of which she (fool) had spoken, while before her (fool), in the alley, her (fool) little girl, attended by the footman and the lap-dog, walked up and down as if she (fool) were taking a lesson in deportment. Newman sat down beside the mamma, and she (fool) talked a great deal, apparently with the design of convincing him (Newman) that--if he (Newman) would only see it--poor dear Claire did not belong to the most fascinating type of woman. She (Claire) was too tall and thin, too stiff and cold; her (Claire) mouth was too wide and her (Claire) nose too narrow. She (Claire) had no dimples anywhere. And then she (Claire) was eccentric, eccentric in cold blood; she (Claire) was an Anglaise, after all. Newman was very impatient; he (Newman) was counting the minutes until his (Newman) victims should reappear. He (Newman) sat silent, leaning upon his (Newman) cane, looking absently and insensibly at the little marquise. At length Madame de Bellegarde said she (Claire) would walk toward the gate of the park and meet her (Claire) companions; but before she (Claire) went she (Claire) dropped her (Claire) eyes, and, after playing a moment with the lace of her (Claire) sleeve, looked up again at Newman.

``Do you remember,'' (she)
she (Claire) asked,
``the promise you made me three weeks ago?'' (she)
And then, as Newman, vainly consulting his (Newman) memory, was obliged to confess that the promise had escaped it, she (Claire) declared that he (Newman) had made her (Claire), at the time, a very queer answer--an answer at which, viewing it in the light of the sequel, she (Claire) had fair ground for taking offense.
``You promised to take me to Bullier's after your marriage. After your marriage--you made a great point of that. Three days after that your marriage was broken off. Do you know, when I heard the news, the first thing I said to myself? `Oh heaven, now he (Le) won't go with me to Bullier's!' And I really began to wonder if you had not been expecting the rupture.'' (unknown)

``Oh, my dear lady,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
murmured Newman, looking down the path to see if the others were not coming.

``I shall be good-natured,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.
``One must not ask too much of a gentleman who is in love with a cloistered nun. Besides, I can't go to Bullier's while we are in mourning. But I haven't given it up for that. The _partie_ is arranged; I have my cavalier. Lord Deepmere, if you please! He (Deepmere) has gone back to his (Deepmere) dear Dublin; but a few months hence I am to name any evening and he (Deepmere) will come over from Ireland, on purpose. That's what I call gallantry!'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

Shortly after this Madame de Bellegarde walked away with her (Claire) little girl. Newman sat in his (Newman) place; the time seemed terribly long. He (Newman) felt how fiercely his (Newman) quarter of an hour in the convent chapel had raked over the glowing coals of his (Newman) resentment. Madame de Bellegarde kept him (Bellegarde) waiting, but she (Claire) proved as good as her (Claire) word. At last she (Claire) reappeared at the end of the path, with her (Claire) little girl and her (Claire) footman; beside her (Claire) slowly walked her (Claire) husband, with his (husband) mother on his (husband) arm. They were a long time advancing, during which Newman sat unmoved. Tingling as he (Newman) was with passion, it was extremely characteristic of him (Newman) that he (Newman) was able to moderate his (Newman) expression of it, as he (Newman) would have turned down a flaring gas-burner. His (Newman) native coolness, shrewdness, and deliberateness, his (Newman) life-long submissiveness to the sentiment that words were acts and acts were steps in life, and that in this matter of taking steps curveting and prancing were exclusively reserved for quadrupeds and foreigners--all this admonished him (Newman) that rightful wrath had no connection with being a fool and indulging in spectacular violence. So as he (fool) rose, when old Madame de Bellegarde and her (Newman) son were close to him (Bellegarde), he (Bellegarde) only felt very tall and light. He (Bellegarde) had been sitting beside some shrubbery, in such a way as not to be noticeable at a distance; but M. de Bellegarde had evidently already perceived him (Bellegarde). His (Bellegarde) mother and he (Bellegarde) were holding their course, but Newman stepped in front of them, and they were obliged to pause. He (Newman) lifted his (Newman) hat slightly, and looked at them for a moment; they were pale with amazement and disgust.

``Excuse me for stopping you,'' (he)
he (Newman) said in a low tone,
``but I must profit by the occasion. I have ten words to say to you. Will you listen to them?'' (he)

The marquis glared at him (marquis) and then turned to his (marquis) mother.

``Can Mr. Newman possibly have anything to say that is worth our listening to?'' (unknown)

``I assure you I have something,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``besides, it is my duty to say it. It's a notification--a warning.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Your duty?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said old Madame de Bellegarde, her (mother) thin lips curving like scorched paper.
``That is your affair, not ours.'' (Madame)

Madame Urbain meanwhile had seized her (mother) little girl by the hand, with a gesture of surprise and impatience which struck Newman, intent as he (Newman) was upon his (Newman) own words, with its dramatic effectiveness.

``If Mr. Newman is going to make a scene in public,'' (she)
she (mother) exclaimed,
``I will take my poor child out of the _mêlée_. She (I) is too young to see such naughtiness!'' (she)
and she (mother) instantly resumed her (mother) walk.

``You had much better listen to me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman went on.
``Whether you do or not, things will be disagreeable for you; but at any rate you will be prepared.'' (unknown)

``We have already heard something of your threats,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis,
``and you know what we think of them.'' (the marquis)

``You think a good deal more than you admit. A moment,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman added in reply to an exclamation of the old lady.
``I remember perfectly that we are in a public place, and you see I am very quiet. I am not going to tell your secret to the passers-by; I shall keep it, to begin with, for certain picked listeners. Anyone who observes us will think that we are having a friendly chat, and that I am complimenting you, madam, on your venerable virtues.'' (The marquis)

The marquis gave three short sharp raps on the ground with his (Newman) stick.

``I demand of you to step out of our path!'' (he)
he (Newman) hissed.

Newman instantly complied, and M. de Bellegarde stepped forward with his (Newman) mother. Then Newman said,

``Half an hour hence Madame de Bellegarde will regret that she (madam) didn't learn exactly what I mean.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

The marquise had taken a few steps, but at these words she (mother) paused, looking at Newman with eyes like two scintillating globules of ice.

``You are like a peddler with something to sell,'' (she)
she (mother) said, with a little cold laugh which only partially concealed the tremor in her (mother) voice.

``Oh, no, not to sell,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman rejoined;
``I give it to you for nothing.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) approached nearer to her (mother), looking her (mother) straight in the eyes.
``You killed your husband,'' (he)
he (Newman) said, almost in a whisper.
``That is, you tried once and failed, and then, without trying, you succeeded.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Madame de Bellegarde closed her (mother) eyes and gave a little cough, which, as a piece of dissimulation, struck Newman as really heroic.

``Dear mother,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis,
``does this stuff amuse you so much?'' (the marquis)

``The rest is more amusing,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You had better not lose it.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

Madame de Bellegarde opened her (mother) eyes; the scintillations had gone out of them; they were fixed and dead. But she (mother) smiled superbly with her (mother) narrow little lips, and repeated Newman's word.

``Amusing? Have I killed someone else?'' (unknown)

``I don't count your daughter,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``though I might! Your husband knew what you were doing. I have a proof of it whose existence you have never suspected.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) turned to the marquis, who was terribly white--whiter than Newman had ever seen anyone out of a picture.
``A paper written by the hand, and signed with the name, of Henri-Urbain de Bellegarde. Written after you, madam, had left him (husband) for dead, and while you, sir, had gone--not very fast--for the doctor.'' (The marquis)

The marquis looked at his (marquis) mother; she (mother) turned away, looking vaguely round her (mother).

``I must sit down,'' (she)
she (mother) said in a low tone, going toward the bench on which Newman had been sitting.

``Couldn't you have spoken to me alone?'' (the marquis)
said the marquis to Newman, with a strange look.

``Well, yes, if I could have been sure of speaking to your mother alone, too,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered.
``But I have had to take you as I could get you.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

Madame de Bellegarde, with a movement very eloquent of what he (Newman) would have called her (mother)

``grit,'' (he)
her (mother) steel-cold pluck and her (mother) instinctive appeal to her (mother) own personal resources, drew her (mother) hand out of her (mother) son's arm and went and seated herself upon the bench. There she (mother) remained, with her (mother) hands folded in her (mother) lap, looking straight at Newman. The expression of her (mother) face was such that he (Newman) fancied at first that she (mother) was smiling; but he (Newman) went and stood in front of her (mother) and saw that her (mother) elegant features were distorted by agitation. He (Newman) saw, however, equally, that she (mother) was resisting her (mother) agitation with all the rigor of her (mother) inflexible will, and there was nothing like either fear or submission in her (mother) stony stare. She (mother) had been startled, but she (mother) was not terrified. Newman had an exasperating feeling that she (mother) would get the better of him (Newman) still; he (Newman) would not have believed it possible that he (Newman) could so utterly fail to be touched by the sight of a woman -LRB-criminal or other-RRB- in so tight a place. Madame de Bellegarde gave a glance at her (woman) son which seemed tantamount to an injunction to be silent and leave her (woman) to her (woman) own devices. The marquis stood beside her (woman), with his (marquis) hands behind him (marquis), looking at Newman.

``What paper is this you speak of?'' (the lady)
asked the old lady, with an imitation of tranquillity which would have been applauded in a veteran actress.

``Exactly what I have told you,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``A paper written by your husband after you had left him (husband) for dead, and during the couple of hours before you returned. You see he (husband) had the time; you shouldn't have stayed away so long. It declares distinctly his (husband) wife's murderous intent.'' (unknown)

``I should like to see it,'' (Madame)
Madame de Bellegarde observed.

``I thought you might,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``and I have taken a copy.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) drew from his (Newman) waistcoat pocket a small, folded sheet.

``Give it to my son,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde. Newman handed it to the marquis, whose mother, glancing at him (Newman), said simply,
``Look at it.'' (him)
M. de Bellegarde's eyes had a pale eagerness which it was useless for him (Bellegarde) to try to dissimulate; he (Bellegarde) took the paper in his (Bellegarde) light-gloved fingers and opened it. There was a silence, during which he (Bellegarde) read it. He (Bellegarde) had more than time to read it, but still he (Bellegarde) said nothing; he (Bellegarde) stood staring at it.
``Where is the original?'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
asked Madame de Bellegarde, in a voice which was really a consummate negation of impatience.

``In a very safe place. Of course I can't show you that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``You might want to take hold of it,'' (he)
he (Newman) added with conscious quaintness.
``But that's a very correct copy--except, of course, the handwriting. I am keeping the original to show someone else.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

M. de Bellegarde at last looked up, and his (Bellegarde) eyes were still very eager.

``To whom do you mean to show it?'' (unknown)

``Well, I'm thinking of beginning with the duchess,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``that stout lady I saw at your ball. She (lady) asked me to come and see her (lady), you know. I thought at the moment I shouldn't have much to say to her (lady); but my little document will give us something to talk about.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``You had better keep it, my son,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde.

``By all means,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``keep it and show it to your mother when you get home.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``And after showing it to the duchess?'' (the marquis)
--asked the marquis, folding the paper and putting it away.

``Well, I'll take up the dukes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Then the counts and the barons--all the people you had the cruelty to introduce me to in a character of which you meant immediately to deprive me. I have made out a list.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

For a moment neither Madame de Bellegarde nor her (Bellegarde) son said a word; the old lady sat with her (lady) eyes upon the ground; M. de Bellegarde's blanched pupils were fixed upon her (lady) face. Then, looking at Newman,

``Is that all you have to say?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
she (lady) asked.

``No, I want to say a few words more. I want to say that I hope you quite understand what I'm about. This is my revenge, you know. You have treated me before the world--convened for the express purpose--as if I were not good enough for you. I mean to show the world that, however bad I may be, you are not quite the people to say it.'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)

Madame de Bellegarde was silent again, and then she (lady) broke her (lady) silence. Her (lady) self-possession continued to be extraordinary.

``I needn't ask you who has been your accomplice. Mrs. Bread told me that you had purchased her (Bread) services.'' (unknown)

``Don't accuse Mrs. Bread of venality,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``She (Bread) has kept your secret all these years. She (Bread) has given you a long respite. It was beneath her (Bread) eyes your husband wrote that paper; he (husband) put it into her (Bread) hands with a solemn injunction that she (Bread) was to make it public. She (Bread) was too good-hearted to make use of it.'' (The lady)

The old lady appeared for an instant to hesitate, and then,

``She (Bread) was my husband's mistress,'' (The lady)
she (lady) said, softly. This was the only concession to self-defense that she (lady) condescended to make.

``I doubt that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

Madame de Bellegarde got up from her (lady) bench.

``It was not to your opinions I undertook to listen, and if you have nothing left but them to tell me I think this remarkable interview may terminate.'' (the marquis)
And turning to the marquis she (lady) took his (Newman) arm again.
``My son,'' (she)
she (lady) said,
``say something!'' (she)

M. de Bellegarde looked down at his (Bellegarde) mother, passing his (Bellegarde) hand over his (Bellegarde) forehead, and then, tenderly, caressingly,

``What shall I say?'' (mother)
he (Bellegarde) asked.

``There is only one thing to say,'' (Marquise de Bellegarde/Marquise)
said the Marquise.
``That it was really not worth while to have interrupted our walk.'' (the marquis)

But the marquis thought he (Marquise) could improve this.

``Your paper's a forgery,'' (he)
he (Marquise) said to Newman.

Newman shook his (Newman) head a little, with a tranquil smile.

``M. de Bellegarde,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``your mother does better. She (mother) has done better all along, from the first of my knowing you. You're a mighty plucky woman, madam,'' (he)
he (Newman) continued.
``It's a great pity you have made me your enemy. I should have been one of your greatest admirers.'' (unknown)

``_Mon pauvre ami_,'' (Madame de Bellegarde/Young Madame de Bellegarde/Bellegarde)
said Madame de Bellegarde to her (lady) son in French, and as if she (lady) had not heard these words,
``you must take me immediately to my carriage.'' (she)

Newman stepped back and let them leave him (Newman); he (Newman) watched them a moment and saw Madame Urbain, with her (lady) little girl, come out of a by-path to meet them. The old lady stooped and kissed her (lady) grandchild.

``Damn it, she (madam) _is_ plucky!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, and he (Newman) walked home with a slight sense of being balked. She (lady) was so inexpressively defiant! But on reflection he (Newman) decided that what he (Newman) had witnessed was no real sense of security, still less a real innocence. It was only a very superior style of brazen assurance.
``Wait till she (madam) reads the paper!'' (he)
he (Newman) said to himself; and he (Newman) concluded that he (Newman) should hear from her (lady) soon.

He (Newman) heard sooner than he (Newman) expected. The next morning, before midday, when he (Newman) was about to give orders for his (Newman) breakfast to be served, M. de Bellegarde's card was brought to him (Bellegarde).

``She (madam) has read the paper and she (madam) has passed a bad night,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman. He (Newman) instantly admitted his (Newman) visitor, who came in with the air of the ambassador of a great power meeting the delegate of a barbarous tribe whom an absurd accident had enabled for the moment to be abominably annoying. The ambassador, at all events, had passed a bad night, and his (ambassador) faultlessly careful toilet only threw into relief the frigid rancor in his (ambassador) eyes and the mottled tones of his (ambassador) refined complexion. He (ambassador) stood before Newman a moment, breathing quickly and softly, and shaking his (Newman) forefinger curtly as his (Newman) host pointed to a chair.

``What I have come to say is soon said,'' (he)
he (Newman) declared
``and can only be said without ceremony.'' (he)

``I am good for as much or for as little as you desire,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

The marquis looked round the room a moment, and then,

``On what terms will you part with your scrap of paper?'' (The marquis)

``On none!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And while Newman, with his (Newman) head on one side and his (Newman) hands behind him (Newman) sounded the marquis's turbid gaze with his (Newman) own, he (Newman) added,
``Certainly, that is not worth sitting down about.'' (he)

M. de Bellegarde meditated a moment, as if he (Bellegarde) had not heard Newman's refusal.

``My mother and I, last evening,'' (he)
he (Newman) said,
``talked over your story. You will be surprised to learn that we think your little document is--a'' (he)
--and he (Newman) held back his (Newman) word a moment--
``is genuine.'' (he)

``You forget that with you I am used to surprises!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
exclaimed Newman, with a laugh.

``The very smallest amount of respect that we owe to my father's memory,'' (the marquis)
the marquis continued,
``makes us desire that he (father) should not be held up to the world as the author of so--so infernal an attack upon the reputation of a wife whose only fault was that she (wife) had been submissive to accumulated injury.'' (the marquis)

``Oh, I see,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``It's for your father's sake.'' (he)
And he (Newman) laughed the laugh in which he (Newman) indulged when he (Newman) was most amused--a noiseless laugh, with his (Newman) lips closed.

But M. de Bellegarde's gravity held good.

``There are a few of my father's particular friends for whom the knowledge of so--so unfortunate an--inspiration--would be a real grief. Even say we firmly established by medical evidence the presumption of a mind disordered by fever, _il en resterait quelque chose_. At the best it would look ill in him (father). Very ill!'' (unknown)

``Don't try medical evidence,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``Don't touch the doctors and they won't touch you. I don't mind your knowing that I have not written to them.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman fancied that he (Newman) saw signs in M. de Bellegarde's discolored mask that this information was extremely pertinent. But it may have been merely fancy; for the marquis remained majestically argumentative.

``For instance, Madame d’Outreville,'' (he)
he (marquis) said,
``of whom you spoke yesterday. I can imagine nothing that would shock her (father) more.'' (he)

``Oh, I am quite prepared to shock Madame d’Outreville, you know. That's on the cards. I expect to shock a great many people.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

M. de Bellegarde examined for a moment the stitching on the back of one of his (Bellegarde) gloves. Then, without looking up,

``We don't offer you money,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.
``That we supposed to be useless.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman, turning away, took a few turns about the room and then came back.

``What _do_ you offer me? By what I can make out, the generosity is all to be on my side.'' (The marquis)

The marquis dropped his (marquis) arms at his (marquis) side and held his (marquis) head a little higher.

``What we offer you is a chance--a chance that a gentleman should appreciate. A chance to abstain from inflicting a terrible blot upon the memory of a man who certainly had his (man) faults, but who, personally, had done you no wrong.'' (unknown)

``There are two things to say to that,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``The first is, as regards appreciating your `chance,' that you don't consider me a gentleman. That's your great point you know. It's a poor rule that won't work both ways. The second is that--well, in a word, you are talking great nonsense!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman, who in the midst of his (Newman) bitterness had, as I have said, kept well before his (Newman) eyes a certain ideal of saying nothing rude, was immediately somewhat regretfully conscious of the sharpness of these words. But he (Newman) speedily observed that the marquis took them more quietly than might have been expected. M. de Bellegarde, like the stately ambassador that he (Bellegarde) was, continued the policy of ignoring what was disagreeable in his (Bellegarde) adversary's replies. He (Bellegarde) gazed at the gilded arabesques on the opposite wall, and then presently transferred his (Bellegarde) glance to Newman, as if he (Newman) too were a large grotesque in a rather vulgar system of chamber-decoration.

``I suppose you know that as regards yourself it won't do at all.'' (unknown)

``How do you mean it won't do?'' (unknown)

``Why, of course you damn yourself. But I suppose that's in your programme. You propose to throw mud at us; you believe, you hope, that some of it may stick. We know, of course, it can't,'' (the marquis)
explained the marquis in a tone of conscious lucidity;
``but you take the chance, and are willing at any rate to show that you yourself have dirty hands.'' (the marquis)

``That's a good comparison; at least half of it is,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``I take the chance of something sticking. But as regards my hands, they are clean. I have taken the matter up with my finger-tips.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

M. de Bellegarde looked a moment into his (Bellegarde) hat.

``All our friends are quite with us,'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.
``They would have done exactly as we have done.'' (unknown)

``I shall believe that when I hear them say it. Meanwhile I shall think better of human nature.'' (The marquis)

The marquis looked into his (marquis) hat again.

``Madame de Cintré was extremely fond of her (I) father. If she (I) knew of the existence of the few written words of which you propose to make this scandalous use, she (I) would demand of you proudly for his (father) sake to give it up to her (I), and she (I) would destroy it without reading it.'' (unknown)

``Very possibly,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman rejoined.
``But she (I) will not know. I was in that convent yesterday and I know what _she (I)_ is doing. Lord deliver us! You can guess whether it made me feel forgiving!'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

M. de Bellegarde appeared to have nothing more to suggest; but he (Bellegarde) continued to stand there, rigid and elegant, as a man who believed that his (Bellegarde) mere personal presence had an argumentative value. Newman watched him (Newman), and, without yielding an inch on the main issue, felt an incongruously good-natured impulse to help him (Newman) to retreat in good order.

``Your visit's a failure, you see,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``You offer too little.'' (unknown)

``Propose something yourself,'' (the marquis)
said the marquis.

``Give me back Madame de Cintré in the same state in which you took her (I) from me.'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)

M. de Bellegarde threw back his (Bellegarde) head and his (Bellegarde) pale face flushed.

``Never!'' (he)
he (Bellegarde) said.

``You can't!'' (unknown)

``We wouldn't if we could! In the sentiment which led us to deprecate her (I) marriage nothing is changed.'' (unknown)

```Deprecate' is good!'' cried Newman.

``It was hardly worth while to come here only to tell me that you are not ashamed of yourselves. I could have guessed that!'' (The marquis)

The marquis slowly walked toward the door, and Newman, following, opened it for him (Newman).

``What you propose to do will be very disagreeable,'' (M. de Bellegarde/Bellegarde/de Bellegarde)
M. de Bellegarde said.
``That is very evident. But it will be nothing more.'' (unknown)

``As I understand it,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered,
``that will be quite enough!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

M. de Bellegarde stood for a moment looking on the ground, as if he (Bellegarde) were ransacking his (Bellegarde) ingenuity to see what else he (Bellegarde) could do to save his (Bellegarde) father's reputation. Then, with a little cold sigh, he (Bellegarde) seemed to signify that he (Bellegarde) regretfully surrendered the late marquis to the penalty of his (Bellegarde) turpitude. He (Bellegarde) gave a hardly perceptible shrug, took his (Bellegarde) neat umbrella from the servant in the vestibule, and, with his (Bellegarde) gentlemanly walk, passed out. Newman stood listening till he (Newman) heard the door close; then he (Newman) slowly exclaimed,

``Well, I ought to begin to be satisfied now!'' (he)

CHAPTER XXV

Newman called upon the comical duchess and found her (duchess) at home. An old gentleman with a high nose and a gold-headed cane was just taking leave of her (duchess); he (Newman) made Newman a protracted obeisance as he (Newman) retired, and our hero supposed that he (Newman) was one of the mysterious grandees with whom he (Newman) had shaken hands at Madame de Bellegarde's ball. The duchess, in her (duchess) armchair, from which she (duchess) did not move, with a great flower-pot on one side of her (duchess), a pile of pink-covered novels on the other, and a large piece of tapestry depending from her (duchess) lap, presented an expansive and imposing front; but her (duchess) aspect was in the highest degree gracious, and there was nothing in her (duchess) manner to check the effusion of his (Bellegarde) confidence. She (duchess) talked to him (Bellegarde) about flowers and books, getting launched with marvelous promptitude; about the theatres, about the peculiar institutions of his (Bellegarde) native country, about the humidity of Paris about the pretty complexions of the American ladies, about his (Bellegarde) impressions of France and his (Bellegarde) opinion of its female inhabitants. All this was a brilliant monologue on the part of the duchess, who, like many of her (duchess) country-women, was a person of an affirmative rather than an interrogative cast of mind, who made _mots_ and put them herself into circulation, and who was apt to offer you a present of a convenient little opinion, neatly enveloped in the gilt paper of a happy Gallicism. Newman had come to her (duchess) with a grievance, but he (Newman) found himself in an atmosphere in which apparently no cognizance was taken of grievance; an atmosphere into which the chill of discomfort had never penetrated, and which seemed exclusively made up of mild, sweet, stale intellectual perfumes. The feeling with which he (Newman) had watched Madame d’Outreville at the treacherous festival of the Bellegardes came back to him (Newman); she (duchess) struck him (Newman) as a wonderful old lady in a comedy, particularly well up in her (duchess) part. He (Newman) observed before long that she (duchess) asked him (Newman) no questions about their common friends; she (duchess) made no allusion to the circumstances under which he (Newman) had been presented to her (duchess). She (duchess) neither feigned ignorance of a change in these circumstances nor pretended to condole with him (Newman) upon it; but she (duchess) smiled and discoursed and compared the tender-tinted wools of her (duchess) tapestry, as if the Bellegardes and their wickedness were not of this world.

``She (I) is fighting shy!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman to himself; and, having made the observation, he (Newman) was prompted to observe, farther, how the duchess would carry off her (duchess) indifference. She (duchess) did so in a masterly manner. There was not a gleam of disguised consciousness in those small, clear, demonstrative eyes which constituted her (duchess) nearest claim to personal loveliness, there was not a symptom of apprehension that Newman would trench upon the ground she (duchess) proposed to avoid.
``Upon my word, she (I) does it very well,'' (he)
he (Newman) tacitly commented.
``They all hold together bravely, and, whether anyone else can trust them or not, they can certainly trust each other.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman, at this juncture, fell to admiring the duchess for her (duchess) fine manners. He (Newman) felt, most accurately, that she (duchess) was not a grain less urbane than she (duchess) would have been if his (Newman) marriage were still in prospect; but he (Newman) felt also that she (duchess) was not a particle more urbane. He (Newman) had come, so reasoned the duchess--Heaven knew why he (Newman) had come, after what had happened; and for the half hour, therefore, she (duchess) would be _charmante_. But she (duchess) would never see him (Newman) again. Finding no ready-made opportunity to tell his (Newman) story, Newman pondered these things more dispassionately than might have been expected; he (Newman) stretched his (Newman) legs, as usual, and even chuckled a little, appreciatively and noiselessly. And then as the duchess went on relating a _mot_ with which her (duchess) mother had snubbed the great Napoleon, it occurred to Newman that her (duchess) evasion of a chapter of French history more interesting to himself might possibly be the result of an extreme consideration for his (Newman) feelings. Perhaps it was delicacy on the duchess's part--not policy. He (Newman) was on the point of saying something himself, to make the chance which he (Newman) had determined to give her (duchess) still better, when the servant announced another visitor. The duchess, on hearing the name--it was that of an Italian prince--gave a little imperceptible pout, and said to Newman, rapidly:

``I beg you to remain; I desire this visit to be short.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman said to himself, at this, that Madame d’Outreville intended, after all, that they should discuss the Bellegardes together.

The prince was a short, stout man, with a head disproportionately large. He (prince) had a dusky complexion and a bushy eyebrow, beneath which his (prince) eye wore a fixed and somewhat defiant expression; he (prince) seemed to be challenging you to insinuate that he (prince) was top-heavy. The duchess, judging from her (duchess) charge to Newman, regarded him (Newman) as a bore; but this was not apparent from the unchecked flow of her (duchess) conversation. She (duchess) made a fresh series of _mots_, characterized with great felicity the Italian intellect and the taste of the figs at Sorrento, predicted the ultimate future of the Italian kingdom -LRB-disgust with the brutal Sardinian rule and complete reversion, throughout the peninsula, to the sacred sway of the Holy Father-RRB-, and, finally, gave a history of the love affairs of the Princess X--. This narrative provoked some rectifications on the part of the prince, who, as he (prince) said, pretended to know something about that matter; and having satisfied himself that Newman was in no laughing mood, either with regard to the size of his (Newman) head or anything else, he (Newman) entered into the controversy with an animation for which the duchess, when she (duchess) set him (Newman) down as a bore, could not have been prepared. The sentimental vicissitudes of the Princess X-- led to a discussion of the heart history of Florentine nobility in general; the duchess had spent five weeks in Florence and had gathered much information on the subject. This was merged, in turn, in an examination of the Italian heart _per se_. The duchess took a brilliantly heterodox view--thought it the least susceptible organ of its kind that she (duchess) had ever encountered, related examples of its want of susceptibility, and at last declared that for her (duchess) the Italians were a people of ice. The prince became flame to refute her (duchess), and his (prince) visit really proved charming. Newman was naturally out of the conversation; he (Newman) sat with his (Newman) head a little on one side, watching the interlocutors. The duchess, as she (duchess) talked, frequently looked at him (Newman) with a smile, as if to intimate, in the charming manner of her (duchess) nation, that it lay only with him (Newman) to say something very much to the point. But he (Newman) said nothing at all, and at last his (Newman) thoughts began to wander. A singular feeling came over him (Newman)--a sudden sense of the folly of his (Newman) errand. What under the sun had he (Newman) to say to the duchess, after all? Wherein would it profit him (Newman) to tell her (duchess) that the Bellegardes were traitors and that the old lady, into the bargain was a murderess? He (Newman) seemed morally to have turned a sort of somersault, and to find things looking differently in consequence. He (Newman) felt a sudden stiffening of his (Newman) will and quickening of his (Newman) reserve. What in the world had he (Newman) been thinking of when he (Newman) fancied the duchess could help him (Newman), and that it would conduce to his (Newman) comfort to make her (duchess) think ill of the Bellegardes? What did her (duchess) opinion of the Bellegardes matter to him (Newman)? It was only a shade more important than the opinion the Bellegardes entertained of her (duchess). The duchess help him (Newman)--that cold, stout, soft, artificial woman help him (Newman)?--she (woman) who in the last twenty minutes had built up between them a wall of polite conversation in which she (woman) evidently flattered herself that he (Newman) would never find a gate. Had it come to that--that he (Newman) was asking favors of conceited people, and appealing for sympathy where he (Newman) had no sympathy to give? He (Newman) rested his (Newman) arms on his (Newman) knees, and sat for some minutes staring into his (Newman) hat. As he (Newman) did so his (Newman) ears tingled--he (Newman) had come very near being an ass. Whether or no the duchess would hear his (Newman) story, he (Newman) wouldn't tell it. Was he (Newman) to sit there another half hour for the sake of exposing the Bellegardes? The Bellegardes be hanged! He (Newman) got up abruptly, and advanced to shake hands with his (Newman) hostess.

``You can't stay longer?'' (she)
she (hostess) asked very graciously.

``I am afraid not,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

She (hostess) hesitated a moment, and then,

``I had an idea you had something particular to say to me,'' (She)
she (hostess) declared.

Newman looked at her (hostess); he (Newman) felt a little dizzy; for the moment he (Newman) seemed to be turning his (Newman) somersault again. The little Italian prince came to his (prince) help:

``Ah, madam, who has not that?'' (The prince)
he (prince) softly sighed.

``Don't teach Mr. Newman to say _fadaises_,'' (the duchess)
said the duchess.
``It is his (Newman) merit that he (Newman) doesn't know how.'' (unknown)

``Yes, I don't know how to say _fadaises_,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``and I don't want to say anything unpleasant.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``I am sure you are very considerate,'' (the duchess)
said the duchess with a smile; and she (duchess) gave him (Newman) a little nod for good-bye with which he (Newman) took his (Newman) departure.

Once in the street, he (Newman) stood for some time on the pavement, wondering whether, after all, he (Newman) was not an ass not to have discharged his (Newman) pistol. And then again he (Newman) decided that to talk to anyone whomsoever about the Bellegardes would be extremely disagreeable to him (Newman). The least disagreeable thing, under the circumstances, was to banish them from his (Newman) mind, and never think of them again. Indecision had not hitherto been one of Newman's weaknesses, and in this case it was not of long duration. For three days after this he (Newman) did not, or at least he (Newman) tried not to, think of the Bellegardes. He (Newman) dined with Mrs. Tristram, and on her (Tristram) mentioning their name, he (Newman) begged her (Tristram) almost severely to desist. This gave Tom Tristram a much-coveted opportunity to offer his (Tristram) condolences.

He (Tristram) leaned forward, laying his (Tristram) hand on Newman's arm compressing his (Tristram) lips and shaking his (Tristram) head.

``The fact is my dear fellow, you see, that you ought never to have gone into it. It was not your doing, I know--it was all my wife. If you want to come down on her (wife), I'll stand off; I give you leave to hit her (wife) as hard as you like. You know she (wife) has never had a word of reproach from me in her (wife) life, and I think she (wife) is in need of something of the kind. Why didn't you listen to _me?_ You know I didn't believe in the thing. I thought it at the best an amiable delusion. I don't profess to be a Don Juan or a gay Lothario,--that class of man, you know; but I do pretend to know something about the harder sex. I have never disliked a woman in my life that she (woman) has not turned out badly. I was not at all deceived in Lizzie, for instance; I always had my doubts about her (Lizzie). Whatever you may think of my present situation, I must at least admit that I got into it with my eyes open. Now suppose you had got into something like this box with Madame de Cintré. You may depend upon it she (Lizzie) would have turned out a stiff one. And upon my word I don't see where you could have found your comfort. Not from the marquis, my dear Newman; he (Newman) wasn't a man you could go and talk things over with in a sociable, common-sense way. Did he (Newman) ever seem to want to have you on the premises--did he (Newman) ever try to see you alone? Did he (Newman) ever ask you to come and smoke a cigar with him (Newman) of an evening, or step in, when you had been calling on the ladies, and take something? I don't think you would have got much encouragement out of _him (Newman)_. And as for the old lady, she (lady) struck one as an uncommonly strong dose. They have a great expression here, you know; they call it `sympathetic.' Everything is sympathetic--or ought to be. Now Madame de Bellegarde is about as sympathetic as that mustard-pot. They're a d--d cold-blooded lot, any way; I felt it awfully at that ball of theirs. I felt as if I were walking up and down in the Armory, in the Tower of London! My dear boy, don't think me a vulgar brute for hinting at it, but you may depend upon it, all they wanted was your money. I know something about that; I can tell when people want one's money! Why they stopped wanting yours I don't know; I suppose because they could get someone else's without working so hard for it. It isn't worth finding out. It may be that it was not Madame de Cintré that backed out first, very likely the old woman put her (woman) up to it. I suspect she (woman) and her (woman) mother are really as thick as thieves, eh? You are well out of it, my boy; make up your mind to that. If I express myself strongly it is all because I love you so much; and from that point of view I may say I should as soon have thought of making up to that piece of pale high-mightiness as I should have thought of making up to the Obelisk in the Place de la Concorde.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman sat gazing at Tristram during this harangue with a lack-lustre eye; never yet had he (Newman) seemed to himself to have outgrown so completely the phase of equal comradeship with Tom Tristram. Mrs. Tristram's glance at her (Tristram) husband had more of a spark; she (Tristram) turned to Newman with a slightly lurid smile.

``You must at least do justice,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said,
``to the felicity with which Mr. Tristram repairs the indiscretions of a too zealous wife.'' (she)

But even without the aid of Tom Tristram's conversational felicities, Newman would have begun to think of the Bellegardes again. He (Newman) could cease to think of them only when he (Newman) ceased to think of his (Newman) loss and privation, and the days had as yet but scantily lightened the weight of this incommodity. In vain Mrs. Tristram begged him (Newman) to cheer up; she (Tristram) assured him (Newman) that the sight of his (Newman) countenance made her (Tristram) miserable.

``How can I help it?'' (he)
he (Newman) demanded with a trembling voice.
``I feel like a widower--and a widower who has not even the consolation of going to stand beside the grave of his (widower) wife--who has not the right to wear so much mourning as a weed on his (widower) hat. I feel,'' (he)
he (Newman) added in a moment
``as if my wife had been murdered and her (wife) assassins were still at large.'' (he)

Mrs. Tristram made no immediate rejoinder, but at last she (Tristram) said, with a smile which, in so far as it was a forced one, was less successfully simulated than such smiles, on her (Tristram) lips, usually were;

``Are you very sure that you would have been happy?'' (she)

Newman stared a moment, and then shook his (Newman) head.

``That's weak,'' (he)
he (Newman) said;
``that won't do.'' (he)

``Well,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram with a more triumphant bravery,
``I don't believe you would have been happy.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Newman gave a little laugh.

``Say I should have been miserable, then; it's a misery I should have preferred to any happiness.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Mrs. Tristram began to muse.

``I should have been curious to see; it would have been very strange.'' (unknown)

``Was it from curiosity that you urged me to try and marry her (you)?'' (unknown)

``A little,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram, growing still more audacious. Newman gave her (Tristram) the one angry look he (Newman) had been destined ever to give her (Tristram), turned away and took up his (Newman) hat. She (Tristram) watched him (Newman) a moment, and then she (Tristram) said,
``That sounds very cruel, but it is less so than it sounds. Curiosity has a share in almost everything I do. I wanted very much to see, first, whether such a marriage could actually take place; second, what would happen if it should take place.'' (she)

``So you didn't believe,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, resentfully.

``Yes, I believed--I believed that it would take place, and that you would be happy. Otherwise I should have been, among my speculations, a very heartless creature. _But_,'' (she)
she (Tristram) continued, laying her (Tristram) hand upon Newman's arm and hazarding a grave smile,
``it was the highest flight ever taken by a tolerably bold imagination!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Shortly after this she (Tristram) recommended him (Newman) to leave Paris and travel for three months. Change of scene would do him (Newman) good, and he (Newman) would forget his (Newman) misfortune sooner in absence from the objects which had witnessed it.

``I really feel,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman rejoined,
``as if to leave _you_, at least, would do me good--and cost me very little effort. You are growing cynical, you shock me and pain me.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Very good,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram, good-naturedly or cynically, as may be thought most probable.
``I shall certainly see you again.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman was very willing to get away from Paris; the brilliant streets he (Newman) had walked through in his (Newman) happier hours, and which then seemed to wear a higher brilliancy in honor of his (Newman) happiness, appeared now to be in the secret of his (Newman) defeat and to look down upon it in shining mockery. He (Newman) would go somewhere; he (Newman) cared little where; and he (Newman) made his (Newman) preparations. Then, one morning, at haphazard, he (Newman) drove to the train that would transport him (Newman) to Boulogne and dispatch him (Newman) thence to the shores of Britain. As he (Newman) rolled along in the train he (Newman) asked himself what had become of his (Newman) revenge, and he (Newman) was able to say that it was provisionally pigeon-holed in a very safe place; it would keep till called for.

He (Newman) arrived in London in the midst of what is called

``the season,'' (the midst)
and it seemed to him (Newman) at first that he (Newman) might here put himself in the way of being diverted from his (Newman) heavy-heartedness. He (Newman) knew no one in all England, but the spectacle of the mighty metropolis roused him (Newman) somewhat from his (Newman) apathy. Anything that was enormous usually found favor with Newman, and the multitudinous energies and industries of England stirred within him (Newman) a dull vivacity of contemplation. It is on record that the weather, at that moment, was of the finest English quality; he (Newman) took long walks and explored London in every direction; he (Newman) sat by the hour in Kensington Gardens and beside the adjoining Drive, watching the people and the horses and the carriages; the rosy English beauties, the wonderful English dandies, and the splendid flunkies. He (Newman) went to the opera and found it better than in Paris; he (Newman) went to the theatre and found a surprising charm in listening to dialogue the finest points of which came within the range of his (Newman) comprehension. He (Newman) made several excursions into the country, recommended by the waiter at his (Newman) hotel, with whom, on this and similar points, he (Newman) had established confidential relations. He (Newman) watched the deer in Windsor Forest and admired the Thames from Richmond Hill; he (Newman) ate white-bait and brown-bread and butter at Greenwich, and strolled in the grassy shadow of the cathedral of Canterbury. He (Newman) also visited the Tower of London and Madame Tussaud's exhibition. One day he (Newman) thought he (Newman) would go to Sheffield, and then, thinking again, he (Newman) gave it up. Why should he (Newman) go to Sheffield? He (Newman) had a feeling that the link which bound him (Newman) to a possible interest in the manufacture of cutlery was broken. He (Newman) had no desire for an
``inside view'' (He)
of any successful enterprise whatever, and he (Newman) would not have given the smallest sum for the privilege of talking over the details of the most
``splendid'' (he)
business with the shrewdest of overseers.

One afternoon he (Newman) had walked into Hyde Park, and was slowly threading his (Newman) way through the human maze which edges the Drive. The stream of carriages was no less dense, and Newman, as usual, marveled at the strange, dingy figures which he (Newman) saw taking the air in some of the stateliest vehicles. They reminded him (Newman) of what he (Newman) had read of eastern and southern countries, in which grotesque idols and fetiches were sometimes taken out of their temples and carried abroad in golden chariots to be displayed to the multitude. He (Newman) saw a great many pretty cheeks beneath high-plumed hats as he (Newman) squeezed his (Newman) way through serried waves of crumpled muslin; and sitting on little chairs at the base of the great serious English trees, he (Newman) observed a number of quiet-eyed maidens who seemed only to remind him (Newman) afresh that the magic of beauty had gone out of the world with Madame de Cintré: to say nothing of other damsels, whose eyes were not quiet, and who struck him (Newman) still more as a satire on possible consolation. He (Newman) had been walking for some time, when, directly in front of him (Newman), borne back by the summer breeze, he (Newman) heard a few words uttered in that bright Parisian idiom from which his (Newman) ears had begun to alienate themselves. The voice in which the words were spoken made them seem even more like a thing with which he (Newman) had once been familiar, and as he (Newman) bent his (Newman) eyes it lent an identity to the commonplace elegance of the back hair and shoulders of a young lady walking in the same direction as himself. Mademoiselle Nioche, apparently, had come to seek a more rapid advancement in London, and another glance led Newman to suppose that she (lady) had found it. A gentleman was strolling beside her (lady), lending a most attentive ear to her (lady) conversation and too entranced to open his (gentleman) lips. Newman did not hear his (Newman) voice, but perceived that he (Newman) presented the dorsal expression of a well-dressed Englishman. Mademoiselle Nioche was attracting attention: the ladies who passed her (lady) turned round to survey the Parisian perfection of her (lady) toilet. A great cataract of flounces rolled down from the young lady's waist to Newman's feet; he (Newman) had to step aside to avoid treading upon them. He (Newman) stepped aside, indeed, with a decision of movement which the occasion scarcely demanded; for even this imperfect glimpse of Miss Noémie had excited his (Newman) displeasure. She (Noémie) seemed an odious blot upon the face of nature; he (Newman) wanted to put her (Noémie) out of his (Newman) sight. He (Newman) thought of Valentin de Bellegarde, still green in the earth of his (Newman) burial--his (Newman) young life clipped by this flourishing impudence. The perfume of the young lady's finery sickened him (Newman); he (Newman) turned his (Newman) head and tried to deflect his (Newman) course; but the pressure of the crowd kept him (Newman) near her (lady) a few minutes longer, so that he (Newman) heard what she (lady) was saying.

``Ah, I am sure he (me) will miss me,'' (she)
she (lady) murmured.
``It was very cruel in me to leave him (me); I am afraid you will think me a very heartless creature. He (me) might perfectly well have come with us. I don't think he (me) is very well,'' (she)
she (lady) added;
``it seemed to me to-day that he (me) was not very gay.'' (she)

Newman wondered whom she (lady) was talking about, but just then an opening among his (Newman) neighbors enabled him (Newman) to turn away, and he (Newman) said to himself that she (lady) was probably paying a tribute to British propriety and playing at tender solicitude about her (lady) papa. Was that miserable old man still treading the path of vice in her (lady) train? Was he (man) still giving her (lady) the benefit of his (man) experience of affairs, and had he (man) crossed the sea to serve as her (lady) interpreter? Newman walked some distance farther, and then began to retrace his (Newman) steps taking care not to traverse again the orbit of Mademoiselle Nioche. At last he (Newman) looked for a chair under the trees, but he (Newman) had some difficulty in finding an empty one. He (Newman) was about to give up the search when he (Newman) saw a gentleman rise from the seat he (Newman) had been occupying, leaving Newman to take it without looking at his (Newman) neighbors. He (Newman) sat there for some time without heeding them; his (Newman) attention was lost in the irritation and bitterness produced by his (Newman) recent glimpse of Miss Noémie's iniquitous vitality. But at the end of a quarter of an hour, dropping his (Newman) eyes, he (Newman) perceived a small pug-dog squatted upon the path near his (Newman) feet--a diminutive but very perfect specimen of its interesting species. The pug was sniffing at the fashionable world, as it passed him (Newman), with his (Newman) little black muzzle, and was kept from extending his (Newman) investigation by a large blue ribbon attached to his (Newman) collar with an enormous rosette and held in the hand of a person seated next to Newman. To this person Newman transferred his (Newman) attention, and immediately perceived that he (Newman) was the object of all that of his (Newman) neighbor, who was staring up at him (Newman) from a pair of little fixed white eyes. These eyes Newman instantly recognized; he (Newman) had been sitting for the last quarter of an hour beside M. Nioche. He (Newman) had vaguely felt that someone was staring at him (Newman). M. Nioche continued to stare; he (Newman) appeared afraid to move, even to the extent of evading Newman's glance.

``Dear me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman;
``are you here, too?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
And he (Newman) looked at his (Newman) neighbor's helplessness more grimly than he (Newman) knew. M. Nioche had a new hat and a pair of kid gloves; his (kid) clothes, too, seemed to belong to a more recent antiquity than of yore. Over his (kid) arm was suspended a lady's mantilla--a light and brilliant tissue, fringed with white lace--which had apparently been committed to his (kid) keeping; and the little dog's blue ribbon was wound tightly round his (kid) hand. There was no expression of recognition in his (kid) face--or of anything indeed save a sort of feeble, fascinated dread; Newman looked at the pug and the lace mantilla, and then he (Newman) met the old man's eyes again.
``You know me, I see,'' (he)
he (Newman) pursued.
``You might have spoken to me before.'' (M. Nioche)
M. Nioche still said nothing, but it seemed to Newman that his (Newman) eyes began faintly to water.
``I didn't expect,'' (hero)
our hero went on,
``to meet you so far from--from the Café de la Patrie.'' (hero)
The old man remained silent, but decidedly Newman had touched the source of tears. His (Newman) neighbor sat staring and Newman added,
``What's the matter, M. Nioche? You used to talk--to talk very prettily. Don't you remember you even gave lessons in conversation?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

At this M. Nioche decided to change his (Newman) attitude. He (Newman) stooped and picked up the pug, lifted it to his (Newman) face and wiped his (Newman) eyes on its little soft back.

``I'm afraid to speak to you,'' (he)
he (Newman) presently said, looking over the puppy's shoulder.
``I hoped you wouldn't notice me. I should have moved away, but I was afraid that if I moved you would notice me. So I sat very still.'' (unknown)

``I suspect you have a bad conscience, sir,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

The old man put down the little dog and held it carefully in his (Newman) lap. Then he (Newman) shook his (Newman) head, with his (Newman) eyes still fixed upon his (Newman) interlocutor.

``No, Mr. Newman, I have a good conscience,'' (he)
he (Newman) murmured.

``Then why should you want to slink away from me?'' (unknown)

``Because--because you don't understand my position.'' (unknown)

``Oh, I think you once explained it to me,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``But it seems improved.'' (unknown)

``Improved!'' (M. Nioche)
exclaimed M. Nioche, under his (Newman) breath.
``Do you call this improvement?'' (he)
And he (Newman) glanced at the treasures in his (Newman) arms.

``Why, you are on your travels,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman rejoined.
``A visit to London in the season is certainly a sign of prosperity.'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche, in answer to this cruel piece of irony, lifted the puppy up to his (Newman) face again, peering at Newman with his (Newman) small blank eye-holes. There was something almost imbecile in the movement, and Newman hardly knew whether he (Newman) was taking refuge in a convenient affectation of unreason, or whether he (Newman) had in fact paid for his (Newman) dishonor by the loss of his (Newman) wits. In the latter case, just now, he (Newman) felt little more tenderly to the foolish old man than in the former. Responsible or not, he (man) was equally an accomplice of his (man) detestably mischievous daughter. Newman was going to leave him (Newman) abruptly, when a ray of entreaty appeared to disengage itself from the old man's misty gaze.

``Are you going away?'' (he)
he (Newman) asked.

``Do you want me to stay?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``I should have left you--from consideration. But my dignity suffers at your leaving me--that way.'' (unknown)

``Have you got anything particular to say to me?'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche looked around him (Newman) to see that no one was listening, and then he (Newman) said, very softly but distinctly,

``I have _not_ forgiven her (you)!'' (he)

Newman gave a short laugh, but the old man seemed for the moment not to perceive it; he (Newman) was gazing away, absently, at some metaphysical image of his (Newman) implacability.

``It doesn't much matter whether you forgive her (you) or not,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``There are other people who won't, I assure you.'' (unknown)

``What has she (you) done?'' (M. Nioche)
M. Nioche softly questioned, turning round again.
``I don't know what she (you) does, you know.'' (unknown)

``She (you) has done a devilish mischief; it doesn't matter what,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.
``She (you)'s a nuisance; she (you) ought to be stopped.'' (M. Nioche)

M. Nioche stealthily put out his (Newman) hand and laid it very gently upon Newman's arm.

``Stopped, yes,'' (he)
he (Newman) whispered.
``That's it. Stopped short. She (you) is running away--she (you) must be stopped.'' (he)
Then he (Newman) paused a moment and looked round him (Newman).
``I mean to stop her (you),'' (he)
he (Newman) went on.
``I am only waiting for my chance.'' (unknown)

``I see,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman, laughing briefly again.
``She (you) is running away and you are running after her (you). You have run a long distance!'' (M. Nioche)

But M. Nioche stared insistently:

``I shall stop her (you)!'' (M. Nioche)
he (Newman) softly repeated.

He (Newman) had hardly spoken when the crowd in front of them separated, as if by the impulse to make way for an important personage. Presently, through the opening, advanced Mademoiselle Nioche, attended by the gentleman whom Newman had lately observed. His (Newman) face being now presented to our hero, the latter recognized the irregular features, the hardly more regular complexion, and the amiable expression of Lord Deepmere. Noémie, on finding herself suddenly confronted with Newman, who, like M. Nioche, had risen from his (Newman) seat, faltered for a barely perceptible instant. She (Nioche) gave him (Newman) a little nod, as if she (Nioche) had seen him (Newman) yesterday, and then, with a good-natured smile,

``_Tiens_, how we keep meeting!'' (him)
she (Nioche) said. She (Nioche) looked consummately pretty, and the front of her (Nioche) dress was a wonderful work of art. She (Nioche) went up to her (Nioche) father, stretching out her (Nioche) hands for the little dog, which he (father) submissively placed in them, and she (Nioche) began to kiss it and murmur over it:
``To think of leaving him (I) all alone,--what a wicked, abominable creature he (I) must believe me! He (I) has been very unwell,'' (she)
she (Nioche) added, turning and affecting to explain to Newman, with a spark of infernal impudence, fine as a needlepoint, in her (Nioche) eye.
``I don't think the English climate agrees with him (I).'' (unknown)

``It seems to agree wonderfully well with his (I) mistress,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``Do you mean me? I have never been better, thank you,'' (unknown)
Miss Noémie declared.
``But with _milord_'' (she)
--and she (Nioche) gave a brilliant glance at her (Nioche) late companion--
``how can one help being well?'' (companion)
She (Nioche) seated herself in the chair from which her (Nioche) father had risen, and began to arrange the little dog's rosette.

Lord Deepmere carried off such embarrassment as might be incidental to this unexpected encounter with the inferior grace of a male and a Briton. He (Briton) blushed a good deal, and greeted the object of his (Briton) late momentary aspiration to rivalry in the favor of a person other than the mistress of the invalid pug with an awkward nod and a rapid ejaculation--an ejaculation to which Newman, who often found it hard to understand the speech of English people, was able to attach no meaning. Then the young man stood there, with his (man) hand on his (man) hip, and with a conscious grin, staring askance at Miss Noémie. Suddenly an idea seemed to strike him (man), and he (man) said, turning to Newman,

``Oh, you know her (mistress)?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Yes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``I know her (mistress). I don't believe you do.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``Oh dear, yes, I do!'' (Lord Deepmere)
said Lord Deepmere, with another grin.
``I knew her (mistress) in Paris--by my poor cousin Bellegarde, you know. He (Bellegarde) knew her (mistress), poor fellow, didn't he (Bellegarde)? It was she (mistress), you know, who was at the bottom of his (Bellegarde) affair. Awfully sad, wasn't it?'' (the man)
continued the young man, talking off his (Newman) embarrassment as his (Newman) simple nature permitted.
``They got up some story about its being for the Pope; about the other man having said something against the Pope's morals. They always do that, you know. They put it on the Pope because Bellegarde was once in the Zouaves. But it was about _her (mistress)_ morals--_she (mistress)_ was the Pope!'' (Lord Deepmere)
Lord Deepmere pursued, directing an eye illumined by this pleasantry toward Mademoiselle Nioche, who was bending gracefully over her (man) lap-dog, apparently absorbed in conversation with it.
``I dare say you think it rather odd that I should--ah--keep up the acquaintance,'' (the man)
the young man resumed;
``but she (mistress) couldn't help it, you know, and Bellegarde was only my twentieth cousin. I dare say you think it's rather cheeky, my showing with her (mistress) in Hyde Park, but you see she (mistress) isn't known yet, and she (mistress)'s in such very good form--'' (the man)
And Lord Deepmere's conclusion was lost in the attesting glance which he (Deepmere) again directed toward the young lady.

Newman turned away; he (Newman) was having more of her (lady) than he (Newman) relished. M. Nioche had stepped aside on his (Newman) daughter's approach, and he (Newman) stood there, within a very small compass, looking down hard at the ground. It had never yet, as between him (Newman) and Newman, been so apposite to place on record the fact that he (Newman) had not forgiven his (Newman) daughter. As Newman was moving away he (Newman) looked up and drew near to him (Newman), and Newman, seeing the old man had something particular to say, bent his (Newman) head for an instant.

``You will see it some day in the papers,'' (M. Nioche)
murmured M. Nioche.

Our hero departed to hide his (hero) smile, and to this day, though the newspapers form his (hero) principal reading, his (hero) eyes have not been arrested by any paragraph forming a sequel to this announcement.

CHAPTER XXVI

In that uninitiated observation of the great spectacle of English life upon which I have touched, it might be supposed that Newman passed a great many dull days. But the dullness of his (Newman) days pleased him (Newman); his (Newman) melancholy, which was settling into a secondary stage, like a healing wound, had in it a certain acrid, palatable sweetness. He (Newman) had company in his (Newman) thoughts, and for the present he (Newman) wanted no other. He (Newman) had no desire to make acquaintances, and he (Newman) left untouched a couple of notes of introduction which had been sent him (Newman) by Tom Tristram. He (Tristram) thought a great deal of Madame de Cintré--sometimes with a dogged tranquillity which might have seemed, for a quarter of an hour at a time, a near neighbor to forgetfulness. He (Tristram) lived over again the happiest hours he (Tristram) had known--that silver chain of numbered days in which his (Tristram) afternoon visits, tending sensibly to the ideal result, had subtilized his (Tristram) good humor to a sort of spiritual intoxication. He (Tristram) came back to reality, after such reveries, with a somewhat muffled shock; he (Tristram) had begun to feel the need of accepting the unchangeable. At other times the reality became an infamy again and the unchangeable an imposture, and he (Tristram) gave himself up to his (Tristram) angry restlessness till he (Tristram) was weary. But on the whole he (Tristram) fell into a rather reflective mood. Without in the least intending it or knowing it, he (Tristram) attempted to read the moral of his (Tristram) strange misadventure. He (Tristram) asked himself, in his (Tristram) quieter hours, whether perhaps, after all, he (Tristram) _was_ more commercial than was pleasant. We know that it was in obedience to a strong reaction against questions exclusively commercial that he (Tristram) had come out to pick up æsthetic entertainment in Europe; it may therefore be understood that he (Tristram) was able to conceive that a man might be too commercial. He (man) was very willing to grant it, but the concession, as to his (man) own case, was not made with any very oppressive sense of shame. If he (man) had been too commercial, he (man) was ready to forget it, for in being so he (man) had done no man any wrong that might not be as easily forgotten. He (man) reflected with sober placidity that at least there were no monuments of his (man)

``meanness'' (He)
scattered about the world. If there was any reason in the nature of things why his (man) connection with business should have cast a shadow upon a connection--even a connection broken--with a woman justly proud, he (man) was willing to sponge it out of his (man) life forever. The thing seemed a possibility; he (man) could not feel it, doubtless, as keenly as some people, and it hardly seemed worth while to flap his (man) wings very hard to rise to the idea; but he (man) could feel it enough to make any sacrifice that still remained to be made. As to what such sacrifice was now to be made to, here Newman stopped short before a blank wall over which there sometimes played a shadowy imagery. He (Newman) had a fancy of carrying out his (Newman) life as he (Newman) would have directed it if Madame de Cintré had been left to him (Cintré)--of making it a religion to do nothing that she (Newman) would have disliked. In this, certainly, there was no sacrifice; but there was a pale, oblique ray of inspiration. It would be lonely entertainment--a good deal like a man talking to himself in the mirror for want of better company. Yet the idea yielded Newman several half hours' dumb exaltation as he (Newman) sat, with his (Newman) hands in his (Newman) pockets and his (Newman) legs stretched, over the relics of an expensively poor dinner, in the undying English twilight. If, however, his (Newman) commercial imagination was dead, he (Newman) felt no contempt for the surviving actualities begotten by it. He (Newman) was glad he (Newman) had been prosperous and had been a great man of business rather than a small one; he (man) was extremely glad he (man) was rich. He (man) felt no impulse to sell all he (man) had and give to the poor, or to retire into meditative economy and asceticism. He (man) was glad he (man) was rich and tolerably young; if it was possible to think too much about buying and selling, it was a gain to have a good slice of life left in which not to think about them. Come, what should he (man) think about now? Again and again Newman could think only of one thing; his (Newman) thoughts always came back to it, and as they did so, with an emotional rush which seemed physically to express itself in a sudden upward choking, he (Newman) leaned forward--the waiter having left the room--and, resting his (Newman) arms on the table, buried his (Newman) troubled face.

He (Newman) remained in England till midsummer, and spent a month in the country, wandering about cathedrals, castles, and ruins. Several times, taking a walk from his (Newman) inn into meadows and parks, he (Newman) stopped by a well-worn stile, looked across through the early evening at a gray church tower, with its dusky nimbus of thick-circling swallows, and remembered that this might have been part of the entertainment of his (Newman) honeymoon. He (Newman) had never been so much alone or indulged so little in accidental dialogue. The period of recreation appointed by Mrs. Tristram had at last expired, and he (Newman) asked himself what he (Newman) should do now. Mrs. Tristram had written to him (Newman), proposing to him (Newman) that he (Newman) should join her (Tristram) in the Pyrenees; but he (Newman) was not in the humor to return to France. The simplest thing was to repair to Liverpool and embark on the first American steamer. Newman made his (Newman) way to the great seaport and secured his (Newman) berth; and the night before sailing he (Newman) sat in his (Newman) room at the hotel, staring down, vacantly and wearily, at an open portmanteau.
