A number of papers were lying upon it, which he (Newman) had been meaning to look over; some of them might conveniently be destroyed. But at last he (Newman) shuffled them roughly together, and pushed them into a corner of the valise; they were business papers, and he (Newman) was in no humor for sifting them. Then he (Newman) drew forth his (Newman) pocket-book and took out a paper of smaller size than those he (Newman) had dismissed. He (Newman) did not unfold it; he (Newman) simply sat looking at the back of it. If he (Newman) had momentarily entertained the idea of destroying it, the idea quickly expired. What the paper suggested was the feeling that lay in his (Newman) innermost heart and that no reviving cheerfulness could long quench--the feeling that after all and above all he (Newman) was a good fellow wronged. With it came a hearty hope that the Bellegardes were enjoying their suspense as to what he (Newman) would do yet. The more it was prolonged the more they would enjoy it! He (Newman) had hung fire once, yes; perhaps, in his (Newman) present queer state of mind, he (Newman) might hang fire again. But he (Newman) restored the little paper to his (Newman) pocket-book very tenderly, and felt better for thinking of the suspense of the Bellegardes. He (Newman) felt better every time he (Newman) thought of it after that, as he (Newman) sailed the summer seas. He (Newman) landed in New York and journeyed across the continent to San Francisco, and nothing that he (Francisco) observed by the way contributed to mitigate his (Francisco) sense of being a good fellow wronged.

He (Francisco) saw a great many other good fellows--his (Francisco) old friends--but he (Francisco) told none of them of the trick that had been played him (Francisco). He (Francisco) said simply that the lady he (Francisco) was to have married had changed her (lady) mind, and when he (Francisco) was asked if he (Francisco) had changed his (Francisco) own, he (Francisco) said,

``Suppose we change the subject.'' (he)
He (Francisco) told his (Francisco) friends that he (Francisco) had brought home no
``new ideas'' (he)
from Europe, and his (Francisco) conduct probably struck them as an eloquent proof of failing invention. He (Francisco) took no interest in chatting about his (Francisco) affairs and manifested no desire to look over his (Francisco) accounts. He (Francisco) asked half a dozen questions which, like those of an eminent physician inquiring for particular symptoms, showed that he (Francisco) still knew what he (Francisco) was talking about; but he (Francisco) made no comments and gave no directions. He (Francisco) not only puzzled the gentlemen on the stock exchange, but he (Francisco) was himself surprised at the extent of his (Francisco) indifference. As it seemed only to increase, he (Francisco) made an effort to combat it; he (Francisco) tried to interest himself and to take up his (Francisco) old occupations. But they appeared unreal to him (Francisco); do what he (Francisco) would he (Francisco) somehow could not believe in them. Sometimes he (Francisco) began to fear that there was something the matter with his (Francisco) head; that his (Francisco) brain, perhaps, had softened, and that the end of his (Francisco) strong activities had come. This idea came back to him (Francisco) with an exasperating force. A hopeless, helpless loafer, useful to no one and detestable to himself--this was what the treachery of the Bellegardes had made of him (Francisco). In his (Francisco) restless idleness he (Francisco) came back from San Francisco to New York, and sat for three days in the lobby of his (Francisco) hotel, looking out through a huge wall of plate-glass at the unceasing stream of pretty girls in Parisian-looking dresses, undulating past with little parcels nursed against their neat figures. At the end of three days he (Francisco) returned to San Francisco, and having arrived there he (Francisco) wished he (Francisco) had stayed away. He (Francisco) had nothing to do, his (Francisco) occupation was gone, and it seemed to him (Francisco) that he (Francisco) should never find it again. He (Francisco) had nothing to do _here_, he (Francisco) sometimes said to himself; but there was something beyond the ocean that he (Francisco) was still to do; something that he (Francisco) had left undone experimentally and speculatively, to see if it could content itself to remain undone. But it was not content: it kept pulling at his (Francisco) heartstrings and thumping at his (Francisco) reason; it murmured in his (Francisco) ears and hovered perpetually before his (Francisco) eyes. It interposed between all new resolutions and their fulfillment; it seemed like a stubborn ghost, dumbly entreating to be laid. Till that was done he (Francisco) should never be able to do anything else.

One day, toward the end of the winter, after a long interval, he (Francisco) received a letter from Mrs. Tristram, who apparently was animated by a charitable desire to amuse and distract her (Tristram) correspondent. She (Tristram) gave him (correspondent) much Paris gossip, talked of General Packard and Miss Kitty Upjohn, enumerated the new plays at the theatre, and enclosed a note from her (Upjohn) husband, who had gone down to spend a month at Nice. Then came her (Upjohn) signature, and after this her (Upjohn) postscript. The latter consisted of these few lines:

``I heard three days since from my friend, the Abbé Aubert, that Madame de Cintré last week took the veil at the Carmelites. It was on her (mistress) twenty-seventh birthday, and she (mistress) took the name of her (mistress), patroness, St. Veronica. Sister Veronica has a lifetime before her (Veronica)!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

This letter came to Newman in the morning; in the evening he (Newman) started for Paris. His (Newman) wound began to ache with its first fierceness, and during his (Newman) long bleak journey the thought of Madame de Cintré's

``life-time,'' (Madame)
passed within prison walls on whose outer side he (Newman) might stand, kept him (Newman) perpetual company. Now he (Newman) would fix himself in Paris forever; he (Newman) would extort a sort of happiness from the knowledge that if she (Upjohn) was not there, at least the stony sepulchre that held her (Upjohn) was. He (Newman) descended, unannounced, upon Mrs. Bread, whom he (Newman) found keeping lonely watch in his (Newman) great empty saloons on the Boulevard Haussmann. They were as neat as a Dutch village, Mrs. Bread's only occupation had been removing individual dust-particles. She (Upjohn) made no complaint, however, of her (Upjohn) loneliness, for in her (Upjohn) philosophy a servant was but a mysteriously projected machine, and it would be as fantastic for a housekeeper to comment upon a gentleman's absences as for a clock to remark upon not being wound up. No particular clock, Mrs. Bread supposed, went all the time, and no particular servant could enjoy all the sunshine diffused by the career of an exacting master. She (housekeeper) ventured, nevertheless, to express a modest hope that Newman meant to remain a while in Paris. Newman laid his (Newman) hand on hers and shook it gently.
``I mean to remain forever,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.

He (Newman) went after this to see Mrs. Tristram, to whom he (Newman) had telegraphed, and who expected him (Newman). She (Tristram) looked at him (Newman) a moment and shook her (Tristram) head.

``This won't do,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said;
``you have come back too soon.'' (she)
He (Newman) sat down and asked about her (Tristram) husband and her (Tristram) children, tried even to inquire about Miss Dora Finch. In the midst of this--
``Do you know where she (Veronica) is?'' (the midst)
he (Newman) asked, abruptly.

Mrs. Tristram hesitated a moment; of course he (Newman) couldn't mean Miss Dora Finch. Then she (Finch) answered, properly:

``She (Veronica) has gone to the other house--in the Rue d’Enfer.'' (she)
After Newman had sat a while longer looking very sombre, she (Finch) went on:
``You are not so good a man as I thought. You are more--you are more--'' (she)

``More what?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman asked.

``More unforgiving.'' (unknown)

``Good God!'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
cried Newman;
``do you expect me to forgive?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``No, not that. I have forgiven, so of course you can't. But you might forget! You have a worse temper about it than I should have expected. You look wicked--you look dangerous.'' (unknown)

``I may be dangerous,'' (he)
he (Newman) said;
``but I am not wicked. No, I am not wicked.'' (he)
And he (Newman) got up to go. Mrs. Tristram asked him (Newman) to come back to dinner; but he (Newman) answered that he (Newman) did not feel like pledging himself to be present at an entertainment, even as a solitary guest. Later in the evening, if he (guest) should be able, he (guest) would come.

He (guest) walked away through the city, beside the Seine and over it, and took the direction of the Rue d’Enfer. The day had the softness of early spring; but the weather was gray and humid. Newman found himself in a part of Paris which he (Newman) little knew--a region of convents and prisons, of streets bordered by long dead walls and traversed by a few wayfarers. At the intersection of two of these streets stood the house of the Carmelites--a dull, plain edifice, with a high-shouldered blank wall all round it. From without Newman could see its upper windows, its steep roof and its chimneys. But these things revealed no symptoms of human life; the place looked dumb, deaf, inanimate. The pale, dead, discolored wall stretched beneath it, far down the empty side street--a vista without a human figure. Newman stood there a long time; there were no passers; he (Newman) was free to gaze his (Newman) fill. This seemed the goal of his (Newman) journey; it was what he (Newman) had come for. It was a strange satisfaction, and yet it was a satisfaction; the barren stillness of the place seemed to be his (Newman) own release from ineffectual longing. It told him (Newman) that the woman within was lost beyond recall, and that the days and years of the future would pile themselves above her (woman) like the huge immovable slab of a tomb. These days and years, in this place, would always be just so gray and silent. Suddenly, from the thought of their seeing him (Newman) stand there, again the charm utterly departed. He (Newman) would never stand there again; it was gratuitous dreariness. He (Newman) turned away with a heavy heart, but with a heart lighter than the one he (Newman) had brought. Everything was over, and he (Newman) too at last could rest. He (Newman) walked down through narrow, winding streets to the edge of the Seine again, and there he (Newman) saw, close above him (Newman), the soft, vast towers of Notre Dame. He (Newman) crossed one of the bridges and stood a moment in the empty place before the great cathedral; then he (Newman) went in beneath the grossly-imaged portals. He (Newman) wandered some distance up the nave and sat down in the splendid dimness. He (Newman) sat a long time; he (Newman) heard far-away bells chiming off, at long intervals, to the rest of the world. He (Newman) was very tired; this was the best place he (Newman) could be in. He (Newman) said no prayers; he (Newman) had no prayers to say. He (Newman) had nothing to be thankful for, and he (Newman) had nothing to ask; nothing to ask, because now he (Newman) must take care of himself. But a great cathedral offers a very various hospitality, and Newman sat in his (Newman) place, because while he (Newman) was there he (Newman) was out of the world. The most unpleasant thing that had ever happened to him (Newman) had reached its formal conclusion, as it were; he (Newman) could close the book and put it away. He (Newman) leaned his (Newman) head for a long time on the chair in front of him (Newman); when he (Newman) took it up he (Newman) felt that he (Newman) was himself again. Somewhere in his (Newman) mind, a tight knot seemed to have loosened. He (Newman) thought of the Bellegardes; he (Newman) had almost forgotten them. He (Newman) remembered them as people he (Newman) had meant to do something to. He (Newman) gave a groan as he (Newman) remembered what he (Newman) had meant to do; he (Newman) was annoyed at having meant to do it; the bottom, suddenly, had fallen out of his (Newman) revenge. Whether it was Christian charity or unregenerate good nature--what it was, in the background of his (Newman) soul--I don't pretend to say; but Newman's last thought was that of course he (Newman) would let the Bellegardes go.

If he (Newman) had spoken it aloud he (Newman) would have said that he (Newman) didn't want to hurt them. He (Newman) was ashamed of having wanted to hurt them. They had hurt him (Newman), but such things were really not his (Newman) game. At last he (Newman) got up and came out of the darkening church; not with the elastic step of a man who had won a victory or taken a resolve, but strolling soberly, like a good-natured man who is still a little ashamed.

Going home, he (man) said to Mrs. Bread that he (man) must trouble her (it) to put back his (man) things into the portmanteau she (it) had unpacked the evening before. His (man) gentle stewardess looked at him (man) through eyes a trifle bedimmed.

``Dear me, sir,'' (she)
she (stewardess) exclaimed,
``I thought you said that you were going to stay forever.'' (she)

``I meant that I was going to stay away forever,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman kindly. And since his (Newman) departure from Paris on the following day he (Newman) has certainly not returned. The gilded apartments I have so often spoken of stand ready to receive him (Newman); but they serve only as a spacious residence for Mrs. Bread, who wanders eternally from room to room, adjusting the tassels of the curtains, and keeps her (stewardess) wages, which are regularly brought her (stewardess) by a banker's clerk, in a great pink Sèvres vase on the drawing-room mantelshelf.

Late in the evening Newman went to Mrs. Tristram's and found Tom Tristram by the domestic fireside.

``I'm glad to see you back in Paris,'' (this gentleman)
this gentleman declared.
``You know it's really the only place for a white man to live.'' (Mr. Tristram/Tristram)
Mr. Tristram made his (Tristram) friend welcome, according to his (Tristram) own rosy light, and offered him (Tristram) a convenient _résumé_ of the Franco-American gossip of the last six months. Then at last he (Tristram) got up and said he (Tristram) would go for half an hour to the club.
``I suppose a man who has been for six months in California wants a little intellectual conversation. I'll let my wife have a go at you.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman shook hands heartily with his (Newman) host, but did not ask him (Newman) to remain; and then he (Newman) relapsed into his (Newman) place on the sofa, opposite to Mrs. Tristram. She (Tristram) presently asked him (Newman) what he (Newman) had done after leaving her (Tristram).

``Nothing particular,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

``You struck me,'' (she)
she (Tristram) rejoined,
``as a man with a plot in his (man) head. You looked as if you were bent on some sinister errand, and after you had left me I wondered whether I ought to have let you go.'' (she)

``I only went over to the other side of the river--to the Carmelites,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman.

Mrs. Tristram looked at him (Newman) a moment and smiled.

``What did you do there? Try to scale the wall?'' (unknown)

``I did nothing. I looked at the place for a few minutes and then came away.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Mrs. Tristram gave him (Newman) a sympathetic glance.

``You didn't happen to meet M. de Bellegarde,'' (she)
she (Tristram) asked,
``staring hopelessly at the convent wall as well? I am told he (Bellegarde) takes his (Bellegarde) sister's conduct very hard.'' (she)

``No, I didn't meet him (Bellegarde), I am happy to say,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman answered, after a pause.

``They are in the country,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Mrs. Tristram went on;
``at--what is the name of the place?--Fleurières. They returned there at the time you left Paris and have been spending the year in extreme seclusion. The little marquise must enjoy it; I expect to hear that she (sister) has eloped with her (sister) daughter's music-master!'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Newman was looking at the light wood-fire; but he (Newman) listened to this with extreme interest. At last he (Newman) spoke:

``I mean never to mention the name of those people again, and I don't want to hear anything more about them.'' (he)
And then he (Newman) took out his (Newman) pocket-book and drew forth a scrap of paper. He (Newman) looked at it an instant, then got up and stood by the fire.
``I am going to burn them up,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``I am glad to have you as a witness. There they go!'' (he)
And he (Newman) tossed the paper into the flame.

Mrs. Tristram sat with her (Tristram) embroidery needle suspended.

``What is that paper?'' (she)
she (Tristram) asked.

Newman leaning against the fireplace, stretched his (Newman) arms and drew a longer breath than usual. Then after a moment,

``I can tell you now,'' (he)
he (Newman) said.
``It was a paper containing a secret of the Bellegardes--something which would damn them if it were known.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Mrs. Tristram dropped her (Tristram) embroidery with a reproachful moan.

``Ah, why didn't you show it to me?'' (unknown)

``I thought of showing it to you--I thought of showing it to everyone. I thought of paying my debt to the Bellegardes that way. So I told them, and I frightened them. They have been staying in the country as you tell me, to keep out of the explosion. But I have given it up.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Mrs. Tristram began to take slow stitches again.

``Have you quite given it up?'' (unknown)

``Oh yes.'' (unknown)

``Is it very bad, this secret?'' (unknown)

``Yes, very bad.'' (unknown)

``For myself,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram,
``I am sorry you have given it up. I should have liked immensely to see your paper. They have wronged me too, you know, as your sponsor and guarantee, and it would have served for my revenge as well. How did you come into possession of your secret?'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

``It's a long story. But honestly, at any rate.'' (unknown)

``And they knew you were master of it?'' (unknown)

``Oh, I told them.'' (unknown)

``Dear me, how interesting!'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
cried Mrs. Tristram.
``And you humbled them at your feet?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman was silent a moment.

``No, not at all. They pretended not to care--not to be afraid. But I know they did care--they were afraid.'' (unknown)

``Are you very sure?'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

Newman stared a moment.

``Yes, I'm sure.'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)

Mrs. Tristram resumed her (Tristram) slow stitches.

``They defied you, eh?'' (unknown)

``Yes,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
said Newman,
``it was about that.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``You tried by the threat of exposure to make them retract?'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
Mrs. Tristram pursued.

``Yes, but they wouldn't. I gave them their choice, and they chose to take their chance of bluffing off the charge and convicting me of fraud. But they _were_ frightened,'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)
Newman added,
``and I have had all the vengeance I want.'' (Newman/Christopher Newman/Christopher)

``It is most provoking,'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
said Mrs. Tristram,
``to hear you talk of the `charge' when the charge is burnt up. Is it quite consumed?'' (Mrs. Tristram/Tristram)
she (Tristram) asked, glancing at the fire.

Newman assured her (Tristram) that there was nothing left of it.

``Well then,'' (she)
she (Tristram) said,
``I suppose there is no harm in saying that you probably did not make them so very uncomfortable. My impression would be that since, as you say, they defied you, it was because they believed that, after all, you would never really come to the point. Their confidence, after counsel taken of each other, was not in their innocence, nor in their talent for bluffing things off; it was in your remarkable good nature! You see they were right.'' (she)

Newman instinctively turned to see if the little paper was in fact consumed; but there was nothing left of it.

End of the Project Gutenberg EBook of The American, by Henry James
